('45', 0, 1, 2, 40) 1. LETTER TO CHILDREN OF BAL MANDIR
('45', 0, 2, 3, 76) KARACHI, February 4, 1929
('45', 0, 3, 4, 102) CHILDREN OF BAL MANDIR, The children of the Bal Mandir 1are too mischievous.
('45', 0, 3, 5, 179) What kind of mischief was this that led to Hari breaking his arm?
('45', 0, 3, 6, 245) Shouldn’t there be some limit to playing pranks?
('45', 0, 3, 7, 294) Let each child give his or her reply.
('45', 0, 3, 8, 332) QUESTION TWO: Does any child still eat spices?
('45', 0, 3, 9, 379) Will those who eat them stop doing so?
('45', 0, 3, 10, 418) Those of you who have given up spices, do you feel tempted to eat them?
('45', 0, 3, 11, 490) If so, why do you feel that way?
('45', 0, 3, 12, 523) QUESTION THREE: Does any of you now make noise in the class or the kitchen?
('45', 0, 3, 13, 599) Remember that all of you have promised me that you will make no noise.
('45', 0, 3, 14, 670) In Karachi it is not so cold as they tried to frighten me by saying it would be.
('45', 0, 3, 15, 751) I am writing this letter at 4 o’clock.
('45', 0, 3, 16, 790) The post is cleared early.
('45', 0, 3, 17, 817) Reading by mistake four instead of three, I got up at three.
('45', 0, 3, 18, 878) I didn’t then feel inclined to sleep for one hour.
('45', 0, 3, 19, 929) As a result, I had one hour more for writing letters to the Udyoga Mandir 2. How nice !
('45', 0, 4, 20, 1017) Blessings from BAPU
('45', 0, 5, 21, 1037) From a photostat of the Gujarati: G.N. 9222
('45', 0, 6, 22, 1081) 1 An infant school in the Sabarmati Ashram 2 Since the new constitution published on June 14, 1928 the Ashram was renamed Udyoga Mandir.

('45', 1, 1, 2, 1258) 2. LETTER TO ASHRAM WOMEN
('45', 1, 2, 3, 1284) KARACHI, February 4, 1929
('45', 1, 3, 4, 1310) SISTERS, I hope your classes are working regularly.
('45', 1, 3, 5, 1362) I believe that no better arrangements could have been made than what has come about without any special planning.
('45', 1, 3, 6, 1476) Take full advantage of these arran gements.
('45', 1, 3, 7, 1520) Rasik’s condition can be described as really very serious.
('45', 1, 3, 8, 1579) I do not know whether he will be alive when this letter reaches you.
('45', 1, 3, 9, 1648) But we try to learn every day that birth and death are two facets of the same thing.
('45', 1, 3, 10, 1733) He who is born dies, and he who dies is born again.
('45', 1, 3, 11, 1785) Some do escape this cycle, but neither they nor the others need rejoice at birth or grieve over death.
('45', 1, 3, 12, 1888) I realize this and, therefore, remain unconcerned.
('45', 1, 3, 13, 1939) Rasik has recently become a votary of the Ramayana, and we feel, therefore, that he enjoys complete peace inwardly.
('45', 1, 3, 14, 2055) I should like you women to make the kitchen and the infant school a shining success.
('45', 1, 3, 15, 2140) Do not tempt the children to eat spiced food.
('45', 1, 3, 16, 2186) You will see in future that such restraint has benefited them.
('45', 1, 3, 17, 2249) You must have discovered by now that abstaining from spices ordinarily does the body no harm.
('45', 1, 3, 18, 2343) It is a different matter, of course, if some persons who have become addicted to spiced food cannot change their habit.
('45', 1, 3, 19, 2463) Think over this matter.
('45', 1, 3, 20, 2487) It is entirely in your hands to stop the children from making noise.
('45', 1, 3, 21, 2556) You should try and lighten Gangabehn’s burden.
('45', 1, 3, 22, 2603) You may get from her other services too.
('45', 1, 3, 23, 2644) You should fix her hours of work and, during certain hours, should not permit her to enter the kitchen at all.
('45', 1, 3, 24, 2755) You should give up the idea of getting ghee from anywhere except Chharodi.
('45', 1, 3, 25, 2830) If you can get no ghee from there, you should learn to do without it.
('45', 1, 3, 26, 2900) It has practically been proved now that linseed oil does no harm whatever.
('45', 1, 3, 27, 2975) So long as we get milk and curds, it does not matter too much if we do not get ghee.
('45', 1, 3, 28, 3060) Do set a limit to the quantity of vegetables cooked.
('45', 1, 3, 29, 3113) Make it a rule that not more than ten tolas of cleaned vegetables are cooked for each person.
('45', 2, 0, 1, 3207) VOL.45: 4 FEBRUARY, 1929 11 MAY, 1929 3
('45', 2, 1, 2, 3247) These changes require your mental co operation.
('45', 2, 1, 3, 3295) That is, you should accept them with your heart and mind.
('45', 2, 1, 4, 3353) You have got to train yourselves for work in the Bal Mandir.
('45', 2, 1, 5, 3414) Now that a teacher has been appointed specially for this—and he is an able person—you can get all the training you need.
('45', 2, 1, 6, 3535) I shall reach there on the 16th evening instead of the 15th.
('45', 2, 1, 7, 3596) Since I arrived here a day late, one day will be wasted.
('45', 2, 2, 8, 3653) Blessings from BAPU [From Gujarati]
('45', 2, 3, 9, 3689) Bapuna Patro—1: Ashramni Behnone
('45', 2, 4, 10, 3722) 3. LETTER TO PURUSHOTTAM GANDHI
('45', 2, 5, 11, 3754) February 4, 1929
('45', 2, 6, 12, 3771) PURUSHOTTAM, You ought to see to it that your physique improves.
('45', 2, 6, 13, 3836) And it would be a great thing if you could do this while you live in the Ashram.
('45', 2, 6, 14, 3917) However, I do not insist on that.
('45', 2, 6, 15, 3951) If you are not confident that you can build your body in the Ashram you may go to Hajira.
('45', 2, 6, 16, 4041) It is the best place we can think of.
('45', 2, 6, 17, 4079) For my part, I am certain that you will do well to take water treated with the sun’s rays admitted through glass bottles of different colours.
('45', 2, 6, 18, 4222) I have again gone through the chapter on the subject.
('45', 2, 6, 19, 4276) Fill with water a bottle of orange yellow colour, keep it in sunlight and use the water for drinking.
('45', 2, 6, 20, 4378) Note the effect.
('45', 2, 6, 21, 4395) The gruel made from wheat bran taken in the morning is also likely to help.
('45', 2, 6, 22, 4471) Consult Chhotelalji about how to prepare it.
('45', 2, 6, 23, 4516) He himself will prepare the bran for your use.
('45', 2, 6, 24, 4563) Personally I would like to keep you with me for some time during my tour and help you to make your body strong.
('45', 2, 6, 25, 4675) Your idea about Wardha is of course right.
('45', 2, 6, 26, 4718) Till I return, adopt the remedies which I have suggested and make up your mind about what you will do afterwards.
('45', 2, 7, 27, 4832) Blessings from BAPU
('45', 2, 8, 28, 4852) From the Gujarati: C.W. 895. Courtesy: Narandas Gandhi
('45', 3, 0, 1, 4907) 4 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('45', 3, 1, 2, 4947) 4. LETTERS TO CHHAGANLAL JOSHI
('45', 3, 2, 3, 4978) Silence Day, February 4, 1929
('45', 3, 3, 4, 5008) CHHAGANLAL, I hope you got the two letters I wrote to you during the journey.
('45', 3, 3, 5, 5086) A postcard, too, is a letter.
('45', 3, 3, 6, 5116) The portions concerning women in the accompanying letters — to Kishorelal and to the [Ashram] women—are of general inte rest; therefore show them to all.
('45', 3, 3, 7, 5270) You should read all letters en closed in an envelope addressed to you.
('45', 3, 3, 8, 5341) When any such letter is not meant to be read by you, I shall write the word “personal”on it.
('45', 3, 3, 9, 5434) You should spare sufficient time from your daily work for general supervision over everything.
('45', 3, 3, 10, 5529) Think in advance of the time which each matter is likely to require, and try your best to finish it within that time.
('45', 3, 3, 11, 5647) Keep a note of things to be attended to later and make it a habit to consult this note every day.
('45', 3, 3, 12, 5745) Such a practice lightens the burden on one’s memory.
('45', 3, 3, 13, 5798) No one can carry in his memory all matters to be attended to.
('45', 3, 3, 14, 5860) I shall return there a day later.
('45', 3, 3, 15, 5894) The programme here got upset and, owing to Monday being a silence day, alternative arrangements could not be made except by extending the programme by a day.
('45', 3, 3, 16, 6052) Make your body strong as a rock; this is possible.
('45', 3, 3, 17, 6103) You should take more milk and ghee.
('45', 3, 3, 18, 6139) If oil agrees with you, I am not particular about ghee.
('45', 3, 3, 19, 6195) If your stomach can digest almonds, I think you will need no ghee at all.
('45', 3, 3, 20, 6269) But you may make that experiment after I return there.
('45', 3, 3, 21, 6324) You yourself should take charge of Vimu 1 and Dhiru 2, or Rama 3
('45', 3, 4, 22, 6389) should learn how to bring them up.
('45', 3, 4, 23, 6424) They are fine children, and only require proper attention.
('45', 3, 4, 24, 6483) I am writing all the letters for today in the early morning.
('45', 3, 4, 25, 6544) The post is cleared early and, since I chanced to get up at three, I sat down
('45', 3, 5, 26, 6622) 1 Addressee’s daughter and son 2 ibid 3 Addressee’s wife
('45', 4, 0, 1, 6679) VOL.45: 4 FEBRUARY, 1929 11 MAY, 1929 5
('45', 4, 1, 2, 6719) to write letters.
('45', 4, 1, 3, 6737) Compared to the temperature there, it is less cold here.
('45', 4, 1, 4, 6794) People say that the weather has changed since yesterday.
('45', 4, 1, 5, 6851) I experienced no difficulty in travelling third class.
('45', 4, 1, 6, 6906) For half of the way there were very few passengers in the train.
('45', 4, 1, 7, 6971) Everyone had enough space to sleep during the night.
('45', 4, 1, 8, 7024) The only difficulty was about the lavatory.
('45', 4, 1, 9, 7068) We, therefore, bought a second class ticket for the professor from Abu to Hyderabad, and he and Subbiah 1 went and sat in that compartment by turns.
('45', 4, 1, 10, 7217) This enabled the latter to do his typing work and the articles for Young India to be typed and dispatched.
('45', 4, 1, 11, 7324) We saved nearly fifty rupees by travelling in this fashion, apart from the greater peace which I enjoyed.
('45', 4, 1, 12, 7430) I could see that people liked my having resumed third class travelling.
('45', 4, 2, 13, 7502) Blessings from BAPU
('45', 4, 3, 14, 7522) From a phootstat of the Gujarati: G.N. 5383
('45', 4, 4, 15, 7566) 5. LETTER TO GANGABEHN VAIDYA
('45', 4, 5, 16, 7596) Silence Day, February 4, 1929
('45', 4, 6, 17, 7626) GANGABEHN, Remember well the two things I mentioned to you in connection with Kaku’s clothes.
('45', 4, 6, 18, 7720) Give up your desire to work as hard as you possibly can.
('45', 4, 6, 19, 7777) You ought to spend at least four hours a day outside the kitchen.
('45', 4, 6, 20, 7843) To guide the other women assisting you, maintain an inventory of all the things.
('45', 4, 6, 21, 7924) If even after that something should get lost or spoilt you need not worry.
('45', 4, 6, 22, 7999) Think what you would do if you were to fall ill for four hours every day.
('45', 4, 6, 23, 8073) Our aim, after all, is to see that the organization runs.
('45', 4, 6, 24, 8131) Running an organization means that the work is carried on not by one individual but by even new persons trained for the purpose.
('45', 4, 6, 25, 8260) This should be so for all our departments without exception.
('45', 4, 6, 26, 8321) No work should depend on any one person doing it.
('45', 4, 6, 27, 8371) This means that we who are working at present must train others for our jobs.
('45', 4, 6, 28, 8449) Don’t think that it is Kusum alone who should have fixed hours of work.
('45', 4, 6, 29, 8521) Having fixed hours of work is part of running an
('45', 4, 7, 30, 8570) 1 Gandhiji’s secretary
('45', 5, 0, 1, 8593) 6 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('45', 5, 1, 2, 8633) organization.
('45', 5, 1, 3, 8647) No organization can run without rules.
('45', 5, 1, 4, 8686) An accident does not occur every day.
('45', 5, 1, 5, 8724) What occurs everyday is not an accident.
('45', 5, 1, 6, 8765) If bread gets spoiled everyday, we may do without it.
('45', 5, 1, 7, 8819) We should think out beforehand what we should do when accidents like bread being spoiled occur.
('45', 5, 1, 8, 8915) Even for that, you ought to enjoy some rest and peace.
('45', 5, 1, 9, 8970) I see that this kitchen has become a hard school in which you learn something every day.
('45', 5, 1, 10, 9059) You are being daily trained through new experience.
('45', 5, 1, 11, 9111) Take care of your health.
('45', 5, 1, 12, 9137) For the present, your food should be milk and fruit.
('45', 5, 1, 13, 9190) Take in small quantities at a time as much milk as you need in the day.
('45', 5, 1, 14, 9262) One is likely to feel tempted to eat fruit, in unrestricted quantity.
('45', 5, 1, 15, 9332) You should, therefore, find the right quantity for yourself.
('45', 5, 1, 16, 9393) Avoid altogether coffee and sugar or sugar candy.
('45', 5, 2, 17, 9443) Blessings from BAPU [From Gujarati]
('45', 5, 3, 18, 9479) Bapuna Patro—6: G. S. Gangabehnne, p.
('45', 5, 4, 19, 9517) 6. A LETTER
('45', 5, 5, 20, 9529) KARACHI, February 4, 1929
('45', 5, 7, 21, 9555) I received your letter.
('45', 5, 7, 22, 9579) You will have got more information about Rasik from Ramdas’s letter of yesterday.
('45', 5, 7, 23, 9661) I am beginning to feel that he is as good as gone.
('45', 5, 7, 24, 9712) I am carefully searching my heart.
('45', 5, 7, 25, 9747) I travel, I eat, and all this only seems right.
('45', 5, 7, 26, 9795) It seems a religious duty.
('45', 5, 7, 27, 9822) What would I do by going to Delhi?
('45', 5, 7, 28, 9857) Rasik is being looked after.
('45', 5, 7, 29, 9886) Having learnt the Gita by heart, how can one rejoice over birth and grieve over death?
('45', 5, 7, 30, 9973) Such illnesses are a test whether our study of the Gita is bearing fruit.
('45', 5, 7, 31, 10047) Young India 2 this time is worth reading.
('45', 5, 7, 32, 10089) I can always make it .
('45', 5, 7, 33, 10112) While travelling I wrote everything in the third class compartment.
('45', 5, 7, 34, 10180) Giving up travelling second class and giving up milk seem to have benefited me at least for now and I therefore feel delighted like a
('45', 5, 8, 35, 10314) 1 Omission as in the source 2Vide “Third Class Travelling”, February 14, 1929.
('45', 6, 0, 1, 10393) VOL.45: 4 FEBRUARY, 1929 11 MAY, 1929 7
('45', 6, 1, 2, 10433) I like it.
('45', 6, 1, 3, 10444) I now feel embarrassed and ashamed to travel second class.
('45', 6, 1, 4, 10503) Praise be to mother almond.
('45', 6, 1, 5, 10531) I may perhaps start saying the same about linseed oil also.
('45', 6, 1, 6, 10591) Please do not make light of these experiments of mind.
('45', 6, 1, 7, 10646) They are as dear to me as the struggle for swaraj.
('45', 6, 1, 8, 10697) I find in them the same peace as I do in the latter.
('45', 6, 1, 9, 10750) They do not involve any risk and may do some good.
('45', 6, 1, 10, 10801) In the event of my going to Europe, Jamnalalji had persuaded Rajaji [to accompany me].
('45', 6, 1, 11, 10888) Both of them were of the opinion that I should go.
('45', 6, 1, 12, 10939) I think my decision is correct.
('45', 6, 1, 13, 10971) It would have been improper to have gone.
('45', 6, 2, 14, 11013) From a copy of the Gujarati: Kusumbehn Desai’s Diary.

('45', 6, 3, 16, 11081) 7. LETTER TO MIRABEHN
('45', 6, 4, 17, 11103) February 4, 1929
('45', 6, 5, 18, 11120) MIRA, I have been awake quite by accident since 3 a.m.
('45', 6, 5, 19, 11175) It is now nearing 5 a.m.
('45', 6, 5, 20, 11200) and I have nearly finished the U.M. 1 post.
('45', 6, 5, 21, 11244) I travelled 3rd class again without any mishap and without any discomfort worth the name.
('45', 6, 5, 22, 11334) And it added to my mental peace.
('45', 6, 5, 23, 11367) I am never at peace with myself travelling 2nd class.
('45', 6, 5, 24, 11421) There is no more news to give you about Rasik 2. There was no wire awaiting me at Karachi and today I shall get nothing before this is posted.
('45', 6, 5, 25, 11564) The post closes at 9 a.m.
('45', 6, 5, 26, 11590) Did I tell you that last week it was so cold at the U.M. that the water in the buckets and the little reservoir had frozen.
('45', 6, 5, 27, 11714) The thermometer registered 28 degrees—an unheard of temperature for Sabaramati.
('45', 6, 5, 28, 11794) We had a most magnificent crop of vegetables, cotton, etc.
('45', 6, 5, 29, 11853) Poor Somabhai had given his whole soul to the thing.
('45', 6, 5, 30, 11906) Well, practically all was destroyed by the terrible frost, even the beautiful papaiya orchard gone.
('45', 6, 5, 31, 12006) The whole fields looked like weeping.
('45', 6, 5, 32, 12044) It was an unbearable sight.
('45', 6, 5, 33, 12072) And yet behind this tragedy Nature has a kindly purpose which we cannot perceive, but believe in full faith—yes, faith is evidence of things unseen and unseeable.
('45', 6, 6, 34, 12235) 1 Udyoga Mandir 2 Harilal Gandhi’s son who died of typhoid fever on February 8, 1929
('45', 7, 0, 1, 12320) 8 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('45', 7, 1, 2, 12360) I hope you have now completely regained your normal health.
('45', 7, 1, 3, 12420) You will—won’t you—recognize the limitations of your body and insist on having the things it may need for its upkeep even as a trustee would be bound to secure the well being of his ward.
('45', 7, 1, 4, 12608) Be sure that you do not pamper the body, that you are treating [it] as a trust from God to be used for your unfoldment and you will be justified, nay bound, to supply its primary wants.
('45', 7, 1, 5, 12794) It is not enough merely to postdate the programme by two days.
('45', 7, 1, 6, 12857) It has been rearranged but it would be wise to treat Hyderabad Sind as headquarters.
('45', 7, 1, 7, 12942) I have not spent money on wiring as, whenever you post your letters, I am bound to get them.
('45', 7, 3, 8, 13035) [PS.] Of course you have read my articles 1 about the European visit.
('45', 7, 3, 9, 13105) Do you not agree?
('45', 7, 3, 10, 13123) You will write to Rolland.
('45', 7, 5, 11, 13150) From the original: C.W. 5340. Courtesy: Mirabehn; also G.N. 9395
('45', 7, 6, 12, 13215) 8. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, KARACHI 2
('45', 7, 7, 13, 13254) Februray 4, 1929
('45', 7, 8, 14, 13271) Mahatmaji in accepting the purse thanked the citizens of Karachi for having
('45', 7, 9, 15, 13347) contributed so liberally but he said that taking into consideration Lalaji’s services to
('45', 7, 10, 16, 13436) the country and for that matter to the whole world the amount could not be very large.
('45', 7, 11, 17, 13523) Lalaji’s services could not be adequately measured in terms of money.
('45', 7, 11, 18, 13593) But money was
('45', 7, 12, 19, 13607) needed to continue and expand the work started by him.
('45', 7, 12, 20, 13662) Mahatmaji hoped Sind would
('45', 7, 13, 21, 13689) give him a very big amount for this Fund.
('45', 7, 14, 22, 13731) 1 Vide “My Apologies”, January 31, 1929. 2 The meeting was held in Rambagh grounds presided over by Narayan Das Anandji, M.L.C. A purse for Lajpat Rai Memorial Fund was presented to Gandhiji.
('45', 8, 0, 1, 13923) VOL.45: 4 FEBRUARY, 1929 11 MAY, 1929 9
('45', 8, 1, 2, 13963) Lalaji’s work was not confined to any particular community or province.
('45', 8, 1, 3, 14035) So was his Society’s 1work.
('45', 8, 1, 4, 14063) Members are from different provinces and its work is being carried on in different provinces.
('45', 8, 1, 5, 14157) So it should not be thought that Sind could not profit by the Society’s work.
('45', 8, 1, 6, 14235) Lalaji loved the whole world, but he had realized that one who did not serve his country could not serve the world.
('45', 8, 1, 7, 14351) He was a true patriot.
('45', 8, 1, 8, 14374) He lived for his country and died in its service.
('45', 8, 1, 9, 14424) The money that they were offering to his memory would be spent in furthering the work that he had started.
('45', 8, 2, 10, 14531) Coming to the second part of his speech Mahatmaji said Lalaji wanted the same thing as Lokamanya Tilak, Swami Shraddhanand, Hakim Ajmal Khan and Deshbandhu Das had wanted.
('45', 8, 2, 11, 14703) It was freedom of India.
('45', 8, 3, 12, 14728) If we could cultivate the same spirit of sacrifice and win swaraj that Lalaji had aspired to win in his lifetime, we would be building a true memorial to him.
('45', 8, 4, 13, 14887) If good work was put in during the course of this year swaraj may come next year and if it did not, non violent non co operation and non payment of taxes will be launched upon.
('45', 8, 4, 14, 15064) This could be done only if preparatory constructive work was done during this year.
('45', 8, 5, 15, 15148) Speaking on important items in the constructive programme he spoke of khaddar as being the only effective way of boycotting foreign cloth.
('45', 8, 5, 16, 15287) He also emphasized the importance of discarding liquor.
('45', 8, 6, 17, 15343) Further, he said he would still repeat what he said in 1921 that swaraj could not be achieved until there was unity between all communities.
('45', 8, 6, 18, 15484) A particular community could no doubt carry on the struggle of non violent non co operation.
('45', 8, 6, 19, 15577) He in his person was non co operating with the Government but that did not bring swaraj for the country.
('45', 8, 6, 20, 15682) Next year some section of people or some province or some taluk might launch upon the campaign of non violent non co operation but the Congress wanted the whole country to prepare for this struggle.
('45', 8, 6, 21, 15881) Again Swami Shraddhanand and Lalaji had told us of our duty to the depressed classes.
('45', 8, 6, 22, 15967) He (Mahatmaji) claimed to be a Sanatanist Hindu though he feared his claim was disputed.
('45', 8, 6, 23, 16056) But even Pandit Madan Mohan Malaviya who was universally recognized as a true Sanatanist was taking untouchable brethren to the banks of the holy Ganges and giving them holy mantra and good advice and making them one with the Hindus.

('45', 9, 9, 12, 16643) 10. SPEECH AT BHARAT SARASVATI MANDIR, KARACHI 3
('45', 9, 10, 13, 16692) February 5, 1929
('45', 9, 11, 14, 16709) Gandhiji made a brief but powerful speech in vindication of the existence of national educational institutions.
('45', 9, 11, 15, 16821) The national institutions were a most important fruit of Non co operation.
('45', 9, 11, 16, 16896) That their number had gone down was unfortunate; it betrayed the apathy of the parents.
('45', 9, 11, 17, 16984) Those that had servived the depressing political atmosphere were like oases in a desert and Gandhiji was sure, would be found at the most critical moment to answer the national call when the balconies of palace like schools and colleges would be used as soldiers’ barracks from which they would be shooting down innocent fighters for freedom.
('45', 9, 11, 18, 17327) The Sardar of Bardoli was able to work wonders because of the volunteers that were supplied either directly by the national institutions of Gujarat or that were otherwise a product of the atmosphere of service that these national institutions spread round them as a flower garden spreads its fragrance in its vicinity.
('45', 9, 11, 19, 17646) During the distress that overtook
('45', 9, 12, 20, 17680) 1 This was sent in reply to Motilal Nehru’s telegram, dated February 4, reading: “Working Committee considers consultation with you necessary regarding boycott foreign cloth programme.
('45', 9, 12, 21, 17865) Could you visit Delhi or Lahore for day on way back Sind or any other date for meeting committee?
('45', 9, 12, 22, 17963) Wire.” 2 To this Motilal Nehru replied on February 5: “Your consultation with full Committee greatly preferable.

('45', 11, 3, 6, 20487) If there was to be rule of any one class over another the English were there resourceful and powerful enough to insure their own rule.
('45', 11, 3, 7, 20622) All that was possible in the prevailing circumstances was either the overthrow of the present rule and establishment of swaraj by the joint effort of all the classes that formed the Indian nation or the perpetuation of the present slavery.

('45', 12, 1, 2, 22110) There is, however, an English proverb which I want to remind you of.

('45', 13, 1, 15, 26332) Instead of adding to national prosperity our foreign trade is only serving to take the bread out of the mouths of millions of our artisans.

('45', 13, 1, 22, 27060) Our commercial classes have been reduced to the position of mere commercial agents for Lancashire and it is out of the 5% which they get as their share of the exploitation that the seeming magnificence of our big ports like Karachi, Bombay and others is built.

('45', 18, 2, 3, 36195) February 6, 1929
('45', 18, 3, 4, 36212) Here Gandhiji delivered a remarkable reply, urging the Indian students to learn two Indian languages just as Europeans in England learnt Greek and Latin.
('45', 18, 3, 5, 36366) He then deprecated the use of the word “Mahatma”, while anyone was alive.
('45', 18, 3, 6, 36440) “Mahatma” was an appreciative term that ought to be used after death.
('45', 18, 4, 7, 36510) Finally, he touched upon the question of headgear and demonstrated the unhygienic nature of the usual headgear worn by Indians.
('45', 18, 4, 8, 36638) Talking of the cap of a young boy near him and pointing towards it, he drew attention to the dust, grease, hair oil and dried perspiration on the cap, which was un washable.
('45', 18, 4, 9, 36812) Yet, he said, men wore such filthy things year in and year out and refused to discard them because they were rather costly.
('45', 18, 4, 10, 36936) The scientists had proved that all dark colours, particularly black, attracted and held heat.
('45', 18, 4, 11, 37030) Most of the caps worn in India were of black or some other dark colour.
('45', 18, 4, 12, 37102) Mr. Gandhi then offered to exchange his khaddar made Gandhi cap free with anyone who would consent to his foreign cap being burned on the spot.
('45', 18, 4, 13, 37246) Several hundred students did so and Dr. Tarachand Lalvani, Secretary of the Karachi Congress Committee, collected all the foreign caps and made a bonfire of them before a bewildered crowd.

('45', 18, 6, 15, 37457) 18. ON DEATH
('45', 18, 7, 16, 37470) Death continues to haunt man as the terror of terrors.
('45', 18, 7, 17, 37525) Whilst we have much in our literature that teaches us to be indifferent to death, there is also much that inculcates in us a paralysing fear of death.
('45', 18, 7, 18, 37676) In these times when we wish to contemplate death in the cause of the country as a matter of joy and honour, the following extract 3 sent by a friend from Lecky’s History of European Morals will be of interest.
('45', 18, 8, 19, 37886) There was much difference of opinion and of certitude in the judgments of the ancient philosophers (the Stoics) concerning the future destinies of the

('45', 19, 1, 2, 38322) Soul, but they were unanimous in regarding death simply as a natural rest, and in attributing the terrors that were connected with it to a diseased imagination.
('45', 19, 1, 3, 38483) Death, they said, is the only evil that does not afflict us when present.
('45', 19, 1, 4, 38557) While we are, death is not; when death has come, we are not.
('45', 19, 1, 5, 38618) It is a false belief that it only follows, it also precedes life.
('45', 19, 1, 6, 38684) It is to be as we were before we were born.

('45', 19, 3, 15, 39424) 19. THE INHUMAN SYSTEM
('45', 19, 4, 16, 39447) The Imperial Indian Citizenship Association, Bombay circulated during the Christmas week the following note 1 to the Press :
('45', 19, 5, 17, 39572) It will be remember that in the month of September last, Reuter reported the death of 37 repatriated Indians on board the s.s.
('45', 19, 5, 18, 39699) Sutlej returning to India from British Guiana.
('45', 19, 5, 19, 39746) The investigations were conducted by Major W. O. Walker, I.M.S., Protector of Emigrants, Calcutta and Mr. E. H. Blandy, I.C.S., Collector of the 24 Parganas.
('45', 19, 5, 20, 39904) The report of this official enquiry says that there were 745 passengers on the s.s.
('45', 19, 5, 21, 39988) Sutlej out of which 37 died.
('45', 19, 5, 22, 40017) Of these deaths, thirty were due to respiratory diseases and seven to other causes such as heart diseases, nephritis, enteritis, senility and malaria.
('45', 19, 5, 23, 40168) The report further observes that the deaths were practically confined to old people, who were not strong and who, but for their great anxiety to return to their homeland, would probably have been advised not to undertake so long a voyage.
('45', 19, 5, 24, 40407) It also shows that the incident was no exception to previous years; as since 1923, deaths among the repatriated Indians on these boats have regularly occurred.
('45', 19, 5, 25, 40567) As it was received at a time when I was hardly able to rest my head on a pillow, the note was placed by my assistant in the Young India file.
('45', 19, 5, 26, 40709) It is only during my journey to Sind that I am able to reach this important note.
('45', 19, 6, 27, 40791) 1 Only extracts are reproduced here.
('45', 20, 0, 1, 40828) VOL.45: 4 FEBRUARY, 1929 11 MAY, 1929 21
('45', 20, 1, 2, 40869) The system of Government which holds us in bondage is so wicked that it successfully denies justice by making a pretence of rendering justice.
('45', 20, 1, 3, 41012) An inordinate mortality occurs on an immigrant ship.
('45', 20, 1, 4, 41065) Lest it might attract public opinion, a guilty conscience appoints a public inquiry so called but in reality a white washing inquiry which finds that such deaths have always occurred on such ships, as if a wrong becomes right by prescription.
('45', 20, 1, 5, 41308) The Committee consists of a person called the ‘Protector’ of Immigrants and a Collector both of whom by the very nature of their occupation are inured to such occurrences.
('45', 20, 1, 6, 41480) I know these boats and I know how the ‘exiles’ are ‘packed like sardines’ (not an expression of my coining but that of those concer ned with emigration) in ill ventilated and worse lighted holes.
('45', 20, 1, 7, 41676) Add to this the habit of our people to shun air and light when there is the least cold.
('45', 20, 1, 8, 41764) These habits do not affect them much when perforce they have to be outdoor for the better part of the day.
('45', 20, 1, 9, 41871) They do affect them mortally as on the s.s.
('45', 20, 1, 10, 41915) Sutlej when they have to be in a dungeon like closed deck practically during the whole of the voyage.
('45', 20, 1, 11, 42017) In my opinion the Imperial Indian Citizenship Association should not allow the matter to rest at the so called inquiry but having drawn public attention to the terrible mortality should demand an impartial public inquiry which should include an examination by experts of the build of the boats designed for emigration purposes.
('45', 20, 1, 12, 42345) It will be found then that more than one department was concerned in the tragedy which as is admitted is of periodical occurrence.
('45', 20, 1, 13, 42476) It will be found too that the greed of the owners of these ships is no less responsible for this mortality than the callous indifference of masters and officers of these ships who regard the emigrants not as fellowmen to be gently treated but as beasts needing no attention.
('45', 20, 1, 14, 42751) As a matter of fact even beasts are better kept for the simple reason that their owners will exact damages if they are not properly tended.

('45', 20, 2, 16, 42913) 20. ‘MY ATTITUDE TOWARDS WAR’
('45', 20, 3, 17, 42943) My article under the above heading published in Young India, 13th September, 1928 has given rise to much correspondence with me and in the European Press that is interested in war against war.
('45', 20, 3, 18, 43136) In the personal correspondence there is a letter from Tolstoy’s friend and follower V. Tcherkoff which, coming as it does from one who
('45', 21, 0, 1, 43271) 22 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('45', 21, 1, 2, 43312) commands great respect among lovers of peace, the reader will like me to share with him.
('45', 21, 1, 3, 43401) Here is the letter : 1
('45', 21, 2, 4, 43424) Your Russian friends send you their warmest greetings and best wishes for the further success of your devoted service for God and men.
('45', 21, 2, 5, 43559) With the liveliest interest do we follow your life, the work of your mind and your activity and we rejoice at each one of your successes.
('45', 21, 2, 6, 43697) We realize that all that you attain in your own country is at the same time also our attainment, for although under different circumstances, we are serving the one and the same cause.
('45', 21, 2, 7, 43881) We feel a great gratitude to you for all that you have given and are giving us by your person, the example of your life and your fruitful social work.
('45', 21, 2, 8, 44032) We feel the deepest and most joyous spiritual union with you.
('45', 21, 3, 9, 44094) Your article “My Attitude towards War”, printed in Young India of the 13th September of this year, has grieved many of your admirers and friends.
('45', 21, 3, 10, 44240) And I have felt the need of expressing that which I feel and think on this subject.
('45', 21, 4, 11, 44324) You justify your past participation in three wars waged by the British
('45', 21, 5, 12, 44395) Government.
('45', 21, 5, 13, 44407) Alluding to the same subject some years ago you in an article
('45', 21, 6, 14, 44469) expressed yourself, if I remember right, in another spirit.
('45', 21, 6, 15, 44529) Then you did not
('45', 21, 7, 16, 44546) justify yourself, but recognized your former inconsistency.
('45', 21, 7, 17, 44606) And I remember
('45', 21, 8, 18, 44621) that this readiness of yours to recognize your past mistake greatly touched and
('45', 21, 9, 19, 44701) consoled me and your other friends here.
('45', 21, 9, 20, 44742) Whereas now, on the contrary, you
('45', 21, 10, 21, 44776) justify yourself, referring to the usual arguments put forward in defence of
('45', 21, 12, 22, 44853) Neither may one solve this question according to whether one sympathizes or not with a given government.
('45', 21, 12, 23, 44958) And yet you do so when you say: “If there was a national government I can conceive occasions when it would be my duty to vote for the military training of those who wish to take it.” In this way you justify others who also vote for the preparation for war because they sympathize with another Government.
('45', 21, 12, 24, 45263) And what a snare is placed in people’s way by a man who denies war to such an extent that he refuses to serve in the army and who at the same time votes for military training?
('45', 21, 13, 25, 45439) Further you say that “all its (the Government’s) members do not believe
('45', 21, 14, 26, 45511) in non violence” and that “it is not possible to make a person or a society
('45', 21, 15, 27, 45587) non violent by compulsion.” But by abstaining from voting for military
('45', 21, 16, 28, 45658) training I compel no one to do anything, just as by refraining from voting for
('45', 21, 17, 29, 45737) training pickpockets I do no violence to pickpockets.

('45', 22, 0, 1, 45828) VOL.45: 4 FEBRUARY, 1929 11 MAY, 1929 23
('45', 22, 1, 2, 45869) You refer to the example of a harvest eaten by monkeys.
('45', 22, 1, 3, 45925) But by transferring the case from men to monkeys you obscure it.
('45', 22, 1, 4, 45990) If your harvest were attacked by men not beasts, would you not deem it your duty to sacrifice the harvest rather than destroy the men ?
('45', 22, 2, 5, 46126) You say that it would be madness for you to sever your connection with the society to which you belong and that as long as you lived under a system of government based on force and voluntarily partook of the many facilities and privileges it created for you you were bound to help it to the extent of your ability when it was engaged in war.
('45', 22, 3, 6, 46468) Firstly, by abstaining from approving those evil deeds which men are engaged in around me I not only do not “sever my connection with the society to which I belong,” but, exactly the opposite.
('45', 22, 3, 7, 46661) I utilize this connection for the best possible way of serving this society.
('45', 22, 4, 8, 46738) Secondly, if living as I live, I am obliged to assist the State in waging war, then I ought at all costs to cease to live as I live, even if I had in doing so to sacrifice my life, and in no wise to help people in the slaughter of their brothers.
('45', 22, 4, 9, 46985) Besides it is quite possible to make use of certain facilities afforded by the State, which could be obtained without violence, and at the same time to abstain from supporting the evil deeds of the State.
('45', 22, 5, 10, 47190) Perhaps the misunderstanding partly arises from your not having sufficiently rigidly drawn the line between violence and killing.
('45', 22, 5, 11, 47320) There are cases when it is indeed difficult, without careful consideration, to make clear whether definite violence is being committed.
('45', 22, 5, 12, 47456) But in the question of war there is no room for doubt as to its being founded on the killing of man.
('45', 22, 5, 13, 47557) In this we probably agree.
('45', 22, 5, 14, 47584) I need hardly assure M. Tcherkoff that not only do I not resent his letter but I welcome it for its warmth of affection and for its transparent sincerity.
('45', 22, 5, 15, 47739) I do not propose to enter into a detailed replay to the points raised in the letter.
('45', 22, 5, 16, 47824) For me the matter does not admit of reasoning beyond a point.
('45', 22, 5, 17, 47886) It is one of deep conviction that war is an unmixed evil.
('45', 22, 5, 18, 47944) I would not yield to anyone in my detestation of war.
('45', 22, 5, 19, 47998) But conviction is one thing, correct practice is another.
('45', 22, 5, 20, 48056) The very thing that one war resister may do in the interest of his mission may repel another war resister who may do the exact opposite and yet both may hold the same view about war.
('45', 22, 5, 21, 48239) This contradiction arises because of the bewildering complexity of human nature.
('45', 22, 5, 22, 48320) I can only therefore plead for mutual toleration even among professors of the same creed.
('45', 23, 0, 1, 48410) 24 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('45', 23, 1, 2, 48451) Now for some points in the letter.
('45', 23, 1, 3, 48486) I do not recall the writing or speech in which I expressed repentance for my participation in Britain’s wars.
('45', 23, 1, 4, 48596) What I am likely to have said is that I was sorry that I aided Britain though her policy was afterwards discovered by me to have been one fraught with harm to India and danger to humanity.
('45', 23, 1, 5, 48785) If I had felt remorse for having taken part in the three wars as wars, I should have remembered it and repeated it unless I had changed my opinion about my participation.
('45', 23, 1, 6, 48956) Whatever I have done was not done from expedience as we understand the term.
('45', 23, 1, 7, 49033) I claim to have done every act described by me for the purpose of advancing the cause of peace.
('45', 23, 1, 8, 49129) That does not mean that those acts really advanced the cause of peace.
('45', 23, 1, 9, 49200) I am merely stating the fact that my motive was peace.
('45', 23, 1, 10, 49255) What is possible however is that I was then weak and am still too weak to perceive my error even as a blind man is unable to see what his neighbours are able to see.
('45', 23, 1, 11, 49421) I observe daily how capable we are of utmost self deception.
('45', 23, 1, 12, 49482) For the time being how ever I am not aware of any self deception.
('45', 23, 1, 13, 49548) What Ifeel is that I am looking at peace through a medium to which my European friends are strangers.
('45', 23, 1, 14, 49650) I belong to a country which is compulsorily disarmed and has been held under subjection for centuries.
('45', 23, 1, 15, 49753) My way of looking at peace may be necessarily different from theirs.
('45', 23, 1, 16, 49822) Let me take an illustration.
('45', 23, 1, 17, 49851) Supposing that both cats and mice sincerely desire peace.
('45', 23, 1, 18, 49909) Now cats will have to adjure war against mice.
('45', 23, 1, 19, 49956) But how will mice promote peace?
('45', 23, 1, 20, 49989) What will they abjure?
('45', 23, 1, 21, 50012) Is their vote even necessary?
('45', 23, 1, 22, 50042) Suppose further that some cats do not observe the pact arrived at by the assembly of cats and continue preying upon mice, what will mice do?
('45', 23, 1, 23, 50183) There may be some wise heads among them and they may say, ‘We will offer ourselves a willing sacrifice till the cats are oversatisfied and find no fun in preying.’These will do well to propagate their cult.
('45', 23, 1, 24, 50390) But what should be their attitude, peace lovers though they are, towards the mice who would instead of runnig away from their oppressors decided to arm themselves and give battle to the enemy?
('45', 23, 1, 25, 50583) The effort may be vain but the wise mice whom I have imagined will, I apprehend, be bound to assist the mice in their desire to become bold and strong even whilst maintaining their attitude of peace.
('45', 23, 1, 26, 50783) They will do so not out of policy but from the highest of motives.
('45', 23, 1, 27, 50850) That is exactly my attitude.
('45', 23, 1, 28, 50879) Non violence is not an easy thing to understand, still less to practise, weak as we are.
('45', 23, 1, 29, 50968) We must all act
('45', 24, 0, 1, 50984) VOL.45: 4 FEBRUARY, 1929 11 MAY, 1929 25
('45', 24, 1, 2, 51025) prayerfully and humbly and continually asking God to open the eyes of our understanding, being ever ready to act according to the light as we daily receive it.
('45', 24, 1, 3, 51185) My task as a lover and promoter of peace therefore today consists in unflinching devotion to non violence in the prosecution of the campaign for regaining our liberty.
('45', 24, 1, 4, 51353) And if India succeeds in so regaining it it will be the greatest contribution to the world’s peace.
('45', 24, 1, 5, 51453) European war resisters therefore may well formulate public opinion in Europe that will compel Britain to retrace her steps and stop the continuing spoliation of India.

('45', 26, 4, 7, 55447) I think there is no question that our League was not in any degree to blame for the occurrence in Graz.
('45', 26, 4, 8, 55551) The militaristic element in Austria, which is causing such grave apprehensions, especially in regard to the demonstrations last Sunday, came out in force at that Graz meeting specially in order to injure General Schonaich.
('45', 26, 4, 9, 55774) This was not foreseen by any of the participants at the meeting who themselves ran very great risks of personal injury, as indeed many of us did who held pacifist meetings during the War.

('45', 28, 4, 14, 59065) 26. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, JACOBABAD 1
('45', 28, 5, 15, 59107) February 7, 1929
('45', 28, 6, 16, 59124) Gandhiji in his speech while thanking the respective committees and organizations for partiotic sentiments in presenting their respective purses for the Lalaji Memorial warned them against the dangers of developing a separatist tendency.
('45', 28, 6, 17, 59362) 2 Why could they not, he asked them, present him a single consoli dated purse on behalf of all of them?
('45', 28, 6, 18, 59466) Was he to infer that they could not find any single person whom they could accept as their common representative?
('45', 28, 6, 19, 59580) Again, it had been suggested to him that response to appeal for the Lalaji Memorial Fund would have been more liberal if the people had the assurance that at least a substantial part of Sind’s money would be earmarked for use in Sind itself.
('45', 28, 6, 20, 59822) The suggestion to him betrayed a narrow outlook.
('45', 28, 6, 21, 59871) He wanted them to feel that in the Service of India consisted the service of Sind also.
('45', 28, 6, 22, 59959) And since every pie of the Fund was to be utilized for the service of India, Sind would be a participator in the benefit of the Fund not only to the extent of its contribution but to the entire extent of the Fund.
('45', 28, 6, 23, 60173) Lalaji’s Servants of the People Society was at the beck and call of any part of India where its services were most needed.
('45', 28, 6, 24, 60296) It was trying to enlist members from all parts of India; if
('45', 28, 7, 25, 60356) 1 Extracted from Pyarelal’s “Weekly Letter”.
('45', 28, 7, 26, 60401) Purses and addresses on behalf of seven different organizations were presented to Gandhiji.
('45', 28, 7, 27, 60493) 2 Fearing that sanatani Hindus might object to untouchables attending the same meeting the organizers had arranged separate meetings for them.
('45', 28, 7, 28, 60636) On learning this Gandhiji said: “You may keep your purses and all your addresses.
('45', 28, 7, 29, 60718) I am going to have the meeting with untouchables only.
('45', 28, 7, 30, 60773) Let all others who want come and present their addresses then.”
('45', 29, 0, 1, 60837) 30 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('45', 29, 1, 2, 60878) no name from Sind was on its roll yet, the fault was not of the Society but of Sind.
('45', 29, 1, 3, 60963) Finally, since a part of the Lalaji Fund was earmarked for untouchability work, if they prepared a suitable scheme for work among the untouchables of Sind, they could apply to the trustees of the Fund for financial aid, and their claim would be favourably considered.
('45', 29, 1, 4, 61231) He then went on to make an impassioned appeal to the workers to purge their hearts of all base feelings of personal rancour, suspicion and distrust that were poisioning the political atmosphere of Sind and paralysing all useful activity.
('45', 29, 1, 5, 61469) It had pained him very much to find that aspersions were cast even on a person like Jairamdas whom he regarded as a cent per cent good servant of India.
('45', 29, 1, 6, 61622) Instead of indulging in recriminations, they should prepare for the fiery ordeal that awaited them by going through the process of self purification and purifying the Congress organization during the present year of probation and grace.
('45', 29, 2, 7, 61859) Young India, 21 2 1929

('45', 31, 0, 1, 64104) 32 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('45', 31, 1, 2, 64145) 29. SPEECH AT STUDENTS’ MEETING, SHIKARPUR 1
('45', 31, 2, 3, 64190) February 8, 1929
('45', 31, 3, 4, 64207) Gandhiji spoke to them on the duty of wearing khadi.
('45', 31, 3, 5, 64260) But the boys were in a rather impish mood.
('45', 31, 3, 6, 64303) When Gandhiji asked them whether they would still wear foreign clothes after what he had told them about khadi there was a mischievous chorus of ‘All’ ‘All’.
('45', 31, 3, 7, 64461) Gandhiji next asked them whether there were any among them who occasionally indulged in lying.
('45', 31, 3, 8, 64556) Some students boldly confessed their failing by raising their hands but the general spirit of exhilaration soon got the better of their earnestness.
('45', 31, 3, 9, 64705) Gandhiji then too asked them whether there were any among them who would persist in the habit of lying.
('45', 31, 3, 10, 64809) But this time not a single hand was raised and the erstwhile frivolous faces of the children at once became serious and drawn up in a grim resolve.
('45', 31, 3, 11, 64957) Gandhiji was deeply touched.
('45', 31, 3, 12, 64986) He spoke to them about the necessity of personal purity and of the greatness of truth.
('45', 31, 3, 13, 65073) Put all your knowledge, learning and scholarship in one scale and truth and purity in the other and the latter will by far outweight the other.
('45', 31, 3, 14, 65217) The miasma of moral impurity has today spread among our school going children and like a hidden epidemic is working havoc among them.
('45', 31, 3, 15, 65351) I therefore appeal to you, boys and girls, to keep your minds and bodies pure.
('45', 31, 3, 16, 65430) All your scholarship, all your study of the scriptures will be in vain if you fail to translate their teachings into your daily life.
('45', 31, 3, 17, 65564) I know that some of the teachers too do not lead pure and clean lives.
('45', 31, 3, 18, 65635) To them I say that even if they impart all the knowledge in the world to their students but inculcate not truth and purity among them, they will have betrayed them and instead of raising them set them on the downward road to perdition.
('45', 31, 3, 19, 65871) Know ledge without character is a power for evil only, as seen in the instan ces of so many talented thieves and ‘gentlemen rascals’ in the world.
('45', 31, 3, 20, 66018) Finally let me tell you, teachers and students, that even if you did not contribute a single pie to the Lalaji Memorial Fund but made yourselves immaculately pure in thought, word and deed you would have rendered the greatest service to Lalaji’s spirit and to the country.
('45', 31, 4, 21, 66291) Young India, 21 2 1929
('45', 31, 5, 22, 66314) 1 Extracted from Pyarelal’s “Weekly Letter”
('45', 32, 0, 1, 66358) VOL.45: 4 FEBRUARY, 1929 11 MAY, 1929 33
('45', 32, 1, 2, 66399) 30. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, SHIKARPUR 1
('45', 32, 2, 3, 66441) February 8, 1929
('45', 32, 3, 4, 66458) At the public meeting in the evening Gandhiji made this incident 2 the text of his appeal to the merchant princes of Shikarpur to use their splendid business talents and energy to become the trustees of Daridranarayana instead of being his spoliators—as they at present were, taking out one hundred rupees out of the pockets of the poor of which they got only five rupees as commission, and the balance of Rs. 95 they exported to their foreign principals.
('45', 32, 3, 5, 66914) He further exhorted them to rid themselves of the evil custom of deti leti, child marriages, marriage of young girls with old men and breaking off out of sordid considerations betrothals solemnly made.
('45', 32, 3, 6, 67116) At the end of the meeting there were questions which drew important observations on the canons of scriptural interpretation.
('45', 32, 3, 7, 67241) He warned them against accepting everything that was written in Sanskrit verse as Shastra.
('45', 32, 3, 8, 67332) Even the Shastras had to stand the test of reason and moral sense.
('45', 32, 3, 9, 67399) The first qualification for the interpretation of the Shastras was that one should have purified oneself by a rigorous preparatory course of the observance of yamas and niyamas.
('45', 32, 4, 10, 67577) Young India, 21 2 1929

('45', 33, 4, 10, 68812) 32. LETTER TO DEVDAS GANDHI
('45', 33, 5, 11, 68840) February 9, 1929
('45', 33, 6, 12, 68857) DEVDAS, I have just now got your two telegrams here at Larkana.
('45', 33, 6, 13, 68921) I also got Dr. Ansari’s telegram.
('45', 33, 6, 14, 68955) The telegram arrived while food was being brought in for me.
('45', 33, 6, 15, 69016) I took my meal as usual and kept on working as I ate.
('45', 33, 6, 16, 69070) Now I sit down to write this.
('45', 33, 6, 17, 69100) My programme here will remain as already fixed.
('45', 33, 6, 18, 69148) This is what I feel now.
('45', 33, 6, 19, 69173) Rasik’s death certainly pains me, but that is only because of selfishness.
('45', 33, 6, 20, 69248) I love the boy.
('45', 33, 6, 21, 69264) I had placed high hopes on him.
('45', 33, 6, 22, 69296) God will in some mysterious way fulfil through him the hopes we had of him.
('45', 33, 6, 23, 69372) But how are we, human beings, to remain steadfast in such faith?
('45', 33, 6, 24, 69437) Our pain at his departure is the result of our selfishness.
('45', 33, 6, 25, 69497) As for Rasik he has been freed from the pains to which the body is subject.
('45', 33, 6, 26, 69573) I have no doubt that he is in a better state in the other world, for he was a devotee of Rama.
('45', 33, 6, 27, 69668) You will feel the greatest pain of all, though you may not show it.
('45', 33, 6, 28, 69736) What you did is beyond praise.
('45', 33, 6, 29, 69767) You will have the reward of your services to him.
('45', 33, 6, 30, 69817) Your fortitude will lead to your progress.
('45', 33, 6, 31, 69860) Rasik died through no fault of yours.
('45', 33, 6, 32, 69898) He went to Delhi to collect the debt owing to him, and departed when it had been paid.
('45', 33, 6, 33, 69985) You did your duty well.
('45', 33, 6, 34, 70009) God will certainly bless you.
('45', 33, 6, 35, 70039) Let me tell you what I feel inwardly.
('45', 33, 6, 36, 70077) It is of course God’s will that prevails,and human intelligence follows the law of karma.
('45', 33, 6, 37, 70167) Man is however entitled to use his reason.
('45', 33, 6, 38, 70210) Accordingly, it appears to me that the best remedies are the remedies I or we employ and are based on nature cure methods.
('45', 33, 6, 39, 70333) It seems to me that both Maganlal and Rasik could perhaps have been saved if simple remedies had been applied.
('45', 34, 0, 1, 70444) VOL.45: 4 FEBRUARY, 1929 11 MAY, 1929 35
('45', 34, 1, 2, 70485) One may put the same idea in another way.
('45', 34, 1, 3, 70527) If Rasik had been destined to live, he would have been put in such circumstances that only nature cure methods would have been used in his treatment.
('45', 34, 1, 4, 70677) This thought, however, is no consolation, nor do we seek any.
('45', 34, 1, 5, 70739) By saying all this, I do not express regret at having sent him to Delhi or at his being put under a doctor’s treatment.
('45', 34, 1, 6, 70859) You did what was pr for him in respect of Maganlal.
('45', 34, 1, 7, 70911) We should never grieve over anyone’s death.
('45', 34, 1, 8, 70955) Dharma lies in doing one’s duty, not in making no mistake at all.
('45', 34, 1, 9, 71021) But after all, mine is only a conjecture.
('45', 34, 1, 10, 71063) What was best Rama alone knows.
('45', 34, 1, 11, 71095) Incidentally, I have to go to Delhi on February 17, and that is exactly as I would have it.
('45', 34, 1, 12, 71187) I shall be able to see you.
('45', 34, 1, 13, 71215) Detain Ba.
('45', 34, 1, 14, 71226) But let her go if she wished to.
('45', 34, 1, 15, 71259) I know you must be comforting Kanti.
('45', 34, 1, 16, 71296) I shall expect a full account from you then.
('45', 34, 1, 17, 71341) I still have enough attachment to be eager to know from you about the last days of Rasik’s life.
('45', 34, 1, 18, 71438) Do not disappoint me in that.
('45', 34, 2, 19, 71468) Blessings from BAPU

('45', 35, 6, 12, 72595) 35. LETTER TO CHHAGANLAL JOSHI
('45', 35, 7, 13, 72626) LARKANA, Saturday [February 9, 1929] 2
('45', 35, 8, 14, 72665) CHHAGANLAL, I have no letter from you today.
('45', 35, 8, 15, 72710) Rasik has passed away.
('45', 35, 8, 16, 72733) As I came out after finishing my bath and was preparing to sit down for my meal, I got a telegram from Devdas.
('45', 35, 8, 17, 72844) I read the telegram and sat down for the meal.
('45', 35, 8, 18, 72891) Work is going on as usual.
('45', 35, 8, 19, 72918) I feel grief at Rasik’s passing away, but see plainly that it is the result of selfishness.
('45', 35, 8, 20, 73010) I had entertained hopes of getting much work done through his body and certainly, therefore, I am suffering today as we suffer for selfish reasons when a machine breaks down.
('45', 35, 8, 21, 73185) If we think of the one within who was driving the machine, we should, on the contrary, be happy, for the cage had become old, was decaying and the swan flew away.
('45', 35, 8, 22, 73348) There is no cause in this for mourning.
('45', 35, 8, 23, 73388) I know this and that is why, suppressing my selfish grief, I go on with my work.
('45', 35, 8, 24, 73469) When one machine breaks down, the rest of us should improve our own machines, make them work more and thus make up for the loss of the one that has broken down.
('45', 35, 9, 25, 73630) 1 From the reference to Rasik’s death, which occurred on February 8 2 Gandhiji was at Larkana on February 9.

('45', 42, 1, 2, 86649) 40. A DEMONIACAL SYSTEM
('45', 42, 2, 3, 86673) There is a steamer called the Sutlej.
('45', 42, 2, 4, 86711) Some months ago that vessel called at the Calcutta port bringing as passengers some Indian labourers returning from British Guiana.
('45', 42, 2, 5, 86843) There are a number of steamers in which steamship companies carry passengers to distant Colonies and back.
('45', 42, 2, 6, 86950) The Sutlej is one of them.
('45', 42, 2, 7, 86977) Of the passengers it had on board 37 died during the voyage.
('45', 42, 2, 8, 87038) This is a shocking figure.
('45', 42, 2, 9, 87065) As soon as the fact became known the Imperial Citizenship Association sent a telegram to the Government suggesting that an inquiry be held into the matter.
('45', 42, 2, 10, 87221) The Government, it appears, already had an explanation.
('45', 42, 2, 11, 87277) Two officials had been appointed to investigate the matter.
('45', 42, 2, 12, 87337) They had reported that such deaths were a common occurrence on such steamers; that those among the passengers of the Sutlej who had died were old people, who, as a matter of fact, ought not to have left British Guiana, as they were not fit enough to undertake a sea voyage.
('45', 42, 2, 13, 87611) Having obtained such a report the Government has exonerated itself.
('45', 42, 2, 14, 87679) Let us try to see who the investigation officials were.
('45', 42, 2, 15, 87735) One held the post of the Protector of Emigrants, the other wasa Collector from that area.
('45', 42, 2, 16, 87825) The point to note in these appointments is that neither officials can be regarded as neutral or impartial because the task of both is to inspect steamers of the kind in question.
('45', 42, 2, 17, 88004) They are supposed to be responsible for the health, etc.
('45', 42, 2, 18, 88061) , of the passengers.
('45', 42, 2, 19, 88082) Hence it is in thier interest to show at the end of an inquiry that there has been no oppression, injustice or irregularity.
('45', 42, 2, 20, 88207) In fact as they were the interested parties they ought to have been made to stand in the dock.
('45', 42, 2, 21, 88302) Whether or not they had properly discharged their duty was the subject matter of the inquiry.
('45', 42, 2, 22, 88396) That means in plain language that the accused were made their own judges.
('45', 42, 2, 23, 88470) Could there be anything wanting in the verdict they would give?
('45', 42, 2, 24, 88534) I call this sytem a demoniacal system.
('45', 42, 2, 25, 88573) To pretend to render justice instead of doing so, to fuss outward formalities in order to throw dust into people’s eyes, to build dykes beforehand, never to accept any mistakes as far as possible, to cover up the guilt of the guilty officials—these are marks of a demoniacal system.
('45', 42, 2, 26, 88856) We observe these marks every day in the British administration.
('45', 43, 0, 1, 88920) 44 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('45', 43, 1, 2, 88961) Let us now examine the Sutlej affair a little more fully.
('45', 43, 1, 3, 89019) If the number of deaths that occurred on the Sutlej occur on every voyage, surely this cannot be used to cover up these deaths.
('45', 43, 1, 4, 89147) It only shows the cruelty and callousness of the officials.
('45', 43, 1, 5, 89207) If deaths on this scale had occurredonly on this occasion it might perhaps be treated as anaccident.
('45', 43, 1, 6, 89308) But if they occur regularly they are unpardonable and indefensible.
('45', 43, 1, 7, 89376) Instead, the officials gave a contrary verdict as if sins or crimes ceased to be so if they took place everyday.
('45', 43, 1, 8, 89489) The questions which arise from the Sutlej incident are: How is the Sutlej built?
('45', 43, 1, 9, 89570) Does she have enough accommodation for the passengers?
('45', 43, 1, 10, 89625) Is there provision for enough light and air?
('45', 43, 1, 11, 89670) Is there protection from cold, heat, rain, etc.?
('45', 43, 1, 12, 89719) Also, did the passengers have enough clothing?
('45', 43, 1, 13, 89766) In considering these questions the inquiry should further cover the owner of the steamer, the mates and other officers, the British Guianese officials and Indian officials connected with this department.
('45', 43, 1, 14, 89970) Who will conduct such an impartial inquiry and in whose interests?
('45', 43, 1, 15, 90037) Who will care for poor indentured labourers?
('45', 43, 1, 16, 90082) Who bothers whether they live or die, whether they eat or do not.
('45', 43, 1, 17, 90148) The Association has done the right thing in drawing attention tothe tragic incident of the Sutlej.
('45', 43, 1, 18, 90247) I hope the Association will not rest satisfied that the Government has exonerated itself.
('45', 43, 1, 19, 90337) This shocking occurrence calls for an impartial public inquiry.
('45', 43, 1, 20, 90401) It need hardly be stressed that persons other than officials should be appointed to conduct it.

('45', 47, 1, 2, 97464) 43. FEAR OF THE PENAL CODE
('45', 47, 2, 3, 97491) While advising a young man several weeks ago,I had suggested that he should repudiate his child marriage and, if his doing so pained his parents, he should put up with it.
('45', 47, 2, 4, 97663) A lawyer friend writes on this subject thus : 1 I see no reason to withdraw my advice.
('45', 47, 2, 5, 97750) The law is no guide to a reformer; in the final analysis it is only his inner voice that shows the way.
('45', 47, 2, 6, 97854) He who fears the law can bring about no reforms.
('45', 47, 2, 7, 97903) With regard to all the great reforms in the world it can be said that they came about because the reformers never bothered about the law.
('45', 47, 2, 8, 98041) In the present case the marriage whose repudiation I advised cannot, truly speaking, be regarded as a marriage at all.
('45', 47, 2, 9, 98160) Where a girl is so young that she does not even understand what marriage is, marriage has no meaning.
('45', 47, 2, 10, 98262) A marriage implies a certain kind of relationship entered into withunderstanding between a man and a woman, and a certain kind of contract.
('45', 47, 2, 11, 98402) And about a contract the law says that both parties must understand it.
('45', 47, 2, 12, 98474) A contract effected without either party understanding it or one concluded by force can never be binding.
('45', 47, 2, 13, 98580) Hence, I feel that the advice I gave is practical.
('45', 47, 2, 14, 98631) And so long as we do not have youths brave enough to act in accordance with such advice, it will not be possible to protect poor, innocent girls.
('45', 47, 2, 15, 98777) If we have to wait for the law to be amended, aeons will pass.
('45', 47, 2, 16, 98840) I do not mean to say that there should be no agitation to amend bad laws or that laws should not be amended.
('45', 47, 2, 17, 98949) The remedy suggested by me is a potent weapon for having the law scrapped.
('45', 47, 2, 18, 99024) A law, truly speaking, should follow public opinion.
('45', 47, 2, 19, 99077) It is only in an autocratic regime, in a regime indifferent to public opinion, that laws opposed to public opinion are made.
('45', 47, 2, 20, 99202) Consequently, the people always look for loopholes to circumvent those laws, and indeed do so successfully and, finally, the respect based on understanding that one should have for the laws disappears.
('45', 47, 2, 21, 99404) I think the remedy that I have suggested is the first step towards abolishing child marriage and similar other wicked practices.
('45', 47, 2, 22, 99533) In this way the people’s attention is at once drawn to the evil customs.
('45', 47, 2, 23, 99606) They begin to think and participate in abolishing laws which support evil
('45', 47, 3, 24, 99680) 1 For text of the letter, vide “A Terror of the Penal Code”, February 7, 1929.
('45', 48, 0, 1, 99759) VOL. 45: 4 FEBRUARY, 1929 11 MAY, 1929 49
('45', 48, 1, 2, 99801) practices.
('45', 48, 1, 3, 99812) Hence, my advice to every enthusiastic reformer is that heshould not bother too much about the intricacies of the law; he should rather, where he sees his duty clearly, act unhesitatingly and be prepared to face the punishment provided by the law.
('45', 48, 1, 4, 100060) The Penal Code may well be necessary for a criminal and may be so for all time.
('45', 48, 1, 5, 100140) But for an innocent reformer, the Penal Code is meaningless and ineffective.
('45', 48, 1, 6, 100217) Punishment has two objects: to deter a criminal from committing crime and to protect society.
('45', 48, 1, 7, 100311) Neither of these things affects a reformer, because he does not have to be deterred from committing any crime and his reform too cannot be halted.
('45', 48, 1, 8, 100458) Punishment actually accelerates reforms.
('45', 48, 1, 9, 100499) In this poor country the innocent harbours more fear of the Penal Code than criminals do.
('45', 48, 1, 10, 100589) A real criminal cares a twopence for that law, while the poor weakling, who has committed no offence and who is not guilty at heart, being a victim of circumstances trembles from fear before the Penal Code.
('45', 48, 1, 11, 100796) This sort of fear has lessened since satyagraha appeared; but the lawyer friend’s letter shows that it still persists.
('45', 48, 1, 12, 100915) Let all reformers save themselves from such fear.

('45', 51, 5, 13, 106365) February 10, 1929
('45', 51, 6, 14, 106383) Gandhiji’s reply was a dissertation on the functions and limitations of our existing municipalities.
('45', 51, 6, 15, 106484) Whilst he agreed with what they had observed in thier address that they could win swaraj through the municipalities, he cautioned them that the statement held good in respect of free and independent municipalities only, not municipalities that were dominated by the Government, as was largely the case in India at present.
('45', 51, 6, 16, 106807) But though the existing municipalities might not by themselves enable them to wrest swaraj from the Government, efficient working would certainly be a great step towards swaraj.
('45', 51, 6, 17, 106985) The first condition of municipal efficiency was that those who entered municipalities should be actuated by a spirit of service, not by considerations of personal gain.
('45', 51, 6, 18, 107154) Secondly, it was necessary that the municipal commissioners should qualify themselves for their work by themselves becoming

('45', 55, 5, 6, 111120) Liberation as I understand it is complete freedom from the bondage of the flesh, that is, from birth and death.

('45', 55, 7, 8, 111241) (2) Life is that which is permanent, that is, ever was, ever is and ever will be and it is superior to all that we can see or sense with our organs.

('45', 55, 9, 10, 111432) (4) Truth and Life in its essence are one and the same.

('45', 55, 11, 16, 111768) That is possible only in the course of a discussion.
('45', 55, 11, 17, 111821) But my answers will perhaps give you an idea how I feel about the paramount questions that agitate all

('45', 57, 2, 3, 113729) February 11, 1929
('45', 57, 3, 4, 113747) SISTERS, I have your letter.
('45', 57, 3, 5, 113776) I am ever content with whatever you can do sincerely.
('45', 57, 3, 6, 113830) My happiness lies in your peace and contentment.
('45', 57, 3, 7, 113879) Deep in my heart there is no sorrow over the death of Rasik.
('45', 57, 3, 8, 113940) I have enough attachment to make me suffer for selfish reasons.
('45', 57, 3, 9, 114004) All of us will go one day where Rasik has gone.
('45', 57, 3, 10, 114052) The difference is only about the time of going.
('45', 57, 3, 11, 114100) Then why feel grief or fear death?
('45', 57, 3, 12, 114135) After death, there is either another birth or moksha.
('45', 57, 3, 13, 114189) We do love life.
('45', 57, 3, 14, 114206) If we long and strive for it we may even attain moksha.
('45', 57, 3, 15, 114262) There is no third state.
('45', 57, 3, 16, 114287) If we do not ceaselessly strive for moksha, then another birth is inevitable.
('45', 57, 3, 17, 114365) And since we love life, we have no cause to feel sorrow.
('45', 57, 3, 18, 114422) Grief is the result of our ignorance.
('45', 57, 3, 19, 114460) Knowing this, I did not stop my work even for a moment.
('45', 57, 3, 20, 114516) This time my tour seems to have begun at such an inauspicious hour that the date of my return is being postponed again and again.

('45', 58, 1, 2, 114814) 58. LETTER TO CHILDREN OF BALMANDIR
('45', 58, 2, 3, 114850) SUKKUR, February 11, 1929
('45', 58, 3, 4, 114876) BIRDS OF THE BAL MANDIR, I got your answers.
('45', 58, 3, 5, 114921) Indu, Vasant and Madhuri state that they will not give upspices as they like them.
('45', 58, 3, 6, 115004) What is this !
('45', 58, 3, 7, 115019) Our practice is to eat, speak or do, not what we like, but what is good.
('45', 58, 3, 8, 115092) Some of you might like chillies, but should you eat them?
('45', 58, 3, 9, 115150) Suppose you havefever and at that time you feel tempted to eat rotli; should youeat it then?
('45', 58, 3, 10, 115243) Eat only what, and as much as, is good for thebody.
('45', 58, 3, 11, 115295) If as children we learn to control the mind, we shall go far.
('45', 58, 3, 12, 115357) Nani says she desires to wear bangles of yarn.
('45', 58, 3, 13, 115404) There is no harm in wearing yarn bangles, but it is best to wear no bangles at all.
('45', 58, 3, 14, 115488) Therefore, even though one may feel tempted to wear yarn bangles, one should suppress the desire.
('45', 58, 3, 15, 115586) Such bangles are bound to get dirty and will have to be washed.
('45', 58, 3, 16, 115650) Wouldn’t it be better, then, not to wear them?
('45', 58, 3, 17, 115697) I had hoped that I would be there in person to hear your answers to this letter.
('45', 58, 3, 18, 115778) But that may not be; in that case you should keep your promises and preserve silence in the class room, the kitchen and at the prayer meeting.

('45', 65, 4, 7, 128057) SWORD V: SPIRIT A friend sends the following interesting extract from an old number ofMy Magazine : 1
('45', 65, 5, 8, 128159) Nepoleon knew that it was folly to rely on force.
('45', 65, 5, 9, 128209) “There are only two powers in the world,” he said, not after he had been defeated and exiled, but while he appeared to be at the height of his success.
('45', 65, 5, 10, 128361) “Those powers are the spirit and the sword.
('45', 65, 5, 11, 128405) In the long run the sword will always be conquered by the spirit.
('45', 65, 6, 12, 128471) But why, we may ask, did Nepoleon, if he saw so plainly the uselessness of war, continue to make war?
('45', 65, 6, 13, 128573) Why did he use the sword untilit was wrenched out of his hand at Waterloo?
('45', 65, 6, 14, 128648) Partly because Nepoleon,like the rest of us, could not always practise what he preached, but partly because other kings and emperors would not let him alone.
('45', 65, 6, 15, 128806) They were not as wise as he.
('45', 65, 6, 16, 128835) When he pleaded for peace they would not believe he wassincere.
('45', 65, 6, 17, 128899) To the Emperor of Austria after a fierce battle he addressed this personal appeal :
('45', 65, 7, 18, 128983) “Amid grief and surrounded by 15,000 corpses, I implore Your Majesty, Ifeel bound to give you an urgent warning.
('45', 65, 7, 19, 129096) You are far from the scene, your heart cannot be so deeply moved as mine is on the spot .
('45', 65, 7, 20, 129186) ” Would that India which through her Congress has subscribed to the policy of non violence will adhere to it and demonstrate to a world groaning under the curse of the sword that the spirit does triumph over the sword in national affairs as it has ever been shown to have triumphed in individual affairs.
('45', 65, 8, 21, 129491) PROHIBITION IN AMERICA One reads conflicting reports in newspapers about the great experiment in prohibition that America is making.
('45', 65, 8, 22, 129624) I question about it the many American tourists who visit me and the majority have assured me that the experiment is working well.
('45', 65, 8, 23, 129754) Among these visitors recently there was an American authoress Madame Sara M. Algeo.
('45', 65, 9, 24, 129838) 1 Only extracts are reproduced here.
('45', 66, 0, 1, 129875) VOL. 45: 4 FEBRUARY, 1929 11 MAY, 1929 67
('45', 66, 1, 2, 129917) She claimed to have worked in the cause of prohibition and was an ardent reformer.
('45', 66, 1, 3, 130000) I therefore asked her to put down in writing as briefly as she could her impressions of the experiment which she very kindly did.
('45', 66, 1, 4, 130130) Here are relevant parts of her enthusiastic letter : 1
('45', 66, 2, 5, 130185) In my interview this afternoon you asked me to write you about our recent great victory for prohibition in the United States.
('45', 66, 2, 6, 130311) It is with real pleasure I do this, for there are so many wild stories afloat about its being a failure that I welcome the chance to put before you the facts.
('45', 66, 2, 7, 130470) You have been a prohibitionist for many years like me.
('45', 66, 2, 8, 130525) We have seen our highest hopes smashed many times and have wondered if our dreams would ever come true.
('45', 66, 3, 9, 130629) Mine were more than realized in the last election in America.
('45', 66, 3, 10, 130691) As you know we have two dominant parties—the Republican and the Democratic party.
('45', 66, 3, 11, 130773) Every four years sees them drawn up in battle regal over certain issues.
('45', 66, 3, 12, 130846) InNovember all other issues paled beside the great one of prohibition which hasbeen in force since 1919 and which had reached a crisis; so many of the richer classes seemed to want their liquor back.
('45', 66, 4, 13, 131046) Governor Alfred Smith of New York State who represented the ‘wets’ staked his hopes of election on the vote of the ‘wets’ and came out boldlyand noisily as in favour of repeal of prohibition laws.
('45', 66, 4, 14, 131243) Mr. Herbert Hoover on the contrary and his running mate Senator Curtis were equally strong in favour of the continuance of prohibition.
('45', 66, 4, 15, 131379) As you know the victory for prohibition and Mr. Hoover was overwhelming not only for the Presidency and Vice Presidency, but for the Senate and Congress as well—8 wet senators going down to defeat and 14 wet Congressmen doing likewise.
('45', 66, 5, 16, 131615) The Women Did It.
('45', 66, 5, 17, 131633) It was the quiet little homebody of the South who contrary to all political expectations deserted her party, the Democratic, that ofMr. Smith, and voted for Mr. Hoover.
('45', 66, 5, 18, 131802) Not only did they vote for Mr. Hoover but they formed clubs and shamed many of their menfolk into supporting him.
('45', 66, 5, 19, 131916) It was indeed a victory for prohibition, a victory for woman suffrage, but especially a great triumph of good over evil.
('45', 66, 5, 20, 132037) WHAT IS COMMON ?
('45', 66, 5, 21, 132054) “What is common to us except Pax Britannica?” is the question that has been often put to me.
('45', 66, 5, 22, 132147) The last time it was put to me was by the editor of the Daily Gazette of Karachi.
('45', 66, 5, 23, 132229) I was sorry I had not the time to answer the question in full detail though my answer was comprehensive enough.
('45', 66, 5, 24, 132341) I suggested that birth, manners, distress and bondage were more common than Pax Britannica.
('45', 66, 5, 25, 132433) But what is this Pax
('45', 66, 6, 26, 132454) 1 Only extracts are reproduced here.
('45', 67, 0, 1, 132491) 68 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('45', 67, 1, 2, 132532) Britannica?
('45', 67, 1, 3, 132544) Does it not mean that it more often keeps us from fighting against one another than protects us from foreign invasions?
('45', 67, 1, 4, 132664) And do we not see that even that condition is more often observed in the breach than in the performance?
('45', 67, 1, 5, 132769) Pax Britannica is unable to prevent Hindu Muslim feuds.
('45', 67, 1, 6, 132825) What it successfully does is to ensure the protection by means of extraordinary military and other dispositions of the few Europeans who are exploiting the country.
('45', 67, 1, 7, 132990) Pax Britannica, therefore, so far as it is common to the whole of the country, is not a blessing calculated to advance the nation either economically or politically.
('45', 67, 1, 8, 133156) It has emasculated the people and reduced them to a state of helplessness.
('45', 67, 1, 9, 133231) My suggestion, therefore, is that common birth, common distress, common manners and common bondage are each in itself and all collectively a real cohesive force, not Pax Britannica.
('45', 67, 1, 10, 133413) Consciousness of distress and consciousness of bondage are unifying the people in a manner in which they have never before been unified.
('45', 67, 1, 11, 133550) And when these become a thing of the past as they are bound to, common birth will prove a force that will make the nation irresistible.
('45', 67, 2, 12, 133686) EVIDENCE BEFORE THE SIMON COMMISSION Among the questions put by the Editor besides the one on Pax Britannica was also one referring to the value of the evidence tendered to the Simon Commission.
('45', 67, 2, 13, 133881) My emphatic opinion is that that evidence has little national value.
('45', 67, 2, 14, 133950) The evidence is mostly from official sources and sources that have always been at the disposal of officials and it was surely a waste of money and effort to bring all the way from London a Parliamentary Commission for the purpose of collecting evidence which could easily have been sent from Delhi to Downing Street at a cost of a few hundred rupees.
('45', 67, 2, 15, 134301) A Government that is irresponsive to public opinion may do any thing it likes over the heads of the people, but it will solve no problems.
('45', 67, 2, 16, 134440) It will make confusion worse confounded.
('45', 67, 2, 17, 134481) Persistence in keeping the Commission in India in defiance of strong public opinion is proof positive of the desire and capacity of this Government to ignore the political opinion of India, no matter how strong, consolidated and unanimous it may be.
('45', 67, 3, 18, 134731) FOR CONSCIENCE’ SAKE Pax International is a monthly journal issued at Geneva, 12 Rue du Vieux College, on behalf of the Women’s International League for Peace and Freedom.
('45', 67, 3, 19, 134903) I have before me a copy of the November number of this monthly which has the following paragraph :
('45', 68, 0, 1, 135002) VOL. 45: 4 FEBRUARY, 1929 11 MAY, 1929 69
('45', 68, 1, 2, 135044) In Yugoslavia 72 members of the religious body of Nazarenes have been condemned by the military court of the Save District to 10 years’ imprisonment for refusing to take up arms.
('45', 68, 1, 3, 135223) All of the condemned have already served 5 years’ imprisonment for the same offence.
('45', 68, 1, 4, 135308) All friends of peace in the whole world should protest against these inhuman sentences and demand the revision of the sentence.
('45', 68, 2, 5, 135436) It is a remarkable awakening in the Western world, this peace movement.
('45', 68, 2, 6, 135508) That 10 years’ servitude for the mere refusal to take up arms is possible under asystem in respect of 70 honourable men who follow the law of love rather than the law of hate which the system promulgates is proof of its barbarity.
