('45', 74, 4, 7, 146266) 74. SPEECH AT P. C. C. MEETING, HYDERABAD 1
('45', 74, 5, 8, 146310) February 14, 1929
('45', 74, 6, 9, 146328) In a brief speech Gandhiji explained the inwardness of the function that was going to be performed.
('45', 74, 6, 10, 146428) A flag was after all a mere piece of cloth.
('45', 74, 6, 11, 146472) And even a child could hoist it.
('45', 74, 6, 12, 146505) Wherein then consisted the merit of hoisting, he asked.
('45', 74, 6, 13, 146561) It consisted in its being the symbol of a nation’s honour and the determination to stand by it though one were all alone.
('45', 74, 6, 14, 146683) The Englishmen had shed their blood freely to upold the honour of the Union Jack and that was what gave it its prestige.
('45', 74, 6, 15, 146804) Again it was to the potential sacrifice which a standard bearer represented that the importance of the office of Alam bardar in Islamic history was due.
('45', 74, 6, 16, 146957) The vindication of the honour of the flag has often called for a reckless sacrifice as was typified in the case of the Moroccan soldiers who throwing away their arms rushed at the French gunners in the face of a withering fire with shouts of Allah.
('45', 74, 6, 17, 147206) The latter were so overcome by the reckless bravery shown by the Moroccans that they threw up their caps in admiration and fraternized with them.
('45', 74, 6, 18, 147352) That was an example for Congressmen to emulate.
('45', 74, 6, 19, 147400) Their unfurling of the Congress flag would be nothing more than a childish mock heroic if it did not carry with it a determination to keep it flying all alone even if everybody else deserted it.
('45', 74, 6, 20, 147595) Similarly their unveiling of the portrait of Lalaji would be reduced to a mere act of idol worship unless it represented their grim resolve to lay down their lives to fulfil the mission for which Lalaji had lived and died, the emancipation of India from bondage.
('45', 74, 6, 21, 147858) The sight of his portrait should evoke a reverence in them for the ideals for which Lalaji stood and render impossible any act unworthy of his memory.
('45', 74, 6, 22, 148009) The installation of Lalaji’s portrait in their building should thus not mean idol worship but what in Hindu ceremonial was known as prana pratishtha 2.

('45', 75, 2, 3, 148496) February 14, 1929 To own up one’s defects is the first step towards reform.
('45', 75, 2, 4, 148572) I will not therefore speak to you about the failings referred to in your address as I take it that having confessed them you will spare no effort to eradicate them.
('45', 75, 2, 5, 148737) But I will speak to you on one or two other moot questions.
('45', 75, 3, 6, 148797) He then proceeded to exhort them to stamp out the liquor habit from their midst.
('45', 75, 3, 7, 148878) They might think that moderate drinking might be allowed since it seemed to do them no harm.
('45', 75, 3, 8, 148971) But, as the Gita said, one had to shape one’s conduct not merely according to one’s own requirements but also with an eye to the effect that it would have on others.
('45', 75, 3, 9, 149137) And if they saw the terrible havoc that this fell habit was causing among the working classes of India they would take a solemn vow not to touch liquor.
('45', 75, 3, 10, 149290) He next warned them against the baneful poisonous literature from the West that was inundating the country and sought under the respectable and attractive garb of science to seduce them from the path of purity and self restraint.
('45', 75, 3, 11, 149520) Manifestos justifying self indulgence were sometimes issued over the signatures of bishops, doctors and other men of weight and influence, but they should never allow themselves to be drawn away from the strait and narrow path of virtue.
('45', 75, 3, 12, 149758) The path of self indulgence and moral indiscipline was the surest way to perdition.
('45', 75, 3, 13, 149842) He appealed to them to cultivate a snow white purity of mind and body and prayed to God that He might give them the wisdom and strength for it.

('45', 77, 1, 8, 154476) It was the one thing by which he would be remembered when everything else about him was forgotten.

('45', 78, 5, 7, 156346) 79. STATEMENT ON SIND CONGRESS AFFAIRS 1
('45', 78, 6, 8, 156387) [On or after February 15, 1929] 2
('45', 78, 7, 9, 156421) At an informal meeting of the Sind Provincial Congress members which was held at Mirpurkhas on 15th instant to consider various domestic questions, I was invited to be present.
('45', 78, 7, 10, 156598) This meeting was originally convened by Manilal Kothari in connection with certain disputes that were referred to him by the two wings of the P.C.C. for disposal and for the election of the Executive.
('45', 78, 7, 11, 156799) But, in view of the tension between the parties, I have advised them to elect Swami Govindanand as President by consent.
('45', 78, 7, 12, 156920) He has named the following as members of the Provincial Executive and the following as members of the A.I.C.C. 3
('45', 78, 8, 13, 157033) I am aware that opinion is sharply divided over the nomination of the President as well as the members of the Executive.
('45', 78, 8, 14, 157154) But I am sure that the interests of Sind will be best served by giving the above arrangement an honest trial, those aggrieved remaining passive and never obstructing the working of the provincial body.
('45', 78, 8, 15, 157356) I have advised and all the parties concerned have agreed that there should be no personal references or comments in the Sind Press controlled of influenced by the respective parties in respect of their opponents, that each party should be allowed to do its work without interference directly or indirectly by the other.
('45', 78, 8, 16, 157676) As many members were absent and as Swami Govindanand suggested that the meeting should be informal, the elections were not held.
('45', 78, 9, 17, 157805) From a photostat: S.N. 5341
('45', 78, 10, 18, 157833) 1Vide the following item and also “Sind Impressions”, February 21, 1929, sub topic “Congress Squabbles”.
('45', 78, 10, 19, 157938) 2 Gandhiji was at Mirpurkhas on February 15, 1929. 3 The names are not found in the source.
('45', 79, 0, 1, 158030) 80 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('45', 79, 1, 2, 158071) 80. LETTER TO SWAMI GOVINDANAND
('45', 79, 2, 3, 158103) MARWAR JUNCTION, February 16, 1929
('45', 79, 3, 4, 158138) DEAR SWAMI, I was sorry I was not able to have more time with you alone than I was able to have.
('45', 79, 3, 5, 158235) I would now share with you my innermost thoughts through the more imperfect medium of correspondence.
('45', 79, 3, 6, 158337) I look to you to discharge your responsibility and shed sweetness around and about you, as you have promised.
('45', 79, 3, 7, 158447) You have to stoop to conquer.
('45', 79, 3, 8, 158477) You should become a real sannyasi with out anger, without malice, without desire for self.
('45', 79, 3, 9, 158568) I was not unobservant of the fact that you had no power behind you outside the ranks of your own immediate and very limited following.
('45', 79, 3, 10, 158703) You are evidently unable to command money when you need it for public work.
('45', 79, 3, 11, 158779) All this must be altered.
('45', 79, 3, 12, 158805) You have sacrifice behind you.
('45', 79, 3, 13, 158836) You have courage.
('45', 79, 3, 14, 158854) What is it that keeps you from possessing greater influence over the people for their own good?
('45', 79, 3, 15, 158950) Why do you want office when the office does not want you?
('45', 79, 3, 16, 159008) The narrow majority by which you may be able to retain office can bring no real satisfaction, can give you no real opportunity for service.
('45', 79, 3, 17, 159148) If you will interpret office in terms of service, why will you not refuse to hold it unless your opponents too insist upon your holding it?
('45', 79, 3, 18, 159288) I have given effect as much as possible to your wishes in so far as I have been able to interpret them.
('45', 79, 3, 19, 159392) But I would like you after the election is over or even before, if you have the humility, to confer with Jairamdas and others and think of another president whom you will unanimously elect.
('45', 79, 3, 20, 159582) Anyway I look to you to run the Congress machinery in Sind smoothly and honestly.
('45', 79, 3, 21, 159664) You will not I hope misunderstand or misinterpret this letter.
('45', 79, 4, 22, 159727) Yours sincerely, [PS.] I am in Delhi between Sunday and Tuesday care Speaker Patel.
('45', 79, 4, 23, 159811) Then Sabarmati for a Week.
('45', 79, 5, 24, 159838) From a photostat: S.N. 15339

('45', 83, 1, 2, 164076) 86. PROHIBITION IN SURAT DISTRICT
('45', 83, 2, 3, 164110) Regarding the prohibition work that is going on in Surat district as a minor consequence of Bardoli Satyagraha, Smt.
('45', 83, 2, 4, 164227) Mithubehn Petit writes: 1
('45', 83, 3, 5, 164253) When Mithubehn backs up a movement, there is little fear of its fizzling out.
('45', 83, 3, 6, 164331) Hence one can hope that if the movement continues at the present rate, no trace of liquor will be left in Surat district in a very short time.
('45', 83, 3, 7, 164474) If this result does follow it may well be looked upon as a minor consequence of Bardoli, but very often minor consequences turn out to be more important than the main consequence.
('45', 83, 3, 8, 164654) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 17 2 1929
('45', 83, 4, 9, 164691) 87. FEAR OF OSTRACISM
('45', 83, 5, 10, 164713) Having read my article on child marriages, marriages of the old and ill matched marriages, a gentleman belonging to the Dasha Shrimali caste of Godhra has written a long letter, the substance 2 of which is as follows: If I had the power to remedy this situation, I would certainly use it.
('45', 83, 5, 11, 165002) But my capacity is limited.
('45', 83, 5, 12, 165030) To stop such marriages, agitations should be organized by all castes in all the villages; these should be conducted by respectable people or by those who have the capacity to win respect.
('45', 83, 5, 13, 165218) I however feel that local agitations need not necessarily be confined only to particular castes.
('45', 83, 5, 14, 165315) But it is the duty and the right of respectable men even of other castes to prevent such cruel marriages.
('45', 83, 5, 15, 165421) The belief that one caste has no right to interfere in the matters of another may be regarded as outmoded.
('45', 83, 5, 16, 165528) It is the duty of men who love justice and carry influence to prevent injustice wherever it occurs.
('45', 83, 5, 17, 165628) People need to give up the fear of ostracism.
('45', 83, 5, 18, 165674) In many cases ostracism is to be welcomed.
('45', 83, 5, 19, 165717) The Mahajan of a caste loses its stature
('45', 83, 6, 20, 165758) 1 The letter is not translated here.
('45', 83, 6, 21, 165795) The correspondent had reported that prohibition was making progress.
('45', 83, 6, 22, 165864) 2 Not translated here.
('45', 83, 6, 23, 165887) The correspondent had said that in his community many such marriages continued to take place.
('45', 84, 0, 1, 165981) VOL.45 : 4 FEBRUARY, 1929 11 MAY,1929 85
('45', 84, 1, 2, 166022) by doing injustice.
('45', 84, 1, 3, 166042) To continue to belong to such a caste is like living under an immoral regime.
('45', 84, 1, 4, 166120) One should get out of such a caste beforethe caste boycotts one.
('45', 84, 1, 5, 166185) Moreover, the elimination of sub castes is desirable in all circumstances.
('45', 84, 1, 6, 166260) And if a large number of people get out of a caste, then that caste will automatically cease to exist.
('45', 84, 1, 7, 166363) People can be happy even where there are no caste barriers, and there is no reason why this should not happen so in Hinduism.
('45', 84, 1, 8, 166489) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 17 2 1929
('45', 84, 2, 9, 166526) 88. TRIUMPH OF JUSTICE
('45', 84, 3, 10, 166549) The students and staff of Gujarat College deserve to be congratulated upon the victory scored by the former.
('45', 84, 3, 11, 166658) 1 The Director of Education also deserves congratulations for fearlessly administering justice.
('45', 84, 3, 12, 166754) Mr. Shirras 2 has done nothing to deserve congratulations.
('45', 84, 3, 13, 166813) He can earn congratulations now only if he voluntarily submits his resignation.
('45', 84, 3, 14, 166893) The teacher who has lost the affection of the pupils, one who does not keep his word, does not deserve to remain a teacher.
('45', 84, 3, 15, 167017) The main features that were to be found in the Bardoli Satyagraha were present here.
('45', 84, 3, 16, 167102) In Bardoli the demand was for justice.
('45', 84, 3, 17, 167141) Leaders of the agitation were competent men.
('45', 84, 3, 18, 167186) People obeyed rules and were determined.
('45', 84, 3, 19, 167227) The peasantry of Bardoli was able, through peaceful conduct, to win over public opinion, hence the Government finally had to bow.
('45', 84, 3, 20, 167357) All these things were true in the case of the students.
('45', 84, 3, 21, 167413) Here too, the leaders were competent, the students has faith in them.
('45', 84, 3, 22, 167483) The students were firm and their demand was just.
('45', 84, 3, 23, 167533) The students obeyed rules and, by their peaceful behaviour, were able to win over public opinion.
('45', 84, 3, 24, 167631) I hope that the students in the pride of their victory will not
('45', 84, 4, 25, 167695) 1 The students of Gujarat College had been on a prolonged strike in protest against punishment meted out to them for staying away from their classes on Simon Commission Boycott Day.
('45', 84, 4, 26, 167877) For details, vide “Duty of Resistance”, January 24, 1929 and “Notes”, January 31, 1929. 2 Principal of Gujarat College.
('45', 85, 0, 1, 167997) 86 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('45', 85, 1, 2, 168038) insult the Principal or their professors.
('45', 85, 1, 3, 168080) Anyone who wages a non violent war does not become proud of his victory and does not overstep the limits.
('45', 85, 1, 4, 168186) But, just as it is necessary for students to be polite and keep within their limits, it is necessary for them to recognize their own strength.
('45', 85, 1, 5, 168329) In spite of studying in Government colleges, they should maintain their freedom and never let their self respect be undermined.To do this, they should learn to become indifferent towards ‘degrees’.
('45', 85, 1, 6, 168527) There is no virtue in a ‘degree’.
('45', 85, 1, 7, 168561) But there is virtue in the acquisition of knowledge.
('45', 85, 1, 8, 168614) And that is worth while only so long as one’s self respect is preserved.
('45', 85, 1, 9, 168687) In this manner if they study with an attitude of detachment, they will increasingly add to their own strength.
('45', 85, 1, 10, 168798) They have proved by their prowess that no one can stop them from participating in national work.
('45', 85, 1, 11, 168895) We hope that, by accumulating such strength, they would contribute their share to the swaraj yajna.

('45', 87, 7, 10, 171518) 92. SIND IMPRESSIONS
('45', 87, 8, 11, 171539) As it is, everything in India attracts me.
('45', 87, 8, 12, 171582) It has everything that a human being with the highest possible aspirations can want.
('45', 87, 8, 13, 171667) But when I first visited Sind in 1916, it attracted me in a special way and a bond was established between the Sindhis and me that has proved capable of bearing severe strains.
('45', 87, 8, 14, 171844) I have been able to deliver to the Sindhis bitter truths without being misunderstood.
('45', 87, 8, 15, 171930) I did not mince matters anywhere during the last extensive but hurried tour in Sind.
('45', 87, 8, 16, 172015) The audiences took my remarks in good part and where it was possible, they gave immediate effect to my advice.
('45', 87, 8, 17, 172126) The warning to the Karachi students against presenting addresses in English and filling them with empty (empty because of lack of action behind it) praise had instantaneous effect.
('45', 87, 8, 18, 172307) The numerous other addresses that followed were much more subdued and were read in easy, simple and graceful Sindhi or in equally easy and graceful Hindi instead of being in high flown and bombastic English which 90 per cent of the audience could never follow.
('45', 87, 8, 19, 172568) Perfection was almost reached at the students’ meeting in Hyderabad.
('45', 87, 8, 20, 172637) The address was first composed in Sindhi and a good translation in Hindi was supplied to me.
('45', 87, 8, 21, 172730) I must deal with this separately next week.
('45', 87, 8, 22, 172774) 2 The only defect was that although it purported to come from the students they knew nothing of the contents.
('45', 87, 8, 23, 172884) There is too
('45', 87, 9, 24, 172897) 1 From the reference to the anticipated meeting on Wednesday; Monday was February 18. 2Vide “Be True”, March 14, 1929.
('45', 88, 0, 1, 173016) VOL.45 : 4 FEBRUARY, 1929 11 MAY,1929 89
('45', 88, 1, 2, 173057) much of laxity observable among us about such simple matters.
('45', 88, 1, 3, 173119) Surely addresses presented on behalf of institutions must be duly approved by them before they are presented.
('45', 88, 2, 4, 173229) LALAJI MEMORIAL
('45', 88, 3, 5, 173245) The response to the Lalaji Memorial appeal was up to my expectations and even beyond those of the ever sanguine and ever successful national beggar Manilal Kothari.
('45', 88, 3, 6, 173410) It amounts to over Rs. 70,000, much more than Sind’s quota calculated according to any of the methods mentioned by me in these pages.
('45', 88, 3, 7, 173544) If the other provinces do half as well as Sind, the amount mentioned in the Memorial appeal will be more than covered.
('45', 88, 3, 8, 173663) And this can be easily done, if those who cherish Lalaji’s memory will bestir themselves to make the collections.
('45', 88, 3, 9, 173777) Our people have not yet acquired the habit of doing their duty without persistent reminders even as we need the loud call of the temple bell to remind us that there is God watching over us and summoning us to prayer.
('45', 88, 5, 10, 173994) As in Travancore so in Sind there is unlimited scope for khadi propaganda for the simple reason that the women of Sind, young and old, do not go in for coloured saris with picturesque borders.
('45', 88, 5, 11, 174187) They wear white scarfs without borders.
('45', 88, 5, 12, 174227) If men of Sind will but do a little national propaganda among the womenfolk, they should have no difficulty in inducing them to take to khadi.
('45', 88, 5, 13, 174370) But the painful fact is that with a few honourable exceptions they are not interested in khadi.
('45', 88, 5, 14, 174466) They will not part with their foreign clothing.
('45', 88, 5, 15, 174514) The terrible poverty of the people which they do not see fails to move them.
('45', 88, 5, 16, 174591) Hence Sind is perhaps one of the most backward provinces in point of khadi.
('45', 88, 5, 17, 174667) Of production there is next to nothing.

('45', 88, 5, 21, 175191) In one collection of about ten rupees from among over a hundred men, forty pies were counted.
('45', 88, 5, 22, 175285) This phenomenon cannot be explained away by saying that the people were stingy or unwilling to give.
('45', 88, 5, 23, 175386) Stinginess I have never experienced in
('45', 89, 0, 1, 175425) 90 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('45', 89, 1, 2, 175466) A people who gave over Rs. 70,000 in twelve days could not be considered unwilling.

('45', 89, 1, 6, 175801) At the same time, I am free to confess that this khadi hawker’s evidence must be taken with a certain amount of reserve because of the fact that for years together he has lived in self imposed exile.

('45', 89, 3, 13, 176638) The courageous chairman of the Kotri Congress Committee told me at its public meeting that he had only twenty members on the Congress register and that if the Khadi franchise was to be faithfully and honestly worked, there would be probably only two members on the Congress register.

('45', 93, 1, 2, 185359) 93. A BOY OF MUCH PROMISE
('45', 93, 2, 3, 185385) I tender my humble thanks to those who have sent me telegrams and letters of condolence on hearing the news of the death of a grandson of mine.
('45', 93, 2, 4, 185529) Rasik was only seventeen years old and was from his infancy being trained to become a national servant.
('45', 93, 2, 5, 185633) He was clever, pushful and ambitious.
('45', 93, 2, 6, 185671) He was an expert carder and had gone to Delhi to help my son Devdas who is teaching spinning and Hindi at the Jamia Millia.
('45', 93, 2, 7, 185795) Hehad grown considerably in wisdom during the past few months.
('45', 93, 2, 8, 185858) Only a few days before he lay on his death bed he wrote to me to show how devoted he had become to the Ramayana and the Gita.
('45', 93, 2, 9, 185984) He had developed a fine sense of responsibility.
('45', 93, 2, 10, 186033) With the views I hold on death Rasik’s death has caused me no grief, or such grief as I have felt is purely based on selfish considerations.
('45', 93, 2, 11, 186174) I had built high hopes on getting much national service from Rasik with his body which is now no more.
('45', 93, 2, 12, 186277) But for him, he has gone because he had outgrown the use of his existing body.
('45', 93, 2, 13, 186356) And he has gone the blessed way which every one of us must tread.
('45', 93, 2, 14, 186422) His death therefore only brings me closer to God, makes me realize my responsibility more fully than before.
('45', 93, 2, 15, 186531) The thought that he died at his post fills me with joy.
('45', 93, 2, 16, 186587) His death has enabled me to come closer to the Mussalman world.
('45', 93, 2, 17, 186651) Rasik’s Mussalman comrades, I hear from Devdas, were ever kind to him.
('45', 93, 2, 18, 186722) Dr. Ansari gave him the attention not merely of a first class physician but bestowed upon him a father’s loving care.
('45', 93, 2, 19, 186840) The principal and staff of the Jamia were never failing in their attention.
('45', 93, 2, 20, 186916) My respectful thanks are due to them all, to Dr. Sharma of the Tibbia College, to the devoted nurses under whose charge the patient had been placed and to the numerous Hindu friends who helped Devdas in the task of nursing Rasik.
('45', 93, 2, 21, 187146) But for the loving and unsolicited aid given by his Hindu and Mussalman friends Devdas might easily have been broken by the strain of nursing his patient and ward whom he loved so dearly during the prolonged unconsciousness that had overtaken Rasik.
('45', 93, 2, 22, 187396) His was a death not to mourn but to envy.

('45', 103, 1, 2, 205180) ambitious ideal that did not obtain in our country probably at any time even in the past.
('45', 103, 1, 3, 205270) The cultivator had always to depend for certain necessaries of life on the middleman and it seems to me that this is just as it should be.
('45', 103, 1, 4, 205409) Interdependence is and ought to be as much the ideal of man as self sufficiency.
('45', 103, 1, 5, 205490) Man is a social being.
('45', 103, 1, 6, 205513) Without inter relation with society he cannot realize his oneness with the universe or suppress his egotism.
('45', 103, 1, 7, 205622) His social interdependence enables him to test his faith and to prove himself on the touchstone of reality.
('45', 103, 1, 8, 205730) If man were so placed or could so place himself as to be absolutely above all dependence on his fellow beings he would become so proud and arrogant as to be a veritable burden and nuisance to the world.
('45', 103, 1, 9, 205933) Dependence on society teaches him the lesson of humility.
('45', 103, 1, 10, 205991) That a man ought to be able to satisfy most of his essential needs himself is obvious; but it is no less obvious to me that when self sufficiency is carried to the length of isolating one self from society it almost amounts to sin.
('45', 103, 1, 11, 206223) A man cannot become self sufficient even in respectof all the various operations from the growing of cotton to the spinning of the yarn.
('45', 103, 1, 12, 206360) He has at some stage or other to take the aid of the members of his family.

('45', 104, 1, 2, 207937) 104. WHAT DID I DO IN DELHI?
('45', 104, 2, 3, 207966) From Sind I went to Delhi.

('45', 104, 2, 6, 208063) Naturally therefore people are anxious to know what happened there.
('45', 104, 2, 7, 208131) However, if people were truly self reliant, they would have no such curiosity.
('45', 104, 2, 8, 208210) What if I met the Viceroy?
('45', 104, 2, 9, 208237) But as a nation, we have been unable to cultivate such indifference.
('45', 104, 2, 10, 208306) We are still awed by the grandeur of British rule.
('45', 104, 2, 11, 208357) As long as this is so, we shall continue to be inquisitive about the Viceroy’s activities, his utterances, and what persons who have met him have seen and heard.
('45', 104, 2, 12, 208519) So I should satisfy this curiosity in some measure.
('45', 104, 2, 13, 208571) When I went to Delhi, I did not have the slightest inkling of Vithalbhai’s scheme.
('45', 104, 2, 14, 208654) Motilalji invited me to Delhi in connection with the boycott of foreign cloth and the meeting of the Congress Working Committee was postponed.
('45', 104, 2, 15, 208797) Putting up with the inconvenience, I wired to Motilalji that I would be in Delhi from the 17th to the 19th.
('45', 104, 2, 16, 208905) On reaching Delhi I came to know of Vithalbhai’s scheme.

('45', 104, 2, 19, 209189) He does not let go a single opportunity to display his independence, his fearlessness and his patriotism and in spite of this he maintains the impartiality and self restraint befitting his position.
('45', 104, 2, 20, 209388) He believes that even if he could do nothing else it would be enough if he could bring together the leaders holding different views and it would be even better if he could bring them in touch with the Viceroy.
('45', 104, 2, 21, 209598) So he took advantage of my visit to Delhi and invited His Excellency the Viceroy and some leaders to tea.

('45', 106, 1, 27, 215605) But the work in Delhi does not end with the two important resolutions already mentioned.

('45', 107, 0, 1, 215746) 108 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('45', 107, 1, 2, 215788) had with Mr. Jinnah and others on the Hindu Muslim question.
('45', 107, 1, 3, 215849) I cannot of course point to any immediate result of these discussions.
('45', 107, 1, 4, 215920) However, it is my firm belief that such efforts can never be in vain.
('45', 107, 1, 5, 215990) This was the reason behind Motilalji’s calling me to Delhi.
('45', 107, 1, 6, 216050) It is necessary to inform the readers that these efforts were limited in scope.
('45', 107, 1, 7, 216130) They were within the framework of the Nehru Report.
('45', 107, 1, 8, 216182) We discussed fully how to meet with the complaints of Muslims with regard to the Nehru Report.
('45', 107, 1, 9, 216277) We came to the conclusions that although changes may be made in it, with the approval of the people when the time comes, for the present and for this year this Report should, from the people’s point of view, be considered a final and definite demand and wherever it is accepted it should be done unconditionally.
('45', 107, 1, 10, 216590) Then alone can the consolidationof the people’s strength be achieved through the Report.
('45', 107, 1, 11, 216679) It can never be achieved through something regarding which no determined public opinion has been created.
('45', 107, 1, 12, 216785) The rule applies to all types of struggles.
('45', 107, 1, 13, 216829) But it is indispensable for satyagraha, that is, non co operation.
('45', 107, 1, 14, 216896) Satyagraha strengthens and is possible only over an issue on which a definite opinion has been formed.
('45', 107, 1, 15, 216999) How can we insist on truth regarding something which can be varied at will?
('45', 107, 1, 16, 217075) For anything which is variable a potent weapon like satyagraha which is constant for all time cannot be used.
('45', 107, 1, 17, 217185) That is its beauty and also its limitation.
('45', 107, 1, 18, 217229) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 24 2 1929
('45', 107, 2, 19, 217266) 105. SUNSET AT MORNING
('45', 107, 3, 20, 217289) There have been letters and telegrams of condolence on the death of my grandson Rasik.
('45', 107, 3, 21, 217376) Instead of replying individually I have thought it proper to express my gratitude to all of them through Young India and Navajivan.
('45', 107, 3, 22, 217508) Those who have sent messages will forgive me for not being able to reply to them individually.
('45', 107, 3, 23, 217603) It was not my intention to notice this death, but as the news appeared in the newspapers and people have written to me, it seems proper for me to take some note of it.
('45', 107, 3, 24, 217771) As for me, the death of friends and relatives does not hurt as much as it used to.
('45', 107, 3, 25, 217854) All religious forbid fear of death or grief over death.
('45', 107, 3, 26, 217910) Yet we are afraid of death and grieve over the death of a dear one.
('45', 107, 3, 27, 217978) And if someone dies in the prime of youth, there is greater grief.
('45', 107, 3, 28, 218045) Truly speaking, death is God’s eternal blessing.
('45', 107, 3, 29, 218094) The body which is
('45', 108, 0, 1, 218112) VOL.45 : 4 FEBRUARY, 1929 11 MAY,1929 109
('45', 108, 1, 2, 218154) used up falls and the bird within flies away.
('45', 108, 1, 3, 218200) So long as the bird does not die, the question of grief does not arise.
('45', 108, 1, 4, 218272) When despite this there is grief on the death of a relative, it only shows our selfishness and delusion.
('45', 108, 1, 5, 218377) For the past many years, I have been trying to rid myself of this delusion.
('45', 108, 1, 6, 218453) Hence the shock on hearing news of Rasik’s death was not severe.
('45', 108, 1, 7, 218518) What shock there was, was due to selfishness.
('45', 108, 1, 8, 218564) Rasik was seventeen years of age.
('45', 108, 1, 9, 218598) He had been under my care from childhood and, like other boys, he was being given training in national service.
('45', 108, 1, 10, 218710) He was an active, clever and bright boy.
('45', 108, 1, 11, 218751) He was sturdy and brave.
('45', 108, 1, 12, 218776) He was always first in taking up work that called for courage.
('45', 108, 1, 13, 218839) During the past one year his boisterousness was turning into strength.
('45', 108, 1, 14, 218910) He was a student of the Gita.
('45', 108, 1, 15, 218940) He was an expert carder and spinner.
('45', 108, 1, 16, 218977) Once or twice he took to spinning continuously for twenty four hours—and did it successfully.
('45', 108, 1, 17, 219071) My youngest son Devdas is working at the Jamia Millia in Delhi.
('45', 108, 1, 18, 219135) He teaches spinning and Hindi to the students there.
('45', 108, 1, 19, 219188) About four months back, he had asked for the services of Rasik and another grandson of mine, Navin, to teach carpentry and weaving.
('45', 108, 1, 20, 219320) Both Rasik and Navin had gone to Delhi and were doing good work there.
('45', 108, 1, 21, 219391) Earlier, because of his keen desire to serve, Rasik had gone to Bardoli.
('45', 108, 1, 22, 219464) He became popular wherever he went.
('45', 108, 1, 23, 219500) The selfish thought that providence took away such a promising worker made me grieve; but then I thought that Providence is always just and is therefore kind and it would get work out of Rasik.
('45', 108, 1, 24, 219694) By this faith I have been consoled.
('45', 108, 1, 25, 219730) After going to Delhi, Rasik turned a devotee.
('45', 108, 1, 26, 219776) When I was on my way back via Delhi after the Congress session, Rasik had told me that he had entered his seventeenth year.
('45', 108, 1, 27, 219900) At that time, like many other boys, he took certain vows: first to eat only three things at a meal; secondly, to have only three meals a day, and thirdly, to complete within two years the study of the Ramayana with commentary.
('45', 108, 1, 28, 220127) Knowing his restless temperament, I had warned him.
('45', 108, 1, 29, 220179) But he told me that he found nothing difficult in this and that he liked to read the Ramayana.
('45', 108, 1, 30, 220274) I was pleased.
('45', 108, 1, 31, 220289) With reference to these vows, Rasik wrote to me the following letter 1, on the 18th of January.
('45', 108, 1, 32, 220385) On the 8th of February he passed away.
('45', 108, 1, 33, 220424) Very few get the care that Rasik received.
('45', 108, 1, 34, 220467) He was a dear nephew and student of Devdas and had received his matchless service.
('45', 108, 1, 35, 220550) Dr. Ansari was not merely his physician; he was like a father to him.
('45', 108, 1, 36, 220620) Dr. Sharma was always at his beck and call.
('45', 108, 1, 37, 220664) Two nurses were appointed by
('45', 108, 2, 38, 220693) 1 Not translated here.
('45', 109, 0, 1, 220716) 110 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('45', 109, 1, 2, 220758) the doctors to nurse him.
('45', 109, 1, 3, 220784) Muslim friends from the Jamia left nothing to be desired so far as nursing him was concerned.
('45', 109, 1, 4, 220878) The Hindus who learnt of his illness were at his service, day and night.
('45', 109, 1, 5, 220951) I am indebted to all of them.
('45', 109, 1, 6, 220981) Rasik had realized at such an early age the value of service and duty and engrossed himself in it; taken difficult vows, regarded them as easy to fulfil and read the Gita with enthusiasm having vowed tofinish study of the Ramayana in two years’ time.
('45', 109, 1, 7, 221232) He met deathwhile cherishing such noble sentiments and receiving unsurpassed care.

('45', 126, 5, 13, 248257) 129. A MARVELLOUS FASTING CURE
('45', 126, 6, 14, 248288) As I had and still have no desire to turn Young India into a herald of health, not because it would be wrong to do so, but because I have neither the time nor the qualifications for the task and because I undertook the charge of Young India in the interest of the movement for India’s freedom, I have hesitated, for the four weeks that the report 1 referred to by K. G. D. has been on my file, to give it publicity.
('45', 126, 6, 15, 248704) I have twice read the report and it reads so true and is so well written that I can no longer resist K.G.D.’s appeal.
('45', 126, 6, 16, 248822) As the reader is aware I believe in fasting both for its spiritual and its medicinal value.
('45', 126, 6, 17, 248914) I daily advise it at the Udyoga Mandir and almost invariably with beneficial results.
('45', 126, 6, 18, 249000) I know that if the medical profession courageously popularized fasting among their patients, there would be infinitely less suffering than there is now and that many would be saved who now die through the drug and the feeding treatment.
('45', 126, 6, 19, 249237) I therefore gladly find room for K.G.D.’s accurately drawn report of his wife’s case.
('45', 126, 6, 20, 249323) I must however warn others interested in fasting and kindred experiments against hoping that their reports too would find room in Young India if they sent them.
('45', 126, 6, 21, 249484) They are at liberty however to send authentic reports for my private information and guidance.

('45', 127, 0, 1, 249633) 128 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('45', 127, 1, 2, 249675) 130. THE DELHI VISIT
('45', 127, 2, 3, 249696) I have dealt with the Speaker’s party elsewhere 1 but I would like to enlist the reader’s serious attention for the business that took me to Delhi.
('45', 127, 2, 4, 249844) The Working Committee needed my presence for understanding my scheme of boycott of foreign cloth before passing it.
('45', 127, 2, 5, 249960) The Committee was in earnest about it.
('45', 127, 2, 6, 249999) I had therefore to interrupt my programme after Sind and go to Delhi at Pandit Motilalji’s call.
('45', 127, 2, 7, 250096) The Working Committee discussed it at great length and finally accepted the scheme without any material alteration.
('45', 127, 2, 8, 250212) A special committee has been formed to give effect to the scheme.
('45', 127, 2, 9, 250278) Not without much hesitation have I shouldered the burden of beingits chairman.
('45', 127, 2, 10, 250357) My hesitation was due to the feeling that those who could, if they meant, bring about the boycott would not respond and that probably they did not believe in khadi.
('45', 127, 2, 11, 250522) But I saw too that I had no business to refuse to shoulder the responsibility, merely because of a feeling which after all might have no foundation in fact.
('45', 127, 2, 12, 250679) Mine was but to try.
('45', 127, 2, 13, 250700) The scheme is now before the country.
('45', 127, 2, 14, 250738) The Committee will try to bring it home to everyone it can reach.
('45', 127, 2, 15, 250804) But meanwhile it is so incredibly simple that everyone can enforce it in his or her own person.
('45', 127, 2, 16, 250900) Let everyone who has any foreign cloth in his or her possession discard it and replace it by genuine khadi.
('45', 127, 2, 17, 251008) Too much stress cannot be put upon the adjective genuine.
('45', 127, 2, 18, 251066) The scheme therefore provides that no khadi should be considered genuine unless it is certified by the All India Spinners’ Association.
('45', 127, 2, 19, 251202) This is easily done by merely buying from depots certified by the All India Spinners’ Association or from trustworthy persons.
('45', 127, 2, 20, 251329) Let no one belittle his or her own individual effort.
('45', 127, 2, 21, 251383) Complete boycott means an aggregate of individual effort.
('45', 127, 2, 22, 251441) Every yard of foreign cloth given up brings the boycott nearer, every yard of khadi bought relieves some distress.
('45', 127, 2, 23, 251556) Even as constant dropping wears away stones so will constant and continuing boycott of foreign cloth stop the greatest drain from India and bring about all the inevitable implications of such boycott.
('45', 127, 2, 24, 251757) It is therefore sinful to sit still and do nothing on the plea of futility of individual action and wait for a call from a committee or for action on a national scale.
('45', 127, 2, 25, 251925) It is the individual effort that will have precipitated the
('45', 127, 3, 26, 251985) 1Vide “Notes”, February 28, 1929.
('45', 128, 0, 1, 252019) VOL.45 : 4 FEBRUARY, 1929 11 MAY,1929 129
('45', 128, 1, 2, 252061) national response whenever it comes.
('45', 128, 1, 3, 252098) Pandit Malaviyaji’s resolution too deserves the earnest attention of every national organization and national worker.
('45', 128, 1, 4, 252216) It seeks to rivet the nation’s attention on the Nehru Report on the 10th March which is a Sunday.
('45', 128, 1, 5, 252314) During this year of grace that Report is the national war cry.
('45', 128, 1, 6, 252377) The swaraj of our coining is to be found in the Nehru Report.
('45', 128, 1, 7, 252439) Self respect demands that we should work for the attainment of swaraj as defined in it.

('45', 128, 1, 9, 252698) But it may be asked what is the use of harping on the Nehru Report when many Mussalmans and many Sikhs are intensely dissatisfied with it?
('45', 128, 1, 10, 252837) My answer is: no document has received so much support as this and no other is likely to receive greater support.
('45', 128, 1, 11, 252951) And when I say that we should concentrate upon securing approval of the Report, I do not exclude the possibility of alterations in it.
('45', 128, 1, 12, 253086) What I however exclude is the possibility of alterations in it at the point of the bayonet.
('45', 128, 1, 13, 253178) Alterations will be and must be made wherever justice demands it.
('45', 128, 1, 14, 253244) It was for that reason that the Convention instead of being wound up was adjourned sine die.
('45', 128, 1, 15, 253337) And these alterations should be made not now but when the Report has gained weight enough to compel acceptance, and when it has arrived at that stage it may not be delivered for acceptance without such alterations as may be absolutely necessary and as may be agreed upon by mutual consent.
('45', 128, 1, 16, 253627) Subject to this reservation, I submit that the Nehru Report should be presented at all public meetings for unconditional acceptance without mental reservations.
('45', 128, 1, 17, 253788) After all that Report is the result of much labour and in the nature of an award delivered by arbitrators.
('45', 128, 1, 18, 253895) No party may lightly repudiate it.
('45', 128, 1, 19, 253930) I therefore whole heartedly support the proposal that the Nehru Scheme be the subject or resolutions all over the country on the 10th proximo.
('45', 128, 1, 20, 254073) The other parts of Malaviyaji’s resolution follow as a matter of course.
('45', 128, 1, 21, 254146) The other parts expect the nation to concentrate on particular Sundays during every month on particular items of constructive programme.
('45', 128, 1, 22, 254283) It does not mean that on week days we should go to sleep; but it means that on the Sundays in question we should concentrate more fully than on week days on the matters for which those Sundays may be specifically reserved.
('45', 128, 1, 23, 254506) The Congress has
('45', 129, 0, 1, 254523) 130 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('45', 129, 1, 2, 254565) seriously devised the constructive programme as a sanction behind the Nehru Report.
('45', 129, 1, 3, 254649) It behoves us therefore to give full effect to the Congress programme which Malaviyaji’s resolution seeks to do in part.

('45', 129, 2, 5, 254793) 131. TO THE BURMA CONGRESS COMMITTEE
('45', 129, 3, 6, 254830) The Congress Working Committee has asked me in terms of its resolution to have the finances of the Burma Congress Committee audited and to do the inspection myself.
('45', 129, 3, 7, 254995) I invite the Committee therefore to keep its accounts ready and have them audited by an auditor of standing and to have its register and everything else in order at the time of my arrival in Burma, so that I might carry on my work without any loss of time.
('45', 129, 3, 8, 255252) What would be required is a register containing the names of original members with their addresses, occupations and the amounts received fromthem, a digest of work done by the Committee, first in respect of Congress resolutions, secondly of the work done for the Congress, a register of volunteers, the amount of donations received in the Committee’s office, description of the office staff, dispatch book and a note upon the working of the khadi rule in the Congress constitution.

('45', 129, 6, 16, 256204) The change from 1920 to now is no doubt great in spite of the so called set back since 1922 but it is not yet great enough to inspire us with self confidence.
('45', 129, 6, 17, 256363) The want of it is the greatest stumbling block in our progress towards our goal.

('45', 130, 1, 4, 256812) But there cannot be much breaking of ice at a private, informal tea party.

('45', 132, 2, 7, 262002) 133. NEED FOR IMMEDIATE RELIEF
('45', 132, 3, 8, 262033) Chakravarti Rajagopalachari is a busy man.
('45', 132, 3, 9, 262076) He is now touring all through the South with Sheth Jamnalalji in the interest of Hindi propaganda.
('45', 132, 3, 10, 262175) That accounts for his sending me the following telegram instead of sending a letter which might easily have been sent but for his touring.
('45', 132, 3, 11, 262314) Here is the telegram: 1
('45', 132, 4, 12, 262338) In response to appeals in Young India in October and December last the Pudupalayam Gandhi Ashram has so far received over Rs. 769. Of this Rs. 225 were received by us direct and Rs. 544 through the Sabarmati Ashram.
('45', 132, 4, 13, 262554) We have restricted our relief work to Adi Dravidas of five villages within a mile of the Ashram.
('45', 132, 4, 14, 262651) A card is given to each family entitling them to buy at concession prices from the Ashram every Saturday not more than five measures of jovari per adult and half this quantity for children below twelve.
('45', 132, 4, 15, 262854) So far 108 families with 344 adults and 179 children have been registered and are receiving relief as above from 2nd February, 1929. .
('45', 132, 4, 16, 262989) Even then the cost of relief will be Rs. 1,312 of which we have received only Rs. 769. But there are other villages near the Ashram whose Adi Dravida population is in a pitiable condition and is clamouring for relief.
('45', 132, 4, 17, 263207) Large numbers are emigrating.
('45', 132, 4, 18, 263237) But very poor and old persons, especially women and children, have not even this escape out of an intolerable situation.
('45', 132, 4, 19, 263358) We would very much like to give them food free.
('45', 132, 4, 20, 263406) But our funds are limited.
('45', 132, 4, 21, 263433) We need at least Rs. 5,000 more to do work fairly satisfactorily.
('45', 132, 4, 22, 263499) The call is very urgent.
('45', 132, 4, 23, 263524) This telegram hardly needs any supplementing.
('45', 132, 4, 24, 263570) A Latin proverb says: bis dat qui cito dat.
('45', 132, 4, 25, 263614) He gives twice who gives soon.
('45', 132, 4, 26, 263645) This is a case in point.
('45', 132, 4, 27, 263670) Donors have been sending money in driblets for which he and I are duly thankful.
('45', 132, 4, 28, 263751) But meanwhile the famine stricken people are starving.
('45', 132, 4, 29, 263806) Instead of reporting that they are starving Rajagopalachari

('45', 136, 1, 2, 267516) 141. SPEECH AT UNVEILING OF TILAK STATUE, AHMEDABAD
('45', 136, 2, 3, 267568) February 28, 1929
('45', 136, 3, 4, 267586) It is clear beyond doubt that after Vallabhbhai’s entering the Municipality, it too has become courageous, and I compliment it for the courage it has shown in installing the statue of the Lokamanya.
('45', 136, 3, 5, 267785) There was a time, only a few years ago, when such acts were considered impertinent, because, formerly, if any library displayed a photograph of the Lokamanya, the Government either compelled the library to remove it or stopped any assistance given to it.
('45', 136, 3, 6, 268040) But now times have changed, which is a matter for rejoicing.
('45', 136, 3, 7, 268101) The late Lokamanya Tilak had sacrificed all his energies for the cause of Swaraj.
('45', 136, 3, 8, 268183) Only one who is ready to lay down his life for swaraj and is capable of winning swaraj for us within a short time can perform the ceremony of unveiling Tilak’s statue.
('45', 136, 3, 9, 268351) Today you have all joined me in performing this ceremony; so, it is your duty too to prepare yourselves to win that swaraj for which the Lokamanya sacrificed his life.
('45', 136, 3, 10, 268519) That being the directive of the Congress also, it is the duty of everyone to prepare himself for it.
('45', 136, 3, 11, 268620) Though, at the moment, the political sky of India is clear, one cannot predict when clouds will gather.
('45', 136, 3, 12, 268724) The Municipality should display, even in difficult times, the same courage that it has shown today in having this statue unveiled and in hoisting the national flag.
('45', 136, 3, 13, 268889) Formerly the very mention of the word ‘swaraj’ was considered an act of high treason.
('45', 136, 3, 14, 268975) The mantra of Swadeshi and swaraj which the Lokamanya breathed into our ears even during such difficult times should find a place first in our minds and then in our hearts.
('45', 136, 3, 15, 269148) We should be ready to lay down our lives for it.
('45', 136, 3, 16, 269197) The other great quality of the Lokamanya was his simplicity.
('45', 136, 3, 17, 269258) Although he could collect funds running into lakhs yet he was extremely economical and simple in matters of food and clothing.
('45', 136, 3, 18, 269385) Our country is very poor compared to rich countries such as England and America.
('45', 136, 3, 19, 269466) Here the average daily income of a person is just seven pice.
('45', 136, 3, 20, 269528) If we exclude from consideration millionaires like Seth Lalbhai and Seth Ambalal, we shall immediately get an idea of the wretched
('45', 137, 0, 1, 269659) 138 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('45', 137, 1, 2, 269701) condition of ordinary people.
('45', 137, 1, 3, 269731) Hence, everyone should be simple and economical in food, clothing, and so on, and should encourage swadeshi.

('45', 138, 3, 11, 272670) There is a great thought behind it.
('45', 138, 3, 12, 272706) It is a confluence of three currents, and the three colours express the hope that all communities would live in harmony, and bestow this blessing upon all; the spinning wheel in the centre suggests that we all have to seek its assistance.

('45', 138, 3, 14, 273199) Today, in India, some people hold that Hindus and Muslims will never get on well together, that these incompatibles can never be on good terms now or in the future, that independence here could either be for the Hindus or for the Muslims.

('45', 141, 4, 13, 278334) 147. INTERVIEW TO DR.
('45', 141, 4, 14, 278356) JOHN MOTT 1
('45', 141, 5, 15, 278368) [Before March 1, 1929] 2
('45', 141, 6, 16, 278393) MOTT:] What do you consider to be the most valuable contribution that India can make to the progress of the world?
('45', 141, 6, 17, 278508) [GANDHIJI:] Non violence, which the country is exhibiting at the present day on a scale unprecedented in history.
('45', 141, 6, 18, 278622) But for it, there might have been a blaze, for provocation of the gravest kind has not been wanting on the side of the Government.
('45', 141, 6, 19, 278753) There is no doubt a school in the country that believes in violence, but it is a mere excrescence on the surface and its ideals are not likely to find a congenial soil in the country.
('45', 141, 7, 20, 278937) 1 Based on the report by Pyarelal 2 The date of the interview, which appears to have taken place at the Ashram on a Monday, is not ascertainable.
('45', 142, 0, 1, 279083) VOL.45 : 4 FEBRUARY, 1929 11 MAY, 1929 143
('45', 142, 1, 2, 279126) What causes you solicitude for the future of the country?
('45', 142, 1, 3, 279184) Our apathy and hardness of heart, if I may use that Biblical phrase, as typified in the attitude towards the masses and their poverty.
('45', 142, 1, 4, 279319) Our youth are full of noble feelings and impulses but these have not yet taken any definite practical shape.
('45', 142, 1, 5, 279428) If our youth had a living and active faith in truth and non violence, for instance, we should have made much greater headway by now.
('45', 142, 1, 6, 279561) All our young men, however, are not apathetic.
('45', 142, 1, 7, 279608) In fact without the closest co operation of some of our educated young men and women, I should not have been able to establish contact with the masses and to serve them on a nationwide scale; and I am sustained by the hope that they will act as the leaven, and in time transform the entire mass.
('45', 142, 2, 8, 279904) From this they passed on to the distinctive contributions of Hinduism, Islam and Christianity to the upbuilding of the Indian nation.
('45', 142, 2, 9, 280038) The most distinctive and the largest contribution of Hinduism to India’s culture is the doctrine of ahimsa.
('45', 142, 2, 10, 280146) It has given a definite bias to the history of the country for the last three thousand years and over and it has not ceased to be a living force in the lives of India’s millions even today.
('45', 142, 2, 11, 280336) It is a growing doctrine, its message is still being delivered.
('45', 142, 2, 12, 280400) Its teaching has so far permeated our people that an armed revolution has almost become an impossibility in India, not because, as some would have it, we as a race are physically weak, for it does not require much physical strength so much as a devilish will to press a trigger to shoot a person, but because the tradition of ahimsa has struck deep roots among the people.
('45', 142, 2, 13, 280773) Islam’s distinctive contribution to India’s national culture is its unadulterated belief in the oneness of God and a practical application of the truth of the brotherhood of man for those who are nominally within its fold.
('45', 142, 2, 14, 280996) I call these two distinctive contributions.
('45', 142, 2, 15, 281040) For in Hinduism the spirit of brotherhood has become too much philos ophized.
('45', 142, 2, 16, 281118) Similarly though philosophical Hinduism has no other god but God, it cannot be denied that practical Hinduism is not so emphatically uncompromising as Islam.
('45', 142, 3, 17, 281276) What then is the contribution of Christianity to the national life of India?
('45', 142, 3, 18, 281353) I mean the influence of Christ as a part from Christianity, for I am afraid there is a wide gulf separating the two at present.
('45', 142, 3, 19, 281481) Aye,there’s the rub.
('45', 142, 3, 20, 281502) It is not possible to consider the teaching of a religious teacher apart from the lives of his followers.
('45', 142, 3, 21, 281608) Unfortunately,
('45', 143, 0, 1, 281623) 144 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('45', 143, 1, 2, 281665) Christianity in India has been inextricably mixed up for the last one hundred and fifty years with the British rule.
('45', 143, 1, 3, 281782) It appears to us as synonymous with materialistic civilization and imperialistic exploi tation by the stronger white races of the weaker races of the world.
('45', 143, 1, 4, 281939) Its contribution to India has been therefore largely of a negative character.
('45', 143, 1, 5, 282017) It has done some good in spite of its professors.
('45', 143, 1, 6, 282067) It has shocked us into setting our won house in order.
('45', 143, 1, 7, 282122) Christian missionary literature has drawn pointed attention to some of our abuses and set us a thinking.
('45', 143, 2, 8, 282227) What has interested me most is your work in connection with the removal of untouchability.
('45', 143, 2, 9, 282318) Will you please tell me what is the most hopeful sign indicating that this institution is as you say on its last legs?
('45', 143, 2, 10, 282437) It is the reaction that is taking place in orthodox Hinduism and the swiftness with which it has come about.
('45', 143, 2, 11, 282546) As a most illustrious example I will mention Pandit Malaviyaji.
('45', 143, 2, 12, 282610) Ten years back he was as punctilious in the observance of the rules with regard to untouchability as perhaps the most orthodox Hindu of that day.
('45', 143, 2, 13, 282756) Today he takes pride in administering the mantra of purification to the untouchables by the bank of the Ganges, sometimes even incurring the wrath of unreasoning orthodoxy.
('45', 143, 2, 14, 282929) He was all but assaulted by the diehard section in Calcutta in December last for doing this very thing.
('45', 143, 2, 15, 283033) In Wardha a wealthy merchant Sheth Jamnalal Bajaj recently threw open his magnificent temple to the untouchables and that without arousing any serious opposition.
('45', 143, 2, 16, 283196) The most remarkable thing about it is that from the record kept in the temple of the daily visitors it was found that the attendance had gone up instead of declining since the admission of the untouchables to it.
('45', 143, 2, 17, 283409) I may sum up the outlook by saying that I expect the tide against untouchability to rise still more swiftly in the near future, astonishingly swift as it has already been.
('45', 143, 3, 18, 283581) Where do you find your friends?
('45', 143, 3, 19, 283613) Do your get the backing of the Mussalmans and the Christians in this work?
('45', 143, 3, 20, 283688) The Mussalmans and the Christians can from the very nature of the case render little help in this matter.
('45', 143, 3, 21, 283794) The removal of untouch ability is purely a question of the purification of Hinduism.
('45', 143, 3, 22, 283879) This can only be effected from within.
('45', 143, 4, 23, 283918) But my impression was that Christians would be a great help to you in this connection.
('45', 143, 4, 24, 284005) The Rev.
('45', 143, 4, 25, 284014) Whitehead, Bishop of the Church of England Mission, made
('45', 144, 0, 1, 284071) VOL.45 : 4 FEBRUARY, 1929 11 MAY, 1929 145
('45', 144, 1, 2, 284114) some striking statements about the effect of Christian mass movement in ameliorating the condition of the untouchables in the Madras Presidency.
('45', 144, 1, 3, 284259) I distrust mass movements of this nature.
('45', 144, 1, 4, 284301) They have as their object not the upliftment of the untouchables but their ultimate conversion.
('45', 144, 1, 5, 284397) This motive of mass proselytization lurking at the back in my opinion vitiates missionary effort.
('45', 144, 2, 6, 284495) There are conflicting opinions on this point .
('45', 144, 2, 7, 284542) There are some who seriously believe that the untouchables would be better off if they turned Christians from conviction, and that it would transform their lives for the better.
('45', 144, 2, 8, 284720) I am sorry I have been unable to discover any tangible evidence to confirm this view.
('45', 144, 2, 9, 284806) I was once taken to a Christian village.
('45', 144, 2, 10, 284847) Instead of meeting among the converts with that frankness which one associates with a spiritual transformation, I found an air of evasiveness about them.
('45', 144, 2, 11, 285001) They were afraid to talk.
('45', 144, 2, 12, 285027) This struck me as a change not for the better but for the worse.
('45', 144, 3, 13, 285092) Do you then disbelieve in all conversion?
('45', 144, 3, 14, 285134) I disbelieve in the conversion of one person by another.
('45', 144, 3, 15, 285191) My effort should never be to undermine another’s faith but to make him a better follower of his own faith.
('45', 144, 3, 16, 285298) This implies belief in the truth of all religions and therefore respect for them.
('45', 144, 3, 17, 285380) It again implies true humility, a recognition of the fact that the divine light having been vouchsafed to all religions through an imperfect medium of flesh, they must share in more or less degree the imperfection of the vehicle.
('45', 144, 4, 18, 285610) Is it not our duty to help our fellow beings to the maximum of truth that we may possess, to share with them our deepest spiritual experiences?
('45', 144, 4, 19, 285754) I am sorry I must again differ from you, for the simple reason that the deepest spiritual truths are always unutterable.
('45', 144, 4, 20, 285875) That light to which you refer transcends speech.
('45', 144, 4, 21, 285924) It can be felt only through the inner experience.
('45', 144, 4, 22, 285974) And then the highest truth needs no commu nicating, for it is by its very nature self propelling.
('45', 144, 4, 23, 286072) It radiates its influence silently as the rose its fragrance without the intervention of medium.
('45', 144, 5, 24, 286169) But even God sometimes speaks through His prophets.
('45', 144, 5, 25, 286221) Yes, but the prophets speak not through the tongue but through their lives.
('45', 144, 5, 26, 286297) I have however known that in this matter I am up against a solid wall of Christian opinion.
('45', 144, 6, 27, 286389) Oh, no, even among Christians there is a school of thought and it is growing—which holds that the authoritarian method should not be employed but that
('45', 145, 0, 1, 286540) 146 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('45', 145, 1, 2, 286582) each individual should be left to discover the deepest truths of life for himself.
('45', 145, 1, 3, 286665) The argument advanced is that the process of spiritual discovery is bound to vary in the case of different individuals according to their varying needs and temperaments.
('45', 145, 1, 4, 286835) In other words they feel that propaganda in the accepted sense of the term is not the most effective method.
('45', 145, 1, 5, 286944) I am glad to hear you say this.
('45', 145, 1, 6, 286976) That is what Hinduism certainly inculcates.
('45', 145, 2, 7, 287020) What counsel do you give to the young men who are fighting a losing battle with their lower selves and come to you for advice?
('45', 145, 2, 8, 287147) Simply prayer.
('45', 145, 2, 9, 287162) One must humble oneself utterly and look beyond oneself for strength.
('45', 145, 3, 10, 287232) But what if the young men complain that their prayer is not heard, that they feel like speaking to brass heavens as it were?
('45', 145, 3, 11, 287357) To want an answer to one’s prayer is to tempt God.
('45', 145, 3, 12, 287408) If prayer fails to bring relief it is only lip prayer.
('45', 145, 3, 13, 287463) If prayer does not help nothing else will.
('45', 145, 3, 14, 287506) One must go on ceaselessly.
('45', 145, 3, 15, 287534) This then is my message to the youth.
('45', 145, 3, 16, 287572) In spite of themselves the youth must believe in the all conquering power of love and truth.
('45', 145, 4, 17, 287665) The difficulty with our youth is that the study of science and modern philosophy has demolished their faith and so they are burnt up by the fire of disbelief.
('45', 145, 4, 18, 287824) That is due to the fact that with them faith is an effort of the intellect, not an experience of the soul.
('45', 145, 4, 19, 287931) Intellect takes us along in the battle of life to a certain limit but at the crucial moment it fails us.
('45', 145, 4, 20, 288036) Faith transcends reason.
('45', 145, 4, 21, 288061) It is when the horizon is the darkest and human reason is beaten down to the ground that faith shines brightest and comes to our rescue.
('45', 145, 4, 22, 288198) It is such faith that our youth require and this comes when one has shed all pride of intellect and surrendered oneself entirely to His will.
('45', 145, 5, 23, 288340) Young India, 21 3 1929
('45', 146, 0, 1, 288363) VOL.45 : 4 FEBRUARY, 1929 11 MAY, 1929 147
('45', 146, 1, 2, 288406) 148. INTERVIEWS TO FOREIGN VISITORS 1
('45', 146, 2, 3, 288444) [Before March 1, 1929] 2
('45', 146, 3, 4, 288469) The first was with a British labour Imperialist.
('45', 146, 3, 5, 288518) This fair visitor began apologetically, “Of course you would like us to clear out of the country altogether.”
('45', 146, 4, 6, 288628) GANDHIJI: No, on the contrary I should like to keep the English here, but on our terms—not as lords and masters but as true servants of the people.
('45', 146, 4, 7, 288776) In a free India the English shall have to be content with an equal status with the sons of the soil which means that they must renounce the special privileges which they at present enjoy as members of the ruling race.

('45', 153, 2, 9, 305002) 153. WHAT DOES ‘CONSTANT WEARER’ MEAN?
('45', 153, 3, 10, 305041) Everywhere there is a desire, more or less, to put into practice the Congress resolution on the constructive programme.
('45', 153, 3, 11, 305161) That there is more of it in Gujarat is not surprising.
('45', 153, 3, 12, 305216) This being the case, it is understandable that the workers seek clarification of the clause regarding the wearing of khadi.
('45', 153, 3, 13, 305340) According to the constitution of the Congress, one has a right to become its member even if one does not wear khadi, and one cannot be prevented from becoming a member.
('45', 153, 3, 14, 305509) But a member thus enrolled cannot take part in the working of the Congress, its committee or subcommittees, nor can he speak, vote at or contest the elections of any of its committees, if he is not ‘a constant wearer of khadi’.
('45', 153, 3, 15, 305737) Therefore, as a result of the khadi clause, one who is not a constant wearer cannot enjoy any of the rights of the Congress and is debarred from rendering certain kinds of service; for instance, he cannot become a volunteer.
('45', 153, 3, 16, 305962) In fact all privileges enjoyed by Congressmen should be and must be in the form of service to be rendered by them.
('45', 153, 3, 17, 306077) Since I deduce this meaning, it is necessary to explain the meaning of the phrase ‘constant wearer of khadi’.
('45', 153, 3, 18, 306187) If we literally translate the equivalent English word, it means one who habitually wears khadi.
('45', 153, 3, 19, 306283) But anyone who is a habitual wearer is a constant wearer.
('45', 153, 3, 20, 306341) If the clothes of a constant wearer are stolen and he is unable to obtain khadi immediately, he will wear whatever clothes he can get for the time being, and will obtain khadi at the first opportunity.
('45', 153, 3, 21, 306543) Despite this he will still be regarded as a constant wearer.
('45', 153, 3, 22, 306604) Hence a person who
('45', 154, 0, 1, 306623) VOL.45 : 4 FEBRUARY, 1929 11 MAY, 1929 155
('45', 154, 1, 2, 306666) wears khadi only while attending to the work of the Congress, but on other occasions wears foreign or mill made clothes is not a constant wearer.
('45', 154, 1, 3, 306812) Similarly, one who wears foreign cloth inside and puts on khadi on top is not a constant wearer.
('45', 154, 1, 4, 306909) Likewise, a man who wears a dhoti of mill cloth and a cap and shirt of khadi is also not a constant wearer.
('45', 154, 1, 5, 307017) In this way, the meaning of ‘constant wearer’ in my view is quite clear.
('45', 154, 1, 6, 307090) How, then, should workers enrol members?
('45', 154, 1, 7, 307131) My advice to them is that if a non wearer has faith in khadi and is prepared to wear it; he accepts the Congress ideals and contributes 4 annas or yarn spun by himself—they should explain the khadi clause to him and enrol him as a member of the Congress.
('45', 154, 1, 8, 307386) If a large number of such members are enrolled, they will have little to do in the way of exercising their right except participating in the elections of the subcommittees.
('45', 154, 1, 9, 307559) If they are not constant wearers, they should forgo this right, help the Congress in a variety of other ways and should, at the very first opportunity, begin to dress in khadi from head to foot.
('45', 154, 1, 10, 307754) It is the duty of the workers not to forget about the members after enrolling them, but to keep a constant watch over them and to persuade them to wear khadi.
('45', 154, 1, 11, 307913) The workers should go out with them to sell khadi from door to door and should familiarize themselves with the latter’s problems and resolve them.
('45', 154, 1, 12, 308060) The greatest difficulty in Gujarat is that of dhotis for men and saris for women.
('45', 154, 1, 13, 308142) Gujarat seems unwilling to spin fine yarn and it finds khadi dhotis expensive.
('45', 154, 1, 14, 308221) It is possible to produce dhotis in Gujarat if we have the will.
('45', 154, 1, 15, 308286) We do produce good cotton.
('45', 154, 1, 16, 308313) In Gujarat, there is a great awakening and there are volunteers also, as well as National Schools.
('45', 154, 1, 17, 308412) I have found from experience that those who card well can also spin well.
('45', 154, 1, 18, 308486) For drawing out fine and strong yarn we should have slivers made of well carded cotton.
('45', 154, 1, 19, 308574) Carding has made the maximum progress in Gujarat.
('45', 154, 1, 20, 308624) Plenty of carding bows can be produced here, and there are also people eager to learn the work.
('45', 154, 1, 21, 308720) But the will is lacking.
('45', 154, 1, 22, 308745) If Gujarat so desires, it can produce fine yarn quite soon.
('45', 154, 1, 23, 308805) But if it is too lazy to do so, and also unwilling to pay for fine dhotis, the men and women here should wear half length dhotis of coarse khadi.
('45', 154, 1, 24, 308951) But all this is meant for wise, sensible people and for khadi lovers.
('45', 154, 1, 25, 309021) Where there is a will there is a way.
('45', 154, 1, 26, 309059) But where there is no will, in spite of the way, we remain stone blind.

('45', 155, 0, 1, 309217) 156 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('45', 155, 1, 2, 309259) 154. A BEAUTIFUL SATYAGRAHA Something appeared in the newspapers about the satyagraha that was offered in Miraj a few months ago.
('45', 155, 1, 3, 309389) But what appears in newspapers is incomplete and sometimes even incorrect, so I did not pay any attention to it.
('45', 155, 1, 4, 309502) But in this context, I came across the name of Pundalik.
('45', 155, 1, 5, 309559) I know him very well, since he has stayed in the Ashram, and is a follower of Gangadharrao Deshpande.
('45', 155, 1, 6, 309661) So I sent for all the information from him.
('45', 155, 1, 7, 309705) What he says deserves to be considered.
('45', 155, 1, 8, 309745) I therefore give the main portion of the letter below.
('45', 155, 1, 9, 309800) The original letter is in Hindi.
('45', 155, 2, 10, 309833) We can well regard this small satyagraha as having been beautifully concluded.
('45', 155, 2, 11, 309912) There are here three points worth noting.
('45', 155, 2, 12, 309954) The first is that the duty of the leader was only to maintain peace, because that is the foundation of satyagraha.
('45', 155, 2, 13, 310069) Secondly, the leaders did not provoke the people to fight to satisfy their own vanity, and allowed the panch appointed by the people to go to negotiate a settlement.
('45', 155, 2, 14, 310235) This means that the satyagraha leaders should be without pride.
('45', 155, 2, 15, 310299) Thirdly, there is no need whatsoever for the satyagraha leader to be a scholar, a lawyer or a barrister.
('45', 155, 2, 16, 310404) He should possess the qualities of truthfulness, placidity, steadfastness, courage, simplicity, etc.
('45', 155, 2, 17, 310505) The real leader of this satyagraha was Pundalik.
('45', 155, 2, 18, 310554) He cannot be regarded as an intellectual.
('45', 155, 2, 19, 310596) His knowledge of English is almost nil but he displayed all the requisite qualities which I have listed above.
('45', 155, 2, 20, 310707) But this work cannot be said to have been finished yet.
('45', 155, 2, 21, 310763) The remaining work is as important as the work already done.
('45', 155, 2, 22, 310824) The awakening of the people should be utilized to make them realize their own condition, their own strength and their own limitations.
('45', 155, 2, 23, 310959) Only then can we preserve the gains achieved which would then spread in the surroundings like the fragrance of flowers.
('45', 155, 2, 24, 311079) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 3 3 1929
('45', 155, 3, 25, 311115) 1 The letter is not retranslated here.
('45', 155, 3, 26, 311154) The correspondent had described how he had successfully led a satyagraha movement in Miraj taluk against an unjust increase in land revenue.
('45', 156, 0, 1, 311295) VOL.45 : 4 FEBRUARY, 1929 11 MAY, 1929 157
('45', 156, 1, 2, 311338) 155. AN IDEAL STUDENTS’ HOSTEL 1
('45', 156, 2, 3, 311371) Since a conference about Hostels is to be held this month in this city, I was asked to express my views as to what would be an ideal hostel.
('45', 156, 2, 4, 311512) I have been running students’ hostels since 1904 according to my lights.
('45', 156, 2, 5, 311585) I am therefore inclined to claim that I have some knowledge and experience of how hostels should be run and managed.
('45', 156, 2, 6, 311702) Here, we would do well to take a wider sense of the term ‘hostel’.
('45', 156, 2, 7, 311769) Every person who is learning anything is a student; and the place where more than one such student lives I consider a students’ hostel.
('45', 156, 2, 8, 311905) The first and the most important condition for the success of such hostels is that the superintendents must be men of good character.
('45', 156, 2, 9, 312039) A hostel should never be allowed to degenerate into a mere boarding house, that is, a place where students live together for the sake of obtaining their meals.
('45', 156, 2, 10, 312199) Students should cultivate a family feeling towards one another, and the superintendent should take the place of a father.
('45', 156, 2, 11, 312321) He should take an interest in them, take part in their social life, and also have his meals with them.
('45', 156, 2, 12, 312424) An ideal hostel would be almost more important to the student than school.
('45', 156, 2, 13, 312499) In fact, the hostel is the real school.
('45', 156, 2, 14, 312539) In schools or colleges the students get only verbal knowledge, while in the hostels they get all kinds of knowledge.
('45', 156, 2, 15, 312656) An ideal hostel should not be a separate institution from the school; hence, both should be under the same management, and teachers and students should live together.
('45', 156, 2, 16, 312823) Thus, we should make the hostels like home, and create in them ideal conditions for growth and development such as do not obtain even in real homes.
('45', 156, 2, 17, 312972) Therefore, the thing to do would be to turn the hostels into gurukuls.
('45', 156, 2, 18, 313043) There are many defects in our hostels.
('45', 156, 2, 19, 313082) The reason lies in the fact that students lack a sense of belonging to a family group, and those who run them do not enter fully into the life of the students.
('45', 156, 2, 20, 313242) Then, these hostels should be outside the city limits, and all the reforms which are considered necessary for the villages or cities should be carried out in them, that is, there must be the necessary arrangements for hygienic and sanitary living and the rules of such
('45', 156, 3, 21, 313511) 1 The translation used here is from True Education, pp.
('45', 157, 0, 1, 313567) 158 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('45', 157, 1, 2, 313609) living should be strictly followed.
('45', 157, 1, 3, 313645) An ideal hostel cannot be set up in a rented building.
('45', 157, 1, 4, 313700) There should be good bath rooms and latrines.
('45', 157, 1, 5, 313746) The building should be well ventilated and have a garden attached to it.
('45', 157, 1, 6, 313819) An ideal hostel should be swadeshi in all respects—in the way the building is constructed, furnished and decorated.
('45', 157, 1, 7, 313935) There should too be a reflection of village arts and crafts and way of life.
('45', 157, 1, 8, 314012) The building itself should be in keeping with our needs and our means, considering the poverty of India.
('45', 157, 1, 9, 314117) Thus, hostels, as built in prosperous and affluent Western countries, cannot serve as models for ours.
('45', 157, 1, 10, 314220) Climatic conditions abroad and here differ.
('45', 157, 1, 11, 314264) Hence, the type of building put up must be in accordance with prevailing conditions.
('45', 157, 1, 12, 314349) There must be nothing in the ideal hostel which might encourage indolence and softness, or lead to waywardness.
('45', 157, 1, 13, 314461) Therefore, the food served there should be simple—as becomes the life of seekers of knowledge.
('45', 157, 1, 14, 314556) There should be regular prayers, and rules governing work, rest and sleep.
('45', 157, 1, 15, 314631) An ideal hostel will be a brahmacharya ashram, i.e., a colony of students living the life of brahmacharis.
('45', 157, 1, 16, 314738) The word ‘student’ is of recent origin—a modern word.
('45', 157, 1, 17, 314792) The old word for a student— brahmachari—is richer in meaning and connotes the ideal of student life more truly.
('45', 157, 1, 18, 314904) Brahmacharya or spiritual discipline—control of the senses, purity of body and mind, and devotion to studies with a view to attaining the Ultimate Reality—is absolutely necessary during the period of study.
('45', 157, 1, 19, 315111) In the rather topsyturvy conditions obtaining today, I would like married students also, if admitted into the hostel, to observe brahmacharya until the completion of their studies.
('45', 157, 1, 20, 315292) This means, among other things, that during this period they should live away from their wives.
('45', 157, 1, 21, 315388) The reader should remember that I have described what would be an ideal hostel.
('45', 157, 1, 22, 315468) It is understandable that all hostels may not be able to realize this goal.
('45', 157, 1, 23, 315544) But, if the ideal described above is accepted as the standard, every hostel should strive to reach it, and assess its achievement by comparison with the ideal.
('45', 157, 1, 24, 315704) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 3 3 1929

('45', 158, 1, 2, 315783) 156. LETTER TO MIRABEHN Unrevised March 4, 1929
('45', 158, 2, 3, 315831) MIRA, This sheet tells you where I am writing from.
('45', 158, 2, 4, 315883) Tomorrow takes me away from you for a fair distance.
('45', 158, 2, 5, 315936) My third class travelling is becoming a fraud in a way.
('45', 158, 2, 6, 315992) From Delhi I had a whole compartment given to me and the party.
('45', 158, 2, 7, 316056) There was thus greater freedom than in the 2nd class and I had the satisfaction of having the whole company with me.
('45', 158, 2, 8, 316173) The separation pained me.
('45', 158, 2, 9, 316199) The being together gives me joy.
('45', 158, 2, 10, 316232) The Mandir is making visible progress, so I fancy.
('45', 158, 2, 11, 316283) The joint kitchen is becoming more and more popular, and I do not think, at the end of the year, anybody would want to break it up.
('45', 158, 2, 12, 316415) But let us see.
('45', 158, 2, 13, 316431) Do not be anxious about me.
('45', 158, 2, 14, 316459) There are three services from Rangoon per week.
('45', 158, 2, 15, 316507) I hope to write to you therefore three times a week.
('45', 158, 2, 16, 316560) The sailings from Calcutta to Rangoon are Sundays, Tuesdays and Fridays.
('45', 158, 2, 17, 316633) So you too need not write more than three times per week.
('45', 158, 2, 18, 316691) The steamer always leaves in the morning.
('45', 158, 2, 19, 316733) You will not forget to give me a summary of your work after some time now.
('45', 158, 2, 20, 316808) I want your informed opinion on the soft spindles and a description of your improvements on the bow, also your digest of comparison between the results of well carded slivers and what they used to have before.
('45', 158, 2, 21, 317018) I hope you are keeping a diary of these bare experiences.
('45', 158, 2, 22, 317076) I want you to treat your experiment scientifically.
('45', 158, 2, 23, 317128) I want you also to tell me from time to time all about the morning and the evening prayers and what you sing there.
('45', 158, 2, 24, 317244) And give me also your final changes about food.
('45', 158, 2, 25, 317292) I am attaching more and more importance to your experiment, for I know you are accurate about these things, and will not easily deceive yourself.
('45', 158, 2, 26, 317438) I have a curious party with me this time.
('45', 158, 2, 27, 317480) It includes a mad girl graduate.
('45', 158, 2, 28, 317513) She is the daughter of a well known Tamil leader—Rajaji’s friend.
('45', 158, 2, 29, 317579) Last time I was in Delhi, she and her cousin came in to see me.
('45', 158, 2, 30, 317643) I suggested their coming to the Ashram for a change.
('45', 158, 2, 31, 317696) The father jumped at the idea.
('45', 158, 2, 32, 317727) And there they are.
('45', 158, 2, 33, 317747) In order to be able to look after her more easily, I have cropped her hair.

('45', 158, 2, 35, 317874) She will listen, if at all, to me and no one
