('45', 162, 1, 2, 322777) 160. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, CALCUTTA 1
('45', 162, 2, 3, 322819) March 4, 1929
('45', 162, 3, 4, 322833) As the Congress has directed we must boycott foreign cloth, not only British cloth but all foreign cloth.
('45', 162, 3, 5, 322939) It will not do to boycott British cloth alone, for it will find its way into the country along with other foreign cloth.
('45', 162, 3, 6, 323060) Bengali friends know this from their experience during the swadeshi movement.
('45', 162, 3, 7, 323138) India is an extremely poor country.
('45', 162, 3, 8, 323174) I wish to draw strength from having the poor of India with me.
('45', 162, 3, 9, 323237) That is why I place so much emphasis on the propagation of khadi.
('45', 162, 3, 10, 323303) The author of the Mahab harata has dwelt at length on the glory of serving the poor.
('45', 162, 3, 11, 323388) Buddha has also spoken of this.
('45', 162, 3, 12, 323420) The people of India sorely need food and clothing.
('45', 162, 3, 13, 323471) Tormented by the pangs of hunger our countrymen have been known to abandon their children.
('45', 162, 3, 14, 323562) There is no remedy for their suffering other than propagation of khadi.
('45', 162, 3, 15, 323634) I have reached this conclusion after having travelled all over India.
('45', 162, 3, 16, 323704) I shall bow to the man who can show an alternative way of removing the distress of the poor millions of India.
('45', 162, 3, 17, 323815) I shall accept him as my guru.
('45', 162, 3, 18, 323846) The only way is the boycott of foreign cloth.
('45', 162, 3, 19, 323892) I have the fullest faith in this measure.
('45', 162, 3, 20, 323934) I hope you will take off such foreign cloth as you may be wearing and burn it here and now and collect all foreign cloth in your homes and bring it to the spot indicated by the Congress and burn it.
('45', 162, 3, 21, 324133) And now please take off all your foreign cloth.
('45', 162, 4, 22, 324181) (As my speech at the foreign cloth burning demonstration campaign at Calcutta on the 4th instant and the statement made to the Press have a significance beyond the Indian border and as they define the scope of the boycott campaign as also of civil disobedience, I transcribe them below from the daily Press.
('45', 162, 5, 23, 324489) M. K. G)
('45', 162, 6, 24, 324498) FRIENDS, I do not propose to translate what I have been saying in Hindustani.
('45', 162, 6, 25, 324576) It is sufficient for me to say that the boycott of foreign

('45', 163, 0, 1, 324857) 164 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('45', 163, 1, 2, 324899) cloth, not merely boycott of British cloth, is in my opinion indispe nsable if we are to attain swaraj in terms of the hungry millions.
('45', 163, 1, 3, 325035) The Congress accepted this proposition last year.
('45', 163, 1, 4, 325085) The Working Committee by accepting the scheme drawn up by me at its instance has also set its seal of approval upon the proposition that I have laid down before you.
('45', 163, 1, 5, 325251) The Working Committee has invited me to shoulder the burden of guiding its deliberations.
('45', 163, 1, 6, 325341) I have faith in you, my countrymen, I have faith in God.
('45', 163, 1, 7, 325398) I have faith in the absolute righteousness of this cause and so in fear and trembling and full hope I have shouldered the burden and now ask you to share that burden with me.
('45', 163, 1, 8, 325573) This meeting is not of my seeking,you have chosen to call this meeting, you have come here well knowing what is to happen here.
('45', 163, 1, 9, 325701) I hope that this is a sign of your determination to lighten the burden that I have shouldered.
('45', 163, 1, 10, 325796) I do not want to argue out the pros and cons of the boycott of foreign cloth through khadi.
('45', 163, 1, 11, 325888) Remember that is the proposition enunciated in the scheme.
('45', 163, 1, 12, 325947) Before the Working Committee would accept this scheme it wanted to subject me to a fire of cross examination.
('45', 163, 1, 13, 326057) The proceedings lasted for four hours and the Working Committee was fully satisfied that this was the only thing we could possibly do if we were to go through this programme during this year and if need be wake up on the first of January next with the whole country as Independencewallahs.
('45', 163, 1, 14, 326347) If we are to achieve our purpose this is the only effective programme.
('45', 163, 1, 15, 326418) I want you therefore to be true to this programme and to yourselves.
('45', 163, 1, 16, 326487) No longer deceive yourselves and the country by crowding at meetings of this character, by giving applause and then going away forgetting everything about what might happen at such meetings.
('45', 163, 1, 17, 326678) I want you to translate every word that you say into effective action.
('45', 163, 1, 18, 326749) I want you to pledge yourselves not before me but before your God that henceforth you are not going to use any foreign cloth, that you are going to give up foreign clothes in your possession, that you will burn them even as you burn rags in your possession which may require to be disinfected,even as a drunkard suddenly become teetotaller empties his cupboard and destroys every bottle of brandy and whisky in his possession, no matter what it might have cost him.
('45', 163, 1, 19, 327215) You will count no cost too great against the cause,the liberty and honour of your country.
('45', 164, 0, 1, 327306) VOL.45 : 4 FEBRUARY, 1929 11 MAY, 1929 165
('45', 164, 1, 2, 327349) But there is a fly in the ointment.
('45', 164, 1, 3, 327385) I have seen a notice served upon the Secretary of the Provincial Congress Committee which proceeds somewhat on these lines: That at this meeting no burning of clothes should take place because it is an offence under the Police Act or Police Regulations, whatever that may be called.
('45', 164, 1, 4, 327668) The clause runs after this fashion that no burning of straw or such other things can take place in or near any public street or thoroughfare.
('45', 164, 1, 5, 327810) Well, I have been taxing my mind as to whether to call this Park a thoroughfare or not.
('45', 164, 1, 6, 327898) Two lawyers put their heads together—I do not count myself as a lawyer, I am disbarred—they put their heads together and advised me that by no stretch of meaning could this Park be called a thoroughfare.
('45', 164, 1, 7, 328102) They drew my attention to another section in the Act where a public street, a public thoroughfare and a place of public resort were also mentioned.
('45', 164, 1, 8, 328250) In this section the place of public resort is specifically omitted.
('45', 164, 1, 9, 328318) I can well understand this Park being a place of public resort.

('45', 167, 3, 6, 335345) 161. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS
('45', 167, 4, 7, 335373) [March 5, 1929] 2
('45', 167, 5, 8, 335391) I was pained and amazed at the uncalled for and wholly unnecessary police interference, especially after the speech that I delivered in connection with the burning of the foreign clothes.
('45', 167, 5, 9, 335579) Out of consideration for the Commissioner of Police I went out of my way and delivered my speech in English so far as it referred to the burning incident.
('45', 167, 5, 10, 335734) I had full hope that, after the clear statement I made that we were not out for breaking any laws by way of civil disobedience but that we did not accept the interpretation put upon the clause in question of the Police Act, there would be no attempt in interfering with the burning.
('45', 167, 5, 11, 336017) I have a little experience of the Police Acts in many other parts of the world.
('45', 167, 5, 12, 336097) Unless there is imminent and grave danger, the police never interfere with acts of the public even though these may amount to a breach of laws and regulations.
('45', 167, 5, 13, 336257) They summon them before a court of law and it is the most natural thing for a police that are humble enough to recognize their limitations to seek redress through courts of law instead of taking the law into their own hands.
('45', 167, 5, 14, 336482) They know that tonight there was no danger imminent, there was not certainly serious danger, the crowd was quite peaceful and responsible men were in charge of the whole demonstration.
('45', 167, 5, 15, 336667) They knew that the demonstration was a part of a big public campaign and on the top of that they had the clearest possible pronouncement from me.
('45', 167, 5, 16, 336813) The act of burning too had actually taken place and I was confident that the police were there merely to watch when all of a sudden I saw them with their big sticks shoving out the crowd that surrounded the fire and then with their sticks putting the fire out.

('45', 169, 2, 8, 341138) 162. THE ETHICS OF BURNING
('45', 169, 3, 9, 341165) [March 5, 1929] 1
('45', 169, 4, 10, 341183) It will be as late as March 17 before this article is in the reader’s hand.
('45', 169, 4, 11, 341259) I write this on the steamer on my way from Calcutta to Rangoon, so that the spectacle of what took place on March 4 in Shraddhanand Park is still fresh in my mind.
('45', 169, 4, 12, 341423) I hope that the lathis of hundreds of thousands of policemen will not be able to extinguish the fire that was kindled in that park on that day.
('45', 169, 4, 13, 341567) For dharma will not be extinguished by anyone trying to do so.
('45', 169, 4, 14, 341630) Once it manifests itself in a man’s heart, it does not perish even when his body perishes.
('45', 169, 4, 15, 341721) The fire of dharma lit by the world’s men of destiny, prophets, and Hindu and Muslim saints has continued to burn even after their bodies have perished.
('45', 169, 4, 16, 341874) But some may ask: Can burning of clothes be dharma?
('45', 169, 4, 17, 341926) It is my humble opinion that the dharma of burning clothes can be proved.
('45', 169, 4, 18, 342000) We burn or bury a body from which life has departed.
('45', 169, 4, 19, 342053) We burn the things which have been contaminated.
('45', 169, 4, 20, 342102) He who discards liquor will throw it away.
('45', 169, 4, 21, 342145) However costly the liquor, when one has given up
('45', 169, 5, 22, 342194) 1 Gandhiji left Calcutta for Rangoon on the morning of March 5.
('45', 170, 0, 1, 342258) VOL.45 : 4 FEBRUARY, 1929 11 MAY, 1929 171
('45', 170, 1, 2, 342301) drinking, one will not commit the sin of selling it to another.
('45', 170, 1, 3, 342365) If costly things are contaminated by the plague, they are burnt.
('45', 170, 1, 4, 342430) It has been regarded as a dharma to do so.
('45', 170, 1, 5, 342473) The Johannesburg Municipality did not feel hurt in burning down the expensive building of the market and the provisions contained in it when the plague broke out in Johannesburg.
('45', 170, 1, 6, 342652) It considered it a duty to do so.
('45', 170, 1, 7, 342686) There may well be a difference of opinion on the necessity of consigning these things to the flames.
('45', 170, 1, 8, 342787) But even those opposed to it will concede that burning may become a dharma for those who believe that it is necessary to do so.
('45', 170, 1, 9, 342915) Likewise, it is my humble view that it is the dharma of every Indian to burn foreign cloth.
('45', 170, 1, 10, 343007) After the insolent and cruel performance of the Calcutta police, that dharma has acquired a new urgency.
('45', 170, 1, 11, 343112) Those who before that event had doubts about the need to burn foreign cloth should have none after it.
('45', 170, 1, 12, 343215) No one will doubt that it is our dharma to boycott foreign cloth which has impoverished out country and through which over 60 crores of rupees are drained out of India every year.
('45', 170, 1, 13, 343395) If this is conceded, what are we to do with the boycotted cloth if not burn it?
('45', 170, 1, 14, 343475) Some say that it should be given away to the poor.
('45', 170, 1, 15, 343526) Those who make this suggestion do not see that thereby they insult both themselves and the poor.
('45', 170, 1, 16, 343623) They insult the poor when they consider them inferior to themselves, and insulting the poor they insult themselves.
('45', 170, 1, 17, 343739) Do not the poor have self respect?
('45', 170, 1, 18, 343774) Do they not want swaraj?
('45', 170, 1, 19, 343799) Why should we give to the poor a thing which we regard as infected?
('45', 170, 1, 20, 343867) We do have the mean habit of offering to the poor left overs from our plates.
('45', 170, 1, 21, 343945) Shall we add to that meanness by giving them the clothes which we ourselves have discarded?
('45', 170, 1, 22, 344037) Let us consider what sort of clothes they are.
('45', 170, 1, 23, 344084) The clothes I have burnt till today comprised handkerchiefs, clean or unclean black caps, neckties, collars, socks, thin long shirts, blouses, fine saris, etc.
('45', 170, 1, 24, 344244) What clothes out of these could one give to the poor?
('45', 170, 1, 25, 344298) And how strange would it be to create in the poor a fondness for them ?
('45', 170, 1, 26, 344370) If we do so, how shall we seek to boycott foreign cloth?
('45', 170, 1, 27, 344427) And, finally, no one can doubt the necessity of the bonfire after that scene at Shraddhanand Park.
('45', 170, 1, 28, 344526) I had told the police that there was no intention of breaking the law for the purpose of burning foreign cloth.
('45', 170, 1, 29, 344638) Only after the lawyers had given their opinion that the police had not correctly interpreted the section of law on the basis of which the order prohibiting the burning was issued, was it decided to burn
('45', 171, 0, 1, 344841) 172 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('45', 171, 1, 2, 344883) clothes in that park.
('45', 171, 1, 3, 344905) Despite this when the police attempted fruitlessly to put out the fire merely to annoy the people, the latter were certainly agitated and then started burning at many spots in the park.
('45', 171, 1, 4, 345091) And that led to some exchange of blows between the police and the people.
('45', 171, 1, 5, 345165) I believe it will be a gross insult to India if, even after such insolence, foreign cloth is not burnt in every home in every village.
('45', 171, 1, 6, 345300) After this action of the police, people should have confidence in place of whatever doubt they may have had about the success of the boycott.

('45', 180, 4, 7, 363937) 172. ‘IN POSSESSION’
('45', 180, 5, 8, 363958) Mr. Pennington is a nonagenarian.
('45', 180, 5, 9, 363992) However much one may differ from him, there is no denying his sincerity.
('45', 180, 5, 10, 364065) He is my unfailing correspondent and is never tired of issuing his periodic warnings to me.
('45', 180, 5, 11, 364157) Here is his latest:
('45', 180, 6, 12, 364177) I have just been reading your essay on “Congress Initiation” (on p.
('45', 180, 6, 13, 364245) 5 of the 3rd Jan.) 2 and am more puzzled than ever at your confidence about swaraj— at the end of this year(?).
('45', 180, 6, 14, 364357) However it happened, Great Britain is in possession of India—some, including my old assistant, the late Sir John Rees, M.P., think, by right of conquest (which is her title to the Punjab), but most of us, I hope, as trustees for the whole population, especially the lower orders; and as trustees we have no right to give up our trust except to somebody considered capable of carrying on the work we have only just begun.
('45', 180, 6, 15, 364778) Is your National Congress such a body even with you as (shall we say?) President of the Republic?
('45', 180, 6, 16, 364876) I quite think you are the most likely person for that office, but would you be prepared to undertake the job with or without a British army?
('45', 180, 6, 17, 365017) If you failed to keep the peace, what then?
('45', 180, 7, 18, 365061) Excuse a very brief note: I am now in my 90th year and have no business to be thinking of sublunary things; but I have been more interested in India than even England since 1861. Again wishing you a safe deliverance
('45', 180, 8, 19, 365277) 1 Pyarelal 2 An Autobiography, Pt. V, Ch. XXXVIII.

('45', 181, 1, 2, 365370) from all India’s troubles and trusting you won’t make confusion worse confounded.
('45', 181, 1, 3, 365452) How is one to persuade men like Mr. Pennington that we repudiate the doctrine of trust and that if a plebiscite was taken even those whom he is pleased to call “the lower orders” would do likewise?
('45', 181, 1, 4, 365650) I happen to know them, if anyone in India does.
('45', 181, 1, 5, 365698) I make bold to say that with the exception of those who have come under the degrading influence of the brandy bottle the vast majority do not want the protection of self appointed trustees.

('45', 181, 1, 10, 366295) The puzzle is that 300 million people stand dispossessed of their own property and lack confidence about their ability to recover it from plunderers whether they be called conquerors or trustees.
('45', 181, 1, 11, 366491) If I could but infect the Congressmen with my confidence in our ability to win back our freedom and, what is more, in the correctness of the means suggested for winning it, ten months that remain out of the twelve should prove more than enough for the task.
('45', 181, 1, 12, 366749) Let me therefore suggest to Mr. Pennington that it is neither armed force nor benevolence that gives Great Britain the possession and the power over India but it is the want of faith of India’s children that is responsible for the tragedy.
('45', 181, 1, 13, 366989) When that faith comes, it will work miracles.

('45', 182, 2, 4, 367778) From Trivandrum Sjt.
('45', 182, 2, 5, 367799) K.G. Shesha Aiyer, President of the Kerala Provincial Hindi Prachar Conference, writes to say that this Conference was held at Ernakulam (Cochin) on 10th February last where the following resolution was unanimously adopted:
('45', 182, 3, 6, 368023) This conference expresses its deep sense of gratitude to Gandhiji and Sheth Jamnalal Bajaj for their untiring efforts in pushing on the Hindi movement in South India and trying to make Hindi the national language of India and urges on all patriotic sons and daughters of India to help the movement by studying the language themselves and also by contributing to the central fund.

('45', 182, 3, 11, 368540) Now I have not published this resolution to advertise either myself or Sheth Jamnalalji or the parties to the resolution.
('45', 182, 3, 12, 368662) Everybody knows my keenness about Hindi prachar in the South.
('45', 182, 3, 13, 368724) Sheth Jamnalalji was a confirmed lover of Hindi before I returned to India in 1915. His tour in the South has given a fresh impetus to Hindi propaganda there.
('45', 182, 3, 14, 368883) The parties to the resolution have had their reward by appearing before audiences that knew them.
('45', 182, 3, 15, 368981) My object then in publishing the resolution and the names is publicly to express the hope that the gentlemen concerned are in their own persons fulfilling the two objects of the resolution, viz., that they are learning Hindi themselves and also contributing to the central fund.
('45', 182, 3, 16, 369260) I am using this incident merely to drive home a patent fact.
('45', 182, 3, 17, 369321) So far as these gentlemen are concerned it is likely that they are Hindi scholars and that they are regular subscribers to the central fund.
('45', 182, 3, 18, 369462) But it is not to be denied that we have not yet shed the evil habit of moving and supporting resolutions we never intend to carry out ourselves.
('45', 182, 3, 19, 369607) It would conduce to national progress and save a great deal of time and trouble if we cultivated the habit of never supporting resolutions either by speaking or voting for them if we had not either the intention or the ability to
('45', 183, 0, 1, 369837) 184 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('45', 183, 1, 2, 369879) carry them out.
('45', 183, 1, 3, 369895) I know that wherever Sheth Jamnalalji and Sjt.
('45', 183, 1, 4, 369942) Rajagopalachari have gone, the meetings have passed resolutions like the foregoing.
('45', 183, 1, 5, 370026) If all these good people were to carry out the resolutions, the Hindi propaganda should make rapid progress and be never in want of funds.

('45', 183, 2, 7, 370187) 174. THE NATIONAL FLAG
('45', 183, 3, 8, 370210) The ceremony of hoisting the national flag over the Town Hall of the Ahmedabad Municipality brings to mind two letters lying in my file from Gujarati correspondents on the subject.
('45', 183, 3, 9, 370391) Before coming to the two letters let me repeat my congratulations which I tendered at the time of performing the hoisting ceremony to the Municipality of Ahmedabad on its courage and patriotism in having the national flag for its Town Hall.
('45', 183, 3, 10, 370632) 1 Such a thing would have been impossible only a few years ago.
('45', 183, 3, 11, 370696) Sardar Vallabhbhai’s brave work in the Municipality has made the hoisting of the national flag quite possible and even natural as was the erection of a bronze statue of Lokamanya Tilak in its only public garden.
('45', 183, 3, 12, 370908) I can only hope that the Municipal councillors and the citizens of Ahmedabad will never lower the flag and will live up to its dignity, and having erected Lokamanya’s statue in its garden will not rest content till the mantra of swaraj bequeathed to us by Lokamanya has become a living reality.
('45', 183, 3, 13, 371203) But one of the correspondents referred to by me who is an ardent nationalist says that Congress workers and Congress committees nowadays take all sorts of liberty with the national flag.
('45', 183, 3, 14, 371390) He complains that some do not retain the three colours, others omit the wheel and yet others even use foreign cloth instead of hand spun and hand woven khadi.
('45', 183, 3, 15, 371549) He rightly observes that this treatment of the flag, unconscious though it may be, diminishes its prestige.
('45', 183, 3, 16, 371657) The other correspondent insists on precision.
('45', 183, 3, 17, 371703) He says the order of the three colours should be rigidly observed and so the position in the flag of the wheel.
('45', 183, 3, 18, 371815) I should add that the coloured strips should be parallel and never horizontal.
('45', 183, 3, 19, 371894) The proportion between the length and width should also be fixed.
('45', 183, 3, 20, 371960) The length should be twice the width of the flag.
('45', 183, 3, 21, 372010) The white colour should be on top to be followed by the green and the red should be the last representing as it does the colour of the majority of
('45', 183, 4, 22, 372157) 1 Vide “Speech at Flag Hoisting Ceremony, Ahmedabad”, February 28, 1929.
('45', 184, 0, 1, 372230) VOL.45 : 4 FEBRUARY, 1929 11 MAY, 1929 185
('45', 184, 1, 2, 372273) the inhabitants of India.
('45', 184, 1, 3, 372299) The minorities other than Hindu and Muslim represented by the white colour being the joint primary care of the latter have their colour on top.
('45', 184, 1, 4, 372443) The same reasoning puts the Muslim minority the second in order.
('45', 184, 1, 5, 372508) The wheel should be in the middle of the oblong so as to cover all the colours.
('45', 184, 1, 6, 372588) There was an informal discussion over the flag at the last meeting of the Working Committee.
('45', 184, 1, 7, 372681) I had drawn attention to the irregularity observed about the flag and pointed out too that there was no formal resolution taken by the Working Committee or the All India Congress Committee about the quality of the national flag.
('45', 184, 1, 8, 372910) It was however the opinion of the members that the convention about the three colours, the wheel and khadi was so well established that it had attained the force of a rule and that anybody using the flag in any other manner clearly committed a breach.
('45', 184, 1, 9, 373162) That being so, I have suggested that the Congress should have these flags of various sizes made and stocked for supply all over India.
('45', 184, 1, 10, 373297) Then the quality and cheapness will be assured.
('45', 184, 1, 11, 373345) The cheapest and the most expeditious method is for the All India Spinners’ Association to have these flags prepared and kept for sale on behalf of the Congress at the different stores.
('45', 184, 1, 12, 373531) As it would be impossible for any individual committee to compete with the All India Spinners’ Association in point of cheapness the flags should find a ready sale all over India, assuming of course that the national revival has set in and that the convention as to the quality is faithfully observed by all Congressmen and Congress organizations.
('45', 184, 2, 13, 373879) Young India, 7 3 1929
('45', 184, 3, 14, 373901) 175. FOREIGN CLOTH BOYCOTT
('45', 184, 4, 15, 373928) It is a matter of great pleasure to me as I hope it is to every nationalist that Sjt.
('45', 184, 4, 16, 374014) Jairamdas has been able promptly to respond to my call on behalf of the Foreign Cloth Boycott Committee to take up its Secretaryship and as a necessary corollary to give up his seat in the Bombay Legislative Council.
('45', 184, 4, 17, 374231) Jairamdas is not a man to take up a cause he does not believe in.
('45', 184, 4, 18, 374297) His coming therefore as a whole time worker is in my opinion a great gain to the movement.
('45', 184, 4, 19, 374388) If the public will similarly respond to the call that will be made upon them from time to time by the Foreign Cloth Boycott Committee, the country
('45', 185, 0, 1, 374535) 186 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('45', 185, 1, 2, 374577) should be able to show a definite advance inside of a few months.
('45', 185, 1, 3, 374643) Given popular determination boycott is a matter of careful organization.
('45', 185, 1, 4, 374716) Two things will have to go together, sale and production of khadi.
('45', 185, 1, 5, 374783) The moment there is a real intention on the part of the public for boycott of foreign cloth, there will be a great rush for khadi.
('45', 185, 1, 6, 374914) If production does not anticipate the demand for khadi, there is danger of a severe disappointment and a consequent loss of faith in the possibility of boycott for mere want of khadi.
('45', 185, 1, 7, 375098) It is therefore necessary for the public not to purchase more khadi than they need.
('45', 185, 1, 8, 375182) They should try to cut down their rations as far as possible.
('45', 185, 1, 9, 375244) I am studiously silent about the indigenous mills.
('45', 185, 1, 10, 375295) It is my firm belief that mills, by reason of the limitations under which they must work, will fail us in the end if we rely upon them.
('45', 185, 1, 11, 375431) Then they, being concerns predominantly for making profits irrespective of national considerations, will not scruple to exploit the public and even to sell foreign cloth as swadeshi.
('45', 185, 1, 12, 375614) I have already exposed in these pages the fraudulent sale of mill cloth under the name of khadi.
('45', 185, 1, 13, 375711) 1 Lastly all mills are not swadeshi because they have their habitation in India as the existing Government is not swadeshi for the mere fact of its habitation being in India.
('45', 185, 1, 14, 375886) Some of them are foreign in every sense of the term.
('45', 185, 1, 15, 375939) They are administered by foreigners on behalf exclusively of foreign shareholders with foreign capital.
('45', 185, 1, 16, 376043) They are here merely to exploit the resources of the country.
('45', 185, 1, 17, 376105) The only thing they reluctantly contribute is to employ the cheap labour of the country and make a gullible public believe that these are swadeshi concerns.
('45', 185, 1, 18, 376262) But this does not mean that the mills will play no part in the boycott compaign.
('45', 185, 1, 19, 376343) They will, but it will be involuntary and fortuitous.
('45', 185, 1, 20, 376397) Congressmen will not be able at once to reach every village of India.
('45', 185, 1, 21, 376467) We will reach the towns and the villages surrounding them.
('45', 185, 1, 22, 376526) The mills reach every village of India.
('45', 185, 1, 23, 376566) The atmosphere created in the country will throw the villagers into the arms of the mill owners’ agents and they will buy whatever is given to them by the mills under the name of swadeshi.
('45', 185, 1, 24, 376755) Congressmen will have to be on the watch regarding their operations.
('45', 185, 1, 25, 376824) There are some patriotic mills which will refuse to betray the country if they cannot by reason of their limitations give active support.
('45', 185, 1, 26, 376962) My conviction is that a time must come and that within a few
('45', 185, 2, 27, 377023) 1Vide “A Mill Owner on Boycott”, pril 5, 1928 and “More of Mill Owners’ Greed”, May 10, 1928.
('45', 186, 0, 1, 377117) VOL.45 : 4 FEBRUARY, 1929 11 MAY, 1929 187
('45', 186, 1, 2, 377160) months when the mills will have to make their choice and accept the terms that were offered to them last year.
('45', 186, 1, 3, 377271) But it will wholly depend upon the determination of the people to boycott foreign cloth at any cost and replace it by genuine khadi.
('45', 186, 1, 4, 377404) Khadi has no limits.
('45', 186, 1, 5, 377425) For we have millions of human spindles and lakhs of human looms.
('45', 186, 1, 6, 377490) The one thing needful is the will to do it.

('45', 186, 2, 8, 377556) 176. THE “SUTLEJ” TRAGEDY
('45', 186, 3, 9, 377582) Dr. Menon writes as follows from Calcutta regarding my article on the Sutlej tragedy: 1
('45', 186, 4, 10, 377670) This forceful letter in my opinion makes things look uglier than I thought they were.
('45', 186, 4, 11, 377756) But I cannot acquit the master and officers as easily as Dr. Menon does.
('45', 186, 4, 12, 377829) Every Master of a ship is surely responsible for the welfare of the passengers under his charge.
('45', 186, 4, 13, 377926) I have known humane masters make the lives of passengers happy in difficult circumstances and I have known callous masters make the lives of their charges needlessly unhappy.
('45', 186, 4, 14, 378101) Indifferent officers often make the lot of passengers unbearable.
('45', 186, 4, 15, 378167) But it was not my purpose to distribute the blame.
('45', 186, 4, 16, 378218) It was enough for me to show that the matter could not be regarded as closed because the Government had held what could not be called an impartial inquiry.
('45', 186, 4, 17, 378374) Young India, 7 3 1929

('45', 186, 6, 22, 378778) He rejects some and accepts some as possible.
('45', 186, 6, 23, 378824) Among the possible and promising secondary occupations, he

('45', 186, 7, 25, 378920) The correspondent, referring to “The Inhuman System”, 7 2 1929, had written that the Surgeon Superintendent and not the Ship’s Master was directly and exclusively responsible for the management of the emigrants; that the ships were unsuitable and the Government was to blame for the inhuman system.

('45', 187, 1, 2, 379261) mentions hand spinning and devotes to it paragraphs which are worthy of careful study by sceptics.
('45', 187, 1, 3, 379360) I reproduce them below: 1
('45', 187, 2, 4, 379386) The Rao Bahadur is probably aware that the All India Spinners’ Association is concentrating its attention on organizing hand spinning in the villages on the self sufficient basis suggested by him.
('45', 187, 2, 5, 379583) I commend to his attention the example of Bijolia and Bardoli.
('45', 187, 2, 6, 379646) At the same time the towns may not be neglected.
('45', 187, 2, 7, 379695) So much is town life now dominating the villages that unless the towns set fashion in khadi, it becomes most difficult to persuade the villagers to spin even in their won interest and just enough for their own use.
('45', 187, 2, 8, 379910) Nor is the question of cost quite so simple as the Rao Bahadur imagines.
('45', 187, 2, 9, 379983) The cotton speculator and the foreign buyer have so disturbed cotton prices and cotton growing that the village often finds it apparently cheaper to buy cloth than to pay for cotton and for weaving.
('45', 187, 2, 10, 380182) Strange as it may appear, it sometimes happens that the cost of a yard of foreign cloth equals the cost of weaving and not unoften even the cost of cotton required for an equal length of handwoven cloth.
('45', 187, 2, 11, 380386) I may not go into these intricacies.
('45', 187, 2, 12, 380423) As a practical spinner I point out the difficulty of the task when there is no State aid and even subtle and subterranean opposition and always indifference to it.
('45', 187, 2, 13, 380587) Hence the necessity in the initial stage for subsidy and town patronage.
('45', 187, 2, 14, 380660) Moreover in these days of democracy, the villagers will not understand the philosophy and the truth of khadi if a distinction is drawn between towns and villages.
('45', 187, 2, 15, 380823) Lastly, since pioneers must be found from the towns, a khadi atmosphere in them is an absolute necessity for nationalizing the reform whose need the Rao Bahadur has so convincingly demonstrated.

('45', 188, 2, 13, 381875) It is quite true if the writings gave you the impression that I do not carry my wife with me through her intellect.
('45', 188, 2, 14, 381991) Her loyalty is amazing and she has followed me through all the transformations that my life has undergone.
('45', 188, 2, 15, 382098) My own conviction is that most probably the reverence felt by the Indian men towards India’s women is quite equal to that felt in the West;but it is of a different type.
('45', 188, 2, 16, 382268) 2 The Western form of reverence yielding the first place to women and many such other things, seems to me to be highly artificial and sometimes even hypocritical.
('45', 188, 2, 17, 382431) All the same, there is much to criticize in our treatment of women.
('45', 188, 2, 18, 382499) Some laws are bad, some husbands are monsters, some parents are heartless towards their daughters.

('45', 192, 7, 10, 387736) 184. INTERVIEW TO FREE PRESS OF INDIA
('45', 192, 8, 11, 387774) RANGOON, March 8, 1929
('45', 192, 9, 12, 387797) As usual Earl Wintert on has lived up to his reputation of being ignorant of the situation and facts.
('45', 192, 9, 13, 387899) He ought to know for instance that everyone here has said that I was arrested though the arrest was a gentlemanly affair.
('45', 192, 9, 14, 388021) It is no doubt true that it was an arrest under law or else why should there be a personal bond given for my appearance on the 26th instant?
('45', 192, 9, 15, 388162) Still grosser ignorance is betrayed by Earl Winterton’s statement that the Government of Bengal had intimated that lighting of bonfire to burn foreign clothes was illegal.
('45', 192, 9, 16, 388334) The Government of Bengal has intimated no such thing.
('45', 192, 9, 17, 388388) It was intimated through the Commissioner of Police that burning of straw and the like is prohibited without previous sanction in or near a public street or thoroughfare and this has reference only to cities.
('45', 192, 9, 18, 388597) The Earl should know that burning in private premises is still going on and will continue if people have grit truly.
('45', 192, 9, 19, 388714) It is untrue to say that my persistence led to a melee.
('45', 192, 9, 20, 388770) In spite of my questioning the legality of the notice and instead of therefore testing this legality in a court of law, the police proceeded in their outrageous conduct in seeking to put out the fire even though there was no imminent danger to person or property.
('45', 192, 9, 21, 389034) Information in my possession goes to show that the figures of injuries to the police are altogether exaggerated and there is wilful suppression of the fact that many members of the public were

('45', 193, 0, 1, 389275) 194 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('45', 193, 1, 2, 389317) injured by unnecessary lathi display of the police.
('45', 193, 1, 3, 389369) The last mis statement made by the noble Earl is that I had agreed to a condition that there would be no similar bonfire in Calcutta.
('45', 193, 1, 4, 389503) The truth is that I have agreed that there should be no similar bonfire in Calcutta in public squares and therefore also in public streets.
('45', 193, 1, 5, 389643) Bonfires continue in private places.
('45', 193, 1, 6, 389680) Whether the high handed action of the police autho rities has created a new political situation or not, it is too early to say.

('45', 193, 3, 8, 389839) 185. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, RANGOON 2
('45', 193, 4, 9, 389880) March 8, 1929 As I observe that a majority of this vast audience is Hindustani speaking, I thought it would be but meet for me to begin my thanksgiving in Hindustani.
('45', 193, 4, 10, 390047) I am deeply grateful too for the great honour you have conferred upon me by presenting me with this address.
('45', 193, 4, 11, 390156) I tender my congratulations to you upon the great progress which you are able to record during the 15 or 16 years when I was last in your midst.
('45', 193, 4, 12, 390301) Whenever I have come to Burma, I have looked forward to the visit.
('45', 193, 4, 13, 390368) I am in love with the men and women of Burma.

('45', 196, 1, 2, 396526) You inform me that you are holding a big conference on the 23rd or the 22nd instant and that at that conference you propose to pass a resolution for boycott of British goods.
('45', 196, 1, 3, 396701) I must in all humility warn you against taking any such step.
('45', 196, 1, 4, 396763) If you will look around yourselves, you will find as practical men and women that if for nothing else, that resolution is useless for this reason that it cannot be reduced to practice by any single one of you.
('45', 196, 1, 5, 396973) I claim to be an expert in this matter and so I would advise you strongly to do what is your duty—not to proclaim a boycott of British goods, but all foreign cloth which necessarily includes British cloth.
('45', 196, 1, 6, 397179) This limitation is based on practical wisdom which I claim for myself, and secondly, on the creed of non violence which also I claim to have studied with great reverence and equally great patience and perseverance.
('45', 196, 1, 7, 397394) The man who is saturated with the spirit of non violence has never any quarrel with a single individual.
('45', 196, 1, 8, 397499) His opposition is directed to a system, to the evil that is in man but not against the man himself.
('45', 196, 1, 9, 397599) Your quarrel, therefore, is not with the British people, but with the Imperialistic spirit of exploitation of the weak races of the earth.
('45', 196, 1, 10, 397738) If you will work along these lines—I must not attempt to work out the whole of this proposition, but I must suggest the deduction from premises if you will work it out—the deduction is that this non violent reasoning puts an automatic restraint on your boycott activity.
('45', 196, 1, 11, 398009) And the limit is foreign cloth.
('45', 196, 1, 12, 398041) Now the mere boycott of foreign cloth does not take you a yard further in your progress towards the amelioration of the peasantry of Burma.
('45', 196, 1, 13, 398181) I tendered at this evening’s meeting, in reply to the Corporation address, my congratulations to the Burmese friends upon their generosity and open mindedness.
('45', 196, 1, 14, 398341) But I am sorry that I cannot tender the same congratulations to you upon the industry of the men of Burma.
('45', 196, 1, 15, 398448) You are satisfied if you scratch the earth a little bit and grow an abundant crop of rice.
('45', 196, 1, 16, 398539) We also do likewise in several parts of India.
('45', 196, 1, 17, 398586) But that does not take you through the whole year and no peasantry in the world has yet been found to keep its head above water by working only for a limited period of the year.
('45', 196, 1, 18, 398764) Well, then, if you import foreign cloth you deny yourselves the privilege and duty of working with your hands and preparing your own cloth.
('45', 196, 1, 19, 398904) This is like cutting off both your hands.
('45', 197, 0, 1, 398946) 198 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('45', 197, 1, 2, 398988) You have talked, I am afraid, light heartedly of the spinning wheel and khadi.
('45', 197, 1, 3, 399067) Believe me you will fail to introduce the spinning wheel or rather to reintroduce the spinning wheel if you will not appreciate this fundamental distinction between the boycott of foreign cloth on the one hand and of British cloth alone on the other.
('45', 197, 1, 4, 399318) I will, therefore, ask wiser heads among you to study a little more deeply the immense bearing of the spinning wheel upon your life as upon that of the starving millions of India.

('45', 212, 3, 5, 432821) 197. ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS 2
('45', 212, 4, 6, 432849) RANGOON, March 10, 1929
('45', 212, 5, 7, 432873) Q. What is the present political condition In India?
('45', 212, 6, 8, 432926) A. In the melting pot.
('45', 212, 7, 9, 432949) Q. What form of Government do you expect to get immediately for India?
('45', 212, 8, 10, 433020) A. The form of Government described in the Nehru Report.
('45', 212, 9, 11, 433077) Q. Do you think you can get Dominion Status?
('45', 212, 10, 12, 433122) A. Most decidedly.
('45', 212, 11, 13, 433141) Q. Should dominion form of Government be accepted as most suitable for the present or should it be the goal of Indian aspirations?
('45', 212, 12, 14, 433272) A. In my opinion Dominion Status can become the final form of Government for India if it is obtained in the way and in the form that I have postulated.
('45', 212, 12, 15, 433424) If it means a partnership at will on a basis of equality with full freedom for either party to secede whenever it should wish I for one should be content with it.
('45', 212, 13, 16, 433587) Q. Do you consider that India should be in the British Empire?
('45', 212, 14, 17, 433650) A. Not in the British Empire as it is today but in it as I conceive it.
('45', 212, 15, 18, 433722) Q. Do you intend to take part in the discussions in England or in India if you are invited by the British Parliament regarding Indian Reforms?
('45', 212, 16, 19, 433865) A. Yes.
('45', 212, 16, 20, 433873) If the invitation is bona fide and sincere.
('45', 212, 17, 21, 433917) 1 This paragraph is taken from the Amrita Bazar Patrika report.
('45', 212, 17, 22, 433981) 2 A deputation of Saydos, heads of the Buddhist religious orders in Burma, presented Gandhiji a long interrogatory.
('45', 212, 17, 23, 434097) The replies given here are collated with a report in The Tribune and the account by Mahadev Desai and Pyarelal of Gandhiji’s tour In Burma.
('45', 213, 0, 1, 434237) 214 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('45', 213, 1, 2, 434279) Q. Do you think that it is in the interests of Burma that it should be part of India for ever?
('45', 213, 2, 3, 434374) A. It is a difficult question for me to answer.
('45', 213, 2, 4, 434422) All I can say is that it will be worth the while of Burma to remain part of India if it means a partnership at will on a basis of equality with full freedom for either party to secede whenever it should wish.
('45', 213, 2, 5, 434631) The main thing is that Burma should have an absolute right to shape her destiny as she likes.
('45', 213, 3, 6, 434725) Q. Do you consider that the line adopted by Swarajists in India helps the cause of the country for getting the form of Government they aspire to have?
('45', 213, 4, 7, 434876) A. No, I do not.
('45', 213, 5, 8, 434893) Q. Will Indians in Burma join hands with the Burmans in the boycotting of foreign goods and in helping the local industry?
('45', 213, 6, 9, 435016) A. Not in the boycott of foreign goods but in the boycott of foreign cloth.
('45', 213, 6, 10, 435092) Boycott of all foreign goods is a wild goose chase.
('45', 213, 6, 11, 435144) But the boycott of all foreign cloth is within the range of present possibility and it will do you good to accomplish it.
('45', 213, 6, 12, 435266) In this work India will join hands with you.
('45', 213, 6, 13, 435311) And India would be an unworthy neighbour and nothing good if she does not help your local industries.
('45', 213, 7, 14, 435413) Q. What protection should be given to minorities in Burma?
('45', 213, 8, 15, 435472) A. The same protection should be given to India minorities in Burma as it is to be given to minorities in India, nothing more.
('45', 213, 8, 16, 435599) If we cannot stay here on our merits, we should retire.
('45', 213, 9, 17, 435655) Q. What advice can you give to us and Indians to secure the willing co operation of both communities, rich and poor alike, in Burma to get the form of Government we aspire for?
('45', 213, 10, 18, 435832) A. We should approach each other not in a spirit of suspicion and distrust but that of amity and goodwill.
('45', 213, 10, 19, 435939) A whole community should not be damned because there are a few scoundrels in it.
('45', 213, 10, 20, 436020) Each community should live in a neighbourly co operation with the other; and not seek to dominate over the other.
('45', 213, 10, 21, 436134) It is clear, therefore, that if any party relies on the strength of the British bayonet for the protection of its supposed interests, there can be no real co operation between it and other communities.
('45', 213, 10, 22, 436336) Our culture is substantially the same as yours; although in externals we may differ.
('45', 213, 10, 23, 436421) I wish we couldtake a leaf out of the history of China in this respect where the
('45', 213, 11, 24, 436502) 1 This question and its answer are taken from Young India.
('45', 214, 0, 1, 436561) VOL.45 : 4 FEBRUARY, 1929, 11 MAY, 1929 215
('45', 214, 1, 2, 436605) Confucians, Buddhists, Christians and Mohammedans mingle together and regard themselves as Chinese rather than the followers of this or that religion.
('45', 214, 1, 3, 436756) Take Burma, Ceylon, Siam, Malaya, Japan and India— there is something fundamentally common between them all, which should make it possible for them to co operate with each other in combating the common danger of Western exploitation.
('45', 214, 2, 4, 436990) Q. What line of action do you consider we should adopt in view of our present political condition in Burma?
('45', 214, 3, 5, 437098) A. The conditions in India and Burma, so far as I can see, are much the same.
('45', 214, 3, 6, 437176) I have there[fore] the same remedy to recommend to both, i.e., non violent non co operation.
('45', 214, 3, 7, 437269) But I am no judge of the local situation.
('45', 214, 3, 8, 437311) You should study the movement carefully and evolve a policy of national action in accordance with your peculiar environment and social conditions.
('45', 214, 3, 9, 437458) I do not want a mere mechanical imitation on your part.
('45', 214, 3, 10, 437514) There must be a conviction behind it, a determination to put it into practice.
('45', 214, 3, 11, 437593) My opinion I consider to be worth nothing of only because I cannot remain here to enforce it.
('45', 214, 3, 12, 437687) You say you have no powerful organization in your country that can mobilize you to common action like the National Congress in India.
('45', 214, 3, 13, 437821) The best thing for you, therefore, is to have a body answering to the Congress in India, a body of pure and selfless workers who would depend not on the strength of numbers but on the strength of quality.
('45', 214, 4, 14, 438026) Q. Are Indian leaders willing to discuss things with Burmans regarding the allocation of subjects?
('45', 214, 5, 15, 438125) A. I see no reason why they should not.
('45', 214, 6, 16, 438165) The Saydos complained to Gandhiji that they had no central body in Burma that could effectively mobilize their nation to action.
('45', 214, 6, 17, 438294) Gandhiji told them that the remedy lay in their own hands, if they could only play their part.
('45', 214, 6, 18, 438389) In this land of monks and monasteries, where women enjoy such freedom and equality of status with men, where the people are so simple minded, with such an amazing faith, you should be able to work wonders if you Phoongys would only shake off lethargy and inertia.
('45', 214, 6, 19, 438653) Yours should not be merely passive spirituality that spends itself out in idle meditation, but it should be an active thing which will carry the war into the enemy’s camp and set the spirit of Burma ablaze from one corner of the land to the other.
('45', 214, 6, 20, 438901) It should burn out allthe sloth in you and the impurity from your surroundings.
('45', 214, 6, 21, 438981) You will
('45', 214, 7, 22, 438990) 1 What follows has been taken from Young India.

('45', 215, 1, 3, 439283) You have renounced the world and taken to a life of religion.

('45', 215, 2, 9, 439776) 198. SPEECH TO LABOURERS, RANGOON 1
('45', 215, 3, 10, 439812) March 10, 1929
('45', 215, 4, 11, 439827) Perhaps you do not know that at the time of the Tilak Swaraj Fund collection I was offered fifty thousand rupees as subscription to the Fund if only I would visit a professional performance for ten minutes.
('45', 215, 4, 12, 440034) But I declined.
('45', 215, 4, 13, 440050) It is not that I disdain to mix with and move among the professional actors’ world, for there is no class of humanity with which I do not claim kinship; but a person in my position has necessarily to guide his conduct not merely with reference to himself but also to the effect that his example might have on others.
('45', 215, 4, 14, 440367) Whatever may be the pros and cons of going to the public theatre, it is a patent fact that it has undermined the morals and ruined the character of many a youth in this country.
('45', 215, 4, 15, 440545) You grown up people, may regard yourselves as immune from the insidious effects of the theatre on yourselves, but you ought to have regard for your little children whose innocence you expose to an unconscionable strain by taking them to questionable performances.
('45', 215, 4, 16, 440809) Look around you.
('45', 215, 4, 17, 440826) We are situated in the midst of a raging fire.
('45', 215, 4, 18, 440873) The cinema, the stage, the race course, the drink booth and the opium den—all these enemies ofsociety that have sprung up under the fostering influence of the present system threaten us on all sides.
('45', 215, 4, 19, 441073) Is it any wonder, then,

('45', 223, 1, 2, 451080) 211. SPEECH AT GUJARATIS’ MEETING, MOULMEIN
('45', 223, 2, 3, 451124) March 12, 1929
('45', 223, 3, 4, 451139) You are busy, but I am busier still; so you should understand how every minute of mine is precious.
('45', 223, 3, 5, 451239) I was shocked to hear that you had collected only Rs. 5,000. Do you know why I roam about so much?
('45', 223, 3, 6, 451338) I feel much exhausted and during this year the exhaustion has reached the limit.
('45', 223, 3, 7, 451419) I wish to take some rest, but how can I do so when I don’t allow others to take any?
('45', 223, 3, 8, 451504) And how can I allow any rest to people?
('45', 223, 3, 9, 451544) When our house is on fire, how can we afford to be lying in bed?
('45', 223, 3, 10, 451609) If there is a fire, even a sick person lying in bed would get up and try to extinguish it.
('45', 223, 3, 11, 451700) Today the whole country is on fire and the soul of India is being destroyed.
('45', 223, 3, 12, 451777) But those who are asleep are not even aware of the fire.
('45', 223, 3, 13, 451834) Once a cousin of mine was sleeping in a house which caught fire.
('45', 223, 3, 14, 451899) He was not aware of it and took to his heels only when he was awakened.
('45', 223, 3, 15, 451971) If we remain asleep, the fire will consume us too.
('45', 223, 3, 16, 452022) I have come here to awaken those who are asleep.
('45', 223, 3, 17, 452071) To the Burmese I may give something, if I can.
('45', 223, 3, 18, 452118) But from you I have come to take.
('45', 223, 3, 19, 452152) You will be unhappy, and you ought to be, to know that most of the khadi work today is in the hands of Marwaris.
('45', 223, 3, 20, 452265) I want the Gujaratis to take up that burden.
('45', 223, 3, 21, 452310) We in Gujarat have a unique Vidyapith.
('45', 223, 3, 22, 452349) I am not exaggerating if I say that it is a centre of Gujarat’s public life and social work.
('45', 223, 3, 23, 452442) Have you heard of Dr. Pranjivandas Mehta who has donated Rs. 10,000 for the school here?
('45', 223, 3, 24, 452531) It was his ambition at one time to devote one half of his time in Gujarat and the other half in Burma.
('45', 223, 3, 25, 452634) After making money in Burma, he wanted to set up a Bank in Gujarat from which I could keep on drawing as much money as I needed for national work.
('45', 223, 3, 26, 452781) In short, we had arrived at an agreement that he should make money to his heart’s content and I should take money to my heart’s content and work away to my heart’s content.
('45', 223, 3, 27, 452954) Once Gokhaleji had also given me a similar assurance.
('45', 223, 3, 28, 453008) But he is now no more, and Dr. Pranjivandas Mehta has become an invalid.
('45', 223, 3, 29, 453081) So who is going to support me?
('45', 223, 3, 30, 453112) I want the Gujaratis to bear that burden.
('45', 223, 3, 31, 453154) I do not ask for crores from you.
('45', 223, 3, 32, 453188) I have never asked for more than what I need.
('45', 223, 3, 33, 453234) I cabled Gokhale from South Africa: “Do not send me more money.” But he went on sending it.
('45', 223, 3, 34, 453326) The result was that I saved and brought back Rs. 2 1/2 lakhs and donated it to the Imperial Citizenship Association, and the amount is now being spent for Indians living in foreign Colonies.
('45', 223, 3, 35, 453517) But my method of work is different.
('45', 223, 3, 36, 453553) I do not carry
('45', 224, 0, 1, 453568) VOL.45 : 4 FEBRUARY, 1929, 11 MAY, 1929 225
('45', 224, 1, 2, 453612) on my work with interest on capital, but with the courage of the people.
('45', 224, 1, 3, 453685) I place my budget before the people every year and tell them that, if they like my work, they should find the money for it.
('45', 224, 1, 4, 453809) How much money could my firm of Daridranarayana need?
('45', 224, 1, 5, 453863) If you can find out how slowly a fire is extinguished, you could know how much money will satisfy my hunger.
('45', 224, 1, 6, 453972) In spite of all this, I tell you that, if someone gives me sixty crore rupees, I would be unable to utilize that sum because I do not have so many workers.
('45', 224, 1, 7, 454128) God has created a protective fence by having man’s power circumscribed.
('45', 224, 1, 8, 454200) I therefore ask for only as much today as I can handle.
('45', 224, 1, 9, 454256) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 24 3 1929
('45', 224, 2, 10, 454293) 212. SPEECH AT MOULMEIN 1
('45', 224, 3, 11, 454319) March 12, 1929
('45', 224, 4, 12, 454334) Those who believe in the teaching of the Buddha as you do cannot afford to pass a single moment in idleness.
('45', 224, 4, 13, 454443) The great Nature has intended us to earn our bread in the sweat of our brow.
('45', 224, 4, 14, 454520) Everyone therefore who idles away a single minute becomes to that extent a burden upon his neighbours, and to do so is to commit a breach of the very first lesson of ahimsa.
('45', 224, 4, 15, 454694) Ahimsa is nothing if not a well balanced exquisite consideration for one’s neighbour, and an idle man is wanting in that elementary consideration...The remedy that I can commend to you for the deplorable state of things is the same as I have recommended to my countrymen in India.
('45', 224, 4, 16, 454975) You have got enough weavers in this beautiful land.
('45', 224, 4, 17, 455027) But they instead of working for the good of the nation are slaving away for a foreign capitalist because it is to foreign yarn that they are applying their skill and workmanship.
('45', 224, 4, 18, 455206) If therefore you will avoid helplessness, if you will become self contained and happy and not become semi starved as we in India are, you will take my word and revert to the spinning wheel while there is still time.
('45', 224, 4, 19, 455422) Young India, 11 4 1929

('45', 225, 1, 2, 455556) 213. LETTER TO D. 1
('45', 225, 2, 3, 455576) MOULMEIN, March 13, 1929
('45', 225, 3, 4, 455601) DEAR FRIEND, I have your letter.
('45', 225, 3, 5, 455634) You are unnecessarily nervous.
('45', 225, 3, 6, 455665) I spoke to Sjt.
('45', 225, 3, 7, 455681) Birla when on my way to Calcutta I passed through Delhi on the 2nd instant.
('45', 225, 3, 8, 455757) It was lapse of memory on his part to tell you that I had suggested Rs. 120 150. I had given him the very figure that you had mentioned to me, i.e., Rs. 175. But now you say you require Rs. 200. Whether Rs. 200 is the minimum or not, you would require Rs. 175 at least.
('45', 225, 3, 9, 456027) I would ask you to be patient and hopeful.
('45', 225, 3, 10, 456070) Birla is anxious to accommodate you.
('45', 225, 3, 11, 456107) You have specialized in theoretical philosophy, you must specialize now in applied philosophy.
('45', 225, 3, 12, 456202) Philosophy to be worth anything has got to be applied in one’s own life.
('45', 225, 3, 13, 456275) A philosopher must be brave and absolutely to the point, whereas your letters are unusually long.
('45', 225, 3, 14, 456373) Do not shower compliments on me or Sjt.
('45', 225, 3, 15, 456413) If he accommodates you or if I do anything for you, it is from a sense of duty.
('45', 225, 3, 16, 456493) And duty carries no merit with it.
('45', 225, 3, 17, 456528) I want you to feel certain that work will be found for you giving you not less than Rs. 175 and not more than Rs. 200. If there is a hitch, you will please write to me.
('45', 225, 3, 18, 456697) I leave here on the 21st instant and reach Calcutta on the 26th and Delhi in the afternoon of the 27th instant.
('45', 225, 3, 19, 456809) I hope you will not mind this letter.
('45', 225, 3, 20, 456847) Good as you are, I want you to be better and I want you to be also a practiser of the philosophy you teach.
('45', 225, 4, 21, 456955) Yours sincerely, SJT.
('45', 225, 4, 22, 456977) D. CAWNPORE
('45', 225, 5, 23, 456989) From a microfilm: S.N. 15379
('45', 225, 6, 24, 457018) 1 A draft of this letter dated March 12 is also available (S.N. 13378).
('45', 225, 6, 25, 457090) It appears the letter was finalized and sent the following day with certain verbal variations.

('45', 226, 1, 2, 457229) 214. LETTER TO SIR CHARLES TEGART
('45', 226, 2, 3, 457263) MOULMEIN, March 13, 1929
('45', 226, 3, 4, 457288) DEAR FRIEND, I hope to attend Court on the appointed date.
('45', 226, 3, 5, 457347) But I think it is due to you to tell you that I have a long standing appointment for 30th March in Kathiawar.
('45', 226, 3, 6, 457457) A Conference there depends on my presence.
('45', 226, 3, 7, 457500) If therefore I am allowed to be free I shall have to leave Calcutta on the 26th instant by the Delhi Express.
('45', 226, 3, 8, 457610) I hope therefore that you would please see to the case being finished before the time of departure from Howrah.
('45', 226, 4, 9, 457722) Yours sincerely,
('45', 226, 5, 10, 457739) SIR CHARLES TEGART COMMISSIONER OF POLICE CALCUTTA

('45', 226, 8, 13, 457851) MOULMEIN, March 13, 1929
('45', 226, 9, 14, 457876) CHHAGANLAL, Today also the mail is about to leave, and so I write only this.
('45', 226, 9, 15, 457953) Everything is going on all right.
('45', 226, 9, 16, 457987) I think of all of you.
('45', 226, 9, 17, 458010) Everyone must have recovered.
('45', 226, 9, 18, 458040) It would be good if all of you sat in the sun every morning with your bodies exposed.
('45', 226, 9, 19, 458126) If anyone falls ill, he should immediately stop eating, take only water and have motions with the help of an enema.

('45', 227, 1, 2, 458394) 216. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, MOULMEIN
('45', 227, 2, 3, 458434) March 13, 1929
('45', 227, 3, 4, 458449) After expressing pleasure in having Burmese majority among the audience, Mahatma Gandhi spoke about the drinking habit.
('45', 227, 3, 5, 458569) I was intensely pained to learn yesterday that the drink evil was on the increase and I was intensely pained to learn that the drink revenue amounted to one third of the land revenue.
('45', 227, 3, 6, 458753) It is a terrific thing to contemplate for any country in the world, but it is nothing less than suicidal in a country like Burma where climatic conditions are totally opposed to the drink habit.
('45', 227, 3, 7, 458948) I know what the habit is doing in India.
('45', 227, 3, 8, 458989) A serious responsibility rests on the shoulders of people living in towns.
('45', 227, 3, 9, 459064) I would like the leaders of public opinion in Burma to consider this thing seriously and make every endeavour to root this thing out.
('45', 227, 3, 10, 459198) Whatever may be true of countries with cold climates I am sure that in a climate like ours there is no need for drink whatsoever.
('45', 227, 3, 11, 459328) Nothing but ruin stares a nation in the face that is a prey to the drink habit.
('45', 227, 3, 12, 459408) History records that empires have been destroyed through the habit.
('45', 227, 3, 13, 459476) We have it in India that the great community to which Shri Krishna belonged was ruined by that habit.
('45', 227, 3, 14, 459578) This monstrous evil was undoubtedly one of the contributory factors in the fall of Rome.
('45', 227, 3, 15, 459667) If therefore you will live decently you will shun this evil whilst there is yet time.
('45', 227, 4, 16, 459753) Addressing the Burmese ladies, Mahatma Gandhi drew their attention to two things: their taste in foreign fineries and smoking habit.
('45', 227, 4, 17, 459886) He fell in love with the men and women of Burma soon after his arrival and his love would have been heightened, if ladies had not gone so much for foreign silk.
('45', 227, 4, 18, 460047) He hoped that Burmese ladies would take a lead in the matter.
('45', 227, 4, 19, 460109) You are enjoying a freedom which no other women on earth are enjoying at the present moment.
('45', 227, 4, 20, 460202) You are noted for your industry and your skill.
('45', 227, 4, 21, 460250) You have great organizing capacity and if you will but revise your taste for foreign fineries and take to heart the message of simplicity that I have given you, you will revolutionize your life.
('45', 227, 5, 22, 460445) I have really less courage to speak about the terrible curse of
('45', 227, 6, 23, 460509) 1 This paragraph is extracted from Mahadev Desai’s account of Gandhiji’s tour in Burma.
('45', 227, 6, 24, 460597) 2 This and the following paragraph are from Young India.
('45', 228, 0, 1, 460654) VOL.45 : 4 FEBRUARY, 1929, 11 MAY, 1929 229
('45', 228, 1, 2, 460698) smoking.
('45', 228, 1, 3, 460707) But I understand that throughout Burma I shall not find a single man or woman free from this habit.
('45', 228, 1, 4, 460807) We who come from India are painfully surprised to see the beautiful Burmese women disfigure their mouths by cheroots and cigars.
('45', 228, 1, 5, 460936) But I know that it is a most difficult thing to speak about an evil which is enveloping the whole world.
('45', 228, 1, 6, 461041) If you have heard the name of Tolstoy I quote his authority to show that Tolstoy being an inveterate smoker himself was speaking from experience when he said that tobacco dulled the intellect of man, let alone other senses.
('45', 228, 1, 7, 461265) Indeed he cites examples to show that most deliberate crimes have been committed under the influence of smoke, and in one of his beautiful stories he pictures the villain of the piece as committing murder not after drink but after having had a smoke.
('45', 228, 1, 8, 461516) Although it is perfectly true that the smoke habit is on the increase and it has amongst its supporters many of the brilliant men of the world, there is a spirit of resistance against it and the opponents are some of the best men in the West and great moralists.
('45', 228, 2, 9, 461779) Gandhiji advised Indians to lead such life as people would think well of them.
('45', 228, 2, 10, 461858) He added that he came to collect money for khaddar and appealed to help him with money and take to khaddar.
('45', 228, 2, 11, 461966) Mahatma Gandhi told the Burmese audience that he came with a selfish mercenary motive having no right to ask them or expect anything from them.
('45', 228, 3, 12, 462110) The Hindustan Times, 16 3 1929, and Young India, 11 4 1929
('45', 228, 4, 13, 462169) 217. BE TRUE
('45', 228, 5, 14, 462182) I promised to give a free rendering of a remarkable address in Sindhi presented to me by the students of Hyderabad.
('45', 228, 5, 15, 462298) 1 Much other work crowded it out.
('45', 228, 5, 16, 462332) I now give it below: We welcome you heartily on behalf of the Hyderabad students.
('45', 228, 5, 17, 462414) We are aware that we are not entitled to have you in our midst as we have not carried out your precepts; but we hope that our hearts would respond after having heard your spoken word.
('45', 228, 5, 18, 462598) We will not deceive you.
('45', 228, 5, 19, 462623) We therefore propose to open out our hearts to you.
('45', 228, 5, 20, 462675) Our town is a centre of education.
('45', 228, 5, 21, 462710) Compared with the other towns, we have a larger proportion of those who have passed the Indian Civil Service examination.
('45', 228, 5, 22, 462832) We have one college here, three high schools for boys, two for girls and numerous other
('45', 228, 6, 23, 462920) 1Vide “Sind Impressions”, February 21, 1929.
('45', 229, 0, 1, 462965) 230 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('45', 229, 1, 2, 463007) English and Sindhi schools.
('45', 229, 1, 3, 463035) In the English schools alone there are 4,000 students.
('45', 229, 1, 4, 463090) But out of these, unfortunately there are not more than 22 or 25 students wearing pure khadi and there cannot be more than 3 or 4 per cent wearing indigenous mill cloth.
('45', 229, 1, 5, 463260) The others wear indifferently swadeshi and videshi.
('45', 229, 1, 6, 463312) The vast majority only wear videshi.
('45', 229, 1, 7, 463349) You know well enough that our living is extravagant.
('45', 229, 1, 8, 463402) We incline towards the English language and Western civilization rather than towards our mother tongue and our own culture.
('45', 229, 1, 9, 463526) We cannot show much of service or simplicity, aware as we are of the poverty of our country.
('45', 229, 1, 10, 463619) We know that it is good for the country that we should use khadi and swadeshi articles; but we regret that we were unmoved even when the heart rending cry of the flood stricken fell on our ears.
('45', 229, 1, 11, 463814) And this indifference is the cause of the absence of our response to the general distress surrounding us.
('45', 229, 1, 12, 463920) Our association has been doing some work during the last four years.
('45', 229, 1, 13, 463989) But there is not much in it of which we can make any boast.
('45', 229, 1, 14, 464049) We are ashamed to have to refer to the evil custom of deti leti.
('45', 229, 1, 15, 464114) In spite of having received higher education we do not hesitate to squeeze thousands of rupees from the wife’s relations.
('45', 229, 1, 16, 464236) Some of us regard it as our birthright to obtain money through our wives.
('45', 229, 1, 17, 464310) Many have no sense of self respect.
('45', 229, 1, 18, 464346) In spite of the higher education amongst girls, hardly half a dozen have been courageous enough to resent it as insult to have to buy their husbands.
('45', 229, 1, 19, 464496) Recently there has been a boycott resolution against those who countenance deti leti.
('45', 229, 1, 20, 464582) But people have not yet freed themselves from the evil.
('45', 229, 1, 21, 464638) But we do not want to give you only the dark side of the picture.
('45', 229, 1, 22, 464704) There is a bright side also.
('45', 229, 1, 23, 464733) You may feel sure that our capacity for good is limitless.
('45', 229, 1, 24, 464792) We can become torchbearers throughout Sind; for we are the inheritors of traditions left in this very town by Sadhu Hiranand, Diwan Navalrai, Bhai Balachandra, Diwan Dayaram and other such heroes.
('45', 229, 1, 25, 464989) Even at the present moment we have in our town men who are noted for their organizing capacity and discipline.
('45', 229, 1, 26, 465100) We have in our midst men who have shown capacity for leadership in the political, the social, the educational and the literary field.
('45', 229, 1, 27, 465234) They have taken a leading part in all patriotic endeavours.
('45', 229, 1, 28, 465294) Merchants of Hyderabad are to be found carrying on their enterprise in all parts of the globe.
('45', 229, 1, 29, 465389) We wish to make no parade of these things, but we want to
('45', 230, 0, 1, 465447) VOL.45 : 4 FEBRUARY, 1929, 11 MAY, 1929 231
('45', 230, 1, 2, 465491) show that we are not devoid of capacity for work or service.
('45', 230, 1, 3, 465552) If our energies can be once organized, it is possible to show good progress.
('45', 230, 1, 4, 465629) We want to feel that we have not forfeited the right to your affection because we have not acted up to your precepts, because we know that it would be only through your affection that our hearts will expand.
('45', 230, 1, 5, 465837) I have given a free rendering of this address first because I want to keep the students to their promise and secondly because it may serve as an example to other students.
('45', 230, 1, 6, 466009) Let me remind the students of Hyderabad that although they did not know the contents of the address before it was read to me, in answer to the question deliberately put by me, they with one voice endorsed the sentiments expressed in the address and promised that they would make every endeavour to make up for past indifference and neglect.
('45', 230, 1, 7, 466350) I therefore expect them to boycott completely foreign cloth and take to khadi.
('45', 230, 1, 8, 466429) I expect them to boycott deti leti once for all.
('45', 230, 1, 9, 466478) For the other students let this address be a model.
('45', 230, 1, 10, 466530) Addresses containing mere praise of leaders are really useless.
('45', 230, 1, 11, 466594) Those who need such praise should not have any address presented to them.
('45', 230, 1, 12, 466668) If addresses are presented to those whom students really love and honour they should contain references that might be of some service to them.
('45', 230, 1, 13, 466811) I do not wish to suggest that every address should be like this one.
('45', 230, 1, 14, 466880) But I do suggest that every address should have a local touch, a local significance and should refer to some matter of importance.
('45', 230, 1, 15, 467011) Real affection is not shown through praise but through service.
('45', 230, 1, 16, 467075) Self purification is a preliminary process, an indispensable condition of real service.
('45', 230, 1, 17, 467163) I have therefore welcomed this address as a token of sincere desire on the part of the students of Hyderabad to go through this preliminary process of self purification, a consummation much to be desired during this year of grace and preparation.
('45', 230, 2, 18, 467410) Young India, 14 3 1929
('45', 231, 0, 1, 467433) 232 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('45', 231, 1, 2, 467475) 218. NOTES
('45', 231, 2, 3, 467486) THE OLD ENEMY
('45', 231, 3, 4, 467500) A friend from Akola sends the two following apparently dissimilar questions:
('45', 231, 4, 5, 467577) 1. How can a man overcome his passion?
('45', 231, 5, 6, 467616) 2. If A is in the habit of wearing khadi and he requests B to do the same and B regrets his inability to comply with A’s wishes, what is to be done in that case?
('45', 231, 5, 7, 467778) How can a husband induce his wife, if she refuses, to wear khadi?
('45', 231, 5, 8, 467844) As to the first, a man has first to give up everything that tends to excite or stimulate his passion and then to wait upon God for help.
('45', 231, 5, 9, 467981) As to the second, it is clear that there should be no compulsion about others adopting one’s views or habits.
('45', 231, 5, 10, 468091) My own experience is that example in such matters is an unfailing preceptor and whether for the khadi or for any other reform, we have to wait patiently for our neighbours to adopt it and remain staunch in our own adherence.
('45', 231, 5, 11, 468316) What I have said about A and B applies equally to the case of husband and wife.
('45', 231, 6, 12, 468396) POOR BOYS’ FUND
('45', 231, 7, 13, 468412) The head master of the New English School, Achra, writes as follows: 1
('45', 231, 8, 14, 468483) I am sorry that owing to my travels at the time the letter was received, it remained buried amongst my papers for nearly two months.
('45', 231, 8, 15, 468616) The amount has been already acknowledged but the letter has a value of its own apart from the collection.
('45', 231, 8, 16, 468722) For the teachers and the boys have responded not only to the letter of the appeal but also to its spirit in that they have determined to give up foreign goods and even tea.
('45', 231, 8, 17, 468895) I suggest to the teachers that the vow to give up foreign goods will not be kept up either by the teachers or by the boys.
('45', 231, 8, 18, 469018) It is too sweeping to be fulfilled.
('45', 231, 8, 19, 469054) For instance, neither the teachers nor the boys will give up, foreign books, nor foreign pins, nor foreign watches, nor foreign needles.
('45', 231, 8, 20, 469191) I suggest to them a revision of their vows.
('45', 231, 8, 21, 469235) It will be better if they will name the foreign articles which they will refrain from using.
('45', 231, 9, 22, 469328) 1 The letter is not reproduced here.
('45', 231, 9, 23, 469365) The students and teachers had sent a collection of Rs. 101 for Lajpat Rai Memorial Fund.
('45', 231, 9, 24, 469454) The head master had requested Gandhiji to reduce the price of khadi, for poor student at any rate.
('45', 232, 0, 1, 469553) VOL.45 : 4 FEBRUARY, 1929, 11 MAY, 1929 233
('45', 232, 1, 2, 469597) As to khadi, I have pointed out often enough that it is cheap at any price, so long as it is sold at the cost price plus a small addition for the upkeep of the stock where it is sold.
('45', 232, 1, 3, 469781) Let it be borne in mind that during the seven years of its career khadi has cheapened itself by 50 per cent.
('45', 232, 1, 4, 469890) If there was more patronage it would be cheaper still.
('45', 232, 1, 5, 469945) And why will not poor boys be taught to help themselves rather than that they should be taught to expect khadi at cheaper than cost price and thus to expect people poorer than themselves to give a gratuity?
('45', 232, 1, 6, 470152) Boys and girls should be taught to spin their own yarn during their idle hours.
('45', 232, 1, 7, 470232) I have suggested at least half an hour per day.
('45', 232, 1, 8, 470280) They can then even weave that yarn, or if that becomes difficult as it may well become so, send the yarn to an agent of the All India Spinners’ Association and get khadi of the same weight and containing yarn of the same count merely for the cost of weaving.
('45', 232, 2, 9, 470539) IN ITS GRIP
('45', 232, 3, 10, 470551) An Agra friend asks:
('45', 232, 4, 11, 470572) Have you insured your life?
('45', 232, 4, 12, 470600) Is there anything objectionable in this Western institution?
('45', 232, 4, 13, 470661) Some insurance companies invest the whole or major portion of their receipts in Government securities.
('45', 232, 4, 14, 470764) Do not these companies help, with the public money, a Government which you brand as Satanic?
('45', 232, 4, 15, 470857) Do they not make our lives dependent upon it and so create a tendency in us to foster its permanence to some extent?
('45', 232, 4, 16, 470974) If so, should patriotic persons be the agents of such companies or insure their life with them?
('45', 232, 4, 17, 471070) If this friend is a regular reader of Young India he should know that I did insure my life in 1901 and a short time after I gave up the policy because I felt that I was distrusting God and making my relatives in whose behalf the policy was taken dependent upon me or the money I might leave them rather than upon God and themselves.
('45', 232, 5, 18, 471403) The opinion arrived at when I gave up the policy has been confirmed by subsequent experience.

('45', 233, 1, 2, 472068) the case of the existing Government, we run helplessly into its arms.

('45', 233, 2, 9, 472824) FUNCTION OF KHADI
('45', 233, 3, 10, 472842) The same friend asks:

('45', 233, 4, 15, 473426) The correspondent is obviously ignorant of the past history of his own country and the present evolution of khadi.
