('45', 235, 2, 3, 476136) March 14, 1929
('45', 235, 3, 4, 476151) MADAM AND FRIENDS, I feel not a little embarrassed in having to address this meeting especially as I do not possess any knowledge about your activities nor was I prepared to face this audience.
('45', 235, 3, 5, 476345) I thought that I would have to meet all sorts of people who would come, some out of curiosity and others in order to know my views about temperance.
('45', 235, 3, 6, 476494) But I see that I am in front of an audience, if I may so name it, of specialists.
('45', 235, 3, 7, 476576) For I hope that you are all specialists in this work.
('45', 235, 3, 8, 476630) You, madam, have suggested that if an educative campaign is carried on amongst the people, and as a consequence of that propaganda people who are in the habit of drinking cease to visit liquor shops, there would be no liquor shops in existence.
('45', 235, 3, 9, 476875) I want to put before you my own experien ence without combating the view that has been suggested from the chair.
('45', 235, 3, 10, 476988) My work in connection with temperance began as early as 1893 when I went to South Africa.
('45', 235, 3, 11, 477078) When I saw my own people, my own countrymen drinking and even women drinking who would never think of drinking in India and as a result leading a life of the gutter, I saw that the task was an uphill one.
('45', 235, 3, 12, 477283) These men and women were not prepared to listen to any lectures on temperance, much less to any personal advice.
('45', 235, 3, 13, 477396) I saw too that some of them were perfectly helpless or they thought that they were helpless.
('45', 235, 3, 14, 477489) I adopted many measures, all such measures as were within the competence of a man who is without any authority.
('45', 235, 3, 15, 477601) But I cannot claim any degree of visible success for those efforts.
('45', 235, 3, 16, 477669) There was a kind of a “Liquor Commission” appointed by the Union Government after South Africa became a Union.
('45', 235, 3, 17, 477780) I gave evidence or rather wrote a note for that Commission, but I am again sorry to have to inform you that nothing came out of it.
('45', 235, 3, 18, 477912) The position in South Africa was and still remains somewhat curious and anomalous.
('45', 235, 3, 19, 477995) There are three different degrees of restriction on the possession and drinking of liquor.
('45', 235, 3, 20, 478086) The Bantus and the Zulus are prohibited from carrying bottles with them or from being served in canteens, and yet they do drink.
('45', 235, 3, 21, 478215) Indians may notpossess bottles, but they may drink as much as they like in the canteens, with the result especially to the women that I have described to you.
('45', 235, 3, 22, 478374) The white man is of course free.
('45', 235, 3, 23, 478407) There is no legislation in connection with him, but you may guess what I would like to say.
('45', 235, 3, 24, 478499) It is that the source of all this

('45', 236, 1, 2, 478668) evil comes from this freedom of the white men in South Africa.

('45', 236, 1, 5, 478978) There was as you are aware a hurricane temperance campaign in 1920 21. And you will not mind my saying to you that if we had then received whole hearted support from all the temperance organizations throughout the length and breadth of India, we would have achieved complete success.
('45', 236, 1, 6, 479262) If you are careful students of the temperance movement in India you would gain the knowledge from the Government reports that we were within an ace of complete success, at least in some provinces.
('45', 236, 1, 7, 479459) Many of the liquor dens were practically closed.
('45', 236, 1, 8, 479508) Hundreds of opium dens in Assam were deserted.
('45', 236, 1, 9, 479555) And then followed the tragedy.
('45', 236, 1, 10, 479586) It consisted in Government repression.
('45', 236, 1, 11, 479625) It was a shameful and sorry affair.
('45', 236, 1, 12, 479661) I admit that the movement had a political colour.
('45', 236, 1, 13, 479711) It was bound to have that political colour.
('45', 236, 1, 14, 479755) But the political motive should not have deterred temperance organizations from helping a movement that was essentially moral.
('45', 236, 1, 15, 479882) You will pardon me for taking you through this history which, if it is tragic, is also deeply interesting.
('45', 236, 1, 16, 479989) The repression came about in this fashion.
('45', 236, 1, 17, 480032) The Government revenue dwindled down at once in Bihar, in Assam, in the Central Provinces.
('45', 236, 1, 18, 480123) There was an onrush of feeling, a desire, a yearning for self purification.
('45', 236, 1, 19, 480199) That yearning came, I do not know how—we do not always know the mysterious ways in which God works.
('45', 236, 1, 20, 480299) But there is the fact that the political movement became also a movement of self purification, and in that onrush thousands of workers became volunteers to picket liquor shops and opium dens and the people also began to believe that it was their duty to desert the drinking booths.
('45', 236, 1, 21, 480581) The Government started repression and thousands of volunteers were thrown into jail for the offence of picketing drink and drug shops with the result that today all those canteens that were deserted and opium dens that were almost closed are, I am afraid, doing probably the same volume of business as they were doing prior to 1920 21. The moral that I would like to draw from this story is that in this connection in India and Burma—treating Burma as a separate entity for our argument—legislation has really to go hand in hand with educative propaganda if not to precede it.
('45', 236, 1, 22, 481158) I have not been able to study as carefully as I would like to have done the drink habit of the Burman.
('45', 236, 1, 23, 481261) I assure you that ever since I have come into touch with

('45', 237, 1, 2, 481360) Burmese opinion I am trying to learn from Burmese friends about this drink habit of the Burman, but I can speak about it only from second hand evidence as against India about which I can speak from first hand knowledge.

('45', 237, 1, 4, 481798) And this is an interesting piece of evidence that I am placing before you.

('45', 237, 1, 20, 483538) In a mighty country like America where drink was so common they have been able to declare prohibition; how much more easy should it be in India or Burma where liquor is not the fashion,where the vast majority of the people do not want liquor, where if you take a referendum you will get millions of signatures in favour of any representation for the introduction of prohibition legislation?

('45', 241, 10, 20, 490818) Mr. Gandhi replying jointly thanked for the addresses especially the women’s address and he was particularly happy that the lady who read the address had been jailed in a national cause.

('45', 245, 4, 10, 498833) 228. "STOMACH MAKES US SLAVES"
('45', 245, 5, 11, 498864) A Patidar writes: 3
('45', 245, 6, 12, 498884) The object of writing this letter is to create in the reader compassion for cows, buffaloes, etc.
('45', 245, 6, 13, 498982) It is a noble objective.
('45', 245, 6, 14, 499007) But the letter has had quite a different effect on me.
('45', 245, 6, 15, 499062) Such cruel slaughter of cows and buffaloes has now been going on for a long time.
('45', 245, 6, 16, 499144) The Hindus and Muslims of Bombay are a witness to it.
('45', 245, 6, 17, 499198) Not only that, they have been participants in this great violence.
('45', 245, 6, 18, 499265) Here it is not a question of religion in a narrow sense; there is here decline of dharma in a wider sense.
('45', 245, 6, 19, 499372) History provides many examples of even meat eaters showing compassion.
('45', 245, 6, 20, 499443) but meat eaters should show, towards the animals whose meat they eat, such compassion as they can.
('45', 245, 6, 21, 499542) Slaughter houses in the West are exemplary from this point of view.
('45', 245, 6, 22, 499610) There new ways are constantly devised and adopted so that cattle are killed instantaneously and suffer the minimum pain.
('45', 245, 6, 23, 499731) Total abstention from meat is of course the best compassion, butthose who cannot practise it should at least lessen the pain inflicted on animals.
('45', 245, 6, 24, 499878) This we do not see in the slaughter houses in India.

('45', 250, 1, 2, 506756) 235. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, MANDALAY 1
('45', 250, 2, 3, 506798) March 18, 1929
('45', 250, 3, 4, 506813) You have rightly reminded me that it was here in Mandalay that the great son of India, Lokamanya Tilak, was buried alive.
('45', 250, 3, 5, 506935) It was he who gave India the mantra of swaraj and in burying him alive the British Government had buried India alive.
('45', 250, 3, 6, 507053) The Lion of the Punjab also was similarly incarcerated here, and lest we should forget those things, Government recently buried alive Sjt.
('45', 250, 3, 7, 507192) Bose and numerous other sons of Bengal.
('45', 250, 3, 8, 507232) Mandalay is thus a place of pilgrimage for us Indians, and it is a remarkable coincidence that we are all sitting here today in the shadow of the walls of the fort and the prison sanctified by those sons of India.
('45', 250, 3, 9, 507446) In India it is a common saying that the way to swaraj is through Mandalay and the British Government has taught you too that great lesson by incarcerating India’s great sons here.
('45', 250, 3, 10, 507626) The way to swaraj is the way of suffering.
('45', 250, 3, 11, 507669) Indeed no country has come to its own without suffering and let Mandalay be an eternal reminder both to you and to us of that great truth.
('45', 250, 3, 12, 507808) You who do well to own the Buddha as your teacher will do well to explore the limitless possibilities of non violence.
('45', 250, 3, 13, 507927) There are things in your practice which I have not been able to reconcile with the teachings of the Buddha but I do not propose to abuse your great hospitality by being critical at this moment.
('45', 250, 3, 14, 508121) You have, as I conceive it, one of the greatest truths that the world can ever have uttered by one of the greatest teachers of mankind, viz., ahimsa.
('45', 250, 3, 15, 508271) If there had been a perfectly silent and a quiet atmosphere I would gladly have spoken to you upon that quiet doctrine.
('45', 250, 3, 16, 508391) As it is I can only ask you to study the doctrine and reduce it to practice in every act of your lives.
('45', 250, 3, 17, 508495) It is infinitely greater than the gems and the diamonds people prize so much.
('45', 250, 3, 18, 508573) It can become, if you will make wise use of it, your own saving and the saving of mankind.

('45', 251, 6, 15, 509665) Delightful as my experiences of the people of Burma were when my visit some years ago was only confined to Rangoon and for a day only to Moulmein, that delight has been heightened by my experience during this tour even as far as Mandalay.

('45', 252, 1, 4, 510961) It radiates life and light and peace and happiness.
('45', 252, 1, 5, 511013) Why do we not see that light, that life, that peace and that happiness in a land that professes the law of ahimsa?
('45', 252, 1, 6, 511128) As I said in Mandalay only yesterday, it has appeared to me that the message of the Buddha, the Enlightened One, has only touched but the surface of the heart of Burma.
('45', 252, 1, 7, 511297) I would like to apply one or two tests.
('45', 252, 1, 8, 511337) Now I hold that where the law of ahimsa reigns supreme, there should be no jealousy, no unworthy ambition, no crime.
('45', 252, 1, 9, 511454) I read your criminal statistics and I find that you are not behindhand in the race for crime.
('45', 252, 1, 10, 511548) Murder on the slightest pretext seems to me to be fairly common in Burma.
('45', 252, 1, 11, 511622) I will therefore appeal to the friends on my lift (the Phoongys) who are supposed to be the repositories of the faith you have inherited from the Buddha.
('45', 252, 1, 12, 511776) Having travelled in Ceylon and now fairly long enough in Burma, I feel that we in India have perhaps more fully, though by no means as fully as possible, interpreted the message of the Buddha than you have done.
('45', 252, 1, 13, 511988) We have it in our Shastras that whenever things go wrong, good people and sages go in for tapasya otherwise known as austerities.
('45', 252, 1, 14, 512118) Gautama himself, when he saw oppression, injustice and death around him, and when he saw darkness in front of him, at the back of him and on each side of him, went out in the wilderness and remained there fasting and praying in search of light.
('45', 252, 1, 15, 512363) And if such penance was necessary for him who was infinitely greater than all of us put together, how much more necessary is it for us, no matter whether we are dressed in yellow or not?
('45', 252, 1, 16, 512550) My friends, if you will become torch bearers lighting the path of a weary world towards the goal of ahimsa, there is no other way out of it, save that of self purification and penance.
('45', 252, 1, 17, 512735) So many priests are sitting here today.
('45', 252, 1, 18, 512775) If some of them will take upon themselves the work of interpreting the message of the Buddha, they will revolutionize life.
('45', 252, 1, 19, 512899) You will not be guided by rigid traditions, but will search your hearts and your scriptures and tear the hidden meaning lying behind the written word and vivify your surroundings.
('45', 252, 1, 20, 513079) You will then find upon searching your hearts that it is not enough not to take animal life, but you must see to it that it is not taken for the pleasures of the palate.
('45', 252, 1, 21, 513249) You will then at once realize that it is inconsistent with the doctrine of love for all that lives to turn our mouths into chimneys.
('45', 252, 1, 22, 513382) I understand that drink is on the increase in a people so simple hearted as the Burmese and in a climate which does not necessitate the drinking of the fiery liquid.

('45', 253, 1, 2, 513590) You will immediately see on further research that there is no room for one who loves everything that lives to have fear lurking in his breast.

('45', 254, 4, 10, 516272) Whenever it was possible he always accepted invitations from Muslim bodies and that was why he paid a visit to the Islamia National School and the Zanniatul Islam Girls’s School.
('45', 254, 4, 11, 516451) Unfortunately the political atmosphere in India had become surcharged with distrust and suspicion which had taken the place of mutual trust and confidence in the hearts of both Hindus and Muslims.

('45', 254, 4, 13, 516723) He said that times without number and he would ask them to understand that his faith was, if possible, firmer today than ever before.
('45', 254, 4, 14, 516857) There could be no real swaraj for India without the willing co operation and heart unity of the Hindus and the Muslims and that such unity and co operation were bound to come sooner or later.

('45', 254, 4, 17, 517338) The other day he spoke at length at the Jubilee Hall about the student movement and purity and he felt it was unnecessary for him to repeat the same here and he asked them to take to their heart and put into practice what he said on that occasion and not merely keep it in their intellects.
('45', 254, 4, 18, 517629) When he went to Aligarh College in 1915 he had spoken to his Muslim friends there and hoped from that College would emerge men who would be prepared to turn fakirs for the political uplift of India and Islam.
('45', 254, 4, 19, 517838) Lastly he considered that any service rendered to the country was service rendered to religion.

('45', 255, 4, 8, 518741) Conceit and ignorance often go together.

('45', 255, 4, 10, 518809) The latest instance is to be found in his answers to the House of Commons in reply to questions on the burning of foreign cloth in Calcutta 2 made world famous by the wanton interference of the Calcutta police.
('45', 255, 4, 11, 519020) I give below the answers of the noble Earl and the correct version against each answer: EARL WINTERTON’S ANSWERS CORRECT VERSION
('45', 255, 5, 12, 519149) Mr. Gandhi was not arrested.
('45', 255, 5, 13, 519178) I was arrested and released on signing a Personal recognizance bond.
('45', 255, 6, 14, 519247) The Government of Bengal had intimated that the lighting of bonfire to burn foreign cloth was illegal.
('45', 255, 7, 15, 519350) The Government of Bengal never intimated that the burning of foreign cloth was illegal.
('45', 255, 7, 16, 519438) The Commissioner of Police at Calcutta notified that the burning of foreign cloth in or near thoroughfares or public streets in Calcutta was illegal in terms of the Police act.

('45', 258, 2, 3, 524197) A VISIT TO MISS MAYO
('45', 258, 3, 4, 524218) Dinabandhu Andrews writes as follows about his visit to Miss Mayo: 1
('45', 258, 4, 5, 524287) I felt it necessary, since I had imputed political motives to Miss Mayo in my first article on Mother India, to see her personally; and an opportunity occurred.
('45', 258, 5, 6, 524448) After a very long conversation with her, during which she herself did most of the talking, it seemed clear to me that she had gone out independently without a conscious political motive….
('45', 258, 6, 7, 524636) But we cannot expect a personality such as that of Miss Mayo ever to understand.
('45', 258, 6, 8, 524717) Therefore, when she writes about India, it is bound to be a misinterpretation.
('45', 258, 7, 9, 524796) This thought grew upon me, hour after hour, as I listened to Miss Mayo and spoke to her in reply.
('45', 258, 7, 10, 524894) I am sorry that I uncharitably imputed political motives to her, which I now withdraw; but at the same time I experienced, while talking with her, a sense of the great and vast dividing rift, which is extending between those who are absorbed in the superficial aspects of Western life and ourselves.
('45', 258, 7, 11, 525194) Dinabandhu has given me the option of publishing this note and whilst in fairness to Miss Mayo, I have thought it necessary to publish it, it is due to the public for me to say that in spite of Dinabandhu Andrews’s retraction, I am not shaken in my opinion that the book bears in it patent evidence of a political bias.
('45', 258, 7, 12, 525514) It contains falsehoods which the authoress must have known to be such.
('45', 258, 7, 13, 525585) She has since written things which too are probably 2 false.
('45', 258, 7, 14, 525646) In the face of such patent facts, evidence to the contrary must be held to be irrelevant.

('45', 265, 3, 9, 536677) 250. PURDAH AND SUNLIGHT
('45', 265, 4, 10, 536702) Dr. Kathleen Olga Baden was for a number of years the chief medical officer in a women’s hospital in Kashmir.
('45', 265, 4, 11, 536812) In addition, she has had a good deal of medical experience also.
('45', 265, 4, 12, 536877) Kashmir has a cold climate and is considered good for health, but it has been her experience that it has proved inimical to the health of middle class women.
('45', 265, 4, 13, 537035) Those women who wear the burqa hardly ever stir out of their houses.
('45', 265, 4, 14, 537104) As a result, their bones get softened.
('45', 265, 4, 15, 537143) The pelvis particularly becomes so much softened and deformed that they suffer great pain at child birth.
('45', 265, 4, 16, 537249) Some of them become too weak to walk and even become bow legged.
('45', 265, 4, 17, 537314) This lady has written a little booklet on her experiences.
('45', 265, 4, 18, 537373) She has expressed the opinion in this booklet that the sole reason, or the chief reason at any rate, why so many women in Kashmir are reduced to such a state is that they are kept away from sunlight.
('45', 265, 4, 19, 537573) They remain confined within their homes where they do not even get daylight, how then could they get any sun?
('45', 265, 4, 20, 537683) Adducing a number of examples and arguments, she proves that those who stay away from sunlight become weak in constitution, their bones get softened, their growth is arrested and they become pale and lackluster.
('45', 265, 4, 21, 537895) On the other hand, those who enjoy open air and light and get the sun’s rays direct on their skin develop a strong constitution.
('45', 265, 4, 22, 538024) They grow to be tall and free from anaemia and diseases like tuberculosis.
('45', 265, 4, 23, 538099) She proves in the course of her article that even a thing like cut glass intervening between a man’s skin and the sun’s rays prevents his receiving the essential health giving elements from the sun.
('45', 265, 4, 24, 538298) Hence she suggests that every man and woman, and especially those women who wish to have children, should take a sun bath with their bodies bared, during the first quarter of the day.
('45', 265, 4, 25, 538482) This sun bath is not to be taken
('45', 266, 0, 1, 538515) VOL.45 : 4 FEBRUARY, 1929 11 MAY, 1929 267
('45', 266, 1, 2, 538558) under a very hot sun and it is to be taken in such a way that one does not feel cold while exposing one’s body to the sun but enjoys the sun’s warmth.
('45', 266, 1, 3, 538709) This lady writes that the chief cause of a number of complications arising at the time of child birth among Indian women is lack of sunlight.
('45', 266, 1, 4, 538851) The houses in India in which women remain confined have neither gardens nor open grounds where the women can walk about bare bodied.
('45', 266, 1, 5, 538984) It is her view that disappearance of the evil custom of the purdah will take time, hence, in the mean while, a condition must be created in which women who observe purdah getfacilities for sun bath and physical exercise.
('45', 266, 1, 6, 539205) Therefore she says there should be facilities in hospitals whereby, unobserved by men, women are able to receive the sun’s rays and walk about bare bodied.
('45', 266, 1, 7, 539361) Likewise, she recommends that there should be schools for girls also.
('45', 266, 1, 8, 539431) These should be located in open country so that no one may be able to observe the girls from terraces, or while passing along the road.
('45', 266, 1, 9, 539567) This sister observes that only harm and no good will result from the practice of making a house dark during summer.
('45', 266, 1, 10, 539683) From this little booklet what we can learn about women is first, that we should strive as hard as possible to put an end to the evil custom of the purdah.
('45', 266, 1, 11, 539838) Secondly, that no one—man or woman— should fear the sun, but should take a sun bath bare bodied for as long as possible.
('45', 266, 1, 12, 539959) After taking a bath in the morning, one should salute the sun a hundred times or more and repeat the Gayatri mantra.
('45', 266, 1, 13, 540076) It is being realized more and more that, while there is certainly spiritual significance and value in this, there is also an equally great worldly meaning and benefit.
('45', 266, 1, 14, 540244) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 24 3 1929
('45', 267, 0, 1, 540281) 268 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI

('45', 271, 7, 13, 548701) 257. STATEMENT IN THE COURT 2
('45', 271, 8, 14, 548731) CALCUTTA, March 26, 1929
('45', 271, 9, 15, 548756) Occupying the position I do in public life I owe an explanation to the Court and the public of my conduct which is the subject matter of this prosecution.
('45', 271, 9, 16, 548911) I am Chairman of the Foreign Cloth Boycott Committee appointed by the Working Committee of the National Congress.
('45', 271, 9, 17, 549025) The scheme of boycott sanctioned by the Working Committee includes burning of foreign cloth wherever it is possible.
('45', 271, 9, 18, 549142) Therefore I naturally advised collection and burning of foreign cloth at the meeting that was held at Shraddhanand Park.
('45', 271, 9, 19, 549263) The notice from the Commissioner of Police came upon me and my colleagues as a disturbing factor.
('45', 271, 9, 20, 549361) We saw at once that it was not meant for protection of property from danger of fire but it was meant to prevent the demonstration.
('45', 271, 9, 21, 549492) It was open to us to conduct the burning demonstration at a private place.
('45', 271, 9, 22, 549567) But two lawyers came to the conclusion that the interpretation sought to be put upon Section 66 of the Police Act was at least open to question, if not altogether wrong.
('45', 271, 10, 23, 549737) 1 This letter appears to have been written from Calcutta after Gandhiji’s return from Burma.
('45', 271, 10, 24, 549830) The presence of Rajendrababu is mentioned in the letter of this date to Mirabehn.
('45', 271, 10, 25, 549912) 2 Of the Chief Presidency Magistrate, Calcutta
('45', 272, 0, 1, 549959) VOL.45 : 4 FEBRUARY, 1929 11 MAY, 1929 273
('45', 272, 1, 2, 550002) We therefore decided to conduct the full demonstration at the Park as advertised and have the police interpretation tested in a Court of Law.
('45', 272, 1, 3, 550144) This boycott is not part of civil disobedience.
('45', 272, 1, 4, 550192) There was no intention to defy the police notice for the sake of defiance and courting imprisonment.
('45', 272, 1, 5, 550293) I made this absolutely clear in English within the hearing of the police at the meeting before I started the burning.
('45', 272, 1, 6, 550411) I believe that the Deputy Commissioner of Police was present whilst I was speaking.
('45', 272, 1, 7, 550495) I was therefore surprised and deeply pained to see the police, after the burning was well nigh over, swoop down upon the crowd surrounding the fire, charge it with their big lathis, disperse it and put out the dying embers.
('45', 272, 1, 8, 550719) The rest of the painful scene I may not describe here though I should gladly answer questions on it if the Court so desires.
('45', 272, 1, 9, 550844) I venture to submit that by taking the law into their own hands, especially in spite of my very clear statement above referred to, the Police put themselves in the wrong and should change places with me.
('45', 272, 1, 10, 551048) They should be the accused and my colleagues and I should be the complainants.
('45', 272, 1, 11, 551127) I have before now in other parts of the world been obliged to differ from police interpretations of laws and act contrary to their notices.
('45', 272, 1, 12, 551267) But they have recognized the civilized practice of testing the points involved in law courts without in the first instance prejudging the issue and thus running the risk of themselves breaking the law and, what is more, of inviting a disturbance of public peace.
('45', 272, 1, 13, 551530) I affirm that the crowd was absolutely peaceful and extremely well behaved.
('45', 272, 1, 14, 551606) There was no danger to the neighbouring property from the little fire that was lighted.
('45', 272, 1, 15, 551694) The site chosen for burning was well protected and isolated.
('45', 272, 1, 16, 551755) It was therefore the duty of the police to refrain from interfering with the peaceful and orderly demonstration.
('45', 272, 1, 17, 551868) Their interference in my opinion was rudely premature, extremely high handed and uncalled for.
('45', 272, 1, 18, 551963) In putting out the fire they usurped the fuction of the Court and anticipated its judgment.
('45', 272, 1, 19, 552055) If you believe the statement of facts I have made I ask Your Worship to discharge me and my colleagues and take such notice of the conduct of the police as may be open to you.
('45', 272, 1, 20, 552231) And this discharge I ask irrespective of the interpretation the Court may put upon the Section under which I am charged.
('45', 272, 1, 21, 552352) One word as to the interpretation of the Section.
('45', 272, 1, 22, 552402) Sen Gupta was one of the lawyer friends referred to in my speech at the Shraddhanand Park.
('45', 272, 1, 23, 552493) After having had another argument with him I
('45', 273, 0, 1, 552538) 274 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('45', 273, 1, 2, 552580) am clear in my mind that Shraddhanand Park is neither a street nor a thoroughfare within the meaning of the Section.
('45', 273, 1, 3, 552697) Since it is not the intention, so far as possible, of the Foreign Cloth Boycott Committee to offer civil disobedience in connection with the campaign, an authoritative interpreation of the Section is necessaray.
('45', 273, 1, 4, 552909) But I may not argue the legal point.
('45', 273, 1, 5, 552946) As to the three of my colleagues who are charged with the primary offence, I should like to state that the burning was actually started by me.
('45', 273, 1, 6, 553089) If therefore any offence has been committed by any of us, the primary offence has been committed by me and the rest three are but the secondary offenders.

('45', 275, 1, 2, 554923) 261. REPORT ON BURMA P. C. C. AFFAIRS
('45', 275, 2, 3, 554961) Confidential [Before March 27, 1929] 1
('45', 275, 3, 4, 555000) In virtue of the instructions given to me by the Working Committee, I inspected the affairs of the Burma P.C.C. The Committee exists only in name.
('45', 275, 3, 5, 555147) Sjt.V. Madanjit is the moving spirit.
('45', 275, 3, 6, 555185) He is the committee and everything.
('45', 275, 3, 7, 555221) There is no executive worth the name.
('45', 275, 3, 8, 555259) Hardly any meetings are held.
('45', 275, 3, 9, 555289) There is no volunteer organization attached to the B.P.C.C. Lawyers are, I was told, afraid to join the Congress.
('45', 275, 3, 10, 555403) There is no contact with the villages.
('45', 275, 3, 11, 555442) Members are enrolled once every year without reference to the registered ones.
('45', 275, 3, 12, 555521) V. Madanjit goes out and collects names and four annas.
('45', 275, 3, 13, 555577) The receipts barely cover his travelling expenses.
('45', 275, 3, 14, 555628) Madanjit is an honorary worker and capable of great sacrifice.
('45', 275, 3, 15, 555691) He has influence too among the people, but it is of a negative character.
('45', 275, 3, 16, 555765) He cannot take any constructive work from the people.
('45', 275, 3, 17, 555819) I could not get hold of any written constitution.
('45', 275, 3, 18, 555869) The Committee has practically no office unless the Khadi Bhandar address may be called an office.
('45', 275, 3, 19, 555967) It has no staff.
('45', 275, 3, 20, 555984) The nominal membership roll is about 800 of whom not more than 10 are Burmese.
('45', 275, 3, 21, 556063) The majority are Rangoon Indians.
('45', 275, 3, 22, 556097) There is a district committee in Akyab, but that too only in name.
('45', 275, 3, 23, 556164) In 1921 there were 5,600 members and 14 taluk committees.
('45', 275, 3, 24, 556222) The finances of the Committee, such as they are, are kept in a most business like manner by able Gujarati merchant.
('45', 275, 3, 25, 556338) I attach here to a copy of the audited account.
('45', 275, 3, 26, 556386) I saw the books.
('45', 275, 3, 27, 556403) They were in a good and clean condition.
('45', 275, 3, 28, 556444) There is a khadi bhandar run under the auspices of the A.I.S.A. It is run without any loss.
('45', 275, 3, 29, 556536) This bhandar may be claimed to be the only substantial and constructive activity carried on in the name of Congress, not that even in this store many people are taking a lively interest.
('45', 275, 3, 30, 556723) It is going on because there is business ability behind it.
('45', 275, 3, 31, 556783) There is a fair proportion of habitual khadi wearers in Rangoon and elsewhere among the Indian community.
('45', 275, 3, 32, 556889) The cry for separation of Burma has created a gulf between the Burmese and the Indians.
('45', 275, 3, 33, 556977) There is an anti separatist Burmese party too.
('45', 275, 3, 34, 557024) I have advised our people not to take sides and to let the Burmans

('45', 276, 1, 2, 557189) decide the question for themselves.
('45', 276, 1, 3, 557225) It is strange but true that an Indian party has claimed communal representation.
('45', 276, 1, 4, 557306) There is, too, in the growing national consciousness, resentment against Indians carrying on intercourse with Burmese women without any formal marriage.

('45', 276, 4, 7, 557490) 151, 1929. Courtesy: Nehru Memorial Museum and Library
('45', 276, 5, 8, 557545) 262. FALLACY OF FAVOURABLE BALANCES
('45', 276, 6, 9, 557581) A Hungarian professor asked me the other day to reconcile my statement about the growing poverty of India with her recurring favourable balance of trade.
('45', 276, 6, 10, 557735) The professor had not gone beyond the cities on India and his knowledge was naturally based upon the usual statistics.
('45', 276, 6, 11, 557854) The information derived from the statistics was enforced by the apparently prosperous appearance of the cities he had seen.
('45', 276, 6, 12, 557978) The honest doubt entertained by the learned professor is not improbably shared by many who study the orthodox economics in the orthodox manner.
('45', 276, 6, 13, 558122) It may be therefore worth while reproducing the gist of my reply for what it may be worth.
('45', 276, 6, 14, 558213) Suppose, I argued, that a country was owned by a certain number of slaveholders who compelled their slaves to grow foodgrains and other articles of value to the world, who paid them hardly enough to keep the wolf from the door, and themselves made enormous profits out of the grain thus grown and exported; suppose further that the total of these exports of grain, etc., was greater than the total imports of this country, the favourable trade balance would be no test of the prosperity of its people in general.
('45', 276, 6, 15, 558726) It could exist side by side with the growing poverty and degradation of the slaves.
('45', 276, 6, 16, 558810) I suggested to the professor that the position of India was not far removed from the slave ridden country imagined.
('45', 276, 6, 17, 558926) I therefore argued that in order accurately to understand the hidden meaning of the recurring favourable balances it was necessary to study the conditions of certain typical villages in India and to see also the villagers face to face.
('45', 276, 6, 18, 559162) Of what use I told him could an all India favourable balance be to the villagers, if they did not reap
('45', 277, 0, 1, 559265) 278 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('45', 277, 1, 2, 559307) the fruits thereof and if the villages betrayed, as I held they did, a process of continuing exhaustion?
('45', 277, 1, 3, 559412) The late Dadabhai Naoroji showed by telling figures how the wealth of India was drained away from year to year owing to the foreign rulers living their more than princely lives practically outside India even whilst they were nominally and physically living in India.
('45', 277, 1, 4, 559679) The favourable balance of India represents the continual bleeding process to which she is subjected in order to sustain a rule which is based not upon the goodwill of the people but upon a show of force which is kept up at an extraordinary expense of which a large part goes out of India.
('45', 277, 1, 5, 559968) It has been truly said by economists themselves that statistics can be made to prove two contradictory propositions.
('45', 277, 1, 6, 560085) It is therefore necessary for a prudent man who is not concerned with merely proving a preconceived proposition but who is concerned solely with finding the truth to probe beneath statistics and test independently every proposition deduced from them.
('45', 277, 1, 7, 560336) It is no doubt good to know the average depth of a river, but a non swimmer who on learning that its average depth is below his height attempts to ford it is likely to find a watery grave.
('45', 277, 1, 8, 560525) Even so will a man lose reputation for sanity who relies upon the mirage of statistics dressed up for him.
('45', 277, 1, 9, 560632) Just as a man who would ford a river must know its highest and its lowest depth, even so should a man desirous to make a valid use of statistical abstracts have access to the underlying figures and know how to handle them.
('45', 277, 1, 10, 560855) But the average man has neither the time nor the ability to study bewildering figures.
('45', 277, 1, 11, 560942) For him the real test is the experience of the village life, if he would know the condition of real India.
('45', 277, 1, 12, 561049) Such experience cannot be belied by any statistical jugglery.
('45', 277, 1, 13, 561111) Eye witnesses including English administrators whose interest it would be to find the contrary have testified that India has been growing poorer under the British regime.
('45', 277, 1, 14, 561282) Go to the villages and you will find misery and despair written in the faces of the inhabitants.
('45', 277, 1, 15, 561379) Both they and their cattle are underfed; mortality is on the increase, they have no resisting power when disease overtakes them.
('45', 277, 1, 16, 561508) It is well known that malaria is not a disease to dread if one has quinine and a good supply of pure milk.
('45', 277, 1, 17, 561615) Yet malaria carries away thousands of villagers year by year.
('45', 277, 1, 18, 561677) They may have quinine thrown at them but they cannot get milk for the convalescent period.
('45', 277, 1, 19, 561768) Their indebtedness
('45', 278, 0, 1, 561787) VOL.45 : 4 FEBRUARY, 1929 11 MAY, 1929 279
('45', 278, 1, 2, 561830) is increasing.
('45', 278, 1, 3, 561845) It is a blasphemy to impute it to marriage expenses and the like.
('45', 278, 1, 4, 561911) These are no new charage on their dwindling purse.
('45', 278, 1, 5, 561962) The story of hoarded wealth and conversion of silver coin into ornaments is a fable.
('45', 278, 1, 6, 562047) Millions have and had not silver or gold ornaments.
('45', 278, 1, 7, 562099) They wear hideous wooden, even stone bangles and rings which interfere with their free movement and undermine their health.
('45', 278, 1, 8, 562223) Their illiteracy is if anything on the increase.
('45', 278, 1, 9, 562272) These are no signs of growing prosperity.
('45', 278, 1, 10, 562314) Now let us glance at the nature of exports and imports.
('45', 278, 1, 11, 562370) The exports in 1927 28 were Rs. 309 croces, the imports over Rs. 231 crores.
('45', 278, 1, 12, 562447) The exports were principally raw products, e.g., cotton, foodgrains, oil seeds, hides and skins, metals and ores.
('45', 278, 1, 13, 562561) These could have remained in India ifwe had skill and capital enough to put into them or if we had a government that would regard it as its bounden duty to give us the necessary skill and to find the necessary capital.
('45', 278, 1, 14, 562780) The story of India’sexports is a story of our impotence and the criminal indifference of the Government to the well being of the people.
('45', 278, 1, 15, 562917) The imports include cotton manufactures Rs. 65 crores, artificial silk Rs. 4 crores, sugar Rs. 18 crores, metals and their manufactures Rs. 23 crores, motor vehicles Rs. 5 crores, liquors Rs. 3 crores, cigarettes nearly 2 crores.
('45', 278, 1, 16, 563147) These imports too tell the same tale of our impotence where it is not worse.
('45', 278, 1, 17, 563224) The imports of a country in a healthy state of progress should be such as the country may need for its growth.
('45', 278, 1, 18, 563335) The imports I have mentioned are not needed for our growth.
('45', 278, 1, 19, 563395) Liquor and cigarettes promote our degradation.
('45', 278, 1, 20, 563442) Cotton manufactures, the largest item among imports, discover our shame and wretchedness.
('45', 278, 1, 21, 563532) They remind us of what the villages must have been when they were manufacturing all that cloth in their own homes with their own hands.
('45', 278, 1, 22, 563668) What is there in the place of hand spinning to supply the villagers with work during their idle hours?
('45', 278, 1, 23, 563771) What can replace the drain of the millions they spend on flimsy foreign calico?
('45', 278, 1, 24, 563851) Such a people must necessarily grow, as they are growing, poorer and duller.
('45', 278, 1, 25, 563928) Young India, 28 3 1929
('45', 279, 0, 1, 563951) 280 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('45', 279, 1, 2, 563993) 263. KHADI IN THE LEGISLATURES Sjt.
('45', 279, 1, 3, 564029) C. Rajagopalachari is applying his legal ingenuity to devising means of giving effect to that clause in the foreign cloth boycott scheme which requires of the legislatures to protect or popularize khadi through them.
('45', 279, 1, 4, 564246) He has therefore sent in to the President of the Congress the following draft bill for his consideration:
('45', 279, 2, 5, 564352) Whereas the name ‘khaddar’ and ‘khadi’ have come to mean cotton cloth which is spun and woven by hand in India;
('45', 279, 3, 6, 564464) And Whereas it is desirable to protect the said names; It is hereby enacted as follows:
('45', 279, 4, 7, 564552) 1. This Act may be called the Indian Khaddar (Name Protection) Act 1929.
('45', 279, 5, 8, 564625) 2. In this Act, ‘khaddar’ and ‘khadi’ mean cotton cloth which is spun and woven by hand in India.
('45', 279, 6, 9, 564723) 3. The names ‘khaddar’ and khadi’ whether in English or in any Indian vernacular language as exclusively signifying cotton cloth spun and woven in India by hand shall be deemed to be trade descriptions within the meaning of the Merchandise Marks Act IV of 1889.
('45', 279, 7, 10, 564985) STATEMENT OF OBJECTS AND REASONS
('45', 279, 8, 11, 565018) Considerable progress has been made in recent years in reviving and popularizing the spinning and weaving of cotton by hand as a supplementary occupation among the agriculturist population off this country, who stand in need of an additional source of income.
('45', 279, 8, 12, 565278) Such progress as has been achieved is very largely supported by the patriotic impulse of the well to do classes who are purchasing khaddar at a sacrifice.
('45', 279, 8, 13, 565433) The situation is sought to be taken advantage of by manufacturers of spurious khaddar both in India and abroad and purchasers have been frequently misled to the detriment of what might easily become a great national industry.
('45', 279, 8, 14, 565659) The Bill, therefore, seeks to extend the protection afforded by the Merchandise Marks Act 1889 to the names ‘khaddar’ and ‘khadi’ which have come to denote hand spun and hand woven cloth only.
('45', 279, 8, 15, 565852) The exclusive use of these terms for this cloth cannot prejudicially affect bona fide producers or distributors of any other variety of cloth.
('45', 279, 8, 16, 565995) The bill is short and effective and if it becomes law it can at once prevent those unpatriotic mill owners and foreigners who manufacture coarse cloth and sell it under the label khaddar or khadi.
('45', 279, 8, 17, 566192) I have already given figures showing what an extensive trade
('45', 280, 0, 1, 566253) VOL.45 : 4 FEBRUARY, 1929 11 MAY, 1929 281
('45', 280, 1, 2, 566296) these men have done in spurious khadi.
('45', 280, 1, 3, 566335) 1 The Assam Council has already successfully piloted a resolution calling upon the local Government to make all its cloth purchase in genuine khadi.
('45', 280, 1, 4, 566484) I hope that the members will not rest till the resolution is enforced in practice and will see to it that the Government do not buy mill Khadi.
('45', 280, 1, 5, 566628) If the members of the legislatures are serious about the constructive programme they can keep both the boycott of foreign cloth and prohibition of liquor and opium constantly before them.
('45', 280, 1, 6, 566816) There is no reason why we should not reach total prohibition at once if all the members desire it and work for it.
('45', 280, 1, 7, 566931) Young India, 28 3 1929

('45', 281, 1, 2, 568031) 266. SPEECH AT KATHIAWAR POLITICAL
('45', 281, 2, 3, 568066) CONFERENCE, MORVI 1
('45', 281, 3, 4, 568086) March 30, 1929
('45', 281, 4, 5, 568101) It is a matter of shame for me that you are not able to hold the Conference without me.
('45', 281, 4, 6, 568189) As far as the rulers are concerned, there is nothing for them to be ashamed of in the desire, but it betrays lack of confidence, and for the sponsors it is a matter of shame.
('45', 281, 4, 7, 568364) One canunderstand my coming here by chance as a native of Kathiawar, but for you to consider my coming as imperative and to fix the time of the Conference to suit my convenience puts me to shame.
('45', 281, 4, 8, 568560) This condition must now be dispensed with.
('45', 281, 4, 9, 568603) If you cannot do without my presence, it is better that the Conference is not held.
('45', 281, 4, 10, 568687) I am saying this on my own; it is sad that there are not young people present here who hold this view.
('45', 281, 4, 11, 568790) I told them that, if they brought forward a censure motion, I would support them.
('45', 281, 4, 12, 568872) I am trying to free even Devchandbhai from this addiction and I wish to tell him that he should not abjectly believe that the Conference cannot be held without me.
('45', 281, 4, 13, 569036) If we wish to organize the people, we should have the capacity to do so witout any man, however great or talented he may be.
('45', 281, 4, 14, 569161) We all believe that there is the same self in all of us; everyone has a hidden power which he can make manifest at any time and become great.
('45', 281, 4, 15, 569303) Democracy consists in developing that power.

('45', 284, 1, 2, 574814) 268. AHIMSA V. COMPASSION
('45', 284, 2, 3, 574840) The following letter has lain with me for a long time.
('45', 284, 2, 4, 574895) I had thought of replying to it when I had some leisure.
('45', 284, 2, 5, 574952) A little of his I have today on the steamer.
('45', 284, 2, 6, 574997) I have abridged the letter as follows: 1
('45', 284, 3, 7, 575038) The intention of the writer is excellent, but I think his study and experience of ahimsa is slight.
('45', 284, 3, 8, 575138) There is as much difference between ahimsa and compassion as there is between gold and the shape givento it, between a root and the tree which sprouts from it.
('45', 284, 3, 9, 575298) Where there is no compassion, there is no ahimsa.
('45', 284, 3, 10, 575348) The test of ahimsa is compassion.
('45', 284, 3, 11, 575382) The concrete form of ahimsa is compassion.
('45', 284, 3, 12, 575425) Hence it is said there is as much ahimsa as there is compassion.
('45', 284, 3, 13, 575490) If I refrain from beating up a man who comes to attack me, it may or may not be ahimsa.
('45', 284, 3, 14, 575578) If I refrain from hitting him out of fear, it is not ahimsa.
('45', 284, 3, 15, 575639) If I abstain from hitting him out of compassion and with full knowledge, it is ahimsa.
('45', 284, 3, 16, 575726) That which is opposed to pure economics cannot be ahimsa.
('45', 284, 3, 17, 575784) Pure artha is that which includes the supreme artha.
('45', 284, 3, 18, 575837) Ahimsa is never a losing transaction.
('45', 284, 3, 19, 575875) The subtraction of one side of ahimsa from the other yields zero, that is to say, the two sides are equal.
('45', 284, 3, 20, 575982) He who eats to live, lives to serve and earns just enough for his food and clothing, is though acting, free from action, and non violent though committing violence.
('45', 284, 3, 21, 576147) Ahimsa without action is an impossibility.
('45', 284, 3, 22, 576190) Action does not merely mean activity of hands and feet.
('45', 284, 3, 23, 576246) The mind performs greater activity than even hands and feet.
('45', 284, 3, 24, 576307) Every thought is an action.
('45', 284, 3, 25, 576335) There can be no ahimsa in the absence of thought.
('45', 284, 3, 26, 576385) The dharma of ahimsa has been conceived only for an embodied being like man.
('45', 284, 3, 27, 576462) When a person who may eat anything limits, out of compassion, the things he will eat, he observes to that extent the dharma of ahimsa.
('45', 284, 3, 28, 576597) On the other hand, when an orthodox person does not eat meat, etc., he does a good thing but we cannot say that he necessarily has ahimsa in him.
('45', 284, 3, 29, 576743) Where there is ahimsa, there ought to be conscious comp assion.
('45', 284, 3, 30, 576807) If the dharma of ahimsa is really good, insistence on following it
('45', 284, 4, 31, 576874) 1 The letter is not translated here.
('45', 284, 4, 32, 576911) The correspondent had said that, in his view, Gandhiji’s use of the word ‘ahimsa’ in place of ‘compassion’ and vice versa was likely to give rise to confusion in the public mind.
('45', 284, 4, 33, 577090) He had asked for a clarification.
('45', 285, 0, 1, 577124) 286 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('45', 285, 1, 2, 577166) in every way in our daily life is not a mistake, but a duty.
('45', 285, 1, 3, 577227) There should be no clash between worldly actions and dharma.
('45', 285, 1, 4, 577288) Action which is opposed to dharma deserves to be eschewed.
('45', 285, 1, 5, 577347) It is himsa and delusion and ignorance to say that ahimsa cannot be practised at all times, in all places and fully and so to set it aside.
('45', 285, 1, 6, 577487) True endeavour consists in seeing that one’s daily conduct follows ahimsa.
('45', 285, 1, 7, 577562) This requires real endeavour.
('45', 285, 1, 8, 577592) Acting thus a man will ultimately gain the supreme state because he will become fit fully to observe ahimsa.
('45', 285, 1, 9, 577701) For other men perfect ahimsa will only remain in the form of a seed.
('45', 285, 1, 10, 577770) There is violence at the root in the very act of living and hence arose the negative word ahimsa indicating of the dharma to be observed by embodied beings.

('45', 285, 3, 13, 578000) How can I describe the love which I receive wherever I go?

('45', 285, 3, 19, 578634) Hence I had to leave out many places, disappoint thousands and, to that extent, the coffers of Daridranaryana remain unfilled.

('45', 292, 1, 2, 590434) 276. LETTER TO MIRABEHN
('45', 292, 2, 3, 590458) SATYAGRAHA ASHRAM, SABARMATI, April 3, 1929
('45', 292, 3, 4, 590502) MIRA, I have your further letters.
('45', 292, 3, 5, 590537) I am glad you are having all the patients coming to you for help.
('45', 292, 3, 6, 590603) You know what to do.
('45', 292, 3, 7, 590624) This I write to put you on the right track about drugs.
('45', 292, 3, 8, 590680) Even castor oil and liquorice powder are expensive things for Indian villages.
('45', 292, 3, 9, 590759) There are indigenous drugs which you should use instead of liquorice powder made in England or Germany.
('45', 292, 3, 10, 590863) You should use liquorice itself.
('45', 292, 3, 11, 590896) It is quite effective and obtainable in every village.
('45', 292, 3, 12, 590951) You get it in the form of a stick, you break the stick and get the gummy substance from the stick.
('45', 292, 3, 13, 591050) A tola of this has simply to be mixed with a little warm milk and administered at the time of retiring to bed or better still at 4 o’clock in the morning, and patients get a clean motion.
('45', 292, 3, 14, 591238) This is cheap.
('45', 292, 3, 15, 591253) It can be administered in water also.
('45', 292, 3, 16, 591291) Then there are the sena leaves cheaper even than liquorice to be obtainable everywhere.
('45', 292, 3, 17, 591379) You can give sena leaves in powdered from or as an infusion.
('45', 292, 3, 18, 591440) You can get hold of physicians who are somewhat honest and good and get through their aid these very simple drugs.
('45', 292, 3, 19, 591555) There is only one thing which I fear you will have to keep and that is quinine for malarial cases.
('45', 292, 3, 20, 591654) But all this is by the way.
('45', 292, 3, 21, 591682) I don’t want to tax you unnecessarily, and you may not wish to distract your attention by having to give your time to a study of these drugs, however superfical that study may be.
('45', 292, 3, 22, 591862) You will therefore use your own judgment and do what may consider is feasible.

('45', 293, 3, 5, 592238) As things are, the Andhra people have not left me a single day to enable me to go to the Ashram and then to come to Bombay, and as now the May part of the tour is really for my recreation, I would not like to leave Bombay for Allahabad on the 27th May.

('45', 293, 3, 11, 593045) I have not got the Andhradesh programme rigidly fixed yet.

('45', 293, 3, 13, 593172) I expect to reach Bezwada on the 8th instant.

('45', 293, 7, 20, 593632) 278. THAT TEST CASE
('45', 293, 8, 21, 593652) Nothing that I did in connection with the cloth burning case that has just ended in a complete triumph for the Calcutta police or the Government of Bengal should serve as copy.
('45', 293, 8, 22, 593829) There are many things in one's life that one would like others to copy; there are others which are not necessarily vices and yet are not meant to be and
('45', 294, 0, 1, 593982) VOL.45 : 4 FEBRUARY, 1929 11 MAY, 1929 295
('45', 294, 1, 2, 594025) ought not to be copied.
('45', 294, 1, 3, 594049) I was therefore glad that several friends were perplexed and distressed over my securing my release from detention even on giving a personal bound than on entering upon a defence and to crown all, being represented by counsel.
('45', 294, 1, 4, 594276) How could I, they urged, as a confirmed non co operator, possibly do the three things and thus act contrary to all I have preached hitherto?
('45', 294, 1, 5, 594417) There is a consistency that is wise and a consistency that is foolish.
('45', 294, 1, 6, 594488) A man who in order to be consistent would go bare bodied in the hot sun of India and sunless Norway in midwinter would be considered a fool and would lose his his life in the bargain.
('45', 294, 1, 7, 594672) I am bound to do things in a representative capacity that I may not do in my individual capacity.
('45', 294, 1, 8, 594770) As a trustee of the A.I.S.A., I possess lakhs of rupees; in my individual capacity, I have not a penny I can call my own.
('45', 294, 1, 9, 594892) As a trustee of the same Association, I authorize, even require the filing of law suits in unavoidable cases.
('45', 294, 1, 10, 595002) In my individual capacity, I can think of no such contingency.
('45', 294, 1, 11, 595065) In the bonfire case as Chairman of the Foreign Cloth Boycott Committee I was a trustee.
('45', 294, 1, 12, 595153) If I had thought that the police notice of prohibition of bonfire was legal, I would have advised cessation of bonfire in the Sharddhanand Park.
('45', 294, 1, 13, 595298) For I was not prepared as yet to advise civil disobedience.
('45', 294, 1, 14, 595358) But the Section under which the notice was issued seemed to me to bear at least a double interpretation.
('45', 294, 1, 15, 595463) It therefore became a fit subject for a test case.
('45', 294, 1, 16, 595514) The steps that followed were in the natural course.
('45', 294, 1, 17, 595566) If the right of the police to stop the burning was to be tested, the case should be defended and if it was to be defended, I should be humble enough to allow myself to be defended by counsel rather than presumptuously rely upon my ability as a one time lawyer to argue technical points of law.
('45', 294, 1, 18, 595860) Not to have signed thepersonal bail bond would have meant taking an un warranted liberty with my position in the public life of the country.
('45', 294, 1, 19, 596001) If I had refused to sign the bail bond, I fancy that the Commissioner of Police would have still let me proceed on my voyage to Burma.
('45', 294, 1, 20, 596136) But I would have lost my reputation for delicate courtesy with which I am credited.
('45', 294, 1, 21, 596220) But cases such as this do not often occur to non co operators.
('45', 294, 1, 22, 596283) They would avoid undertaking trusts wherein there might be conflict between public duty and private conduct.
('45', 294, 1, 23, 596392) It is therefore that I warned the public against copying me in this case.
('45', 294, 1, 24, 596466) The general test is that a non co operator should have nothing to do with bail bond or defence for his personal advantage or comfort.
('45', 295, 0, 1, 596600) 296 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('45', 295, 1, 2, 596642) The result of the case is a disappointment and a confirmation of my view about British courts of law.
('45', 295, 1, 3, 596744) I was unprepared for the Court’s justification of the conduct of the police.
('45', 295, 1, 4, 596821) It was its duty to condemn the action of the police in creating the disturbance they did in the face of my clearest possible statement that in seeking to light the bonfire I was not acting as a civil resister but in the bona fide belief that the Section in question did not apply to places like the Shraddhanand Park.
('45', 295, 1, 5, 597139) As it is, the Calcutta police have received a certificate of good conduct for their rowdyism.
('45', 295, 1, 6, 597233) This judgment thus confirms my opinion that in cases of a serious clash between the authorities and the public, the judges would, even if unconsciously, exonerate the former.
('45', 295, 1, 7, 597408) It was however well that the case was fought as a test case.
('45', 295, 1, 8, 597469) For without it, the great demonstration in Shraddhanand Park would have been impossible.
('45', 295, 1, 9, 597558) The high handed action of the police gave the boycott movement an advertisement and an encouragement it would never otherwise have had.
('45', 295, 1, 10, 597694) The police are therefore welcome to their certificate of good conduct.
('45', 295, 1, 11, 597765) Young India, 4 4 1929
('45', 295, 2, 12, 597787) 279. NOTES
('45', 295, 3, 13, 597798) THE INDISCRIMINATE ARRESTS
('45', 295, 4, 14, 597825) The arrests of labour leaders or so called Communists show that the Government is in a panicky state and is betraying the symptoms to which we have been used and which presage a period of terrorism.
('45', 295, 4, 15, 598024) Evidently it believes in a periodical exhibition of its capacity to supersede all law and to discover to a trembling India the red claws which usually remain under cover.
('45', 295, 4, 16, 598195) Of course the farce of a trial will be duly enacted.
('45', 295, 4, 17, 598248) If the accused are wise they will not run into the trap and assist the farce by being represented by counsel.
('45', 295, 4, 18, 598358) But they will boldly risk imprisonment.
('45', 295, 4, 19, 598398) Presently it will be the turn of thousandsnot merely to risk but to face and even to court imprisonment if this reign of lawlessness under the guise of law is to be ended once for all.
('45', 295, 4, 20, 598583) It seems to me that the motive behind these prosecutions is not to kill Communism, it is to strike terror.
('45', 295, 4, 21, 598690) If by Communism is meant seizure of power and property by violent means, public opinion was successfully fighting that demon.
('45', 295, 4, 22, 598816) The Congress creed, indeed the creed of all political parties, is attainment of political liberty through non violent means.
('45', 295, 4, 23, 598941) But the Government by its action has given a
('45', 296, 0, 1, 598986) VOL.45 : 4 FEBRUARY, 1929 11 MAY, 1929 297
('45', 296, 1, 2, 599029) strength to the cult of violence which it never possessed.
('45', 296, 1, 3, 599088) They are shrewd enough to know that such was bound to be the case.
('45', 296, 1, 4, 599155) The motive behind these arrests has therefore to be searched in another direction.
('45', 296, 1, 5, 599238) One thing is certain.
('45', 296, 1, 6, 599260) Terrorism like plague has lost its terror for the public.
('45', 296, 1, 7, 599318) The movement of swaraj has found too deep a root in the public mind to be shaken or destroyed.
('45', 296, 1, 8, 599413) It is bound to gain strength through these arrests and the other similar indications of the Government’s intention to strike a death blow at the liberty movement.
('45', 296, 1, 9, 599576) For, the prosecution of Sjt.
('45', 296, 1, 10, 599605) Sambamurti and Sjt.
('45', 296, 1, 11, 599625) Khadilkar, the proscription of Pandit Sundarlal’s volume, the police conduct at Shraddhanand Park and such other incidents that may have escapade my notice cumulatively point in but one direction.
('45', 296, 2, 12, 599822) DAYLIGHT ROBBERY
('45', 296, 3, 13, 599839) Proscription without trial, without examination, without the author being able to defend himself in any shape or form, of Pandit Sundarlal’s learned volume in Hindi is nothing short of daylight robbery by the U.P. Government.
('45', 296, 3, 14, 600065) These volumes represent years of labour.
('45', 296, 3, 15, 600106) They were brought out at great expense, and if the proscription is allowed to stand, it means ruin to the author or the publisher whoever may have incurred the expense.
('45', 296, 3, 16, 600275) The clear statement issued by the publisher shows that the Government was not taken unawares.
('45', 296, 3, 17, 600369) They knew that the volumes were about to be published, they knew what they were likely to be.
('45', 296, 3, 18, 600463) And yet they confiscated them without warning and apparently without proper examination thereof.
('45', 296, 3, 19, 600560) According to the publisher’s note they could not have had more than two days to examine the volumes.
('45', 296, 3, 20, 600661) Surely the author and the public were entitled to know what there was objectionable in them.
('45', 296, 3, 21, 600754) I write from bitter experience.
('45', 296, 3, 22, 600786) Even to this day I do not know why my booklets Hind Swaraj and adaptation of Ruskin’s Unto This Last were proscribed.” I had no notice given to me.
('45', 296, 3, 23, 600934) It was only through a friend I came to know that these copies were proscribed.
('45', 296, 3, 24, 601013) But there is one consolation the public may derivefrom this daylight robbery.
('45', 296, 3, 25, 601091) The Government are by such acts providing us with easy methods of civil disobedience should it be necessary for us next year to undertake it on a large scale.
('45', 296, 4, 26, 601250) “NAVAKAL” PROSECUTION
('45', 296, 5, 27, 601272) The case against Sjt.
('45', 296, 5, 28, 601294) Khadilkar of Navakal I have headed prosecution.
('45', 296, 5, 29, 601342) In truth it is persecution.
('45', 296, 5, 30, 601370) But under a Government run in the teeth of popular opposition, especially when as in our case much of it is suppressed, prosecution must be as it is the lot of every plain spoken journalist.
('45', 296, 5, 31, 601561) Khadilkar has always believed in calling a spade
('45', 297, 0, 1, 601610) 298 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('45', 297, 1, 2, 601652) a spade.
('45', 297, 1, 3, 601661) And he is an effective popular writer.
('45', 297, 1, 4, 601700) He had paid the price of popularity based on plain speech.
('45', 297, 1, 5, 601759) I tender him my congratulations.
('45', 297, 1, 6, 601792) I know that he is a philosopher.
('45', 297, 1, 7, 601825) He once told me that he often wrote plays to pay the fines he had at times to pay for his journalistic adventures.
('45', 297, 1, 8, 601940) He was content to run his paper and through it educate public opinion according to his lights, so long as he could do so without running into debts for paying fines.
('45', 297, 1, 9, 602106) The unconcern with which he was describing his adventures enhanced the respect I always felt for his ability and constancy of purpose and sacrifice for the sake of the country.
('45', 297, 1, 10, 602283) I wish that he had not thrown away good money in counsel’s fees.
('45', 297, 1, 11, 602348) Law courts like every other Government institution are designed to protect the Government in time of need.
('45', 297, 1, 12, 602455) We have had practical experience of this times without number.
('45', 297, 1, 13, 602518) They are necessarily so.
('45', 297, 1, 14, 602543) Only we do not realize it when popular liberty and Government run in the same direction.
('45', 297, 1, 15, 602632) When however popular liberty has to be defended in spite of Government opposition, law courts are poor guardians thereof.
('45', 297, 1, 16, 602754) The less we have to do with them the better for us.
('45', 297, 2, 17, 602806) DUTY OF DISAFFECTION
('45', 297, 3, 18, 602827) When during the Burma tour I heard that Sjt.
('45', 297, 3, 19, 602872) Sambamurti was convicted, I thought he must have said something very wicked about the Government to deserve the conviction and the severe sentence.
('45', 297, 3, 20, 603020) But a perusal of the published judgment in the case which summarizes the seven speeches of Sjt.
('45', 297, 3, 21, 603116) Sambamurti shows, as the Working Committee properly points out in its resolution, that there is nothing in those speeches which most Congressmen have not repeatedly said from a hundred platforms.
('45', 297, 3, 22, 603312) Sambamurti was charged under the disaffection section.
('45', 297, 3, 23, 603367) But disaffection with Congressmen, indeed with every nationalist, has long been a sacred duty.
('45', 297, 3, 24, 603462) How shall a Government escape disaffection whenit continuously acts so as to deserve disaffection?
('45', 297, 3, 25, 603561) The fact is that if many who use much stronger language than Sjt.
('45', 297, 3, 26, 603627) Sambamurti are not honoured with convictions, it is because Sjt.
('45', 297, 3, 27, 603692) Sambamurti was making himself felt, his preaching was proving infectious; whereas with most of us our disaffection is a sterile virtue.
('45', 297, 3, 28, 603828) If we would deserve the honour that has been given to Sjt.
('45', 297, 3, 29, 603887) Sambamurti, our disaffection must become as dynamic as Sjt.
('45', 297, 3, 30, 603947) Sambamurti’s was becoming.
('45', 297, 3, 31, 603974) He had become a tall poppy.
('45', 297, 3, 32, 604002) He has set a good example by refusing to be bailed out or to enter upon a defence.
('45', 297, 3, 33, 604085) Personally I would have certainly made a brief statement not so much for the guidance of the court as for that of the public.
('45', 297, 3, 34, 604211) The public would for instance want to know whether he was
('45', 298, 0, 1, 604269) VOL.45 : 4 FEBRUARY, 1929 11 MAY, 1929 299
('45', 298, 1, 2, 604312) correctly reported or not.
('45', 298, 1, 3, 604339) But I confess that this is a small matter.
('45', 298, 1, 4, 604382) We are used to exaggerated and inaccurate reporting.
('45', 298, 1, 5, 604435) And where a particular act is not only not deplored but defended, what matters it whether it is painted in loud or in subdued colours?
('45', 298, 1, 6, 604570) His refusal to give a message to the public was characteristic of him.
('45', 298, 1, 7, 604641) If his conviction was not a sufficient message, no words of his could coin one worth the name.

('45', 301, 5, 11, 608916) 286. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, BOMBAY 1
('45', 301, 6, 12, 608956) April 5, 1929
('45', 301, 7, 13, 608970) It was, true Gandhiji began in Hindi, that he was addressing a public meeting in Bombay after so many years.
('45', 301, 7, 14, 609079) Even this time he was not aware that he would be called upon to address any meeting.
('45', 301, 7, 15, 609164) He had come to Bombay in response to two telegrams from the B.P.C.C. and the Bombay Youth League.
('45', 301, 7, 16, 609262) There was a time, he said, in the history of Bombay when it was impossible for him to address a public meeting in such a small place as the one where they had assembled.
('45', 301, 7, 17, 609432) Even the sands of Chaupati sometimes fell short of their requirements.
('45', 301, 7, 18, 609503) There was a lot of enthusiasm then among the people.
('45', 301, 7, 19, 609556) Looking to the national programme which the country had undertaken for the current year, he would at once say that there was greater need now than in the years 1921 22 for all the enthusiasm and energy they could bring to the service of the country.
('45', 301, 8, 20, 609806) Speaking about the observance of the National Week, Mahatma Gandhi recalled that it was on the 13th of April that there was Jallianwala Bagh massacre.
('45', 301, 8, 21, 609957) For all these years since that incident, the whole country was observing the National Week from the 6th to the 13th of April.
('45', 301, 8, 22, 610083) From Kanyakumari to Kashmir and from Dibrugarh to Karachi, people had to take to work again if the resolve of the nation expressed through the Congress was not to be an empty boast.
('45', 301, 9, 23, 610265) Referring to the library which was to be opened in honour of the memory of the late Mr. Omar Sobhani, Mahatmaji observed that the services of Omar Sobhani to Bombay were, indeed, matchless.
('45', 301, 9, 24, 610455) It was only meet and proper that his memory shouldbe consecrated.
('45', 301, 9, 25, 610521) Gandhiji then referred to the new premises of the B.P.C.C. which he was soon going to declare open.
('45', 301, 9, 26, 610621) He humorously remarked that if the Congress could open new office, it could also open a new era of freedom for the country.
('45', 301, 9, 27, 610745) What was wanted, he added, was self confidence.
('45', 301, 9, 28, 610793) Proceeding, he reminded his hearers that the Congress had asked the country to prepare for a vigorous national
('45', 301, 10, 29, 610904) 1 The meeting was held in the compound of the Congress House.
('45', 302, 0, 1, 610966) VOL.45 : 4 FEBRUARY, 1929 11 MAY, 1929 303
('45', 302, 1, 2, 611009) fight which was to commence at the end of year 1929. He hoped that during this year the country would carry out the programme which the Congress had laid down.
('45', 302, 1, 3, 611169) The first and the most important item of the Congress programme, he pointed out, was the use of khaddar and boycott of all foreign cloth.
('45', 302, 1, 4, 611307) It was a pity, he added, that so many young men and even women who had come to the meeting, had put on foreign dress on their bodies.
('45', 302, 1, 5, 611441) The bazaar which he witnessed before him was videshi (foreign) bazaar although he was called there to open the khaddar bazaar.
('45', 302, 1, 6, 611568) He reiterated his conviction that without khadi there would be no swaraj.
('45', 302, 1, 7, 611642) He attached more importance to khaddar as a principal item of the Congress programme because, he said, it was a thing in which all could participate.
('45', 302, 2, 8, 611792) He then appealed to the audience to discard on the spot their foreign caps and other articles of dress.

('45', 302, 5, 11, 611977) April 6, 1929
('45', 302, 6, 12, 611991) Gandhiji, seated in a chair on the dais, made a short reply in Urdu, in the course of which he said that he had come to Hyderabad before, but had not asked for money.
('45', 302, 6, 13, 612158) He would ask for it now in the name of Daridranarayana.
('45', 302, 6, 14, 612214) He pointed out that India was the poorest of the nations and that more than three crores of people were starving every day and asked them to realize what it meant.
('45', 302, 6, 15, 612378) Speaking about charkha, he said it was a Kamadhenu, giving our necessities.
('45', 302, 6, 16, 612454) In his opinion Hyderabad State which was endowed with several facilities could help British India by producing khadi in abundance.
('45', 302, 6, 17, 612585) He was told by Shrimati Sarojini Devi that very superior kind of khadi was produced there and he was very glad of that.
('45', 302, 6, 18, 612705) He had rarely come across such a fine texture of khadi which was used in the garland presented to him and if that was prepared by the depressed class boys he congratulated them and was very glad of that.
('45', 302, 7, 19, 612909) Then he referred to the Hindu Muslim question in British India and said that the time was coming again when the unity which once was witnessed in the year 1921 was going to be witnessed once again and he asked the audience to help the people of India in achieving it.
('45', 302, 7, 20, 613177) Referring to the evil of drink, he said that it was a disgrace to the nation that their children were educated out of the money raised by such means.
('45', 302, 7, 21, 613327) He said conditions were different in Hyderabad and asked them to make a representation to His Exalted Highness, the Nizam, and see that a new departure was made in this

('45', 303, 1, 4, 613833) Lastly, he touched upon the question of the depressed classes and said that the curse of untouchability had no sanction of the Shastras and asked the Hindus to see that it was eradicated from their society.

('45', 304, 1, 2, 615324) 289. MY SHAME AND SORROW 1
('45', 304, 2, 3, 615351) I have been greatly exercised in my mind as to whether or not to write on this topic.
('45', 304, 2, 4, 615437) But after fullest consideration I have come to the conclusion that not to write would constitute a grave dereliction of duty.
('45', 304, 2, 5, 615563) Many friends look upon the Satyagraha Ashram, the present Udyoga Mandir, as a sacred institution and send donations on the death of dear ones in respect of its manifold activities which I have thankfully accepted.
('45', 304, 2, 6, 615777) Recently some lapses of a serious character have been brought to light on the part of some members of this institution.
('45', 304, 2, 7, 615897) I have freely spoken about them to the inmates of the Mandir at prayer times.
('45', 304, 2, 8, 615975) But I do not consider this publicity sufficient.
('45', 304, 2, 9, 616024) My relations with the readers of Navajivan are not commercial, but have a strictly moral base.
('45', 304, 2, 10, 616119) They are naturally founded on the assumed purity of myself and the institution.
('45', 304, 2, 11, 616199) I have time and again written on the sin of secrecy.
('45', 304, 2, 12, 616252) Personally I have no secrets.
('45', 304, 2, 13, 616282) It is, therefore, necessary for me to take the reader into my confidence.
('45', 304, 2, 14, 616356) If he has assumed me and the institution to be pure it is but meet that he should know our impurity also.
('45', 304, 2, 15, 616462) Chhaganlal Gandhi, elder brother of the late Maganlal Gandhi, is a cousin of mine.
('45', 304, 2, 16, 616545) He has been like a son to me and was brought up by me under my care from his youth.
('45', 304, 2, 17, 616629) He has been discovered to be engaged in a series of petty larcenies over a number of years.
('45', 304, 2, 18, 616721) I should not have felt the aberration so much if the repentance had been voluntary, but as it was the thing was detected quite accidentally and brought to light by a namesake, the vigilant Secretary of the Mandir.
('45', 304, 2, 19, 616935) Indeed Chhaganlal Gandhi even made an unsuccessful attempt to conceal the guilt.
('45', 304, 2, 20, 617016) He is now apparently consumed with remorse and is shedding bitter tears.
('45', 304, 2, 21, 617089) He has, further, of his own accord left the Mandir, but I have hopes that he will one day return to the Mandir completely purified and the Mandir will then welcome him back to its fold with open arms.
('45', 304, 2, 22, 617290) His larcenies seem to have been of a very trivial character involving very inconsiderable sums of money on the whole.
('45', 304, 2, 23, 617408) I am inclined to treat the lapse in the nature of a disease.
('45', 304, 2, 24, 617469) So far as one can see these thefts have not meant any pecuniary loss to the Mandir.

('45', 305, 1, 2, 617688) Chhaganlal Gandhi had laid up an amount of about ten thousand from his savings.
('45', 305, 1, 3, 617768) I do not wish here to enter into the history of these savings.
('45', 305, 1, 4, 617831) This amount he made over to the Mandir only a few months ago at my suggestion not from any impulse of generosity but from a sense of the duty pointed out.
('45', 305, 1, 5, 617986) Private possession of wealth being inconsistent with principles of the Mandir, this ownership of not an inconsiderable sum of money jarred on me and intimated to him accordingly.
('45', 305, 1, 6, 618165) After holding consultations with his wife and two sons, none of whom desired its use for their sakes, Chhaganlal made it over unconditionally to the Udyoga Mandir.
('45', 305, 1, 7, 618329) So far as I am aware Chhaganlal at present owns no property whatever except his share in the ancestral property.
('45', 305, 1, 8, 618442) When I think of Chhaganlal Gandhi’s record of thirty years of service and his artlessness and simplicity on the one hand and these lapses on the other, I am perplexed and take refuge in the reflection that the working of the Law of Karma is inscrutable.
('45', 305, 1, 9, 618696) This is but one chapter of the story of my shame and sorrow.
('45', 305, 1, 10, 618757) Now for the second chapter.
('45', 305, 1, 11, 618785) I have lavished unstinted praise on Kasturbai (Mrs. Gandhi) in my Autobiography.
('45', 305, 1, 12, 618866) She has stood by me in the changes of my life.
('45', 305, 1, 13, 618913) I believe hers to have been an immaculate life.
('45', 305, 1, 14, 618961) It is true that her renunciation has not been based on an intelligent appreciation of the fundamentals of life, but from a blind wifely devotion.
('45', 305, 1, 15, 619107) At any rate she has never hindered me in my progress towards my ideals.
('45', 305, 1, 16, 619179) By her exemplary care and nursing during my illness she has easily commanded a patient’s gratitude.
('45', 305, 1, 17, 619279) I have spared her no ordeals.
('45', 305, 1, 18, 619309) She has been a tower of strength to me in my self imposed vow of brahmacharya.
('45', 305, 1, 19, 619388) But the white surface of these virtues is not without the glaringly dark spots.
('45', 305, 1, 20, 619468) Although impelled by her sense of wifely devotion she has renounced so far as the world knows earthly possessions, longing for them has persisted.
('45', 305, 1, 21, 619615) As a result, about a year or so ago she had laid up a sum of about a couple of hundred rupees for her own use out of the small sums presented to her by various people on different occasions.
('45', 305, 1, 22, 619806) The rule of the Mandir, however, is that even such personal presents may not be kept for private use.
('45', 305, 1, 23, 619908) Her action, therefore, amounted to theft.
('45', 305, 1, 24, 619950) Fortunately for her and the Mandir, thieves broke into her room about two years ago.
('45', 305, 1, 25, 620035) This incident resulted in the discovery of the forgoing misappropriation.
('45', 305, 1, 26, 620109) For a moment her remorse appeared to be genuine.
('45', 305, 1, 27, 620158) Events have proved, however, that it was only momentary.
('45', 305, 1, 28, 620215) Evidently it did not root out the desire for possession.
('45', 305, 1, 29, 620272) Recently some unknown visitors to the Mandir brought her a sum of four rupees.
('45', 305, 1, 30, 620351) Instead of

('45', 306, 1, 3, 620498) A tried inmate of the Mandir was present when the donation was made.
('45', 306, 1, 4, 620567) It was his obvious duty to put Kasturbai on her guard; but impelled by a false sense of courtesy he remained instead a helpless witness of the wrong.
('45', 306, 1, 5, 620717) After Chhaganlal’s episode the members of the Udyoga Mandir became suddenly vigilant.

('45', 306, 1, 11, 621279) Her penitence has been accepted by Udyoga Mandir and he well remain there just as before and accompany me in my tours.

('45', 306, 1, 23, 621910) If those who have believed in me and the Mandir desert us after these revelations it will serve two purposes at a stroke.
('45', 306, 1, 24, 622032) Both they and myself will be extricated from the false position and I would welcome the relief and the lightening of my burden it will bring me.
('45', 306, 1, 25, 622177) If all good men in the Mandir left it in disgust the problem would again be readily solved.
