('45', 308, 0, 1, 624970) VOL.45 : 4 FEBRUARY, 1929 11 MAY, 1929 309
('45', 308, 1, 2, 625013) 290. “JODANIKOSH” 1
('45', 308, 2, 3, 625033) The Gujarat Vidyapith has brought out this week a standard dictionary of the Gujarati language.
('45', 308, 2, 4, 625129) It is, as its name Jodanikosh suggests, a dictionary of spellings of words.
('45', 308, 2, 5, 625205) This is the first dictionary of its kind.
('45', 308, 2, 6, 625247) There are a few dictionaries in Gujarati, but they have not attempted to fix the spellings of words in keeping with any accepted standard.
('45', 308, 2, 7, 625386) A language which has no fixed spellings for its words is in the same position as a man without a nose.
('45', 308, 2, 8, 625489) I have always felt, therefore, the want of a standard dictionary in Gujarati.
('45', 308, 2, 9, 625567) The number of readers of the Navajivan is by no means small.
('45', 308, 2, 10, 625628) Similarly, there are many who lean upon the Gujarat Vidyapith for the right guidance in linguistic and literary matters.
('45', 308, 2, 11, 625749) How, then, can they do without a standard dictionary?
('45', 308, 2, 12, 625803) This dictionary has been prepared and brought out to meet their needs.
('45', 308, 2, 13, 625874) It may be asked: How is one to accept that the spellings given in this dictionary are correct while those in others are not?
('45', 308, 2, 14, 625999) The answer is that it is not a question of deciding which spellings are correct and which are not.
('45', 308, 2, 15, 626098) The principle followed in the compilation of this dictionary is that the spellings adopted by those who have a good knowledge of Gujarati and who try to write grammatically correct Gujarati be accepted as correct.
('45', 308, 2, 16, 626312) All those who have a love of the Gujarati language, who want to write correct Gujarati, and who care to adopt those spellings of words which are used by numberless Gujaratis taking part in the national movement, will do well to have a copy of this dictionary.
('45', 308, 2, 17, 626572) We should be more ashamed of committing mistakes of spellings in our mother tongue than we are of committing them in English.
('45', 308, 2, 18, 626698) After the publication of this dictionary, now no one has the right to do as his fancy dictates in the matter of spelling.
('45', 308, 2, 19, 626820) I recommend to those whose knowledge of Gujarati is as incomplete as mine to use this dictionary in dealing with their correspondence.
('45', 308, 2, 20, 626955) This dictionary contains 43,743 words.
('45', 308, 2, 21, 626994) It is not necessary for me to write about how it came to be written or the principles which it has followed in fixing the spelling of words.
('45', 308, 2, 22, 627135) Let the readers know these details from the book itself.
('45', 308, 2, 23, 627192) The well to do who are interested
('45', 308, 3, 24, 627226) 1 The Gujarati original of which this is a translation was published in Navajivan, 7 4 1929.

('45', 312, 5, 11, 632812) SISTERS, I cannot banish from my mind the memory of the incidents that took place in the Udyoga Mandir.

('45', 312, 5, 13, 632954) Where there is no courage there can never be truth.

('45', 312, 5, 15, 633074) If a person sincerely admits his sin, it is washed off and he can return to the path of right.

('45', 319, 2, 3, 643427) April 9, 1929
('45', 319, 3, 4, 643441) Mahatmaji said that he was very glad for the calmness prevailing there from 1920 onwards.
('45', 319, 3, 5, 643531) His idea was that swaraj was peace of mind and peace with all the people.
('45', 319, 3, 6, 643605) It was very difficult to reform the people of big cities but there were greater opportunities in the villages where he saw dirt and desolation.
('45', 319, 3, 7, 643749) Could not the people who were responsible for the clean and healthy life of these villages devote their attention to this task?
('45', 319, 3, 8, 643877) He hoped—and he believed that his hope would not be in vain—the hundreds of youths who had gathered there that day before him would come forward to help in this direction.
('45', 319, 3, 9, 644049) In your place cotton is available and in your addresses you said that all should wear khaddar.
('45', 319, 3, 10, 644144) If only you did so I should be very glad indeed.
('45', 319, 3, 11, 644193) Here I see some sisters, and a few of them are wearing khadi.
('45', 319, 3, 12, 644255) Why only a few?
('45', 319, 3, 13, 644271) Women also should take part in the attainment of swaraj and self purification like the men.
('45', 319, 3, 14, 644363) I do not speak of swaraj but of Ramarajya.

('45', 319, 3, 16, 644449) If you want Ramarajya all of you should become Sitas.

('45', 319, 3, 18, 644570) It is on account of that purity that Ravana could not even touch Sita.
('45', 319, 3, 19, 644641) Sita entered fire, but was safe.
('45', 319, 3, 20, 644674) Hindu ladies can become so pure if they try.
('45', 319, 3, 21, 644719) Today drinking is a bad habit.

('45', 319, 3, 24, 644874) You know of course that untouchability should be removed in swaraj.

('45', 326, 2, 9, 656828) 312. DECK PASSENGERS
('45', 326, 3, 10, 656849) Resumption of travelling third class by rail and deck on sea is reviving old experiences in circumstances somewhat different from the old.
('45', 326, 3, 11, 656988) When no one or few people knew me, I could easily be lost in the crowd and share its trials and its joys to the full.
('45', 326, 3, 12, 657106) Now I am a distinguished untouchable.
('45', 326, 3, 13, 657144) They must make room for me and give me facilities which they will not give to any other fellow passenger.
('45', 326, 3, 14, 657250) Consequently when I travelled as a deck passenger on board the s.s.
('45', 326, 3, 15, 657318) Aronda on my way to Burma, I was isolated from the rest of my fellows.
('45', 326, 3, 16, 657389) On the outward voyage the steamship authorities too had conspired with the passengers in the scheme of isolation.
('45', 326, 3, 17, 657503) They had set apart a portion of the second saloon deck for me and insisted on my use of the second saloon latrines.
('45', 326, 3, 18, 657619) I was therefore able to see little of the inconveniences of the deck passengers.
('45', 326, 3, 19, 657700) On the return voyage I happened to have the same boat but the steamship authorities had allowed things to take their natural course and I found myself in the midst of the deck passengers.
('45', 326, 3, 20, 657888) Though, therefore, I suffered from the disabilities of mahatmaship, I was able fairly to share their trials.
('45', 326, 3, 21, 657997) And I found that as in railway carriages so in steamships, there was not much difference between the condition of travelling in 1915 and 1929 so far as the lowest class travelling is concerned.
('45', 326, 3, 22, 658191) There was the same squalor, the same indeference, the same overcrowding, the same stenches and the same din and noise as before.
('45', 326, 3, 23, 658320) I observed on the Aronda that the space reserved for the passengers was encroached upon by motor cars, fowl and cattle.
('45', 326, 3, 24, 658440) I felt keenly this criminal disregard of the welfare and the feelings of human cargo.
('45', 326, 3, 25, 658526) Indeed it seemed to me that the other cargo both animate and inanimate claimed greater attention inasmuch as negligence in respect thereof by the steamship authorities might involve them in financial loss.
('45', 327, 0, 1, 658732) 328 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('45', 327, 1, 2, 658774) latrines were filthy beyond the description.
('45', 327, 1, 3, 658819) The sorest trial for me was in reaching the latrines to wade through a corridor reeking with urine and on reaching there to find that I could not lock even the half door of the latrine.
('45', 327, 1, 4, 659005) As however I was unable owing to my foregoing disability to make an inspection myself I asked one of my companions to make a diligent inspection of the whole of the deck accommodation and draw up a brief report of such inspection.
('45', 327, 1, 5, 659236) I reproduce the report below:
('45', 327, 2, 6, 659266) There is deck accommodation on board the s.s.
('45', 327, 2, 7, 659312) Aronda for about 1,500 passengers though in the busy season this limitation is overlooked.
('45', 327, 2, 8, 659403) There are for the use of these 1,500 passengers two tiny bath rooms and twelve latrines in sets of 4 for men and 2 bath rooms and 8 latrines for women.
('45', 327, 2, 9, 659555) This gives an average of one latrine to 75 passengers and one bath room to 375 passengers.
('45', 327, 3, 10, 659646) There is only a sea water tap in the bath rooms, but on fresh water tap, nor any facility whatever for keeping the clothes in a dry place while one is bathing.
('45', 327, 3, 11, 659806) Either the bath rooms have no latches or the latter are out of repair.

('45', 338, 1, 21, 682983) Remember one vital thing about this burning, that it is the owner of the foreign cloth who is called upon to deliver for burning such cloth in his possession.

('45', 339, 1, 7, 684430) And today acted upon by inertia we are repeating that crime.

('45', 339, 1, 9, 684571) You do not need to have a knowledge of economics to understand the simple truth that if we could distribute among the starving millions of India 60 crores of rupees that go to the purchase of foreign cloth none of them need starve, nor do you need to have an extraordinary knowledge of arithmetic in order to appreciate the fact that if we could produce all the cloth that is needed in India it is possible to prevent these 60 crores from going out of the country.
('45', 339, 1, 10, 685036) This is a thing that we were doing only 100 years ago.

('45', 347, 9, 27, 704730) The grime of perspiration is removed by bathing with hot water and then rubbing the skin hard with a towel.
('45', 347, 9, 28, 704838) That way the skin becomes strong.

('45', 348, 1, 2, 704946) oil in it which is essential to its health.

('45', 348, 1, 4, 705103) There is no harm in your use of earth, but I do not consider it necessary.
('45', 348, 1, 5, 705178) The better thing to use is gram flour, or even wheat flour.
('45', 348, 1, 6, 705238) But ordinarily nothing except hot water is required.
('45', 348, 1, 7, 705291) Bathe with water and then rub the body with a small wet towel.
('45', 348, 1, 8, 705354) After the bath is over, cleanse the body with a dry towel of khadi.
('45', 348, 1, 9, 705422) I mention a khadi towel particularly because its roughness stimulates the skin.
('45', 348, 1, 10, 705502) If you gently suck the pulp of raisins or oranges, there is no harm in taking either.

('45', 353, 3, 4, 713342) 1, Remember that untruth is worse than lechery.
('45', 353, 3, 5, 713390) Sometimes what the world takes to be lechery may not be lechery; but untruth is untruth at all times and is the source of countless other sins.
('45', 353, 3, 6, 713534) People may call it immoral if a widow remarries, but there is really no immorality in it if she does so openly.
('45', 353, 3, 7, 713646) But it is an untruth if I have eaten a grape stealthily and then deny having done so.
('45', 353, 3, 8, 713732) It is worse than lechery.
('45', 353, 3, 9, 713758) Therefore save yourself from lying.

('45', 355, 4, 18, 717398) He has done something improper.
('45', 355, 4, 19, 717430) 2 I felt so bad about it.

('45', 355, 4, 21, 717552) I thought that .

('45', 355, 4, 30, 717995) This also suggests the need for a man to take a vow.

('45', 355, 4, 33, 718179) A vow is the key to progress.
('45', 355, 4, 34, 718209) Such poor resolve that “as far as possible, I will not eat meat” will certainly make me eat meat.
('45', 355, 4, 35, 718307) And a firm resolve like “even if I die, I will not eat meat” will save me and help me progress.
('45', 355, 4, 36, 718403) The three vows I had taken before going to England certainly saved me.

('45', 358, 1, 2, 722852) 345. LETTER TO KUSUM DESAI
('45', 358, 2, 3, 722879) ANDHRA TOUR, April 17, 1929
('45', 358, 3, 4, 722907) KUSUM, I have your letter.
('45', 358, 3, 5, 722934) I have not liked your leaving the Ashram at this time.
('45', 358, 3, 6, 722989) It is true that you had secured permission to leave.
('45', 358, 3, 7, 723042) But the permission is subject to an implicit understanding, namely, that one should not leave a duty one has accepted and go even for the sake of one’s own mother.
('45', 358, 3, 8, 723206) What would Jadavbehn 1 have done supposing you had not been there?
('45', 358, 3, 9, 723273) What would she have done supposing you had been touring with me?
('45', 358, 3, 10, 723338) What would she have done supposing you had been beyond the seas?
('45', 358, 3, 11, 723403) You had Manu under your charge and Katto and Vimala were added, and you were a great help to Chhaganlal.

('45', 358, 3, 14, 723636) Can you understand that this was your dharma?
('45', 358, 3, 15, 723682) This is the Gita dharma, as I understand it.
('45', 358, 3, 16, 723727) I would expect from you at least this.
('45', 358, 3, 17, 723766) Do not argue in your defence that Joshi permitted you to go.
('45', 358, 3, 18, 723827) He could not have done otherwise.
('45', 358, 3, 19, 723861) The milk has been spilt and that cannot be undone now.
('45', 358, 3, 20, 723916) this advice is for future guidance.
('45', 358, 3, 21, 723952) Do not take it as a rebuke.
('45', 358, 3, 22, 723980) What would I gain by rebuking you?
('45', 358, 3, 23, 724015) I myself might have often laid myself open to blame.
('45', 358, 3, 24, 724068) But when we find ourselves guilty of such a lapse it will be enough if we draw from the error a lesson for the future.
('45', 358, 3, 25, 724187) You need not now rush back from Umreth.
('45', 358, 3, 26, 724227) Since you are already there, you should finish the work before returning.
('45', 358, 3, 27, 724301) When you do, make up your mind not to undertake any responsibility in the Ashram, or if you do, not leave it till it is taken over by somebody else.

('45', 360, 8, 10, 725905) 350. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, GUNTUR
('45', 360, 9, 11, 725943) April 17, 1929
('45', 360, 10, 12, 725958) Mahatmaji, while replying to the Municipal address, paid homage to the memory and work of the late Duggiralu Gopalakrishnaiya and said that as leaders passed away, the burden of the people’s duty would become more heavy.
('45', 360, 10, 13, 726179) Referring to the Municipal address, he said the Municipality had much to do in the way of combating the evil habits of people abusing public grounds and maidans.
('45', 360, 10, 14, 726341) He saw a ghastly sight that day while crossing the river Krishna.
('45', 360, 10, 15, 726407) That was not the way of using a sacred river.
('45', 360, 10, 16, 726453) Many people were abusing also the sacred sands of that holy river and it was high time for the people and the Municipality to eradicate those habits.
('45', 360, 10, 17, 726603) He would ask of the Municipality one question: what was the work they were doing now particularly in the cause of public health and sanitation?
('45', 360, 10, 18, 726747) Before I leave this place I want to ascertain from you how far the Congress programme has been carried out in these parts.
('45', 360, 10, 19, 726870) Of course I ask you all, I request you earnestly, on behalf of the poor and starving millions of our land, to use khaddar and promote its production.
('45', 360, 10, 20, 727020) If you think of their hunger, and the hunger of their helpless women and children, you will, as true Indians, come out to help them and then you will not mind untouchability or caste.
('45', 361, 0, 1, 727204) 362 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('45', 361, 1, 2, 727246) youare really sincere in your sympathy and in your desire to serve those starving stomachs, then you will come out to work and remove not only the evil of untouchability from your path, but also help those poor countrymen of yours to banish the curse of drink from their lives.
('45', 361, 1, 3, 727524) Now, my question to you is: are you so sincere?
('45', 361, 1, 4, 727572) The Hindu, 18 4 1929
('45', 361, 2, 5, 727593) 351. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, KERINCHEDU
('45', 361, 3, 6, 727635) April 17, 1929 I have heard that you have been sitting here from 5.30 onwards.
('45', 361, 3, 7, 727714) I am sorry for the delay; it is now eleven in the night, but I am glad to see you and heartily congratulate you on your patience.
('45', 361, 3, 8, 727844) I thank you all for that and for your purse.
('45', 361, 3, 9, 727889) But I should like to ask one question, is your desire to see me equal to your desire to see your country free?

('45', 362, 2, 14, 730395) 353. THE BOMB AND THE KNIFE
('45', 362, 3, 15, 730423) At the back of the bomb thrown in the Assembly by men bearing Hindu names and the knife of Rajpal’s assassin bearing a Muslim name runs the same philosophy of mad revenge and impotent rage.
('45', 362, 3, 16, 730613) The bomb throwers have discredited the cause of freedom in whose name they threw the bombs; the user of the knife has discredited Islam in whose name the perpetrator did the mad deed.
('45', 362, 3, 17, 730797) The Government would be Foolish if they become nervous and resort to counter madness.
('45', 362, 3, 18, 730883) If they are wise, they will perceive that they are in no small measure to blame for the madness of the bomb thrower.
('45', 362, 3, 19, 731000) By their indifference to popular feeling they are exasperating the nation and the exasperation is bound to lead some astray.
('45', 362, 3, 20, 731125) Congressmen whose creed is non violence will do well not to give even secret approval to the deed but pursue their method with redoubled vigour, if they have real faith in it.Rajpal’s assassination has given him a martyrdom and a name which he did not deserve.
('45', 362, 3, 21, 731386) He had made full reparation in regard to his pamphlet.
('45', 362, 3, 22, 731441) 1 He had also already suffered for it.
('45', 362, 3, 23, 731480) The assassination has brought him posthumous renown.
('45', 362, 3, 24, 731533) I tender the members of the martyr’s family my condolences and hope that neither they nor the Arya Samajists will harbour any ill will against the Mussalmans because of the deed of one mad man amongst them.
('45', 362, 3, 25, 731740) The assassin will, I expect, in due course pay the last penalty for his deed.
('45', 362, 4, 26, 731818) 1 Rangila Rasool
('45', 363, 0, 1, 731835) 364 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('45', 363, 1, 2, 731877) It is to be fervently hoped that there will not be a repetition of the sorry scenes one witnessed over the funeral of Abdul Rashid.
('45', 363, 1, 3, 732009) Of course the bomb and the knife derive their lease of life from the world’s belief in violence as a remedy for securing supposed justice.
('45', 363, 1, 4, 732148) Organized destruction is no less immoral because it is not a crime in the penal code of nations.
('45', 363, 1, 5, 732245) The insensate speed with which the nations of the West are hourly forging new weapons of destruction for purposes of war is suffocating the world with the spirit of violence.
('45', 363, 1, 6, 732420) Little wonder if hot heads of all nations and all faiths should overstep the limits of the penal code even at the risk of their lives.
('45', 363, 1, 7, 732555) The bomb thrower and the assassin will live on so long as public opinion of the world tolerates war.
('45', 363, 1, 8, 732656) But they can always be kept under check if local opinion does not approve of or tolerate their activity.
('45', 363, 1, 9, 732761) The bomb is more easily dealt with than the knife.
('45', 363, 1, 10, 732812) The bomb has no milieu in India.
('45', 363, 1, 11, 732845) The Government can stop it today if they choose, not by frightfulness but by conceding the national demand gracefully and in time.
('45', 363, 1, 12, 732976) But that is hoping against hope.
('45', 363, 1, 13, 733009) For the Government to do so would be a change of heart, not merely of policy.
('45', 363, 1, 14, 733087) And there is nothing on the horizon to warrant the hope that any such change is imminent.
('45', 363, 1, 15, 733177) The hope therefore lies really in the nation, in the Congressmen.
('45', 363, 1, 16, 733243) In my wanderings I have sensed no belief amongst national workers in methods of violence.
('45', 363, 1, 17, 733333) I have however missed a living faith in the method of non violence, I have felt even a want of faith in it.
('45', 363, 1, 18, 733441) An atmosphere of despair undoubtedly pervades the air.
('45', 363, 1, 19, 733496) This demoralizing uncertainty disables workers from appreciating to the full the programme prescribed by the National Congress.They do not see that if non violence is to express itself in national activities for attainment of freedom, the Congress programme is the natural and inevitable outcome.
('45', 363, 1, 20, 733793) We can to a great extent checkmate the bomb thrower, if we would have faith in our own programme and work for it.
('45', 363, 1, 21, 733907) Young India, 18 4 1929
('45', 363, 2, 22, 733930) 354. FOREIGN CLOTH BOYCOTT
('45', 363, 3, 23, 733957) Jairamdas, Secretary of the Foreign Cloth Boycott Committee appointed by the Working Committee, has not allowed grass to grow under his feet.

('45', 364, 1, 3, 734318) An important leaflet gives the names and addresses of sale and production khadi depots throughout India.
('45', 364, 1, 4, 734423) The reader can have the list by sending an anna stamp to the F.C.B. Committee, Congress House, Bombay 4. The registered telegraphic address is ‘Boycott’.
('45', 364, 1, 5, 734577) It will interest the reader to know that there are in all 328 such centres of which Bengal has 66 and Tamilnad 64. Next come Andhra with 39 and Bihar with 33. Whilst by itself the list is encouraging, it is but a drop in the ocean compared with the foreign cloth shops in the country.
('45', 364, 1, 6, 734862) There is no doubt that Bombay alone has more than 328 foreign cloth sale depots.
('45', 364, 1, 7, 734943) It is for the public to capture this trade which drains away crores of rupees annually from India.
('45', 364, 1, 8, 735042) One rupee spent on khadi giveth life, one rupee spent on foreign cloth killeth.

('45', 364, 2, 15, 735429) 355. IN ANDHRA DESHA [–I]
('45', 364, 3, 16, 735455) I am paying this oft postponed visit at a time trying for me as also for the workers.
('45', 364, 3, 17, 735541) It is about the hottest part of the year and when owing to long travelling I am almost washed out.
('45', 364, 3, 18, 735640) Happily though the tour programme is stiff and requires daily travelling mostly by motor cars, I am left alone between 10 to 5 except for one hour when I am spinning.
('45', 364, 3, 19, 735807) This gives me time for some recuperation, editing and correspondence.
('45', 364, 3, 20, 735877) The tour may be said to have commenced with Hyderabad.
('45', 364, 3, 21, 735932) Dr. Latifi of Hyderabad met us at Wadi junction and covered the whole party with unobtrusive attention.
('45', 364, 3, 22, 736036) Immense crowds greeted us at Hyderabad and it took over 45 minutes to pass from the carriage to the car.
('45', 364, 3, 23, 736141) By right on either side our lodging was fixed at Sarojini Devi’s golden threshold where Dr. Naidu and Padmaja made us feel perfectly at home.
('45', 364, 3, 24, 736283) Vamanrao Naik was the boss of the whole show.
('45', 364, 3, 25, 736329) But in spite of the able assistance of his volunteers and the help, willingly accepted, of the Hyderabad police, he could not regulate the immense crowds that pressed in from everywhere at the mass meeting.

('45', 371, 0, 1, 747874) 372 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('45', 371, 1, 2, 747916) 362. BOYCOTT AS POPULAR EDUCATION I An ordinary man hardly has any idea how much popular education is implied in the boycott of foreign cloth.
('45', 371, 1, 3, 748059) Bhai Jethalal Govindji who is working in Bijolia writes to me from time to time his experiences of the work being done there in this direction.
('45', 371, 1, 4, 748203) I give below a summary of his ideas so as to make clear to the readers the meaning of the above statement.
('45', 371, 1, 5, 748310) The boycott of foreign cloth will succeed only when the twenty two crores of our peasants begin to use khadi.
('45', 371, 1, 6, 748420) And to convert them to the use of khadi means to explain to them the science of khadi, to show them the advantages of self helpand to teach them the entire process of khadi production.
('45', 371, 1, 7, 748605) For this we need volunteers, mobile schools and preparation and distributi on of booklets describing the processes of spinning, carding,etc.
('45', 371, 1, 8, 748746) I have only given a summary.
('45', 371, 1, 9, 748775) Let the reader himself fill in the details and imagine the amount of popular education inherent in the boycott programme.
('45', 371, 1, 10, 748897) Who is to impart this education?
('45', 371, 1, 11, 748930) What place would educationists accord this in their scheme of education?
('45', 371, 1, 12, 749003) English oriented educatio nists who have to sustain the present regime will certainly give it no place.
('45', 371, 1, 13, 749107) It is then for the nationalist minded educationists who wish for the establishment of a Kisan raj in India to take up the idea and make it the pivot of their activity.
('45', 371, 1, 14, 749275) If this premise is sound, it is up to the national schools and colleges to arrange for the kind of education mentioned above.
('45', 371, 1, 15, 749401) That is to say, they should undertake to train workers for its propagation.
('45', 371, 1, 16, 749477) And this training should become for national workers their A.B.C. All science is interesting.
('45', 371, 1, 17, 749571) He who says that such and such a science is interesting while the others are not does not know the meaning of science.
('45', 371, 1, 18, 749690) There is a great difference in merely knowing to do a thing and in knowing its why and wherefore.
('45', 371, 1, 19, 749788) A tanner knows how to tan the hide and give it colour but that does not make him a chemist.
('45', 371, 1, 20, 749880) A chemist finds delight in his science, is crazy about it.
('45', 371, 1, 21, 749939) The tanner has merely a mechanical knowledge of the processes handed down to him from his forefathers; he performs those processes and earns his living.
('45', 371, 1, 22, 750092) But if he feels so inclined, he will willingly give up the trade and find some other way of making a living.
('45', 371, 1, 23, 750201) It is the same with other trades.
('45', 371, 1, 24, 750235) A scientist however can derive all the joy from his particular science, can go on making new discoveries and improving
('45', 372, 0, 1, 750354) VOL.45 : 4 FEBRUARY, 1929 11 MAY, 1929 373
('45', 372, 1, 2, 750397) the science.
('45', 372, 1, 3, 750410) This difference is at present clearly marked between weaving as a trade and weaving as a science.
('45', 372, 1, 4, 750508) Maganlal Gandhi died thinking about this every hour of the day and ever inventing something new.
('45', 372, 1, 5, 750605) Lakshmidas can think of nothing else but this.
('45', 372, 1, 6, 750652) If her were to be removed to other surroundings, he would feel suffocated like fish out of water.
('45', 372, 1, 7, 750750) Jethalal Govindji can take interest in no other work and gently upbraids me for giving my time to other activities.
('45', 372, 1, 8, 750866) Mirabehn, in spite of her indifferent health, has buried herself in Bihar villages and is trying to discover the potentialities of the old type of spinning wheel and other implements.
('45', 372, 1, 9, 751050) I can cite many other such instances.
('45', 372, 1, 10, 751088) But our Vidyapith will not recognize these activities, for the requisite atmosphere is lacking.
('45', 372, 1, 11, 751184) If a worker like Kaka showed himself inclined to recognize them, he would lose his reputation and the learned members of the Vidyapith would feel ashamed to be found in his company.
('45', 372, 1, 12, 751366) At the most they would recognize him as an expert carpenter.
('45', 372, 1, 13, 751427) I don’t wish to blame anybody for this.
('45', 372, 1, 14, 751467) For it is impossible to change human nature under compulsion.
('45', 372, 1, 15, 751529) People are not yet ready to look on weaving as a science and to systematize it.
('45', 372, 1, 16, 751609) It is not laid down that every science shall be pursued everywhere.
('45', 372, 1, 17, 751677) The inhabitants of the Sahara do not know the science of navigation.
('45', 372, 1, 18, 751746) Similarly, crores in India do not know that horseracing is a science and many consider it evil.
('45', 372, 1, 19, 751842) But many books have been written on it and it has its own terminology.
('45', 372, 1, 20, 751913) The people of the Sahara would develop an interest in the science of navigation and assign it a place in their education if the Sahara were to have water and the people wished to use it for commerce, if they saw their destiny tied with it.
('45', 372, 1, 21, 752153) Once our people begin to appreciate the great power of the charkha, writers and thinkers would also be drawn to it.

('45', 375, 2, 4, 757713) 365. MERCHANTS AND KHADI
('45', 375, 3, 5, 757738) A member of the Spinners’ Association writes: 1
('45', 375, 4, 6, 757786) There is no doubt that ultimately merchants will have to adopt khadi; but if they have not yet taken to selling khadi, the fault does not lie with the khadi workers.
('45', 375, 4, 7, 757952) The merchant class is susceptible to temptation and is timid.
('45', 375, 4, 8, 758014) Hence khadi cannot attract it all at once.
('45', 375, 4, 9, 758057) Nowadays,only people imbued with the spirit of selflessness andpatriotism take up khadi.
('45', 375, 4, 10, 758146) A merchant does not generally show a spirit of altruism in his trade.
('45', 375, 4, 11, 758216) Hence a merchant’s altruism ends with his doing charity, etc., in such a way as not to palace his business in jeopardy.
('45', 375, 4, 12, 758336) But it is only when the merchants are moved by true patriotism that they will take up the khadi trade.
('45', 375, 4, 13, 758439) We must, however, admit that there is a difficulty in their way.
('45', 375, 4, 14, 758504) the manner in which they conduct their trade at present will not do in the khadi trade.
('45', 375, 4, 15, 758592) As no consideration is given to the good of the buyer in present day business, the merchant regards himself for the most part as free from any moral obligations.
('45', 375, 4, 16, 758754) If this code is applied to khadi, khadi will perish.
('45', 375, 4, 17, 758807) Hence only merchants with a saintly nature can trade in khadi.
('45', 375, 4, 18, 758870) An average merchant will not earn much from the sale of khadi.
('45', 375, 4, 19, 758933) A merchant who does ordinary business hopes to earn money quickly, whereas khadi merchants have to content themselves with merely making a living.
('45', 375, 4, 20, 759080) A trader in ordinary cloth has a fixed line and has standard varieties, whereas a khadi merchant has to hit upon new ways every day.
('45', 375, 4, 21, 759213) Hence we cannot expect many merchants to engage in khadi trade at present.
('45', 375, 4, 22, 759288) The few merchants who trade in khadi know that they have to labour hard in order to succeed.
('45', 375, 4, 23, 759381) Hence those who work in that field at present are themselves imperfect and yet are in a position to do propaganda.
('45', 375, 4, 24, 759496) The wonder is that, though imperfect, they have been keeping the flag of khadi flying.

('45', 381, 4, 5, 770374) 374. FOREIGN CLOTH BOYCOTT
('45', 381, 5, 6, 770401) DUTY OF LOCAL BODIES
('45', 381, 6, 7, 770422) Jairamdas Doulatram has addressed a circular letter to the local bodies from which I take the following: The local self governing bodies in India can render substantial help in the following ways: 1. By imposing a prohibitive octroi, terminal tax or other rate on all foreign cloth imported within the local area.
('45', 381, 6, 8, 770736) Where the existing municipal or Local Boards Acts do not permit this, the local representatives on the Provincial Legislature should be approached to have the law suitably amended.
('45', 381, 6, 9, 770917) 2. By exempting hand spun and hand woven khadi from octroi, terminal tax and every other local rate.
('45', 381, 6, 10, 771018) 3. By making all its cloth purchases in hand spun and hand woven khadi irrespective of its so called costliness.

('45', 383, 0, 1, 774330) 384 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('45', 383, 1, 2, 774372) PRODUCTION OF KHADI
('45', 383, 2, 3, 774392) Some nervous patriots are already raising the question how khadi can meet the deficit that must be caused by a successful boycott of foreign cloth.
('45', 383, 2, 4, 774540) The question is no doubt relevant.
('45', 383, 2, 5, 774575) But it is easilyanswered.
('45', 383, 2, 6, 774601) Khadi alone has an infinite capacity for expansion, if there is a demand for it.
('45', 383, 2, 7, 774682) Every hamlet is a potential spinning mill requiring little capital to set it up.
('45', 383, 2, 8, 774763) The wheels can be fitted up in no time.
('45', 383, 2, 9, 774803) The skill and the time are there running to waste for want of use.
('45', 383, 2, 10, 774870) And when there is a general and insistent demand for khadi, the petty trader who is today slaving for the foreign cloth market will deem it a privilege to work for khadi.
('45', 383, 2, 11, 775041) It will then pay him to work for the additional manufacture of khadi.
('45', 383, 2, 12, 775111) Moreover it should be remembered that the market will not be called upon to stock khadi for the millions, even as biscuit manufacturers are not expected to supply the millions with their biscuits.
('45', 383, 2, 13, 775308) Once khadi becomes current coin, the toiling millions will spin their own yarn and get it woven by the village weaver as they used to do before.
('45', 383, 2, 14, 775453) And in this very natural decentralization there will be the least fraud perpetrated.
('45', 383, 2, 15, 775538) What is therefore wanted is for national workers to learn the technique of khadi and organize the villages as the occasion arises.
('45', 383, 2, 16, 775669) As soon as the khadi atmosphere is established in the country, there will be a demand from the villagers for organization.
('45', 383, 2, 17, 775792) Thus khadi has in it a capacity for self production whereas millcloth has not.
('45', 383, 2, 18, 775871) No doubt when the general demand for khadi rises, for the time being the public will have to be satisfied with coarse khadi.
('45', 383, 2, 19, 775996) The A.I.S.A. has found from experience that the manufacture of fine khadi is matter of slow education.
('45', 383, 2, 20, 776099) The ordinary woman will easily spin coarse counts, but she requires patient and persevering tuition to induce her to spin fine counts.
('45', 383, 2, 21, 776234) The evolution of khadi from coarse to fine during the past seven years has been most encouraging.
('45', 383, 2, 22, 776332) But it will have to suffer temporary suspension when the demand for khadi becomes imperative.
('45', 383, 2, 23, 776426) And when it does, I have no doubt that in that wave of enthusiasm people will shed the fastidious taste they show now but will gratefully receive any khadi they can get so long as it is genuine hand spun.
('45', 383, 2, 24, 776631) Young India, 25 4 1929
('45', 384, 0, 1, 776654) VOL.45 : 4 FEBRUARY, 1929 11 MAY, 1929 385
('45', 384, 1, 2, 776697) 375. THE ‘EVE’
('45', 384, 2, 3, 776712) We belong to an Empire beside whose fame that of Rome sinks to a shadow.
('45', 384, 3, 4, 776785) We control more than a fourth of the world’s land and a quarter—460 million—of its 1,852,000,000 inhabitants.
('45', 384, 3, 5, 776895) 300,000 of our people rule 333,373,000 natives in India, Ceylon, British North Borneo, British Malaya, Palestine, Iraq and elsewhere in Asia—an area of over two million square miles.
('45', 384, 3, 6, 777078) Put that in your pipe and smoke it !!!
('45', 384, 4, 7, 777117) Sixty million natives are controlled by 706,000 British in Africa in an area of 3,820,000 square miles.
('45', 384, 4, 8, 777221) Five millions in Canada and over six in Australia occupy another 7,278,000 square miles of the world’s surface.
('45', 384, 5, 9, 777333) Ours, the greatest mercantile marine the world has ever known, carries more than a billion yards of cotton cloth and more than twelve million pounds worth of machinery annually to India, from which country British shareholders, creditors and officials draw some 30 million pounds a year !!!
('45', 384, 6, 10, 777624) Thank God for the British Navy and drink to His Majesty the King!
('45', 384, 6, 11, 777690) The foregoing is a condensation 1 from an article headed “Cheer Up”, printed in Britannia of 15th February last.
('45', 384, 6, 12, 777803) The article has been sent by a courteous English correspondent with the following footnote:
('45', 384, 7, 13, 777895) If Mr. Blinking Gandhi saw this lot, he’d probably cut his throat on one of his own spinning wheels.
('45', 384, 7, 14, 777996) I have decided not to cut my throat yet for a while.
('45', 384, 7, 15, 778049) I want to live to see the spinning wheel produce the whole of the billion yards of cloth that “the greatest mercantile marine the world has even known” carries to India from England.
('45', 384, 7, 16, 778232) Only, India has to wake from her torpor.
('45', 384, 7, 17, 778273) Young India, 25 4 1929
('45', 384, 8, 18, 778296) 376. A NATIONAL DEFECT
('45', 384, 9, 19, 778319) Although we have the credit for being a personally clean people, we have little reason to be satisfied with that certificate.
('45', 384, 9, 20, 778445) Our cleanliness, i.e., cleanliness compared to that of other nations is based upon the almost universal habit of taking the daily bath and of keeping our cottages clean and tidy.
('45', 384, 9, 21, 778624) But I fear that it ends there.
('45', 384, 9, 22, 778655) We purchase that cleanliness at the expense of our neighbours.
('45', 384, 9, 23, 778718) Hence our villages are a dungheap and streets not walkable in spite of the fact
('45', 384, 10, 24, 778798) 1 Only extracts are reproduced here.
('45', 385, 0, 1, 778835) 386 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('45', 385, 1, 2, 778877) that millions go barefoot.
('45', 385, 1, 3, 778904) We do believe in removing dirt from our rooms but we also believe in throwing it in the street without regard to the well being of society.
('45', 385, 1, 4, 779044) We are clean as individuals but not as members of the society or the nation of which the individual is but a tiny part.
('45', 385, 1, 5, 779164) Whenever I travel in the South this serious shortcoming obtrudes itself on my attention and makes me feel most uncomfortable and sad.
('45', 385, 1, 6, 779298) The evil is by no means peculiar to the South but it is in my opinion accentuated in the South.
('45', 385, 1, 7, 779394) One does not see the defilement of rivers to the same extent in the other parts of India as in the South.
('45', 385, 1, 8, 779500) On 17th instant at 6 a.m.
('45', 385, 1, 9, 779526) we left Bezwada for Guntur by motor.
('45', 385, 1, 10, 779563) We had to cross the great Krishna river.
('45', 385, 1, 11, 779604) The scene I have often painfully witnessed from the trains in the South now met my gaze at closer quarters.
('45', 385, 1, 12, 779712) The car practically passed by hundreds of men and women evacuating themselves not many yards from the rive bank.
('45', 385, 1, 13, 779825) It is the stream in which people bathe and from which they drink.
('45', 385, 1, 14, 779891) Here there was a breach of the code of decency and a criminal disregard of the most elementary laws of health.
('45', 385, 1, 15, 780002) Add to this the economic waste of the precious manure, which they would be if these evacuations were made in a field and buried in the living surface of the earth and will mixed with loosened soils, instead of being filth and a danger to the health of the citizens, as they are when deposited on the river banks.
('45', 385, 1, 16, 780315) Here is work for the municipalities, if they will but do their primary duty of conserving the health of the citizens under their care.
('45', 385, 1, 17, 780450) There is, I know, the custom of saying that these reforms must not be permitted to take the nation’s attention away from the work of swaraj.
('45', 385, 1, 18, 780591) I venture to submit that conservation of national sanitation is swaraj work and may not be postponed for a single day on any consideration whatsoever.
('45', 385, 1, 19, 780742) Indeed if swaraj is to be had by peaceful methods it will only be attained by attention to every little detail of national life.Such work will promote cohesion among workers and create an indissoluble bond between them and the people—a bond necessary for the final overthrow of the existing system of government.
('45', 385, 1, 20, 781055) The system depends for its existence upon the weakness of the nation.
('45', 385, 1, 21, 781125) If there are no weaknesses to exploit, it will automatically cease to exist.
('45', 385, 1, 22, 781202) A foreign government is like a foreign body in diseased system.
('45', 385, 1, 23, 781266) And even as for eradication of a foreign body the system has to be made healthy from within, so also for the removal of a foreign government, it is necessary to remove all the internal causes of diseases.
('45', 385, 1, 24, 781471) Corporate insanitation is not the least of such diseases.
('45', 385, 1, 25, 781529) Any municipality tackling the evil of insanitation will have though work before it, not by way of finding money for carrying out
('45', 386, 0, 1, 781658) VOL.45 : 4 FEBRUARY, 1929 11 MAY, 1929 387
('45', 386, 1, 2, 781701) the reform but in the way of fighting colossal national prejudices and habits that have become second nature.
('45', 386, 1, 3, 781811) It will therefore be good training in swaraj.
('45', 386, 1, 4, 781857) So far as the finance is concerned, the reform will not only cost little but it will ultimately be a source of wealth.
('45', 386, 1, 5, 781976) I suggest that in this country it can be carried out only if the councillors will themselves take up the broom and the basket and not otherwise.
('45', 386, 1, 6, 782121) The remedy is no doubt heroic, but it is cheap, efficient and capable of being immediately put into effect.
('45', 386, 1, 7, 782229) When the city fathers are in earnest about the reform, they will be able to command the willing service of numberless volunteers.

('45', 386, 2, 9, 782382) 377. B.I.S.N. CO.’S DENIAL
('45', 386, 3, 10, 782409) Whilst I am touring in the villages of Andhra Desha, I see the following Free Press message in The Hindu:
('45', 386, 4, 11, 782515) The B.I.S.N. Co., in a statement to The Englishman, denies the allegations made by Mahatma Gandhi, who, referring to the sanitary arrangements of the boats playing to Rangoon, termed them as ‘criminal disregard of the welfare and feelings of the human cargo’.
('45', 386, 4, 12, 782775) 1 The Company says that Mahatma Gandhi thought that a deck passenger enjoyed second class privileges.

('45', 386, 4, 18, 783539) Instead of setting about correcting the disgraceful state of affairs, the agent has chosen to refute my very mild condemnation of the treatment of deck passengers based on personal observations.
('45', 386, 4, 19, 783734) I hope I am not so stupid as to expect second class privileges for deck passengers but I do resent the unnatural gulf that separates the deck passenger from the saloon passenger.
('45', 386, 4, 20, 783913) The deck passenger may not claim the luxurious conveniences provided for saloon passengers but he is entitled, whether he asks for it or not, to complete sanitary arrangements, and ample and clean accommod 
('45', 386, 5, 21, 784120) 1Vide “Deck Passengers”, 11 4 1929 2 For the full text of the statement, vide “A Malicious Libel”, 2 5 1929.
('45', 387, 0, 1, 784229) 388 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('45', 387, 1, 2, 784271) It should be possible for a person used to cleanly conditions to travel as deck passenger without running the risk of being ill or without having partially to starve as I had to starve for want of proper latrine arrangements.
('45', 387, 1, 3, 784497) A ‘blackhole’ may not be claimed as ‘extra space placed at the disposal of deck passengers’.
('45', 387, 1, 4, 784590) I suggest that deck passengers should be prevented from occupying space not intended for human habitation.
('45', 387, 1, 5, 784697) I admit that the ordinary deck passenger will take up any space to which he may have access in order to avoid the feeling of being cramped and in order to have some freedom of movement.
('45', 387, 1, 6, 784883) That the Company has sufficient men to keep the latrines, etc., clean does not prove that they do keep them clean.
('45', 387, 1, 7, 784998) My charge is that the latrines were not kept clean, that the half doors were in a state of disrepair, making it impossible to lock them from within and that they were not enough for the number of passengers taken on board.
('45', 387, 1, 8, 785221) I had hoped that the Company’s agent would not resort to the trick common in such cases of saying that “no complaint has been sent to the Commander about any inconvenience”.
('45', 387, 1, 9, 785395) When the class of passengers who travel deck learn the art of complaining of incon venience, there would be no occupation for men like me.
('45', 387, 1, 10, 785534) It is unfortunate that we as a nation will not air our discontent or do it clumsily and that we will put up with inconveniences which a humanbeing should never tolerate.
('45', 387, 1, 11, 785704) What is worse, I admit that the ordinary deck passenger has no sense of situation.
('45', 387, 1, 12, 785787) But that to me makes it all the more necessary for a carrying company to be extra careful to ensure sanitation on its boats or trains.
('45', 387, 1, 13, 785922) The last statement in this extraordinary denial, if it correctly represents the original, is pure libel.
('45', 387, 1, 14, 786027) I am not in the habit of occupying places to which I am not entitled; such practice is contrary to the habit of lifetime.
('45', 387, 1, 15, 786149) I could not even have unconsciously occupied a space reserved as hospital accommodation, for it was allotted to me and my friends by the Company’s officers.
('45', 387, 1, 16, 786306) There was thus no question of occupying anything without permission.
('45', 387, 1, 17, 786375) Let me now describe what space I was permitted to occupy.
('45', 387, 1, 18, 786433) It was the open space on the bow between two lifeboats and surrounded on all sides by passengers.
('45', 387, 1, 19, 786531) Nor were I and my company the only passengers on this space.
('45', 387, 1, 20, 786592) Moreover I observed that the space was used by the officers for lifebuoy practice by the crew.
('45', 387, 1, 21, 786687) There was no notice anywhere to show that this open space was reserved as hospital accommodation.
('45', 387, 1, 22, 786785) Let me add too that there was a continuous shower of coal dust blowing over our heads the whole of the three days of the voyage.
('45', 387, 1, 23, 786914) It was difficult to keep anything clean.
('45', 387, 1, 24, 786955) If this was hospital accommodation, it reflects little credit either on the Company or the medical officer who would be satisfied with an
('45', 388, 0, 1, 787093) VOL.45 : 4 FEBRUARY, 1929 11 MAY, 1929 389
('45', 388, 1, 2, 787136) accommodation dangerous even for a healthy person and almost fatal for patients in some illnesses.
('45', 388, 1, 3, 787235) Needless to say there could be no privacy in an open space like this which the passengers and officers mist frequently cross and recross.
('45', 388, 1, 4, 787373) I have seen hospital accommodation for deck passengers on other boats.
('45', 388, 1, 5, 787444) This has been a properly fitted cabin with reserved latrine accommodation for patients.
('45', 388, 1, 6, 787532) Neither I nor my companions noticed anything of this character on s.s.

('45', 388, 2, 12, 787967) 378. IN ANDHRA DESHA [ II]
('45', 388, 3, 13, 787994) The reader will find elsewhere the second week’s itinerary and collections.
('45', 388, 3, 14, 788070) Though I am gaining more and more insight into the village life in Andhra, the tour continues to be too giddy for my liking.
('45', 388, 3, 15, 788195) I see the villages and yet miss seeing them for the mad rush through space.
('45', 388, 3, 16, 788271) It is good no doubt to make collections but to do so at the sacrifice of the richer village experience is not good enough.
('45', 388, 3, 17, 788394) But it would be foolish for me to grumble at the appointments made by the devoted co workers who are wearing themselves out to make the tour a financial success and to enable the message at khadi to be delivered to the largest number of villages possible during the seven weeks’ tour.
('45', 388, 3, 18, 788679) In my speeches to the villagers, I am copying the example of the late Sir Surendranath Banerji who, when he was asked why he delivered, during his English visit about 1890, the same speech to almost all his audiences, said: ‘Because I want to give to all my best.
('45', 388, 3, 19, 788943) Having conceived my first speech to the best of my ability, why should I give second best to the others?’ So my message to the villagers is identical: 1. Boycott foreign cloth, 2. Wear khadi manufactured in your own villages, 3. Banish untouchability, 4. Promote unity between Hindus, Mussalmans, Christians and others.
('45', 388, 3, 20, 789263) 5. Banish drink, let the village elders go to the drinkers and reason with them to give up drink, and 6. Avoid internal quarrels, but when they do occur, adjust them through voluntary village panchayats.
('45', 389, 0, 1, 789467) 390 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('45', 389, 1, 2, 789509) It is at big centres where ‘politicians’ flourish that I enter into discussions and touch upon other matters.
('45', 389, 1, 3, 789619) Thus at Masulipatam I had occasion to dwell upon several contentions matters including those arising out of the addresses that were presented.
('45', 389, 1, 4, 789762) But the majority of addresses were loaded with nothing but adjectives in praise of me.
('45', 389, 1, 5, 789849) Such praise can do no good to the reciters and may possibly do harm to the receiver if he seriously believes himself to be all that the reciters make him.
('45', 389, 1, 6, 790004) I therefore warned my admirers against framing their addresses in hyperboles.
('45', 389, 1, 7, 790082) I told them that the best form of praise was to adopt in one’s own conduct what one found praiseworthy in another.
('45', 389, 1, 8, 790197) The Andhra workers I have mostlyfound to be responsive.
('45', 389, 1, 9, 790253) The hint was quickly taken up.
('45', 389, 1, 10, 790284) The addresses in the Guntur district have been for the most part colourless.
('45', 389, 1, 11, 790361) There is yet one step further to be taken.
('45', 389, 1, 12, 790404) They should contain detailed information on the following points: Number of men and women in each village or in the area covered by the particular address; number of Hindus, Muslims and others; number of ‘untouchables’, their conditions; number of Congress members male and female; number of people given to drink; number of spinners, their hours of work, earnings, quantity and count of yarn turned out per month, quantity of cotton grown, if any, whether spinners do their own carding, number of looms weaving only hand spun, weaving both hand spun and mill spun and number weaving only mill spun yarn; weight of khadi manufactured per month, rates of wages paid for each process; number of national schools and attendance, and such other information as may be of use from the national standpoint.
('45', 389, 1, 13, 791204) Address giving accurate information on the points mentioned would be a record I should prize and treasure.
('45', 389, 1, 14, 791311) They would be for me a mine of valuable information.
('45', 389, 1, 15, 791364) I must now give a condensed summary of my address at Masulipatam already referred to before.
('45', 389, 1, 16, 791457) It was delivered on the Jallianwala Bagh Day.

('45', 390, 3, 7, 791902) 380. SPEECH AT TADEPALLIGUDEM April 25, 1929
('45', 390, 4, 8, 791947) Gandhiji thanked them all and said, in the course of his speech, that after they had all given their bit to the poor millions of their motherland he hoped they were prepared for some more work than mere offering of money and jewels.
('45', 390, 4, 9, 792180) He had a belief in him and a belief in Andhra Desha and he knew, that if he spoke in that country they were sure to listen to his words.
('45', 390, 4, 10, 792317) First, he would mention a small matter to them.
('45', 390, 4, 11, 792365) That was: they should not have put their addresses in costly frames.
('45', 390, 4, 12, 792434) For, they must remember that the cost spent on those frames, made their help to Daridranarayana so much the less and thereby shortened the relief to that extent.
('45', 390, 4, 13, 792596) They should, every one of them, give and give and still go on giving and giving in service to their Daridranarayana, whose blessing would come to them in their giving.
('45', 390, 4, 14, 792764) They must give not only in money but also in service.
('45', 390, 4, 15, 792818) They should give more and more, if they would receive more and even without expecting to receive they should still give, for therein lay their salvation and the salvation of their country.
('45', 390, 4, 16, 793007) Considering their profits and their position, the mills of that place had given very little.
('45', 390, 4, 17, 793100) Were their hearts so little?
('45', 390, 4, 18, 793129) Why should they give?
('45', 390, 4, 19, 793151) Because, the khadi movement meant a small meal to starving millions and the more they give for the khadi cause, the grater would be the food for those hungry stomachs, and if they went on giving in service, which meant their continuous wearing of khadi clothes, their poor sisters and brothers in the villages would keep on having their meal and work for them to give them clothes.

('45', 399, 1, 2, 809804) 388. ABOUT THE MEERUT PRISONERS A friend writes about the prisoners held in Meerut: 1
('45', 399, 2, 3, 809890) The writer’s attitude does not seem proper to me.

('45', 399, 2, 7, 810094) It may have only 300 members and yet it would serve the thirty crores and run to their help.
('45', 399, 2, 8, 810187) It does not treat any Indian as an enemy but helps all when they get into difficulties.
('45', 399, 2, 9, 810275) So in my view the question of friendship or enmity towards the Congress does not arise here.
('45', 399, 2, 10, 810368) But in what manner can the Congress help the Meerut prisoners or others like them?
('45', 399, 2, 11, 810451) The Congress can agitate for them, write about the matter.
('45', 399, 2, 12, 810510) Their sufferings will rouse its wrath and, being more awakened it will win swaraj the sooner and open the locks of the prisoners’ cells.
('45', 399, 2, 13, 810647) But it will not engage lawyers for them.
('45', 399, 2, 14, 810688) It has not given up non co operation altogether.
('45', 399, 2, 15, 810737) Such prisoners should not bother about their defence.

('45', 418, 1, 2, 847558) 408. INTERVIEW TO ABEL 1
('45', 418, 2, 3, 847583) May 1, 1929
('45', 418, 3, 4, 847595) When I saw you, my heart actually leapt with joy and I really thought of Christ when I contemplated your consecration to the service of mankind.
('45', 418, 3, 5, 847740) I have specially come to ask you what you think of Christ.
('45', 418, 4, 6, 847799) GANDHIJI: I consider Christ as one of the great teachers of the world.
('45', 418, 4, 7, 847870) Beyond that I have not gone.
('45', 418, 5, 8, 847899) Is there any other kind of salvation apart from Christ’s way?
('45', 418, 5, 9, 847961) These things are to be taken figuratively and not literally.
('45', 418, 5, 10, 848022) Christ, no doubt, said: “I am the way,” etc., but he also said: “The letter killeth.” Any teacher could say what Christ has said.
('45', 418, 5, 11, 848152) After all, Christ is a common noun and Jesus Christ means Jesus the Anointed.
('45', 418, 5, 12, 848230) Any teacher who has dedicated his life to the service of God and humanity and attained to complete purity can say that.
('45', 418, 5, 13, 848350) The Gita said the same thing.
('45', 418, 6, 14, 848380) Have you any special plan of salvation?
('45', 418, 6, 15, 848420) My knowledge I derive from all the scriptures.
('45', 418, 6, 16, 848467) What greater salvation does man need than the attainment of absolute purity in self sacrifice and service?
('45', 418, 7, 17, 848574) Is not Jesus Christ the only sinless one?
('45', 418, 7, 18, 848616) What do we know of the whole life of Christ?
('45', 418, 7, 19, 848661) Apart from the years of his life as given in the four gospels of the New Testament we know nothing of the rest of his life.
('45', 418, 7, 20, 848785) As a man well versed in the Bible, you ought to have known that.
('45', 418, 7, 21, 848850) Christ is, no doubt, one of those who attained sinlessness.
('45', 418, 7, 22, 848910) These are, after all, not matters to be argued by the intellect but to be felt by the heart.
('45', 418, 7, 23, 849003) All this is not for debate.
('45', 418, 7, 24, 849031) The Hindu, 3 5 1929

('45', 422, 2, 13, 856461) TALKS ON KHADI
('45', 422, 3, 14, 856476) At every centre in the different districts where I have toured, I have held talks with workers about khadi, drink, national education, etc.
('45', 422, 3, 15, 856616) I have found greater faith in khadi than in any other items.
('45', 422, 3, 16, 856677) Dr. Pattabhi is decidedly of opinion that the production of khadi can be increased almost to a limitless extent if it is properly organized.
('45', 422, 3, 17, 856818) Sitaram Shastri holds a similar opinion.
('45', 422, 3, 18, 856859) But I have, I am sorry to have to observe, noticed absence of a scientific and diligent study of the question of Andhra Desha.
('45', 422, 3, 19, 856986) I do not know a single expert in Andhra like say the late Maganlal Gandhi or Lakshmidas or Satis Babu or others whom I can mention in other provinces.
('45', 422, 3, 20, 857137) No attempt has been made to introduce carding among the spinners.
('45', 422, 3, 21, 857203) It is the opinion of many experienced workers, and I share the opinion, that unless self carding is introduced, the spinners will not be able to hold out for long and that the quality of yarn cannot be much improved.
('45', 422, 3, 22, 857420) Nor is it sufficiently realized that khadi has no status if its yarn is manufactured by those who need not spin to supplement their bread earnings.
('45', 422, 3, 23, 857568) It would be a deception upon the people to collect funds in the name of Daridranarayana, if there are no people for whom the wheel can be the only needed accessory occupation.
('45', 422, 3, 24, 857744) There should therefore be a map of Andhra showing the spots where there is grinding poverty and where the message of khadi would be taken assoon as there are men and money.
('45', 422, 3, 25, 857917) I have therefore suggested the following propositions to the workers for their guidance: 1. Spinning for wages should be introduced only in those villages where people are in perpetual want because they do not get
('45', 423, 0, 1, 858131) 424 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('45', 423, 1, 2, 858173) enough from agriculture and because they have leisure.
('45', 423, 1, 3, 858228) Khadi so made may be subsidized by way of not adding overhead charges to the cost price.
('45', 423, 1, 4, 858317) 2. Spinning for one’s own requirements should be introd uced in all the villages irrespective of poverty.
('45', 423, 1, 5, 858423) In such cases the help to be given to the people should take the form of teaching them ginning, carding or spinning as the case may be and supplying them with cotton and accessories at cost price and getting their yarn woven for them at ordinary rates.
('45', 423, 1, 6, 858676) In this case, organizing charges will have to be incurred.
('45', 423, 1, 7, 858735) 3. Sacrificial spinning should be promoted wherever possible.
('45', 423, 1, 8, 858797) Help, as in the case 2, may be given but without, as a rule, costing the head office any money on this score.
('45', 423, 1, 9, 858907) Sacrificial spinning loses all merit when it is organized at a loss.
('45', 423, 1, 10, 858976) In this class of spinning, self carding should be insisted upon.
('45', 423, 1, 11, 859041) I am not sure that it is not the wisest plan to being one’s spinning lesson with ginning and carding.
('45', 423, 1, 12, 859143) As a matter of fact an intelligent worker can learn the elements of the three processes in one day.
('45', 423, 1, 13, 859243) It follows from the foregoing that there should be a standard spinning wage in all Andhra for counts below 12. For finer counts, fancy rates may be given and when given should be charged against their khadi.
('45', 423, 1, 14, 859451) In this connection it is useful to mention the generous donation of Rs. 1,500 made by Raja Nayani Venkataranga Rao Bahadur of Munagala at Hyderabad (Deccan) for the special purpose of running a small technical department in Andhra.
('45', 423, 1, 15, 859683) It would now appear to me as if he knew instinctively what a desideratum such a department was in Andhra.
('45', 423, 1, 16, 859789) With the charkha in so much vogue in Andhra there is no reason why it cannot run the best department of the type in all India.
('45', 423, 1, 17, 859916) Only it must have men with an abiding faith in the wheel and an iron determination to master the science.
('45', 423, 1, 18, 860022) If this technical department is to be opened, it is necessary to send one or two promising young men for training to Sabarmati, Sodepur or some such place.
('45', 423, 2, 19, 860178) VISIT TO A YOUNG WIDOW
('45', 423, 3, 20, 860201) When we were going from Bezwada to Ellore I was told that a girl who had just been widowed wanted to give me all her jewellery valued at Rs. 1,400 and that she wished me to go to her house in a village only less than two miles from Pedapadu where we had to go.
('45', 423, 3, 21, 860462) Her caste people observed the purdah and in no case could a girl recently widowed venture out especially to a public meeting.
('45', 423, 3, 22, 860588) The jewellery had little attraction for me.
('45', 423, 3, 23, 860632) In fact I did not believe my
('45', 424, 0, 1, 860661) VOL.45 : 4 FEBRUARY, 1929 11 MAY, 1929 425
('45', 424, 1, 2, 860704) informants when they told me that the girl widow could possibly wish to give up all her costly jewellery.
('45', 424, 1, 3, 860810) But the fact of her being young and only recently widowed (I was told she was a virgin widow) was enough to take me to her house.
('45', 424, 1, 4, 860940) And I was glad I went.
('45', 424, 1, 5, 860963) The girl’s name is Satyavatidevi.
('45', 424, 1, 6, 860997) She is under 20. Her husband was a well educated nationalist.
('45', 424, 1, 7, 861059) She knows Telugu well.
('45', 424, 1, 8, 861082) I found her to be a girl of courage and decision.
('45', 424, 1, 9, 861132) She had both the parents alive.
('45', 424, 1, 10, 861164) She placed into my hands all her ornaments so far as I am aware.
('45', 424, 1, 11, 861229) And they did appear to me to be worth fully Rs. 1,400. She put into my hands also a note which asked me to take her to the Ashram.
('45', 424, 1, 12, 861360) The parents were present when I met Satyavatidevi.
('45', 424, 1, 13, 861411) And they were agreeable to her surrendering her ornaments for khadi work.
('45', 424, 1, 14, 861485) I suggested to the parents that they should not keep her confined to the house and that she should be treated just like the other girls in the family.
('45', 424, 1, 15, 861636) I told the girl that she had no need to discard her ornaments merely because she was widowed.
('45', 424, 1, 16, 861730) But she was firm.
('45', 424, 1, 17, 861748) She had no longer any use for them.
('45', 424, 1, 18, 861784) I told her I would gladly take her to the Ashram if the parents consented.
('45', 424, 1, 19, 861859) The latter have promised to give the matter their consideration and have given the girl every hope of her being sent with me at the end of the tour.
('45', 424, 1, 20, 862008) The father, though he was undoubtedly cautious and reticent, appeared to me to be generously inclined towards his daughter.
('45', 424, 1, 21, 862132) I was sorry I was unable to bring any greater consolation to the widow.
('45', 424, 1, 22, 862204) It was with a heavy heart I parted from her.
('45', 424, 1, 23, 862249) At Pedapadu therefore my speech was devoted to Satyavatidevi.
('45', 424, 1, 24, 862311) I told the audience that it was their duty to break down the purdah and to help the parents of the widow to remarry her if she was at all so inclined.
('45', 424, 1, 25, 862462) If a young man of 18 being widowed could remarry, why should not a widow of that age have the same right?
('45', 424, 1, 26, 862568) Voluntary enlightened widowhood is a great asset for any nation as enforced ignorant widowhood is a disgrace.
('45', 424, 1, 27, 862678) The audience listened with respect and great attention.
('45', 424, 1, 28, 862734) The father of the widow was present at the meeting.
('45', 424, 1, 29, 862786) I subsequently learnt that the idea of parting with the ornaments was the widow’s own original idea and that she had no desire whatsoever of remarrying.
('45', 424, 1, 30, 862939) Her great desire is, I was told, to give herself to study with a view ultimately to dedicating her life to national service.
('45', 424, 1, 31, 863064) All honour to Satyavati, if such is really her mature decision.
('45', 424, 1, 32, 863128) Hindu society must make theway absolutely open
('45', 425, 0, 1, 863175) 426 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('45', 425, 1, 2, 863217) for such widows to remarry whenever they like.
('45', 425, 1, 3, 863264) The story of Satyavati is enacted in hundreds of Hindu homes every day.
('45', 425, 1, 4, 863336) The curse of every widow who is burning within to remarry but dare not for fear of a cruel custom descends upon Hindu society so long as it keeps the widow under an unforgivable bondage.

('45', 425, 2, 6, 863545) 411. A MALICIOUS LIBEL
('45', 425, 3, 7, 863568) I have now before me the full text of the Englishman interview given by an official of the B.I.S.N. Company.
('45', 425, 3, 8, 863677) I reproduce it below in full:
('45', 425, 4, 9, 863707) Interviewed by a representative of The Englishman yesterday, an official of the steamship company said:
('45', 425, 5, 10, 863811) Mr. Gandhi had no special privileges when he travelled as deck passenger on the s.s.
('45', 425, 5, 11, 863896) Aronda but he and his friends occupied a portion of the deck which was actually second class space.
('45', 425, 5, 12, 863996) The isolation of Mr. Gandhi from his fellow deck passengers was by his or his friends’ arrangement.
('45', 425, 5, 13, 864096) The party were allowed to occupy the space hey had taken.
('45', 425, 5, 14, 864154) The steamer authorities did not set apart a special portion of the second saloon deck for his party nor did they insist on his using it and if he used the second class latrine, it was against orders.
('45', 425, 5, 15, 864354) Mr. Gandhi was nominally a deck passenger; there was nothing to prevent him seeing the alleged inconveniences of other deck passengers.
('45', 425, 6, 16, 864490) The din and noise complained of could only have been made by the deck passengers themselves.
('45', 425, 7, 17, 864583) The space reserved for passengers, alleged to have been encroached upon by motor cars, fowl and cattle was actually space set aside for the particular purpose of carrying this sort of cargo.
('45', 425, 7, 18, 864774) It was not intended to be used by passengers.
('45', 425, 7, 19, 864820) The motor cars referred to were carried not in passengers’ sleeping accommodation but on a deck only required when a full complement of passengers is being carried, far more than on that particular voyage.
('45', 425, 8, 20, 865026) As to the statement that the latrines were filthy, four topasses are solely employed in keeping the latrines and decks clean.
('45', 425, 8, 21, 865152) Deck passengers themselves always object to having decks and latrines cleaned but an endeavour is made to keep them clean as far as possible.
('45', 425, 9, 22, 865294) Every latrine door has an automatic lock and also latches for closing.
('45', 425, 9, 23, 865365) There are notices in various places round the decks informing all passengers that if they have any complaint to make they should make it to the Commanderwhen he is doing his rounds.
('45', 425, 9, 24, 865547) No complaints were made on this voyage.
('45', 425, 9, 25, 865587) Commanders of steamers personally go round and inspect all passenger decks at least twice a day, sometimes thrice.
('45', 426, 0, 1, 865702) VOL.45 : 4 FEBRUARY, 1929 11 MAY, 1929 427
('45', 426, 1, 2, 865745) It is seldom that the full number of passengers allowed by the Indian Passenger Act is carried and the occasion on which Mr. Gandhi travelled there were only about 400 passengers outward and inward.
('45', 426, 2, 3, 865944) HOSPITAL OCCUPIED
('45', 426, 3, 4, 865962) With reference to the tween or lower deck referred to by Mr. Gandhi as a ‘Black Hole’ this is the tween deck which the Company always places at the disposal of deck passengers.
('45', 426, 3, 5, 866139) It is extra space over and above that required by law even when a full complement of passengers is carried.
('45', 426, 3, 6, 866247) The lower hatches of this deck are always kept wide open which allows for good ventilation.
('45', 426, 4, 7, 866339) The forepart of the main deck which he refers to as being a cattle hold was not intended for passengers but passengers themselves apparently made use of it.
('45', 426, 4, 8, 866496) The cage referred to at the stern end of the shade deck where sheep, goats, ducks and poultry are kept (actually there are never any goats) contains the steamer livestock.
('45', 426, 5, 9, 866668) There are arrangements for a hospital on board but Mr. Gandhi and his friends occupied it on the return journey from Rangoon without the permission of the officers of the ship.
('45', 426, 5, 10, 866845) In rainy weather which Mr. Gandhi speaks about, there is no necessity for deck passengers to get wet unless they, through their own wish, prefer sleeping on the exercise deck, as all passenger carrying accommodation The original is much more malicious than the Free Press summary.
('45', 426, 5, 11, 867126) I have had the misfortune to expose many falsehoods but I cannot recall more falsehoods packed in a column of newspaper than I find in this interview.
('45', 426, 5, 12, 867277) The discerning reader will not fail to detect the falsehoods for himself unless he thinks me to be an inventor of lies and utterly devoid of self respect.
('45', 426, 5, 13, 867432) I wish indeed it was true that I had no special privileges when I travelled as deck passenger from Calcutta to Rangoon.
('45', 426, 5, 14, 867552) My own companion had gone to buy the tickets and the Company issued a special ticket for me.
('45', 426, 5, 15, 867645) For deck passenger tickets names are not entered, mine however was a special coupon and bore my name.
('45', 426, 5, 16, 867747) When I boarded the vessel, the Company’s men took me to a place which they said was reserved for me.
('45', 426, 5, 17, 867848) I thankfully occupied that seat but had no intention whatsoever of using second saloon facilities.
('45', 426, 5, 18, 867947) I went to the deck latrine.
('45', 426, 5, 19, 867975) This was noticed by the officers.
('45', 426, 5, 20, 868009) A messenger thereupon came to me and said that the first officer did not like my using the deck latrines and thathe would like me to use the second class latrine.
('45', 426, 5, 21, 868172) I told the messenger that I had chosen to travel deck and that I could accommodate myself to the latrine meant for deck passengers.
('45', 426, 5, 22, 868304) This led to a discussion between the message bearing official and myself, and in order not to appear fussy

('45', 427, 1, 2, 868453) or punctilious I availed myself of the courtesy extended to me.

('45', 427, 1, 4, 868827) If the space occupied by deck passengers was really not intended for them and was intended for fowl, cattle and motor cars, it means that the latter 1 had better accommodation reserved for them than the human cargo.
('45', 427, 1, 5, 869043) For this space occupied by sub human cargo was the best and the most airy.
('45', 427, 1, 6, 869118) I would certainly have loved to have taken the space occupied by the motor cars which blocked the air in addition to occupying the floor space.

('45', 427, 1, 8, 869421) I have known Company’s officials kick passengers who dared to occupy space not allotted to them.
('45', 427, 1, 9, 869518) The rest of the interview was dealt with by me last week.
('45', 427, 2, 10, 869576) I am sorry that my article, the subject matter of the interview, has missed its mark, and instead of resulting in a quiet inquiry by the Company and amelioration of the lot of deck passengers, has resulted in an insolent exhibition of power derived from wealth and Government patronage.
('45', 427, 2, 11, 869863) I invite the Company to probe the matter deeply and withdraw the libellous statements so recklessly made by the interviewed official and, what is more, right the wrong that is being done to the deck passengers.

('45', 428, 1, 2, 870208) 412. SOUTH AFRICAN REPATRIATES The Secretaries of the South African Indian Congress have sent me the following letter: 1
('45', 428, 2, 3, 870329) It was stated that the Government of Indian have taken no steps to assist the repatriates, that they are stranded and are unable to find employment, that the present day conditions in India are not congenial to them, that reports have been read conveyed by letters from repatriates, that owing to absence of work and assistance from the authorities, they are either starving or undergoing much suffering and consequently many of them have, by force of adverse circumstances, migrated to Fiji or Malaya.
('45', 428, 3, 4, 870832) In the Cape Town Agreement, one of the conditions accepted by the Government of India in regard to the scheme is that on their arrival in India the emigrants will be helped as far as possible to settle in the occupations for which they are best suited by their attitude or their resources.
('45', 428, 4, 5, 871122) Judging from the report received from the repatriates, it is doubtful whether the Government of India are doing anything at all to help the repatriates.
('45', 428, 5, 6, 871275) This Congress will be extremely grateful to you if you will afford information on the subject so that it may be guided in making full representations to the authorities.
('45', 428, 5, 7, 871445) I refrain from offering any comment at the present moment.
('45', 428, 5, 8, 871504) But I shall await some statement from the authorities.
('45', 428, 5, 9, 871559) There is no doubt that if these repatriates are to be received, they must be specially cared for.
('45', 428, 5, 10, 871657) India to most of them is like a foreign land .
('45', 428, 5, 11, 871704) Young India, 2 5 1929

('45', 431, 6, 24, 876186) It would be good if they stayed till my return.

('45', 431, 6, 33, 876998) I do not know what the amount in question was.
('45', 431, 6, 34, 877045) Whatever it might be, he certainly cannot us money which contains a portion which was stolen.

('45', 433, 5, 8, 879616) 418. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, TUNI
('45', 433, 6, 9, 879652) May 2, 1929
('45', 433, 7, 10, 879664) I thank you all for the addresses of welcome presented to me by the Union Board of Tuni and its people and also for the purses to the Khadi Fund.
('45', 433, 7, 11, 879810) That means you realize the need of the nation today.
('45', 433, 7, 12, 879863) Much is spoken about khaddar in your address of welcome.
('45', 433, 7, 13, 879920) Surely you are competent to speak about khaddar, for I know that your place is a khadi producing centre and there are several merchants engaged in that trade.
('45', 433, 7, 14, 880079) But that makes it all the more disgraceful to your place even if one amongst you were to put on foreign cloth.
('45', 433, 7, 15, 880190) You are able to spin and weave your own cloth here, so why should you have foreign cloth brought to you from abroad.
('45', 433, 7, 16, 880307) Is it not a disgrace to your manliness?
('45', 433, 7, 17, 880347) I want you to wipe out this shame and you must see that no piece of foreign cloth is here anylonger.
('45', 433, 7, 18, 880448) It is necessary that your Board should do propaganda among the people for the use of khaddar alone and for purchasing the cloth spun and woven here.
('45', 433, 7, 19, 880597) Also; you must go to dealers in foreign cloth and silently do propaganda work among them and win them over to your side by all peaceful means.
('45', 433, 7, 20, 880740) You must tell them that to the extent to which they purchase foreign cloth, to that extent they are starving their own brothers and sisters here and impoverishing their country.
('45', 433, 7, 21, 880918) I hope they will yield to you.
('45', 433, 7, 22, 880949) I further hear that some people are selling cloth woven of mill yarn as khaddar.
('45', 433, 7, 23, 881030) It is unjust on their part to do so.
('45', 433, 7, 24, 881067) The yarn spun by your good and devoted sisters on the spinning wheel and then woven into cloth for you by your brother weavers on the handloom is what is known as khaddar.
('45', 433, 7, 25, 881239) Everything else produced in any different manner cannot be called khaddar and to resort to such a different process or means is sinful.
('45', 433, 7, 26, 881375) Pandit Motilal
('45', 434, 0, 1, 881390) VOL.45 : 4 FEBRUARY, 1929 11 MAY, 1929 435
('45', 434, 1, 2, 881433) Nehru introduced a bill in the Legislative Assembly to the effect that one who cheats the public by manufacturing or selling spurious khaddar should be made liable to punishment.
('45', 434, 1, 3, 881612) I think a bill superfluous and unnecessary if there is a true and sincere discipline and adherence to dharma in the country.
('45', 434, 1, 4, 881737) May I therefore pray that whoever sins in this respect by doing business in deceitful ways shall henceforth put a stop to it.
('45', 434, 1, 5, 881863) I pray to those that wear foreign cloth in this town, where their own brothers and sisters are ready to give them the clothes they need, to discard all foreign cloth and burn it.
('45', 434, 1, 6, 882042) I also pray to those who are habituated to drinking toddy, brandy and other drinks to abandon the habit.
('45', 434, 1, 7, 882147) You must also see that no people are untouchables.
('45', 434, 1, 8, 882198) Hindus, Muslims and others should be united in the common cause of freedom.
('45', 434, 1, 9, 882274) All communal disputes should be settled amongst yourselves and you must maintain an esprit de corps.
('45', 434, 1, 10, 882375) If we do all these things swaraj will be in our hands.
