('45', 434, 4, 18, 882724) I think for the present your good lies in doing this.
('45', 434, 4, 19, 882778) You have an extremely straightforward nature but your judgment is immature.
('45', 434, 4, 20, 882854) You are unable to decide independently what is dharma and what is not, nor is there logical consistency in your thought.

('45', 435, 1, 2, 883521) Budhabhai.
('45', 435, 1, 3, 883532) You should be free from such restrictions as observance of the Ashram’s external rules.
('45', 435, 1, 4, 883620) It is another thing if you come to the prayers of your own accord.

('45', 435, 1, 15, 884332) Some people give willingly, some under compulsion; some knowingly, some unknowingly.
('45', 435, 1, 16, 884417) All these are merely suggestions.
('45', 435, 1, 17, 884451) If, for the sake of your peace of mind you feel that for the present you should stay away from that atmosphere by all means do so.
('45', 435, 1, 18, 884582) Now let me point out the obvious flaw in your reasoning.
('45', 435, 1, 19, 884639) Here is your statement: “I do not think that I am guilty of violating the aswadavrata 1 if I take spiced food, or that if I cannot memorize the Gita I violate an Ashram rule and my progress will stop.” This statement in itself is true; it is however false in so far as it is a statement of facts.
('45', 435, 1, 20, 884936) Taking of spices is bad because in our book of rules it is regarded as breach of the aswada vow, though in fact it may not be so.
('45', 435, 1, 21, 885066) If it is not, the rule needs to be abolished.
('45', 435, 1, 22, 885112) But so long as the rule stands it is our duty to observe it.
('45', 435, 1, 23, 885173) The aswada vow many have nothing to do with the practice of taking only five articles of food but anyway I have taken the vow and since there is nothing immoral about it I must observe it.
('45', 435, 1, 24, 885362) The same argument applies to the memorizing of the Gita.
('45', 435, 1, 25, 885419) This is not covered by our rules, but we have accepted its desirability.
('45', 435, 1, 26, 885492) We get the children to memorize it; we call it a spiritual treasury.
('45', 435, 1, 27, 885561) I have therefore believed that you all support me in my estimate of it.
('45', 435, 1, 28, 885633) Then if we make no efforts in this direction we strain our vow of truth.
('45', 435, 1, 29, 885706) I can understand your inability to memorize the Gita owing to your many occupations; but would it not be a breach of truth if, in spite of constantly commending the memorizing of the Gita, you did not take some time off to undertake it?
('45', 435, 2, 30, 885943) 1 Vow of not pampering the palate
('45', 436, 0, 1, 885977) VOL.45 : 4 FEBRUARY, 1929 11 MAY, 1929 437
('45', 436, 1, 2, 886020) But that is enough.
('45', 436, 1, 3, 886040) Thinking generally tires us and we move in endless circles.
('45', 436, 1, 4, 886100) This is exactly why the votaries of truth do not let their fancy wander, but like a ghost cling to only a few things, and draw the whole truth from out of them.
('45', 436, 1, 5, 886261) They would humbly stick to what they have undertaken rather than perpetually doubt whether it is correct or not.
('45', 436, 1, 6, 886374) But every single thought, every single act of ours is for ever imperfect, we are liable to err; now what can we do about this?
('45', 436, 1, 7, 886501) If we would not take up these or remain sceptical about them as long as we are not perfect, well, in that case we shall never become perfect.

('45', 443, 8, 19, 898325) 431. OUR IGNOMINY
('45', 443, 9, 20, 898343) The publication of the second part of Thakkar Bapa’s Antyaja Directory begins from this issue.
('45', 443, 9, 21, 898438) It is now many months since this Directory came to me.
('45', 443, 9, 22, 898493) It did not accompany me on my tour, but when it did come, I hardly got time to have a look at it during this whirlwind tour.
('45', 443, 9, 23, 898618) The tour of Andhra Pradesh is strenuous, but the people here are very kind and Deshabhakta Venkatappayya takes such good care of me that he allows no one near me in the afternoons which are
('45', 443, 10, 24, 898808) 1 This is not translated here.
('45', 444, 0, 1, 898839) VOL.45 : 4 FEBRUARY, 1929 11 MAY, 1929 445
('45', 444, 1, 2, 898882) supposed to be periods of respite for me, and for that reason, I am able to deal with the Directory.
('45', 444, 1, 3, 898983) That Directory is a history of our, that is, the Hindus’ ignominy—I have intentionally used the pronoun “our”.
('45', 444, 1, 4, 899094) Among the readers of Navajivan are Muslims, Parsis and also Christians.
('45', 444, 1, 5, 899166) I write this article, however, as a Hindu for all the Hindus of Gujarat.
('45', 444, 1, 6, 899239) What can one say about the cruelty of the followers of a religion who have a custom under which the Antyajas have difficulty even in getting water!
('45', 444, 1, 7, 899387) Even an enemy cannot be denied drinking water.
('45', 444, 1, 8, 899434) How can the Antyajas have courage to come to our house to quench their thirst when we do not allow them even to draw water from our well?
('45', 444, 1, 9, 899572) On the trains they are shunned; they are similarly treated when they come to the shops; if they set foot into a temple, the god of the high castes is polluted.
('45', 444, 1, 10, 899732) Our children object if they sit with them at school.
('45', 444, 1, 11, 899785) And all this is done in the name of religion!
('45', 444, 1, 12, 899831) I see no authority for all this in sanatana dharma.
('45', 444, 1, 13, 899883) An observer can see that hypocrisy is flourishing in the name of religion.
('45', 444, 1, 14, 899958) We cannot see our own back, but others can and they say that it is shocking.
('45', 444, 1, 15, 900035) However, we are not willing to admit it.
('45', 444, 1, 16, 900076) Some like me who are brought up in the same fold and have noted the horror are shunned by the sanatanis as polluted.
('45', 444, 1, 17, 900193) But we shall not able to maintain this state of affairs for long.
('45', 444, 1, 18, 900259) Not only I, but many Hindus like me have been able to see this sin and are making efforts to remove it.
('45', 444, 1, 19, 900363) This Directory is a help in these efforts.
('45', 444, 1, 20, 900406) It makes us conscious of ours sins and shows us how low we are.
('45', 444, 1, 21, 900470) We should make use of this Directory.
('45', 444, 1, 22, 900508) We do not lack funds for rendering service to the Antyajas.
('45', 444, 1, 23, 900568) The donation of Shri Rameshawardas Birla has not been fully spent.
('45', 444, 1, 24, 900635) In fact, service to the Antyajas is similar to khadi work; if there is faith many young men can earn a livelihood out of it.
('45', 444, 1, 25, 900760) Thousands of pure and hardworking Hindus who do not get polluted or tired by this work can earn their livelihood by doing it.
('45', 444, 1, 26, 900886) But where do we find capable Hindu teachers to run an Antyaja school?
('45', 444, 1, 27, 900956) Everywhere I see adventurous Kutchis laying railway lines.
('45', 444, 1, 28, 901015) But where are the artisans and the contractors to dig wells at market rate for the Antyajas?
('45', 444, 1, 29, 901108) Any such teachers, masons, workers and contractors should write to Thakkar Bapa and get their names registered in his office.
('45', 444, 1, 30, 901234) No one should misinterpret this article.
('45', 444, 1, 31, 901275) Anyone who wishes to give a donation may gladly do so.
('45', 444, 1, 32, 901330) But the aim of publishing this
('45', 445, 0, 1, 901361) 446 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('45', 445, 1, 2, 901403) Directory is to gauge the extent of our sins and enlarge the band of workers in the field.
('45', 445, 1, 3, 901494) May I suggest one thing to the compiler?
('45', 445, 1, 4, 901535) There is no place in a directory for phrases like” It is likely to be such and such”.
('45', 445, 1, 5, 901621) A compiler has no right to make conjectures.
('45', 445, 1, 6, 901666) He should set down what he observes.
('45', 445, 1, 7, 901703) It is for the reader to do the guessing.
('45', 445, 1, 8, 901744) If villages with names like Gillespiepura or Brookhill occur, it will be interesting and also instructive to give details of the origin of these villages.
('45', 445, 1, 9, 901899) Also it would be worth while to give a line or two each to the prominent men among the Antyajas.
('45', 445, 1, 10, 901996) If self control and piety are observed in any of the Antyajas, the fact should be noted.
('45', 445, 1, 11, 902085) The size of the Directory will not increase by incorporating such information.
('45', 445, 1, 12, 902164) That can be dealt with in a line or two.
('45', 445, 1, 13, 902205) It lends colour to the Directory and is useful.
('45', 445, 1, 14, 902253) True art is never useless.
('45', 445, 1, 15, 902280) The argument of some artists that the enmity between art and utility has existed for generations is not worth considering.
('45', 445, 1, 16, 902403) We see daily that Nature abounds in art and experienced people say that art is filled to the brim with utility.
('45', 445, 1, 17, 902515) There is not a single useless colour in a peacock’s plumage; if we are not aware of their purpose the reason is our ignorance, not the extravagance of Nature.
('45', 445, 2, 18, 902674) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 5 5 1929
('45', 445, 3, 19, 902710) 432. MY NOTES
('45', 445, 4, 20, 902724) TOUR PROGRAMME
('45', 445, 5, 21, 902739) Many readers complain that they have no intimation of my tours or of my absence from the Udyoga Mandir, and as a result, they are put to inconvenience and are not able to contact me if they want to.
('45', 445, 5, 22, 902938) The complaint is justified.
('45', 445, 5, 23, 902966) Therefore I give below my tour programme of Andhra Pradesh from May 5 onwards.
('45', 445, 5, 24, 903045) I am leaving out the minor villages to be covered on one and the same day.
('45', 445, 5, 25, 903120) Ordinarily, the practice is to be begin the tour at six in the morning and to cover as many villages as possible by nine; to camp at nine; to
('45', 446, 0, 1, 903262) VOL.45 : 4 FEBRUARY, 1929 11 MAY, 1929 447
('45', 446, 1, 2, 903305) start again at 5.30 and to settle down at eight.
('45', 446, 1, 3, 903354) The places I give below are those where I shall stay during the day.
('45', 446, 1, 4, 903423) 5th Palivela 6th Amalapuram 7th Gollammadidada 8th & 9th Rajahmundry 10th 13th Nellore 14th Nayudupeta 15th Tirupati 16th Madanapalle 17th Anantapur 18th Tadipatri 19th Nandayal20th Kurnool 21st Pattikonda 22nd On train from Adoni to Bombay 23rd 27th Bombay 28th Sabarmati 28th May to 10th June Udyoga Mandir The programme after the 10th of June has not been finalized yet.
('45', 446, 1, 5, 903797) There is some talk about a tour in Almora.

('45', 446, 2, 7, 903913) A WIDOW’S TALE
('45', 446, 3, 8, 903928) A widow, twenty three years old, who has given her name and address writes: 1
('45', 446, 4, 9, 904006) My advice to this and to her such sisters is that they should definitely remarry and put up with the obstacles that may come in their way.
('45', 446, 4, 10, 904145) She will not need the help of her uncle and brothers if she gets a suitable husband.
('45', 446, 4, 11, 904230) It is better to make allowances for the body than indulge in lustful thoughts.
('45', 446, 4, 12, 904309) The best thing of course is that when desire enters one’s mind one does not entertain it but tries to control it.
('45', 446, 4, 13, 904423) But if in the absence of physical contact the mind remains engrossed in lustful thoughts as seems the case with this sister, I have no doubt it is one’s duty to satisfy the body.
('45', 446, 4, 14, 904602) There is no sin in a widow marrying, rather, there is as much sin in it as in a widower marrying.
('45', 446, 4, 15, 904700) Widowhood is not the ultimate dharma..
('45', 446, 4, 16, 904739) It is an ornament

('45', 451, 1, 2, 911232) 438. LETTER TO CHHAGANLAL JOSHI 6.25 a.m., Silence Day, May 6, 1929
('45', 451, 2, 3, 911300) CHHAGANLAL, Your recent letters make me feel a little worried.
('45', 451, 2, 4, 911363) I feel that you are forcing yourself to do what is beyond your strength.
('45', 451, 2, 5, 911436) Do nothing out of false regard for me.
('45', 451, 2, 6, 911475) I know that you find it difficult to stand alone.
('45', 451, 2, 7, 911525) Do not believe that the dairy, or for that matter even the weaving factory, should run in any circumstances.
('45', 451, 2, 8, 911634) I have made it my profession in life to break up homes and have felt no wrench in the heart at any time while doing so.
('45', 451, 2, 9, 911754) I started doing this in the year 1891; that is, ever since I became independent, I have been doing nothing but that.
('45', 451, 2, 10, 911871) I set up a home in Bombay and broke it up; did the same in Rajkot, broke it up and went to Bombay at a mere suggestions by Kevalram.
('45', 451, 2, 11, 912004) 1 Then I broke up the home in India to go to South Africa for one year only.
('45', 451, 2, 12, 912081) The books remained unused, the furniture and other house hold thing became useless, the dress became useless and I had to buy everything new.
('45', 451, 2, 13, 912223) I had built up the home in Natal with much thought, had exercised much care in buying furniture of my liking.
('45', 451, 2, 14, 912333) I had furnished a room as a gymnasium.
('45', 451, 2, 15, 912372) I threw up all this in a moment.
('45', 451, 2, 16, 912405) I gave away many of the things, something to this friend and something to another.
('45', 451, 2, 17, 912488) I returned to Bombay and set up a home if Girgaum.
('45', 451, 2, 18, 912539) Manilal fell ill there and was at death’s door.
('45', 451, 2, 19, 912587) I decided that we could not live in that air.
('45', 451, 2, 20, 912633) After hunting for a house everywhere, I chose the “Viller Villa.” I got a rent note drawn up and signed it.
('45', 451, 2, 21, 912741) Revashanker, too, came to live with us.
('45', 451, 2, 22, 912781) I took out a first class season ticket, and rented an office in Bombay in Payne Gilbert’s chambers.
('45', 451, 2, 23, 912881) At least, I felt, I had settled down.
('45', 451, 2, 24, 912919) Just then came a cable: ‘Come to South Africa.’ I left Ba under the care of Chhaganlal and went to South Africa, accompanied by some youths who cared to come with me.
('45', 451, 2, 25, 913086) There was the same story there.
('45', 451, 2, 26, 913118) I cannot tell now how much money I must have wasted on furniture.
('45', 451, 2, 27, 913184) But I do not remember having ever felt a wrench in the heart in all these wild adventures.
('45', 451, 2, 28, 913275) I felt lighter every time and convinced that that was God’s will and the change was for my good.
('45', 451, 2, 29, 913372) I shall, then, feel no wrench in my heart in breaking up this Ashram and building a new one.
('45', 451, 2, 30, 913465) Yes, I crave for one thing sincerity.
('45', 451, 2, 31, 913503) Only those of you who can live sincerely may remain.
('45', 451, 2, 32, 913556) I would not say that those who remain out of a false sense of shame or under pressure from others are sincere in what they do.
('45', 451, 2, 33, 913683) Sincerity may
('45', 451, 3, 34, 913697) 1 Kevalram Mavji Dave, a Rajkot lawyer who encouraged Gandhiji to go to London to study law.

('45', 453, 1, 2, 916191) 439. LETTER TO ASHRAM WOMEN
('45', 453, 2, 3, 916219) RAJOLE, May 6, 1929
('45', 453, 3, 4, 916239) SISTERS, I am writing this in a village far away from a railway station.
('45', 453, 3, 5, 916312) One must cross a river to go to any place from here.
('45', 453, 3, 6, 916365) There is no bridge, so the village is like an island.
('45', 453, 3, 7, 916419) When the river is in flood it deposits silt on the land round the village.
('45', 453, 3, 8, 916494) Hence the soil here is very fertile and some of the residents are fairly well off.
('45', 453, 3, 9, 916577) They have tempted me to come here with the prospect of getting contributions.
('45', 453, 3, 10, 916655) And I do get them.
('45', 453, 3, 11, 916674) From Kakinada, a lady named Durgabai has been touring with us.
('45', 453, 3, 12, 916737) Her husband earns Rs. 4,000 a year; out of this the lady spends about Rs. 2,000 on a women’s school.
('45', 453, 3, 13, 916838) She herself teaches Hindi in that school, as also spinning.
('45', 453, 3, 14, 916898) About 80 girls know Hindi.
('45', 453, 3, 15, 916925) The lady is kind and hard working.
('45', 453, 3, 16, 916960) I think that she has faith in her work, but not equal knowledge about how to do it.
('45', 453, 3, 17, 917044) She cannot be said to know Hindi very well.
('45', 453, 3, 18, 917088) Her spinning, too, is of indifferent quality.
('45', 453, 3, 19, 917134) She says that she has no one in Kakinada to help or guide her.
('45', 453, 3, 20, 917197) Consequently, it seems, her abilities are not being fully used.
('45', 453, 4, 21, 917261) Blessings from

('45', 455, 1, 2, 920026) 442. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, RAJAHMUNDRY
('45', 455, 2, 3, 920069) May 7, 1929
('45', 455, 3, 4, 920081) I tender my thanks to you for the addresses of welcome and for the money that you have given me for the Khadi Fund.
('45', 455, 3, 5, 920197) There are certain matters in the addresses presented to me and let me say a few words regarding them.
('45', 455, 3, 6, 920299) I have not forgotten the fact that I visited this place some time back.
('45', 455, 3, 7, 920371) Among others, I take first the address of welcome presented by the Municipal Council, in which the problems of untouchability has been referred to.
('45', 455, 3, 8, 920519) It is also stated there that “We members of the Council, look forward with great hopes when your efforts forcomplete prohibition (of drink and other intoxicants) would attain success.” It is very surprising to me to see these two references.
('45', 455, 3, 9, 920761) Let me tell you, the work is not mine alone in the matter of prohibition and the removal of untouchability.
('45', 455, 3, 10, 920869) The responsibility lies more on the Municipal Councillors than on a private individual, and it rests very largely on the intelligent public.
('45', 455, 3, 11, 921010) It would be an illusion that I am going to achieve these miracles.
('45', 455, 3, 12, 921077) I am only urging you to be awake to your duty to your country which is now in intense suffering on account of these two evils.
('45', 455, 3, 13, 921204) If we do not do our duty by our motherland, we will have been born in vain, and we would not be doing our dharma.
('45', 455, 3, 14, 921318) I wish to place another matter before the Municipal Council for consideration.
('45', 455, 3, 15, 921397) While I was coming here, I noticed that a road was particularly bad and some were badly kept.
('45', 455, 3, 16, 921491) Truly you must make your Municipality an ideal municipality.
('45', 455, 3, 17, 921552) This is considered to be a very sacred place and many come here to bathe in the Gautami, and if all filth and sewage water is to be found outside, what do you think the result will be ultimately?
('45', 455, 3, 18, 921748) It is therefore necessary that the town should be kept neat and clean and sanitary without any stench.
('45', 455, 3, 19, 921851) But you know it better than I do.
('45', 455, 3, 20, 921885) I congratulate the Municipality on its khaddar work.
('45', 455, 3, 21, 921938) I hear that there is one Hindu Samaj working here for a very long time but Mr. N. Subba Rao Pantulu (the President of that Samaj) tells me that it is not now running satisfactorily.
('45', 455, 3, 22, 922120) Those who recognize Hindu dharma ought to take interest in the study of the Bhagavad Gita.
('45', 455, 3, 23, 922211) It is regrettable that people do not evince sufficient interest when
('45', 456, 0, 1, 922280) VOL.45 : 4 FEBRUARY, 1929 11 MAY, 1929 457
('45', 456, 1, 2, 922323) there is such a useful institution by their side to study Bhagavad Gita and learn the guiding principles of their life.
('45', 456, 1, 3, 922443) References have been made in the addresses to the varanganas (the fallen sisters).
('45', 456, 1, 4, 922526) It is a matter for deep shame that there should be still a class of our sisters living the life of prostitution.
('45', 456, 1, 5, 922639) You should not rest satisfied until there is not even one fallen sister amongst you.
('45', 456, 1, 6, 922724) You must not sleep until you accomplish this and wipe out the blot of the whole nation.
('45', 456, 1, 7, 922812) Remember that this could be done only through your purity and moral integrity.
('45', 456, 1, 8, 922891) I request you all to be united without any jealousies and distinctions and not to engender communal feelings, as we are all trying to attain swaraj and we are all soldiers of one army.
('45', 456, 1, 9, 923076) We shall win by our strength of spirit, by our calm courage and by our faith in freedom.
('45', 456, 1, 10, 923165) Make the boycott of foreign cloth complete and effective.
('45', 456, 1, 11, 923223) Do not touch a piece of foreign cloth, give work to all your workers by insisting on khadi and khadi alone.
('45', 456, 1, 12, 923331) Do not wait for others to begin and other places to lead.
('45', 456, 1, 13, 923389) Here, in Rajahmundry you have colleges and other institutions.
('45', 456, 1, 14, 923452) You have many great men doing social service and public work.
('45', 456, 1, 15, 923514) If you all join hands and work unitedly, I have no doubt that we would achieve our goal early.

('45', 459, 1, 2, 926798) 447. LETTER TO SURENDRA
('45', 459, 2, 3, 926822) May 8, 1929
('45', 459, 3, 4, 926834) SURENDRA, I was surprised to read your note.
('45', 459, 3, 5, 926879) It contains a serious error of reasoning.
('45', 459, 3, 6, 926921) Your conduct is unnatural.
('45', 459, 3, 7, 926948) The right thing is for everyone to live according to his or her nature.
('45', 459, 3, 8, 927020) If a man six feet tall tries to look five feet by bending, he is guilty [of deceiving others].
('45', 459, 3, 9, 927115) A man of sincere humility may ride an elephant and a hypocrite may be living in a hut.
('45', 459, 3, 10, 927202) Because a person who feels crushed by the burden of his vow releases himself from it, does it mean that another whom his vow may help to progress should give up that vow?
('45', 459, 3, 11, 927373) If all others live in rented quarters, what should I do?
('45', 459, 3, 12, 927430) If all are such as cannot live except in this manner, I know what to do.
('45', 459, 3, 13, 927503) But I would have to think what I should do if a person like you plans living in a rented room.
('45', 459, 3, 14, 927598) Supposing others wish to beget children, would you, in order to be in their company, marry and live as they do?
('45', 459, 3, 15, 927710) Before writing the note, you should have discussed the matter with me.
('45', 459, 3, 16, 927781) If it is beyond you strength to observe the vows of the Ashram, you may by all means live in a rented room.
('45', 459, 3, 17, 927889) If, on the other hand, you have that strength, if you have faith in the vows, admit your error and withdraw your note.

('45', 461, 1, 2, 929857) 450. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, SITANAGRAM May 9, 1929 I am very happy for having come to this Ashram.
('45', 461, 1, 3, 929959) 1 I had heard of this Ashram before.
('45', 461, 1, 4, 929996) I have now seen its various activities and I am very satisfied.
('45', 461, 1, 5, 930060) I hope the neighbouring villages would be greatly benefited by the useful work of this Ashram.
('45', 461, 1, 6, 930155) The first and foremost thing that is being done here is, to my mind, with regard to khaddar.
('45', 461, 1, 7, 930248) Something is being done in the neighbouring villages also in that direction but much more is expected of them.
('45', 461, 1, 8, 930359) You have to work the charkha always and on it rests the wealth vice of your country and its salvation.
('45', 461, 1, 9, 930462) Of all the instruments of service the charkha is the most powerful and promises you wealth.
('45', 461, 1, 10, 930554) You will produce wonderful results, only you should get into that work regularly.
('45', 461, 1, 11, 930636) You must all co operate in and help this activity.
('45', 461, 1, 12, 930687) I hope you will all co operate with and help the Ashram to achieve still better results in all directions.
('45', 461, 1, 13, 930794) You must send your boys and girls to it and see they get real education here.
('45', 461, 1, 14, 930872) Help this good Ashram with all your might.
('45', 461, 1, 15, 930915) I congratulate you on your heroism in banishing the drink evil and your having paid the punitive tax of Rs. 7,500 for that.
('45', 461, 1, 16, 931039) Such struggles are bound to come.
('45', 461, 1, 17, 931073) Be bold and face them.
('45', 461, 1, 18, 931096) In the huge attempt for the attainment of swaraj such lossof money or even loss of life is nothing.
('45', 461, 1, 19, 931196) I am collecting money for the Khadi Fund.
('45', 461, 1, 20, 931238) I wish to get some money from you also.
('45', 461, 1, 21, 931278) I believe I have received some money from the rich.
('45', 461, 1, 22, 931330) They might give a large sum.
('45', 461, 1, 23, 931359) But even if you poor people offer the least pie, I will be pleased as if it were a large sum of money.
('45', 461, 1, 24, 931462) When I visited Bihar and Utkal I collected even pies.
('45', 461, 1, 25, 931516) Those pies went to give food and clothing to many starving villagers who were asked to spin and renew their charkha plying.
('45', 461, 1, 26, 931640) In our cause every little help counts.
('45', 461, 1, 27, 931679) The Hindu, 11 5 1929
('45', 461, 2, 28, 931700) 451. A BRILLIANT CAREER
('45', 461, 3, 29, 931724) Forward, a creation of Deshbandhu, fully lived up to its name and the aspirations of its distinguished founder.
('45', 461, 3, 30, 931836) By its dash, enterprise, resourcefulness and, above all, fearlessness it proved a thorn in the side of the Government.
('45', 461, 3, 31, 931955) It was therefore marked out for destruction by means fair or foul.
('45', 461, 3, 32, 932022) It has had several prosecutions launched against
('45', 461, 4, 33, 932071) 1 Gautami Satyagraha Ashram
('45', 462, 0, 1, 932099) VOL.45 : 4 FEBRUARY, 1929 11 MAY, 1929 463
('45', 462, 1, 2, 932142) it for daring to speak out the nation’s mind by calling a spade a spade.
('45', 462, 1, 3, 932215) But it outlived all the prosecutions.
('45', 462, 1, 4, 932253) It rather thrived upon them and the imprisonment of its editor and printer.
('45', 462, 1, 5, 932329) But it was impossible for a moneyless newspaper to survive vindictive damages.
('45', 462, 1, 6, 932408) The Judge’s verdict may be right though his leanings one can read in his judgment.
('45', 462, 1, 7, 932491) But the Government’s action and, which is the same thing, the Railway Company’s action was wrong.
('45', 462, 1, 8, 932589) If the article of the Forward was an overstatement, surely neither of the parties attacked could suffer pecuniary damage, for they were too powerful.
('45', 462, 1, 9, 932739) And no damage exacted by them could possibly recoup them if they did suffer material damage at all.
('45', 462, 1, 10, 932839) If it was a question of moral damage, I suggest that neither the Government nor the Company had any reputation to keep in such matters as were the subject matter of criticism by the Forward.
('45', 462, 1, 11, 933030) In any case their amour propre should have been satisfied by the obtaining of the precious verdict.
('45', 462, 1, 12, 933130) But the application for compulsory liquidation shows that the object of the action was not compensation for the plaintiffs but it was destruction of the defendant.
('45', 462, 1, 13, 933294) Well, they have had their satisfaction.
('45', 462, 1, 14, 933334) They are welcome to it.
('45', 462, 1, 15, 933358) Only they are riding for a fall.
('45', 462, 1, 16, 933391) The Forward so vindictively crushed will live in the lives of the people.
('45', 462, 1, 17, 933465) The fire lighted by it will rage with redoubled fury in the breasts of thousandsas it will no longer be able to find legitimate vent through the columns of their favourite paper.
('45', 462, 1, 18, 933644) Though during my tour in the villages of Andhra I cannot follow the events in their proper sequence, I observe that a mean attempt is being made even to prevent the publication of the New Forward.
('45', 462, 1, 19, 933841) The legal resourcefulness of the brains that are backing the national movement in Bengal against tremendous odds may circumvent the Government.
('45', 462, 1, 20, 933985) But even if they cannot cope with the legal and extra legal powers possessed and unscrupulously used by the Government, they will still have deserved the gratitude of the country for bravely and fearlessly engaging in an unequal fight with the Government.
('45', 462, 1, 21, 934241) A spirit has been awakened that cannot be crushed by any power on earth.
('45', 462, 1, 22, 934314) Forward is dead, long live Forward.
('45', 462, 1, 23, 934350) Young India, 9 5 1929

('45', 464, 1, 2, 936909) (subsequent collections),46 8 0; Total Rs. 1,54,961 15 0. I must add too that the time sense of the co workers has become most agreeably keen and there is a pleasant rivalry among them to conform to the scheduled time.
('45', 464, 1, 3, 937128) The result is that we are at present travelling and taking meetings with the regularity of an express train.
('45', 464, 1, 4, 937237) Exactly at the stated time of departure the smiling face of Deshabhakta and local friends greet me in the morning and in the evening.
('45', 464, 1, 5, 937371) This regularity and comparative orderliness in the meetings make the tour in the extreme heat of summer not only bearable but even pleasant.
('45', 464, 1, 6, 937512) The eagerness with which men and women bring their rupees and their pies fills one with hope and joy.
('45', 464, 1, 7, 937614) I am writing these notes just after a women’s meeting in Tuni 1. An old manifestly poor woman nearly 75 years old bent double with the weight of her years but with a benign face and carrying sparkling eyes put into my hands four annas without any apology traceable in those never to be forgotten eyes.
('45', 464, 1, 8, 937916) Immediately after a khadi clad middle aged woman put into my hands five rupees and a copper.
('45', 464, 1, 9, 938009) I straightway asked her: “Whose donation is greater, yours or this old sister’s?
('45', 464, 1, 10, 938090) Pat came the bold, quick, decisive reply: “Both are equal.” I was pleased beyond measure and was glad to be nonplussed.
('45', 464, 1, 11, 938210) I was unprepared for this most intelligent and penetrating reply.
('45', 464, 1, 12, 938276) She added: “I have been interested in the national movement for many years.
('45', 464, 1, 13, 938352) I have always contributed to the best of my ability.
('45', 464, 1, 14, 938405) I believe in khadi and I always wear it.” This is only one sample from the inexhaustible store house of joyful experiences it has been my privilege to have.
('45', 464, 1, 15, 938562) I must however pass on to other matters.
('45', 464, 1, 16, 938603) WORKERS MEET At Tanuku there was the usual meeting of workers which I always have between three and four in the afternoon at every place, more especially at the end of the tour in each district.
('45', 464, 1, 17, 938798) We were about 100 workers.
('45', 464, 1, 18, 938825) All kinds of questions were discussed.
('45', 464, 1, 19, 938864) The question whether Congressmen’s contesting seats in Taluk Boards, District Boards, Municipalities and Councils did not interfere with khadi and other constructive work has been cropping up everywhere.
('45', 464, 1, 20, 939068) At this meeting it came with greater insistence.
('45', 464, 1, 21, 939117) What I have found is that these bodies take up more energy of good workers than they are worth.
('45', 464, 1, 22, 939213) Some of the best men had to leave their Municipalities in order to be able to do more solid work.
('45', 464, 1, 23, 939311) There is too much wrangling, too much
('45', 464, 2, 24, 939349) 1 On May 2
('45', 465, 0, 1, 939360) 466 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('45', 465, 1, 2, 939402) jealousy, too much wire pulling and too much self seeking in these bodies to enable honest workers to hold out for long.
('45', 465, 1, 3, 939523) The one advantage that was claimed by a Congressman on behalf of the policy of Congressman interesting themselves in these bodies was that the presence of Congressmen introduced a healthy mentality of resistance in the place of obsequiousness.
('45', 465, 1, 4, 939767) On the whole I am inclined to think that this mentality of resistance is purchased at too great a price, if it means sacrifice of constructive work.
('45', 465, 1, 5, 939916) I therefore suggested to the workers at Tanuku that if they were satisfied that there was no effective service possible in taking interest in these bodies or in taking part in the elections, they should not think of them even as they would not if no Congressmen were contesting and participating in these elections.
('45', 465, 1, 6, 940232) When choice has got to be made, there cannot be a shadow of doubt that constructive work is any day far superior to working in these bodies.
('45', 465, 1, 7, 940373) After all, whilst we have thousands of Congress workers, there can only be a few men in each district who can enter these so called elective institutions.
('45', 465, 1, 8, 940528) Let those who believe in them enter them.
('45', 465, 1, 9, 940570) But let not the others who do not believe in them betray jealousy or impatience in respect of those who enter them.
('45', 465, 1, 10, 940686) Another suggestion made was that yarn should be brought from districts where it was spun to those districts where owing to absence of grinding poverty there was no one to spin but where there were weavers who would gladly weave khadi if they were supplied with hand spun yarn.
('45', 465, 1, 11, 940963) My answer was an emphatic no, so long as the yarn could be used up by the district producing it.
('45', 465, 1, 12, 941060) The secret of successful hand spinning lies in the yarn being woven where it is spun.
('45', 465, 1, 13, 941146) There should be no impatience about weaning local weavers from foreign or mill spun yarn so long as there is no local yarn produced and so long as there is no yarn to be had in one’s district.
('45', 465, 1, 14, 941339) What can however be done is to popularize self spinning or sacrificial spinning as much as possible.
('45', 465, 1, 15, 941440) If such yarn is produced in abundance it should keep all the available weavers in a district going.
('45', 465, 2, 16, 941540) A MODEL CO OPERATIVE SOCIETY
('45', 465, 3, 17, 941569) It was at Vizianagaram that I discovered a Khaddar Co operative Society which appeared to me to be a very successful venture and without an equal in all India.
('45', 465, 3, 18, 941729) I offer no apology for copying the following from the address of the Society: 1
('45', 465, 4, 19, 941809) The cloth in our depot is all made by us solely out of the cotton purchased by us and we have imported none of it from other places.
('45', 465, 4, 20, 941942) We have resolved not to import khaddar either from other provinces or even from other

('45', 466, 1, 2, 942108) districts in our province, as we believe such importation will prejudice the development of khaddar even as importation of foreign cloth.
('45', 466, 1, 3, 942246) We also believe the object of the khaddar movement is to develop khaddar in each place by spreading spinning and weaving locally as wide as possible and securing livelihood for as many people as possible.
('45', 466, 1, 4, 942451) In some cases, our prices are higher than the prices of A.I.S.A. by Rs. 0 0 6 per yard.
('45', 466, 1, 5, 942539) We humbly offer a pair of (woven) trousers and a blanket 2_ yards wide and 3 yards long, both being the work of Pappu Jagannayakulu, who is a weaver and also a Director of our Society.

('45', 466, 1, 17, 943677) Young India, 9 5 1929
('45', 466, 2, 18, 943699) 453. A COMPLEX PROBLEM
('45', 466, 3, 19, 943722) It is not without diffidence that I approach the question raised by Rev.
('45', 466, 3, 20, 943795) B. de Ligt in his open letter to me with regard to my attitude towards war.
('45', 466, 3, 21, 943871) To remain silent at the risk of being misunderstood is an easy way out of the difficult situation I find myself in.
('45', 466, 3, 22, 943987) To say that I made a mistake in participating in war on the occasions in question would be easier still.
('45', 466, 3, 23, 944092) But it would be unfriendly not to answer questions put in the friendliest manner; and I must not pretend repentance when I do not feel it.
('45', 466, 3, 24, 944231) My anxiety to avoid a discussion of the question does not proceed from want of conviction, but it proceeds from the fear that I may not be
('45', 466, 4, 25, 944370) 1 Not reproduced here.
('45', 467, 0, 1, 944393) 468 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('45', 467, 1, 2, 944435) able to make my meaning clear and thereby create an impression about my attitude towards war which I do not desire.
('45', 467, 1, 3, 944551) Often do I find language to be a poor vehicle for expressing some of my fundamental sentiments.
('45', 467, 1, 4, 944647) I would therefore urge Mr. B. de Light and other fellow war resisters not to mind my faulty or incomplete argument and still less to mind my participation in war which they may be unable to reconcile with my professions about war.
('45', 467, 1, 5, 944878) Let them understand me to be uncompromisingly against all war.
('45', 467, 1, 6, 944941) If they cannot appreciate my argument, let them impute my participation to unconscious weakness.
('45', 467, 1, 7, 945038) For I would feel extremely sorry to discover that my action was used by anyone to justify war under certain conditions.
('45', 467, 1, 8, 945158) But having said this much I must adhere to the position taken up in the article 1 which is the subject matter of Mr. B. de Ligt’s letter.
('45', 467, 1, 9, 945296) Let the European war resisters appreciate one vital difference between them and me.
('45', 467, 1, 10, 945380) They do not represent exploited nations, I represent the most exploited nation on earth.
('45', 467, 1, 11, 945469) To use an unflattering comparison they represent the cat and I represent the mouse.
('45', 467, 1, 12, 945553) Has a mouse eventhe sense of non violence?
('45', 467, 1, 13, 945596) Is it not a fundamental want with him to strive to offer successful violence before he can be taught to appreciate the virtue, the grandeur, the supremacy of the law of non violence ahimsa in the field of war?
('45', 467, 1, 14, 945806) May it not be necessary for me as a representative of the mouse tribe to participate in my principal’s desire for wreaking destruction even for the purpose of teaching him the superiority of non destruction?
('45', 467, 1, 15, 946014) Here the analogy of the cat and the mouse ends.
('45', 467, 1, 16, 946062) The mouse has no capacity in him to alter his nature.
('45', 467, 1, 17, 946116) A human being, however debased or fallen he may be, has in him the capacity of rising to the greatest height ever attained by any human being irrespective of race or colour.
('45', 467, 1, 18, 946290) Therefore even whilst I may go with my countrymen a long way in satisfying their need for preparation for war, I should do so in the fullest hope of weaning them from war and of their seeing one day its utter futility.
('45', 467, 1, 19, 946509) Let it be remembered that the largest experiment known to history in mass non violence is being tried by me even as I seem to be lending myself for the purpose of war.
('45', 467, 1, 20, 946677) For want of skill the experiment may fail, but the war resister in Europe should strain every nerve to understand and appreciate the phenomenon going on before him in India of the same man trying the bold experiment in non violence whilst hobnobbing with those who would prepare for war.
('45', 467, 2, 21, 946965) 1Vide “My Attitude Towards War”, 13 9 1928; also “War Against War”, 8 3 1928.
('45', 468, 0, 1, 947043) VOL.45 : 4 FEBRUARY, 1929 11 MAY, 1929 469
('45', 468, 1, 2, 947086) It is part of the plan of non violence that I should share the feelings of my countrymen if I would ever expect to bring them to non violence.
('45', 468, 1, 3, 947229) The striking fact is that India including the educated politician is nolens volens driven to the belief that non violence alone will free the masses from the thraldom of centuries.
('45', 468, 1, 4, 947410) It is true that all have not followed out the logical consequences of non violence.
('45', 468, 1, 5, 947494) Who can?
('45', 468, 1, 6, 947503) In spite of my boast that I know the truth of non violence and try my utmost best to practise it, I fail often to follow out the logical conclusions of the doctrine.
('45', 468, 1, 7, 947669) The working of nature’s processes in the human breast is mysterious and baffles interpretation.
('45', 468, 1, 8, 947765) This I know that if India comes to her own demonstrably through non violent means, India will never want to carry a vast army, an equally grand navy and a grander air force.
('45', 468, 1, 9, 947939) If her self consciousness rises to the height necessary to give her a non violent victory in her fight for freedom, the world values will have changed and most of the paraphernalia of war would be found to be useless.
('45', 468, 1, 10, 948157) Such an India may be a mere day dream, a childish folly.
('45', 468, 1, 11, 948214) But such in my opinion is undoubtedly the implication of an India becoming free through non violence.
('45', 468, 1, 12, 948316) When that freedom comes, if it ever does, it will have come through a gentlemanly understanding with Great Britain.
('45', 468, 1, 13, 948432) But then it will not be an imperialistic haughty Britain manoeuvring for world supremacy but a Britain humbly trying to serve the common end of humanity.
('45', 468, 1, 14, 948586) India will no longer then be helplessly driven into Britain’s wars of exploitation but hers will be the voice of a powerful nation seeking to keep under restraint all the violent forces of the world.
('45', 468, 1, 15, 948786) Whether all these fanciful ideas are ever realized or not, my own lifeline is cast.
('45', 468, 1, 16, 948870) I can no longer in any conceivable circumstance take part in Britain’s wars.
('45', 468, 1, 17, 948947) And I have already said in these pages that if India attains (what will be to me so called) freedom by violent means she will cease to be a country of my pride; that time would be a time for me to civil death.
('45', 468, 1, 18, 949157) There can therefore never be any question of my participation direct or indirect in any war of exploitation by India.
('45', 468, 1, 19, 949275) But I have already pointed out in these pages that fellow war resisters in the West are participants in war even in peace time inasmuch as they pay for the preparations that are being made for it and otherwise sustain governments whose main occupation is such preparation.
('45', 468, 1, 20, 949548) Again all activity for stopping war must prove fruitless so long as the causes of war are not understood and radically dealt with.
('45', 468, 1, 21, 949679) Is not the prime cause of modern wars the inhuman race for exploitation of the so called weaker races of the earth?
('45', 468, 1, 22, 949795) Young India, 9 5 1929

('45', 469, 2, 3, 949903) CHHAGANLAL, I got the letter in which you write about the theft.

('45', 469, 7, 19, 951100) Owing to the altered state of things, it has become difficult for me to reach here.

('45', 473, 3, 17, 959295) 460. LETTER TO MADHAVJI V. THAKKAR
('45', 473, 4, 18, 959330) [After May 10, 1929] 1
('45', 473, 5, 19, 959353) BHAISHRI MADHAVJI,
('45', 473, 6, 20, 959372) I have your letter of the 10th.
('45', 473, 6, 21, 959404) It is not that soda is to be taken necessarily with lemon.
('45', 473, 6, 22, 959463) You were asked to take lemons along with soda because the combination produces some digestive secretions.
('45', 473, 6, 23, 959569) Since acid things do not agree with you I have suggested that you should take lemons separately.
('45', 473, 6, 24, 959666) However, you can certainly take lemons along with your vegetables and the soda too may be taken by itself with water.
('45', 473, 6, 25, 959784) My suggestion about alfonso mangoes too is to save you from acidity.
('45', 473, 6, 26, 959853) There is no harm in taking langra mangoes.
('45', 473, 6, 27, 959896) Maybe it would not matter if you had a mango or two even now.

('45', 474, 7, 14, 960740) Imam Saheb has nearly collapsed.
('45', 474, 7, 15, 960773) He is dragging on.
('45', 474, 7, 16, 960792) Prabhavati too is feeling the heat.
('45', 474, 7, 17, 960828) I am praying that during these last ten days, we may be able to pull through.
('45', 474, 7, 18, 960906) I hope you have got over the shock of detention.
('45', 474, 7, 19, 960955) The meeting in Bombay will be all the more precious.
('45', 474, 7, 20, 961008) I am personally 1st class, because I insist on what I need.

('45', 477, 1, 2, 964513) APPENDICES
('45', 477, 2, 3, 964524) APPENDIX I
('45', 477, 3, 4, 964535) KHADI AND SWARAJ1
('45', 477, 4, 5, 964553) WHY CAN KHADI HELP US TO WIN SWARAJ?
('45', 477, 5, 6, 964590) Because
('45', 477, 6, 7, 964598) Over three quarters of India’s population are under employed and underfed agriculturists, and khadi can give them work and food.
('45', 477, 7, 8, 964727) Because
('45', 477, 8, 9, 964735) One of England’s chief reason for holding India in subjection is that she finds in India the finest market for her cotton cloth, and khadi can put an end to that market.
('45', 477, 9, 10, 964905) WHY CAN KHADI HELP US TO WIN SWARAJ?
('45', 477, 9, 11, 964942) BETTER THAN INDIAN MILL CLOTH?
('45', 477, 10, 12, 964973) Because
('45', 477, 11, 13, 964981) Khadi can give supplementary work to the crores of distressed agriculturists who must not leave their land, and therefore cannot go to work in mills.
('45', 477, 12, 14, 965131) Because
('45', 477, 13, 15, 965139) Cotton mills could never give sufficient work to relieve the vast masses of the unemployed.
('45', 477, 14, 16, 965231) Because
('45', 477, 15, 17, 965239) The production of Khadi can be quickly organized on an enormous scale at very small cost, whereas to substantially increase the mills would mean enormous expenditure and delay of many years.
('45', 477, 17, 18, 965430) The cost of setting up a modern yarn mill of 20,000 spindles is approximately Rs. 1,660,917. If this sum were invested in charkhas, it could provide at least 1,660,917 hand spindles instead of 20,000 mill spindles and the output of yarn could be at least 13 to 14 times greater than that of the mill.
('45', 477, 17, 19, 965731) This is allowing 10 hours a day at the rate of 600 yards per hour for mill spindles and 4 hours a day at the rate of 250 yards for hand spindles.
('45', 477, 18, 20, 965877) From the original: C.W. 5345. Courtesy: Mirabehn
('45', 477, 19, 21, 965926) 1 Extracted from “Notes on Khadi”, by Mirabehn; vide “Letter to Mirabehn”, 24 2 1929.
('45', 478, 0, 1, 966012) VOL.45 : 4 FEBRUARY, 1929 11 MAY, 1929 479
('45', 478, 1, 2, 966055) APPENDIX II
('45', 478, 2, 3, 966067) PROHIBITION CAMPAIGN1
('45', 478, 3, 4, 966089) 1. Each Provincial Congress Committee shall appoint a Prohibition Sub Committee or put a single person in charge in order to prosecute the Congress anti drink and drug campaign in the province, and set aside sufficient funds for the purpose.
('45', 478, 4, 5, 966331) 2. The Sub Committee or member in charge in each province shall call for honorary workers who are willing to organize the anti drink campaign in the talukas.
('45', 478, 4, 6, 966489) The provincial Sub Committee shall thereupon select from these one worker for each taluka who shall be the anti drink secretary for the taluka, provided that the Sub Committee shall have power to change the secretary if it deems necessary.
('45', 478, 5, 7, 966729) 3. The organizing secretary of each taluka shall proceed to form Anti Drink Sabhas in as many towns and villages of the taluka as possible, enrolling as members all persons sympathizing with the object, viz., the eradication of the drink and drug evil and the enactment of laws for total prohibition.
('45', 478, 5, 8, 967030) Members of these Sabhas need not necessarily be members of any Congress Committee or habitual wearers of khadi.
('45', 478, 6, 9, 967142) 4. Attached to every such Anti Drink Sabha and subject to its control shall be organized a volunteer corps in which shall be enrolled men and women ready to render honorary active service strictly adhering to the principle of non violence and carrying out the instructions issued from time to time by the Provincial Sub Committee and the taluka secretary.
('45', 478, 7, 10, 967498) 5. On the second Sunday of every month meetings and processions shall be organized against the use of intoxicating drugs and drinks and demanding total prohibition.
('45', 478, 8, 11, 967663) 6. Besides the holding of the above monthly meetings, it will be the duty of primary organizations and the taluka secretary to organize as many gatherings as possible in their respective areas, and village to village and house to house visits for combating the evil within their jurisdiction.
('45', 478, 9, 12, 967956) 7. Anti Drink Sabhas and Congress Committees shall organize wherever possible healthy counter attractions at such places and hours as may be suitable in order to divert people from the drink habit.
('45', 478, 10, 13, 968154) 8. At each anti drink meeting, pledges shall be taken in solemn form from all persons promising to abstain from alcoholic drink and drugs.
('45', 478, 11, 14, 968293) 9. Sabhas may after obtaining the sanction of the Provincial Sub Committee organize peaceful picketing of liquor and drug shops wherever the same may be usefully done by their volunteers.
('45', 478, 12, 15, 968481) 10. Sabhas shall exercise their influence to prevent landholders and lessees
('45', 478, 13, 16, 968558) 1 Vide “Prohibition Campaign”, 4 4 1929 & 23 5 1929.
('45', 479, 0, 1, 968611) 480 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('45', 479, 1, 2, 968653) from letting out their trees for tapping for manufacture of intoxicating drinks.
('45', 479, 2, 3, 968734) 11. Sabhas shall dissuade people from bidding at auction sales of the right to vend drinks and drugs.
('45', 479, 3, 4, 968836) 12. On or before the third Sunday of every month each taluka secretary shall gather information and send to the Provincial Sub Committee a brief report of the meetings held on the Sunday preceding and other work done during the month in his taluka.
('45', 479, 3, 5, 969085) The Provincial Sub Committee shall consolidate these reports and send them to the Working Committee and to the Press for publication.
('45', 479, 4, 6, 969219) 13. Written pledges shall be taken from voters and citizens supporting total prohibition in the following form with names and full addresses legible written:
('45', 479, 5, 7, 969377) “I hereby pledge myself to support the enactment of laws for the total prohibition of intoxicating drinks and drugs as indispensable for the moral, economic and social welfare and progress of our country.
('45', 479, 5, 8, 969582) I further declare that in any election to local bodies and provincial and all India legislative bodies I shall not vote for or support any candidate who has not signed the pledge in support of total prohibition.”
('45', 479, 6, 9, 969795) Suitable books for taking these pledges shall be distributed by Provincial Committees.
('45', 479, 7, 10, 969882) 14. The Provincial Sub Committee may appoint a District Prohibition Secretary when the amount of work within the district calls for such appointment.
('45', 479, 8, 11, 970032) 15. If and when elections to the Legislative Councils and Assembly are held and Congressmen participate in them the introduction and active promotion of total prohibition shall be made a part of the election pledge of Congress candidates.
('45', 479, 9, 12, 970271) Young India, 23 5 1929
